  • Use sulphur based sprays. Sulphur is, however, harmful to mites that feed on broad mites and also burns young foliage at high dosage.
  • Other chemicals to use for control include Abamectin, Bifenthrin and Dicofol.
When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

Images.Caption: Broad Mite Damage on Passion Fruit.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Passion Fruit Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP HORTICULTURE, 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
Brown spot sickness is caused by a fungus. This sickness shows itself on the leaves as brown spots up to 10 mm wide often enlarging along the veins and drying out in the middle.
On the stems, spots are about 25 mm long. When they occur at the leaf edge, the vine is likely to die.
On the fruit, the spots appear light brown, round and sunken; they often join together, covering large areas, and produce red-brown circular spots.

The fungus is scattered by wind-blown rain. It likes warm, moist weather and a crowded leafy canopy. It survives in the diseased plant materials such as the leaf, vine or diseased fruits for a long time. The fungus does not like yellow passion fruit and its hybrids.

Non-chemical control
  • Plant yellow passion fruit and its hybrids.
  • Practice field hygiene by removal and destruction of fallen sick vines, fruits or leaves.
  • Prune vines to decrease thick vine canopy, thereby reducing humidity within the crop. This also increases air movement and light.
Chemical control
  • A well-timed spray with copper based fungicides is recommended for preventing the disease.
  • When the weather is moist, the vines grow faster, so reduce the intervals between spray applications to 2 weeks to cover the new growth efficiently.
  • Prune vines before spraying for better access and coverage of the spray.
  • Sprays that can be used for the control of brown spot include Famoxadone + Cymoxanil and Mancozeb.
When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

Images.Caption: Brown spots on passion fruit.
Brown spot on leaf.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Tomato Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture, 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value: Buckeye rot disease is caused by a fungus. This fungus causes brown, green or grey rot on both ripe and unripe fruits. Affected parts show brown-like rings that alternate inside each other. These rings have watery margins which may in the end cover half of the fruit. Fruit rot leads to poor yields.

The fungus is carried in the seed or seedlings. It is carried over from one season to another on the soil by old crop residues. Fruits on or near the ground are infected most. The disease is favoured by warm wet weather. It is mainly a problem of non-staked plants on poorly drained soils.

Non-chemical control:
  • Plant certified disease free seeds from recognised sources.
  • The disease is reduced by practicing crop rotation.
  • To control the disease stake the tomatoes.
  • Plant on ridges and avoid poorly drained soils especially on the lower parts of a farm.
  • Avoid irrigating frequently when using overhead irrigation as it helps spread the disease. Use furrow irrigation instead.
  • Applying mulch keeps the fruit off the soil, which reduces the chances of the disease getting into the fruit.
Chemical control:
  • Where the disease is prevalent, spray the crops with fungicides at fruit set. These include Mancozeb, Metalaxyl-M and copper oxychloride.
When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

Images.Caption: Buckeye rot on tomato fruit.
Images.Credit: Florida Division of Plant Industry Archive, Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, Bugwood.org

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Brassica Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value: Loopers are green caterpillars, usually with a narrow white stripe along each side and several narrow lines down the back. Looper caterpillars can be identified from most other common caterpillars by their distinctive looping movement.
Seedlings are sometimes damaged but the lethal damage occurs after heading. Loopers cut through heads and contaminate cabbage heads and leaves with their bodies and feaces.

Non-chemical control
  • Conserve natural enemies by avoiding spraying pesticides when there are enough natural enemies to reduce the number of caterpillars in the field.
  • Use biopesticide Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) to control cabbage loopers. The application of Bt will not harm natural enemies.
  • The number of loopers should be monitored to determine when to control them.
  • If the affected area is small and if the population level is low, caterpillars can be picked by hand and destroyed.
Chemical control
  • Effective chemical products include Bifenthrin, Deltamethrin, Lufenuron and Lambda cyhalothrin.
When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

Images.Caption: Cabbage Looper.
Looper on cabbage.
Images.Credit: Alton N. Sparks, Jr., University of Georgia, Bugwood.org

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Brassica Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
Visible symptoms include wilted and yellowish leaves, and stunting of the plants.
If a sick plant is uproot, more symptoms may be visible on the roots. Club root disease causes huge swelling and distortion of the roots. Some Brassica crops like turnips develop swellings called galls while others like broccoli and cabbage form club-like swellings. Galled roots are often attacked by rot organisms such as soft rot bacteria. This results in rotting of roots.

The fungus that causes the disease lives in soil and can remain alive in the soil for 10 years or longer. The fungus is dispersed from field to field by movement of diseased seedlings, infested soil by machinery and surface drainage water that is infected. The disease is most serious on soils that are cold, wet and acidic. Lime does not kill the fungus but creates soil conditions unfavourable for fungal growth.

Non-chemical control
  • A two-year crop rotation from Brassica crops to cereals may be helpful.
  • Minimize the spread of the pathogen by using disease-free transplants.
  • Restrict the movement of contaminated soil especially on farm tools from infested to non-infested fields.
  • Control Brassica weeds and other weeds from the same family (cruciferous weeds) and improve soil drainage.
  • Where fields are infested with club root pathogen, application of lime can be done annually to maintain a high soil pH (alkaline).

Images.Caption: Club root on cabbage.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Tomato Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture, 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
Cutworms are greyish, hairless worms that have a waxy appearance. They coil up into a little ring when held in the hand.
They’re usually found where the cut plant is. They hide in the soil during the day and only emerge at night to feed on the young plants, cutting the young plant parts at the base. They sometimes cause wilting of the plant by partially cutting the plant stem.

Fields which are usually weedy, high in organic residue and very wet due to a lot of irrigation are associated with cutworms. Cutworms may hide about the weeds. They are not able to chew away mature, fibrous hardy seedlings. They shy away from sunlight and may not be able to avoid predators when out in the open. Damage is severe in dry conditions.

Non-chemical control:
  • Fields need to be kept free of weeds and thoroughly ploughed at least two weeks before planting.
  • Transplanting can be delayed in order to plant bigger seedlings which will tolerate cutworm damage.
  • Detecting the cutworms early helps to control them and avoid serious damage.
  • Ploughing helps expose the cutworm to natural predators and sunlight which eventually kills them.
  • Small infestations might be controlled by digging out the damaged seedling to find and kill the cutworm.
  • Sprays of Bacillus thuringiensis are also effective. Use a baited trap (flour and water with Bacillus thuringiensis or other pesticide).
  • Ashes deter cutworms when spread on seed beds, around plants or mixed with soil in planting holes.
Chemical control:
  • Use Bifenthrin, Deltamethrin, Indoxacarb, L-Cyhalothrin and Methoxyfenozide to control.
When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

Images.Caption: Cutworm.
Images.Credit: James Kalisch, University of Nebraska, Bugwood.org

Images.Caption: Variegated cutworm, Peridroma saucia.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Brassica Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
Damping off is caused by a fungus. It mainly affects very young or newly emerged seedlings, but can cause non-lethal damage to mature plants. Seedlings wilt, fall over and die after heavy rains or too much irrigation. This condition is known as 'bottom rot'. If the disease spreads upwards, the heads of cabbages are affected hence 'head rot'.
The disease affects the lower stem tissue in contact with the soil. This causes the decay of the outer stem but the inner stem is unaffected. Leaves wilt as they turn black-brown or black but remain on the plant.

The fungus lives in the soil and dies in hot temperatures. The infections may lead to bacterial infections that cause complete rotting of the head, which has an unpleasant smell. Disease is common in wet soils of poor drainage.

Non-chemical control
  • Make the soil fungus-free in the seedbed by sun or fire.
  • Plant when the soils are warm because seeds grow faster and seedlings are healthier.
  • Planting on raised beds is recommended to reduce soil moisture in the root zone and provide appropriate drainage in the field.
  • Do not plant too deep where the disease is a problem.
  • Avoid throwing soil into plant heads while cultivating.
  • Practice crop rotation especially with cereals.
  • Use biological control products containing the soil fungus Trichoderma spp.
Chemical control
  • Use mancozeb to control damping off.
  • Chestnut compound, a mix of copper sulphate and Ammonium carbonate, is often used to manage damping off.
When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

Images.Caption: Symptoms on cabbage.
Images.Credit: Gerald Holmes, Valent USA Corporation, Bugwood.org

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Tomato Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture, 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
Damping-off means the death of seedlings before or after they germinate. Infection is through the seeds, roots or leaves that are touching the soil or have been splashed by water or rain.
Infected seedlings fail to grow and where they do grow, they shrivel at the soil line, causing stems to become thin and thread-like, known as ‘wire-stem’. The greatest loss is death of seedlings in the seedbed or immediately afterwards. The upper part of the seedling begins to die and plants fall over.

The disease is caused by a fungus which is common in wet soils and may survive for several seasons. Overcrowding, poor drainage, compacted soil and inadequate air flow increase the chances of seedlings getting infected. The heat from sunlight or burnt straw can be used to kill the fungus prior to planting.

Non-chemical control:
  • Use certified disease-free seeds.
  • Good water management and proper seedbed preparation can significantly reduce damping-off. Keep water to a minimum in the soil without letting the seedlings wilt.
  • Avoid crowding of seedlings in the seedbed by following recommended sowing densities.
  • Exposing soil to the sun or burning straw on the seed bed site can help to reduce damping-off fungus.
  • Sprays of Trichoderma spp. control damping-off.
Chemical control:
  • Spray the seed bed with effective fungicides such as Metalaxyl-M, mancozeb and copper oxychloride.
When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

Images.Caption: Damping-off.
Images.Credit: Clemson University - USDA Cooperative Extension Slide Series, Bugwood.org

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Brassica Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
Young diamondback moths are pale green caterpillars. They feed by eating the lower side of the leaf leaving a see-through hole mostly referred to as a 'window'. They are small compared to other caterpillars. The adult moths have 3 diamond shapes on their wings hence the name of the pest. The females lay small yellow eggs on the leaves. These hatch into green caterpillars with no markings. When fully grown, the caterpillars grow inside a whitish silk cocoon attached to leaves or stems.
They are most serious when they damage the crowns or growing points of young plants. This injury can severely stunt growth, keeping the plant small.

The numbers of caterpillars can increase rapidly during dry weather and decrease in rainy conditions. Overhead irrigation and heavy rains tend to wash off young caterpillars. Large numbers in the field, if uncontrolled, can destroy the crop.

Non-chemical control
  • Conserve natural enemies such as parasitoids, ground beetles, true bugs, syrphid fly larvae and spiders, which can eat or kill the diamondback moth. Supply flowering plants to serve as a food source for adult syrphids. Avoid spraying pesticides when there are enough natural enemies in the field to reduce caterpillar numbers.
  • Interplanting Brassica crops with tomato or pepper can repel the diamondback moth.
  • Monitor the crop with yellow sticky traps or pheromone traps to discover the pest early for easy control.
  • Planting during the rainy season and use of overhead irrigation can help control the larvae.
  • Use biological pesticides like Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) and Beauveria bassiana.
Chemical control
  • Use chemicals such as Indoxacarb, Lufenuron, and Methoxyfenozide.
When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

Images.Caption: Diamondback moth caterpillar.
Diamondback moth adult.
Images.Credit: Russ Ottens, University of Georgia, Bugwood.org

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Brassica Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value: Irregular yellow patches are seen on leaves. Affected plants show a feathery fungal growth on the underside of leaves which later produces brown to black spots on the upper surface. The disease is most serious on young seedlings and the young plant may be underdeveloped and later die.

This disease requires cool, damp weather for infection and disease development to take place. It is mainly spread by wind, rain and overhead irrigation. The disease is serious on young seedlings and young plants. The disease survives on plant remains and can be found in the soil.

Non-chemical control
  • Rotate crops for at least two years with crops not related to brassicas.
  • Practice good nursery and field hygiene.
  • Allow crops to get good air movement by planting with wider spacing and parallel to the wind direction.
  • Plant varieties that are tolerant to downy mildew.
Chemical control
  • Famoxadone + cymoxanil, Mancozeb and mancozeb + metalaxyl are suitable for control of downy mildew.
When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

Images.Caption: Symptoms on broccoli leaf.
Images.Credit: Virginia Tech Learning Resources Center, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Bugwood.org

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Tomato Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture, 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
Tomato plants infected with early blight develop small dark brown to black spots on lower shaded leaves, stems and fruits. Leaves develop spots that are brown and leathery with faint concentric rings that look like a target. The spots later become uneven in shape. Spots on fruits often occur near the calyx end, where the fruit attaches to the plant.
In the seedbed the small plants wilt and eventually die. In older crops, stem death occurs while leaves fall off the crop and fruits drop early. The fruits are then exposed to sunburn.

Early blight is a seed-borne disease that results in poor germination of seedlings. Disease development is most serious during warm wet conditions. It is caused by a fungus that also attacks old transplanted seedlings and plants that are stressed due to poor fertilization or attack by nematodes. The disease is also spread by wind, rain, running water, farm tools and also farm workers.

Non-chemical control:
  • Use certified disease free seeds and tolerant varieties.
  • Practice crop rotation with non-host plants and plants that do not belong to the tomato family.
  • Avoid plant injury during transplanting.
  • Ensure a strong plant growth so that plants can escape attack of the fungus.
  • Plants should be staked and pruned correctly to allow good air flow and avoid disease spread.
  • Avoid planting tomatoes next to related crops like eggplant, pepper and potatoes.
  • Remove and destroy the old plants and weeds.
Chemical control:
  • Some of the effective chemicals available include Mancozeb, Azoxystrobin, copper oxychloride , Cymoxanil + Famoxadone, Dimethomorph + Mancozeb.
When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

Images.Caption: Early blight on tomato leaf.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Mango Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value: Fruit flies cause damage that lowers the market value of fruits such as mango and passion fruit. Adult fruit flies are small insects about 5-8 mm in length. They puncture the fruit and lay eggs under the skin. This leaves the fruit with small spots on the skin and leakage of fruit sap. The eggs hatch into whitish maggots within 1 to 2 days. The maggots feed on the fruit flesh causing faster ripening and rot. Between 5 and 20 days, the maggots exit the fruit leaving holes.

Fruit flies have many host plants. When fruit fly maggots leave the fruits, they move into the soil and develop into adults. The fruit flies may live and fly from other favourable plants to the mango tree at the beginning of the harvest season. Fruit flies get attracted to sex attractants and protein food baits.

Non-chemical control
  • Gather and destroy all infected fallen fruits twice a week and bury them about 50cm deep.
  • Uproot non-useful host plants with fruits e.g. neglected citrus, guava, hot and sweet pepper in the farm or nearby.
  • Pick out infected fruits with dimples and those that leak clear sap and destroy.
  • If possible, cover young fruits in paper bags or newspapers to put off fruit flies. This may be impractical on a large scale.
  • Harvest overripe fruits as they attract fruit flies.
  • Use fruit fly traps with protein bait to attract the adults.
Chemical control
  • Use poison baits that contain protein hydrozylate or molasses mixed with Bifenthrin, Buprofezin, Deltamethrin or L-cyhalothrin.
  • Spot treatment with insecticide sprays can be applied to non-fruiting regions.
When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

Images.Caption: Fruit fly damage on unripe mango.
Mango rot with fruit fly maggots.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Passion Fruit Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP HORTICULTURE, 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
Fusarium wilt sickness is caused by a fungus. The fungus infects the plant through the roots and then travels up the plant stem.
The sickness also known as "collar rot" shows itself as yellowing of leaves followed by complete death of the plant.
Initially, Infection causes the base of the stem to swell and cracks appear. On close observation of the sick stem, the parts of the stem which feed the plant show brown discolouration.

The germ is both seed-borne and soil-borne and can live in the soil for many years. Infestation by root-knot nematodes allows the germ to get inside the plant. The germs also get into the farm through farm tools, stacking materials and shoes.
The germ does not like yellow passion and its hybrids. The sickness is favoured by warm weather.

Non-chemical control
  • Join (graft) yellow passion fruit rootstock and purple passion (scion). Yellow passion is resistant to the disease.
  • Avoid planting where severe fusarium wilt has been detected within the last three years.
  • Field hygiene should also be practiced, by uprooting the affected plants and burning them.
  • Control root-knot nematodes as well as weeds.
  • Avoid cutting sick plants and then using the same knife on healthy plants.
  • Use a biopesticide like Trichoderma spp. which is a fungal opponent.

Images.Caption: Fusarium wilt on passion fruit vine.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Tomato Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture, 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
Fusarium wilt is caused by a fungus which infects the plant through the roots and then goes up the plant system. It sometimes affects only one side of the plant.
Infected plant branches turn yellow and wilt leading to death of the whole plant. If the main stem is cut, dark brown to red streaks may be seen running lengthwise through the stem. Disease leads to reduced yields and poor quality tomatoes.

The fungus is seed-borne and can be introduced through infected seeds or seedlings .The fungus is also transported on farm tools, stacking materials and shoes. The disease is favoured by acidic soils, nitrogenous fertilizers and warm wet weather. Presence of root knot nematodes encourages the disease. The fungus survives in the soil for many years. There are some cultivars of tomatoes that are tolerant to the disease.

Non-chemical control:
  • Plant resistant varieties.
  • Use certified disease free seeds and clean seedlings.
  • Avoid fields where severe fusarium wilt has been detected within the last three years.
  • Farm equipment should be cleaned and disinfected.
  • Where soils are acidic apply lime or farmyard manure.
  • Avoid excess use of nitrogenous fertilizers and control root knot nematodes.
  • Use sprays of Trichoderma spp. to control the Fusarium.
  • Infected plants should be bagged and removed from the field. They should then be destroyed by burning, otherwise you will spread the disease.
There are no safe, reliable chemical controls available.
When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

Images.Caption: Fusarium wilt on tomato.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Brassica Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value: Fusarium yellows disease occurs at all stages of crop growth. Disease symptoms consist of yellowing of the lower leaves. The yellowing spreads to the upper leaf which eventually leads to leaf fall leaving only the middle leaves. The plant may eventually die.

This disease is found both on seed and soil. The disease is usually introduced to uninfected locations by the movement of infected transplants, plant remains, infected farm equipment and drainage water. The disease persists in the soil and is difficult to control. The disease is severe in warm climatic conditions due to warmer soil temperatures.

Non-chemical control
  • Avoid introducing the pathogen in clean fields by destroying infected crop remains.
  • Plant resistant cabbage cultivars.
  • Avoid growing crops of the cabbage family in the same place, year after year.
  • Farm equipment should be kept clean and disinfected to avoid disease spread.
  • Liming reduces soil acidity thereby making soil conditions unsuitable for yellows fungus.

Images.Caption: Fusarium yellows on cabbage.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Tomato Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture, 2011

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
These are cracks that appear when the fruit is developing. They occur when the fruit approaches maturity. They can be radial (from the top of the fruit down, see image) or concentric (a circle around the top of the fruit).
These cracks are caused by very fast growth in high temperatures and high moisture levels, a dry period followed by heavy rain, or irrigation during ripening.
The circular or linear cracks form at the stem end of the fruit. The cracks reduce the market value of the fruits. They also provide entry points for germs which could cause disease.

There are varieties of tomatoes that do not experience growth cracking.
Proper management of irrigation regimes is very important. This ensures that water is available to the plant at the right time for uniform growth of the fruits. Nitrogen fertilizers tend to lock up maturity of the fruits.

Non-chemical control
  • Manage irrigation programmes so all plants have water to grow at the same time.
  • Grow varieties that are not susceptible to cracking.
  • Avoid over-use of nitrogen fertilizers.
There is no known chemical control.

Images.Caption: Growth cracking on tomato fruit.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Mango Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
This disorder is called "internal breakdown" because the signs are not visible from the outside.
It appears as soft nose, jelly seed and spongy tissue. Other disorders that come as a result of the internal breakdown are softening of the flesh, change of colour and brown tissues. If internal breakdown is severe, the flesh rots and gives off an unpleasant odour. This reduces the fruit quality.

Internal breakdown is considered as collapse of the flesh. The tissues soften and turn spongy. This problem starts from the stone and spreads toward the peel. Sometimes the whole flesh gets too soft, resembling bacteria rot. Internal breakdown may be caused by excess nitrogen, for instance on farms where livestock has been kept.

Non-chemical control
  • Ensure a balanced Calcium nutrition.
  • Mango orchards should not be established where livestock has been previously kept.
  • Plant varieties that are less susceptible to the internal breakdown.

Images.Caption: Mango internal breakdown.
Mango internal breakdown.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Tomato Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture, 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
Late blight is a minor disease during the dry season; however it is most serious during cool moist conditions. Spores from the sick plant can move into a clean plant and infect it.
At first, the disease causes irregular greenish or water soaked lesions on the leaves, stems and fruits. Leaf spots turn a bluish-grey colour and sometimes when the weather is wet have a white fuzzy growth around the margins of the spots on the undersides of the leaves. Infected leaves turn brown and wither, but stay attached to the plant. Fruits develop watery brownish green spots which develop on the upper half of fruit. The disease leads to a very quick death of the entire plant.

The disease is spread by water splashes from the soil. The disease can also be spread by overhead irrigation and in overcrowded farms. The disease survives in old crop residues and other plants related to the tomato. There are varieties of tomatoes that are tolerant to the disease.

Non-chemical control:
  • Practice crop rotation by avoiding tomato or related crops (e.g. Irish potatoes, capsicum, brinjals etc) for at least 3 to 4 seasons.
  • Plant resistant varieties.
  • Transplants should be free of disease.
  • Stake the plant to keep them off soil.
  • Mulch the plant to reduce water splashes.
  • Irrigating during the day can help reduce the severity of the infection because this disease needs to have free water around to spread.
Chemical control:
  • Fungicide sprays should be applied as soon as the disease symptoms are seen, or before if there are prolonged periods of wet weather as these conditions favour the disease.
  • These chemicals include copper oxychloride, Dimethomorph + Mancozeb, Famoxadone + Cymoxanil, Metalaxyl-M + Mancozeb and Mancozeb.
When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

Images.Caption: Late blight on tomato.
Late blight on tomato leaves.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Brassica Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value: Leaf miner adults are small black flies with a bright yellow spot on their back. Females puncture leaves to feed on plant juice and lay eggs in the leaf tissues. After 2-4 days, the eggs hatch and larvae feed between the upper and lower surface of leaves making whitish lines or leaf mines. These suggest that the leaf miners are present.

Leaf miners are found in old crop remains and also on crops related to brassicas. Their population is high on seedlings. The mines or tunnels can kill seedlings and in older plants, allow fungal diseases to enter the leaves. The leaves are rendered unmarketable. Leaf miners are attracted to the colour yellow.

Non-chemical control
  • Conserve natural enemies especially parasitoids by avoiding spraying pesticides when there are enough natural enemies to reduce the number of caterpillars in the field.
  • Where possible, avoid planting next to infested fields, especially those near harvested crops.
  • Plough to expose the miners so they burn in the sun and get eaten by natural enemies.
  • Plant seedlings free of leaf miners.
  • Practice field hygiene e.g. handpicking and destroying mined leaves, burning all infected plant parts and destroying hosts such as old crop debris.
  • Use yellow sticky traps or yellow basins filled with water to attract adults.
Chemical control
  • Effective insecticides to use include Abamectin, Bifenthrin and Methoxyfenozide.
When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

Images.Caption: Leaf mine on Brassica leaf.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Tomato Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture, 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
Leafminer adults look like small black and yellow flies about 2mm long. They lay eggs which hatch into small larvae that feed by mining between the upper and lower layers of the leaves making a tunnel as they move along.
The act of laying eggs and feeding on leaves can kill seedlings and in older plants allow fungal diseases to enter the leaves. During heavy infestations, adults feed and lay eggs on the leaves causing white spotting or stippling. However, the major damage is caused by larvae which tunnel, or "mine" inside the leaves reducing the leaf area that the plant can use. They affect many crops including tomato and passion fruit.

Leafminers are eaten by some insects and some other insects cause them to get sick and die. The adults are attracted to the yellow colour and like living in other plants as well. The larvae fall to the ground to first develop into pupae, before later developing into an adult leafminer. The pupae, which have soft skin, can get dried by the sun once they fall to the ground.

Non-chemical control
  • Control leafminers by natural enemies. Conserve parasitic wasps such as Diglypus spp.
  • Regularly plough the farm. This exposes the pupae, so that they burn in the sun and get noticed by some other insects that will eat them.
  • Use yellow sticky traps or yellow basins filled with water to trap the adults.
  • Uproot and destroy infected old crop debris and practice crop rotation.
Chemical control
  • Pesticides used should be able to pass through the outer layers of the leaves or move into the plant sap because the pupae hide in the tunnel.
  • Leaf miners develop pesticide resistance. Practice regular rotation of pesticides to stop this happening.
  • Use Abamectin, Bifenthrin, Cyromazine and Methoxyfenozide.
When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

Images.Caption: Leafminer damage on tomato leaf.
Images.Credit: Clemson University - USDA Cooperative Extension Slide Series, Bugwood.org

Images.Caption: Adult leafminer.
Images.Credit: Central Science Laboratory, Harpenden Archive, British Crown, Bugwood.org

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Mango Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value: Gall flies are small flies about 1-2 mm. The female pierces and lays eggs on young leaves. The eggs hatch later into maggots. These maggots make the tissue swollen and soft leading to formation of galls. A gall fly maggot lives inside each of the galls, which are about 4mm wide. The galls cause the bordering tissues to die. Severe invasion of the galls makes the leaf die and drop early. Young trees may die and old trees fail to pick up normal growth after many attacks.

Gall flies are killed by many species of wasps. Maggots move from the leaf to the soil where they develop into adults. During heavy infestation, leaves fall carrying maggots which develop into adult gall flies.

Non-chemical control
  • Conserve parasitic wasps which are natural enemies for gall flies.
  • If possible, flood the soil around the mango trees before flowering. This stops the emergence of the gall flies from the soil.
Chemical sprays are neither recommended nor necessary.

Images.Caption: Galls on leaf caused by mango gall flies.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Brassica Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value: Nzi tunda husababisha hasara ambayo hushusha bei za maembe na matunda ya karakara sokoni. Wadudu hawa huwa ni wadogo na wana urefu wa milimita 5-8. Wanauwezo wakutoboa mashimo kwenye matunda na kutaga mayai yao humo ndani. Hii husababisha matunda kuwa na madoadoa madogo kwenye ngozi na kuvuja kwa utomvu. Baada ya siku 1 hadi 2, mayai huangua mabuu. mabuu haya hula matunda na kuyafanya yaive kwa haraka na kuoza. Mabuu hutoka kwenye matunda baada ya siku 5 hadi 20, huku wakiacha mashimo mengi.

Nzi tunda huwa ni ‘wenyeji wa’ au ‘huishi kwa’ mimea mingi. Mabuu ya nzi tunda yatokapo kwenye matunda, huingia kwenye mchanga na kupevuka. Nzi tunda hawa wanauwezo wa kuishi na kupepea kutoka kwenye mimea mingine hadi katika miembe mwanzoni mwa msimu wa uvunaji. Kivutio chao huwa ni harufu itokayo kwenye kemikali zinazowafanya kuhisi kujaamiana au kwenye mitego yenye vyakula vya protini.

Kudhibiti bila kemikali

Okota na uharibu matunda yote yaliyoanguka mara mbili kwa wiki, halafu uyazike kwenye shimo lenye urefu wa sentimita 50.

Ng’oa mimea yeyote isiyokuwa na manufaa lakini yana matunda katika shamba lako au karibu nalo, kwa mfano michungwa au mindimu iliyopuuzwa, mipera na pilipili aina zote.

Kwamua matunda yeyote yaliyoambukizwa au kuathirika na yamebonyea, pamoja na yale yanayovuja utomvu na uyaharibu.

Kama inawezekana, funikia mimea midogo ya matunda kwa kutumia mifuko ya karatasi au magazeti, ili kufukuza Nzi tunda. Hii inaweza kuwa ngumu kwako kama uko na shamba kubwa.

Vuna matunda yote yaliyoiva, kwa kuwa huvutia nzi tunda.

Tumia mitego ya nzi yenye chambo cha protini kuvutia nzi tunda waliopevuka.

Kudhibiti ukitumia kemikali

Tumia mitego yenye sumu aina ya protein hydrolysate au molasi iliyochanganywa na Bifethrin, Buprofezin, Deltamethrin au L-cyhalothrin.
  • Unaweza pia kunyunyizia viuwa wadudu katika maeneo yasiyoota matunda.
Wakati wa kutumia kemikali, vaa mavazi ya kinga wakati wote na ufuate maelekezo kwenye lebo ya bidhaa, kama vile kipimo, majira ya kuweka, muda kabla ya kuvuna

Images.Caption: Fruit fly damage on unripe mango.
Mango rot with fruit fly maggots.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Brassica Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
Viwavi vya aina ya Leafminer vikipevuka hufanana na nzi wadogo wenye urefu wa milimita mbili na wenye rangi nyeusi na manjano. Hawa nzi hutaga mayai ambayo huangua viwavi wadogo vinavyokula kwa kuchimba kutoka upande wa juu wa tawi hadi chini, huku vikiendelea kula matawi na kuacha mashimo.

Hali yao ya kutaga mayai na ulaji wa matawi inaweza kuua miche midogo na pia kwa mimea iliyopevuka inaweza kusababisha magonjwa ya kuvu kuingia katika matawi. Wakati mimea imeathirika sana, nzi wa ‘leafminer’ hula na kutaga mayai juu ua matawi, hii husababisha matawi kuwa na madoadoa au mabatobato meupe. Walakini uharibifu mkubwa hutokea pale viwavi huchimba au kutoboa mashimo, na hivyo kupunguza eneo la tawi ambalo lingetumika na mmea wenyewe. Hawa nzi huharibu mimea mingi sana ikiwemo minyanya na matunda ya karakara.

Viwavi aina ya ‘Leafminers’ huliwa na wadudu wengine na hufanya wadudu wa aina nyingine kuwa wangonjwa na kufa. Viwavi vilivyopevuka na kuwa nzi, huvutiwa na rangi ya manjano na hupenda kukaa pia ndani ya mimea mingine. Kwanza viwavi huanguka kwenye ardhi na kuota kuwa pupae kabla ya kupevuka baadae na kuwa nzi aina ya ‘Leafminer’.

Kudhibiti bila kemikali
  • Unaweza kudhibiti hivi viwavi vya leafminers kwa kutumia adui wao wa kawaida. Hifadhi nyigu kama vile aina ya Diglypus spp.
  • Lima shamba lako kila mara. Hii huchimbua viwavi au pupae, ili waweze kuchomwa na jua na pia watambulike na wadudu wengine wanaoweza kuwala.
  • Unaweza kutumia mitego ya kushika wadudu ya rangi ya manjano au beseni la manjano lililojazwa maji, ili kutega nzi aina ya leaminers.
  • Ng’oa na uharibu mabaki yoyote ya mimea iliyoathirika na ujaribu kutumia mtindo wa mapangilio wakati unapopanda mimea yako.
Kudhibiti ukitumia kemikali
  • Tumia viuwa wadudu vyenye uwezo wa kuingia ndani ya mimea au ndani ya utomvu wa mimea, kwasababu humo kwenye mashimo ndimo wajifichapo pupae wa leafminer.
  • Leafminers wana uwezo wa kugomea viuwa wadudu. Kuzuia jambo hili tumia mpangilio wa viuwa wadudu aina tofauti tofauti kila mara.
  • Tumia viuwa wadudu aina ya Abamectin, Bifenthrin, Cyromazine and Methoxyfenozide.
Wakati wa kutumia kemikali, vaa mavazi ya kinga wakati wote na ufuate maelekezo kwenye lebo ya bidhaa, kama vile kipimo, majira ya kuweka, muda kabla ya kuvuna

Images.Credit: Clemson University - USDA Cooperative Extension Slide Series, Bugwood.org

Images.Caption: Adult leafminer.
Images.Credit: Central Science Laboratory, Harpenden Archive, British Crown, Bugwood.org

Sections.Value: Viwavi vya aina ya ‘Stem borer’ hutengeneza mashimo kwenye mabua ya mahindi. Ukipasua wazi bua lililoathirika, utaona viwavi hao humo ndani. Viwavi hawa hutengeneza shimo humo ndani mwa bua. Wkati mwingine shimo hilo linaweza kuwa refu hadi likafikia siko la mahindi. Matawi ya mahindi huanza kubadili rangi na kuwa manjano na hatimaye bua lake huanza kuoza. Upepo mkali unaweza kuangusha mimea iliyathirika.

Kiwavi aina ya ‘stem borer’ hula na kukua kwa wiki tatu hadi tano. Viwavi hivi huanguliwa kutoka kwa mayai yaliyotagwa na nondo wenye rangi ya maji ya kunde na madoadoa kwenye mbawa zao. Nondo hao hutaga vifungu vya mayai mahali ambapo tawi hushikana na bua la mahindi. Viwavi hawa wanaweza kuishi ndani ya bua lizee kwa muda wa mwaka mmoja hadi mwingine. Wakati mmea ufikiapo kimo cha futi mbili, mayai huangua na viwavi hukusanyika katika shimo.

Udhibiti
  • Choma mabua yanayobaki baada ya kuvuna mahindi. Hii itaweza kusaidia kuwaua viwavi vyote vinavyoishi ndani ya mabua hayo. Unaweza pia kuwaua viwavi hao kwa kukatakata mabua hayo na kulisha mifugo yako.
  • Usipande mahindi kila mwaka katika shambo hilo hilo moja. Ni vyema baada ya kuvuna mahindi, upande mimea mingine kama vile maharage au njugu, ambayo haiathiriki na viwavi hivi aina ya stem borer.
  • Unaweza pia kunyunyizia dawa aina ya Deltamethrin 25EC, kwa kiwango cha nusu lita kwa hekta moja, wakati miche ya mahindi iko na kimo cha chini ya futi mbili.

Images.Caption: Maize stem borer.
Stem borer damaging the cob.
Apply insecticide in the maize funnel when the plant is small to kill the stem borers that collect there.

Sections.Value: Maize stalk borer ni kiwavi. Kiwavi hiki hula undani wa mabua ya mahindi, halafu mmea wenyewe hunyauka na kubadilika rangi kuwa manjano. Sehemu ya juu ya mmea wa mahindi hukauka na kufa. Wakati mwingine viwavi hivi hutengeneza mashimo yanayoingia ndani ya mabua. Ukiweza kupasua wazi bua la mahindi, utaweza kuona kinyesi cha mabuu hawa humo ndani. Upande wa ndani wa bua hilo kutakuwa pia kumebadilika rangi na kuwa rangi ya manjano au ya maji ya kunde. Unaweza pia kuona kiwavi chenyewe humo ndani mwa bua.

Kiwavi cha stalk borer huanguliwa kutoka kwa mayai yaliyotagwa na nondo. Nondo hao huwa hawapendi harufu ya mmea uitwao Desmodium. Walakini wao hupendelea harufu ya nyasi aina ya mabingobingo (au Nepia). Nondo hawa hutaga mayai yao kwenye matawi ya nyasi ya mabingobingo, ingawaje kiwavi cha stalk borer kinaweza kunaswa na hata kufariki kwenye matawi ya nyasi hii.

Mimea aina ya Desmodium na nyasi ya mabingobingo inaweza kulishwa ng’ombe vizuri. Mmea wa Desmodium unaweza kuwa shida kupata, lakini unashauriwa utembelee taasisi ya KALRO iliyokaribu nawe.

Viwavi aina ya stalk borer kwa mara nyingi hushindwa kudhibitiwa na dawa au viuwa wadudu, kwa kuwa viwavi hivi hujificha ndani mwa mmea. Ni bora Zaidi kuzuia viwavi hawa kuingia kwenye mahindi.

Fukuza viwavi hawa mbali na mahindi kwa kutumia mmea wa Desmodium. Ilhali pia unaweza kuwavutia viwavi hao kuenda kwenye ukingo wa shamba lako kwa kutumia nyasi ya mabingobingo.

Mvua inapoanza, panda mstari mmoja wa Desmodium kati ya kila mistari au mipando mitatu ya mahindi.

  • Kwanza, pandikiza mimea ya Desmodium katika mistari yao. Panda hii mimea kabla ya kupanda mahindi, ili iweze kuanza kuwafukuza hao viwavi aina ya stalk borer, kabla ya mahindi kumea. Ipande hii Desmodium ukizingatia umbali kati ya mistari kama upandavyo mahindi.
  • Pili, panda mahindi kwenye mistari iliyobaki.
  • Tatu, pandikiza vipande vya nyasi ya mabingobingo katika takriban mistari mitatu kuzunguka mahindi uliyopanda.
Ukifanya hivi nondo watataga mayai yao kwenye nyasi ya mabingobingo na sio kwenye mahindi.

Images.Caption: The maize stalk borer is a caterpillar that lives and grows inside the maize stem.
Maize crop plan with thara and Desmodium.

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Brassica Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
Thrip ni wadudu wadogo walio na urefu wa milimita moja, wenye mbawa nne ambazo ni refu, nyembamba na zenye shungi.Thrip walio wachanga huwa na rangi ya manjano. Ilhali waliopevuka huwa na rangi nyeusi na wenye tabia ya kuinua vipeo vya miili yao.

Ili waweze kula, thrips husugua mmea na kusababisha madoadoa madogo yenye rangi ya fedha. Hawa thrips hupenda kula upande wa chini wa matawi machanga, tumba, maua na matunda. Wakati wadudu hawa huvamia tumba za maua, maua hayo huwa hayachipuki na matunda yanayovamiwa pia huwa ya gredi ya chini. Thrips husambaza magonjwa ya nyanya kama vile Tomato spotted wilt virus. Hasara au uharibifu mkubwa husababishwa kwenye miche.

Kabla ya viwavi vya thrips kupevuka na kuwa wadudu, wao kwanza huota na kuwa pupa, ambao huishi kwa muda wa zaidi ya wiki moja juu ya matawi yaliyooza au kwenye mchanga. Thrips wanaweza kudumu au kuishi kwenye mimea aina nyingi. Hawa ni wadudu ambao wanapatikana nje na hata ndani ya nyumba aina za ‘greenhouse’. Thrips waliopevuka wanaweza kupeperushwa na upepo hadi mbali sana.

Kudhibiti bila kemikali
  • Chunguza mimea yako mara kwa mara. Unaweza kujua kama thrips wamevamia nyanya katika shamba lako kwa kutingisha au kupukusa matawi na maua ya nyanya juu ya karatasi nyeupe.
  • Shamba likifurika na maji, pupa zilizo kwenye mchanga hufa.
  • Kulima shamba pia huchangia kuua pupa walio mchangani.
  • Utunzaji wa shamba bila magugu, umeonekana kusaidia kupunguza viwango vya wadudu hawa aina ya thrips.
  • Hifadhi adui wa kawaida wa thrips kama vile ‘predatory thrips’, ‘green lacewings’, ‘pirate bugs’, nyigu na ‘predatory mites’ kama vile Amblyseius spp., kwa kutotumia viuwa wadudu wakati hawa maadui wa kawaida wako wengi kiasi cha kudhibiti viwango vya thrips.
  • Unaweza pia kutumia mitego ya kushikwa wadudu na kuwaua yenye rangi ya samawati/bluu au ya manjano.

Kudhibiti kutumia kemikali
  • Tumia viuwa wadudu kama vile Azadirachtin (Mwarubaini), Abamectin, Deltamethrin, Lambda cyhalothrin and Lufenuron.
Wakati wa kutumia kemikali, vaa mavazi ya kinga wakati wote na ufuate maelekezo kwenye lebo ya bidhaa, kama vile kipimo, majira ya kuweka, muda kabla ya kuvuna

Images.Credit: P.M.J. Ramakers, Applied Plant Research, Bugwood.org

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Brassica Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
Nzi weupe huwa ni wadudu wadogo wenye urefu wa milimita moja hadi mbili. Wadudu hawa hupatikana mara nyingi kwenye upande wa chini wa matawi. Nzi weupe wanatabia ya kubeba mabawa yao kama paa juu ya miili yao.
Wadudu hawa hula matawi ya mimea, na kuyafanya kubadilika rangi na kuwa manjano na kusokotana.  Hawa wadudu pia hutoa ulimbo uitwao ‘honeydew’ ambayo hufanya matawi kumetameta na kuwa meusi au yenye masizi. Nzi weupe wanauwezo wa kusambaza virusi vinavyo sababisha magonjwa.

Nzi weupe wanauwezo wa kuishi kwenye mimea mingi na ya aina tofauti tofauti, ikiwemo nyanya, kabeji na maembe. Kunyunyizia mimea maji yaliyo na sabuni huwa kunawakosesha hewa nzi weupe na kufanya mimea iwe na utelezi, hivyo basi nzi hawa huoshwa kutoka kwa mmea. Bidhaa za mwarubaini zinauwezo wa kuzuia kukua kwa nzi weupe wachanga, pia kuwakufukuza nzi waliokomaa na kupunguza utagaji wao wa mayai.

Kudhibiti bila kemikali
  • Ili kuzuia wadudu hawa kuishi katika shamba lako, weka shamba hilo bila magugu.
  • Maadui wa kawaida wa nzi weupe pia wanaweza kutumika kuwadhibiti kwa mfano aina ya nyigu iitwayo ‘Encarsia Formosa’; pia ‘lace wings’, ‘big-eyed bugs’ na ‘pirate bugs’ wadogo.
  • Nyunyizia mimea iliyoathirika na mafuta ya madini na pia maji yaliyo na sabuni.
  • Toa mimea au sehemu za mimea iliyoathirika kama vile matawi ilikuzuia wadudu hawa kuongezeka.
  • Baada ya kuvuna, ng’oa mimea yote na uichome ili kuharibu mayai ya nzi weupe.
Kudhibiti kutumia kemikali
  • Viuwa wadudu vyenye uwezo wa kudhibiti nzi hawa weupe ni kama vile Bifethrin, Buprofezin, Deltamethrin, Lambda cyhalothrin na Pymetrozine. Nyunyizia hizi dawa upande wa chini wa matawi.
Zingatia: Dawa aina ya Deltamethrin na Lambda cyhalothrin zinauwezo wa kudhuru maadui wa kawaida wa nzi weupe.
Wakati wa kutumia kemikali, vaa mavazi ya kinga wakati wote na ufuate maelekezo kwenye lebo ya bidhaa, kama vile kipimo, majira ya kuweka, muda kabla ya kuvuna

Authors.Surname: This factsheet is based on information written for "The Mango Farming Handbook", first published by KENGAP Horticulture 2011.

Institution.Name: Kengap Horticulture Ltd, P.O Box 12898-00400 Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
Leaf coating mites are very small whitish to cream orange, cigar shaped mites. They are about 0.2mm long and cannot be seen by eyes without aid.
The mites live in groups under a white coating on the upper leaf surface. The affected leaves eventually drop off after yellowing.
In general, the coating has minimal effect on fruit yield.

Leaf coating mites suck plant sap from the leaves beneath the waxy coating on the upper leaf surfaces.
They are mostly a problem with uncared for mango trees which have not been pruned for a long time.

Non-chemical control
  • Remove and destroy leaves with white coating.
  • Prune the plant to increase the amount of light that will reach the leaves.
It is not necessary to use chemical miticides for control.

Images.Caption: Waxy leaf coating on leaves.

Authors.Surname: Nancy Murage (Ministry of Agriculture ), Miriam Otipa (KARI), Dora Kilalo Dr. (Nairobi University), Alfayo Ombuya (KEPHIS), Willis Ochilo (CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Intercrop with onion, garlic, spider plant, coriander to attract natural enemies
- Avoid too much N which makes plants to be very succulent and attractive to aphids
- Plant in a well prepared fertile seedbed to promote crop vigour
- Keep the fields free of weeds and alternative hosts such as wild mustards
- Manage the field to favour natural enemies such as lady bird beetles, hover flies and Aphidius sp
- Encourage growth of milk weed within the field. Milk weed is a host of other types of aphids which are natural enemies
- Mulch with wheat straw or clear/transparent polyethylene sheet as reflectors of UV light discourage aphids from landing on the crop

- Monitor early in the season after transplanting and when the conditions are cool and dry favouring aphid development
- Look at the lower leaves, stems and growing points for soft bodied insects, curled or capping of infested leaves, black sooty mould
- Institute control measures when 1 to 2 % of plants are infested

- Apply overhead irrigation to knock aphids off the leaves
- Spray soapy solution (potassium soaps) (add 10-15 tablespoons of liquid soap in 20lt bucket and spray). Avoid powder detergent soaps because they can burn plant leaves and if used frequently, will reduce soil fertility
- Spray with botanical extracts, e.g. Mixture of garlic, neem , Red chilli pepper and soap (take 50g mix in 2 lts of water, boil for 15 minutes, allow to cool and spray); Pyrethrum flower

- Wear protective clothing when handling chemicals
- Follow instructions on the product label such as dosage, pre-harvest interval and appropriate time of application

- Spray with Deltamethrin based products such as Farm-X, Atom 2.5EC, Decis 2.5 EC etc at the rate of 10-15mls/20L of water; Contact pyrethroid pesticide with residual activity. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Toxic to aquatic organisms. Avoid using near water ways; High risk to bees and other non-target arthropods. Don’t spray when plants are flowering
- Spray with Imidacloprid based products such as Confidor 200SL, Imaxi 200SL and Tata Mida 200SL at the rate of 10mls/20L of water; Apply as seed dressing; Mode of action: Neonicotinoid. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Maximum number of treatments: one per batch of seed; Treated seed is harmful to humans and wildlife
- Spray with Pirimicarb based products such as Pirimor 50WG at the rate of 20gms/20L of water; Mode of action: Carbamate. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); PHI 14 days; Dangerous to fish and other aquatic species. Do not contaminate surface water or water ways
- Spray with Thiamethoxam based products such as Actara 25WG at the rate of; Mode of action: Pyrethroid. General Restrictions: Not classified by WHO; PHI 3 days

Images.Caption: Green peach aphid adults and nymphs (NRI, UK – Handbook for extension staff, Zimbambwe)

Factsheets.Title: Aphids on cabbages and kale
ScientificNames: Cabbage aphid (Brevicoryne brassicae), False cabbage aphid (Lipaphis erysimi), Green peach aphid and (Myzus persicae)

Sections.Value:
- Sowing as early as possible in the rainy season allows plants to start flowering before aphids appear
- Use a variety that is tolerant to aphids if available
- Plant natural barriers, such as maize or sorghum, around the crop at least 20 days before planting the green gram
- Practice close plant spacing as it provides a barrier to aphids coming from the field edges
- Mulch with rice/wheat straw or a clear polyethylene sheet to discourage winged aphids from landing on the crop
- Intercrop with onion or garlic
- Remove weeds and alternative hosts (leguminous plants)
- Avoid crop rotation with other host plants (e.g. groundnuts, cowpeas, pigeonpeas, chickpeas, beans, lupins, lentils, and lucerne) and avoid planting green gram for more than one season
- Avoid excess use of nitrogen which make the plants attractive to aphids
- Encourage the presence of natural enemies (ladybird beetles, parasitoids, syrphids larvae and spiders) by reducing the use of chemicals

- Weekly monitoring of young plants, leaflets, stems and pods for:
- Aphids:
• Adults have shiny black or dark brown body with brown to yellow legs
• Immature aphids are slightly dusted with wax
- Signs of aphids:
• Look for honeydew and sooty mould (or ants attracted to honeydew)
• Young leaves become twisted due to feeding
- Monitor every 3 days when conditions are favourable for aphids (around 24-28°C and 65% RH)
- Apply control measures when colonies are seen on 2 out of 20 plants in the field as A. craccivora is an important vector of more than 30 plant viruses

- Use overhead irrigation to remove aphids from the leaves
- Use natural enemies if available in your country (e.g. Aphidius spp., Trioxys indicus or Chrysoperla spp.); follow directions for their spread or release
- After harvest, destroy crop residues immediately to reduce aphid movement
- Use yellow sticky traps to control the winged aphids coming from the edges of the field and older crops
- Spray in the early morning or evening with 160-200 cc neem oil and 100g of liquid soap in 20L of water

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adults and nymphs A. craccivora (E. Neering)

Authors.Surname: Miriam Otipa (KARI), Stephen Kiritai (Ministry of Agriculture), K.  Kagai (MoA), Benson Ngigi (MoA), Margaret Mulaa (CABI), Dora Kilalo (University of Nairobi), Thomas Kwambai (KALRO), Keneth Kagai (MOAL&F) and Jacob Ndungu (MOAL&F)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean planting material from tissue culture
- Select vigorous healthy suckers from banana stools free from weevils
- Trim (pair) banana suckers to reduce number of eggs and grubs and immerse them in a hot water bath at 52-55°C for 15 to 27 minutes or 43°C for 3 hours before planting
- Avoid replanting on previously infested land for 6-24 months
- Cut and remove all pseudo-stems after harvesting
- Avoid movement of materials from infested plantation to clean fields
- Cover the stumps with a layer of soil to prevent entry of weevils
- Spread mulch 60 cm away from the base of the banana stool to avoid weevil hiding underneath.
- De-sucker unwanted suckers as early as possible by ensuring a 3-5 pseudo-stem regime
- Remove debris and dead leaves at the base of the pseudo-stems in the banana mat.
- Keep the field weed free all the time
- Apply fertilizer and manure at planting and regularly top dress using CAN

- Monitor for weevils (black insects with clearly pronounced snout and hard forewings) using cut pieces of pseudo-stem. Place near the stools and inspect every 3 days for weevils
- Look out for: -wilting and death of young suckers starting from the central young leaves, -fallen pseudo-stems even in absence of strong wind or when water is adequate, -irregular tunnels in the corm and pseudo-stem. -dull yellow and floppy foliage
- Intervene when 1-2 weevils is observed

- Trap and manually kill the weevils using weevil traps made of pieces of pseudo-stem 3 inches thick and 20-60 cm long left for at least 3 days with the cut surface downwards near the stools. Collect used traps and burn or bury about 50 cm deep
- Use neem seed powder/cake at the rate of 60g/stool at planting and subsequently every 4 months
- Dip suckers in 20% neem seed solution when planting to offer protection

- Spray early morning or late evening to avoid harming bees
- Dispose properly to avoid aquatic contamination
- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)
- Read and follow instructions on the label

- Spray Bifenthrin based products e.g. Biferan 25EC, Seizer 80SC, Talstar at a rate of 20ml in 20 litres of water. Pyrethroid; IRAC 3A. Non-systemic with contact and stomach action. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). MRL 0.1 mg/kg. PHI 3 days
- Drench with imidacloprid based products e.g. Confidor 200SL, Imax 200SL,and Tata Mida 200SL at a rate of 10mls in 20 litres of water. Neonicotinoid; IRAC 4A. Systemic insecticide with translaminar activity and with contact and stomach action. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). MRL 0.05 mg/kg. PHI 3 days

Images.Caption: Adult Banana weevil (Photo: A.M. Varela, icipe)
Toppled banana plant (Photo:Thomas K. Kwambai, KALRO,  Kenya)

Authors.Surname: Miriam Otipa (KARI),Eunice K. Ringera (KEPHIS), MaryLucy Oronje (CABI), Margaret Mulaa (CABI), Esther macharia  (KALRO), Boniface N. Ndung’u (MoALF), Edward Okonjo (Dudutech), Hannah Oduor (MOALF), Martha Kariuki (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Practice two year crop rotation with non-leguminous plants such as tomatoes, cabbages and kales
- Remove and burn old crop residues since the disease can live for one year on the material left in the field
- Plant resistant varieties like GLP-X 1127 new mwezi moja, New rose coco, for common bean and Kutuless (J12) for French beans.
- Use clean bean seeds originating from non-diseased plants or from certified seeds dealers
- Deep plough to about 45 cm to turn residues into the soil to encourage rotting of the plant remains and reduce the amount of fungal disease carried over to the next bean season
- Avoid planting new bean crop next to an old bean field
- Maintain weed-free field, in particular remove alternate host plants e.g. Oxalis spp
- Avoid relay planting
- Avoid walking through the field during wet weather to prevent disease spread from one plant to another

- Look out for small orange to yellow halo-like powdery pustules on the upper side and orange to red circular pustules on the lower leaf surface.
- Also look out for pustules on the petioles, pods and the stem.
- Consider applying direct control when brown pustules are observed on the leaves of 4-5 plants

- Pick affected leaves, transport away from the field in a plastic bag and destroy by burning as soon as possible to prevent spores from spreading
- Work on the healthy part of the field first before the infected area

- When using a pesticide always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains
- WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Hexaconazole (e.g. Cotaf 5% EC) at 75-100ml/20L of water . General Restrictions: WHO III (Slightly hazardous); PHI 14 days; FRAC mode of action 3
- Chlorothalonil (e.g. Daconil) at 72ml/20L, Twigathalonil 720 SC at 40ml/20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use); Toxic to aquatic organisms; Do not spray near surface water or empty into water drains; PHI 7 days; FRAC mode of action 3
- Mancozeb (eg Biothane WP) Mix 5g of Biothane 80WP in 20litres of water . General Restrictions: WHO class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use); Toxic to aquatic organisms; Do not spray near surface water or empty into water drains; PHI 14 days; FRAC mode of action 3

Images.Caption: Bean rust spots on bean leaf (AgrEvo)
Rust spots on bean pod (Howard Schwartz, Colorado State University, Bugwood)

Authors.Surname: Miriam Otipa (Kenya Agriculture Research Institute), Rose Kamau(Ministry of Agriculture), Maina Gekone (MoA) Kenya Agricultural Research Institute, P.O. Box 14733-00800, Nairobi, Kenya.

Sections.Value:
- Use certified tolerant varieties like Baraka F1, Globe Master F1, Blue dynasty FI, Riana F1, Field winner F1
- Rotate with non-brassicas like maize and beans, onions and pumpkins for at least 2 years
- Use disease free transplants
- Keep field free from weeds to avoid alternate host of the Brassiceae family
- Avoid weeding during wet conditions to avoid spread on inoculums
- Apply mulch to avoid disease spread by rain splash
- After harvest remove all the plant debris
- Do not allow machinery and equipment movement from infested to non-infested fields

- In the nursery look out for a yellow appearance along the margin of the cotyledon which later shrivel and drop off. The affected seedlings turn yellow to brown wilt and die.
- On the mature plant look out for: 1. Yellow, brown or black v-shaped patches at the edge of the leaves; 2. Black veins when the yellow black lesions are held against light; 3. A black ring in a cross-section of the stem
- In later stages, check out for blackheads with an offensive foul smell
- Disease is common during wet conditions with high temperatures
- Take immediate action when first symptoms appear
- Remove all infected plants and debris from the field and destroy by burning

- Spray the remaining healthy plants using a copper-based protective fungicide to supress further damage (e.g. Kocide at 50g/20L); FRAC code M1. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous9; Spray interval of 14 days during wet weather; PHI 7 days; Use a maximum of 3 sprays; When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains.; WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes; Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

Characteristic v-shaped necrosis (Rose Kamau, MoA Kenya)
A field heavily infested by blackrot in Nakuru North (Rose Kamau, MoA Kenya)

Factsheets.Title: Black rot on cabbage- uozo mweusi wa kabichi

Authors.Surname: Maina Gekone (MOALF), Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Rose Kamau (MOALF), Edward Okonjo (Dudutech), Hannah Oduor (MOALF), Martha Kariuki (MOALF)i, Rahab Magotii (KALRO), Cyrus Njoroge (MoALF)

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant varieties e.g. Ruiru 11 or Batian
- Prune properly after harvest to maintain open penetration and improve aeration
- Remove old stems and thin out branches as the old stems are more susceptible than young ones
- Change the crop cycle after every 7 years
- Do a pre-rain preventive spray before the short and long rain seasons. (see yellow direct control)

- During wet, cold and humid conditions inspect for: - Brown black sunken spots on berries - Lesions on young berry stalk that shed off - Visible pink spore masses on lesions - Black berries
- Apply direct control immediately after noting signs of disease

- Pluck off diseased berries, collect in a container and destroy by burning or burying
- Cut back the affected plants and graft gradually using resistant varieties like Ruiru 11 or Batian

- When using a pesticide always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains
- WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray using Copper oxychloride based products such as Kocide, Funguran, Cobox 50WP at 50g/20L in water). General Restrictions: Spray interval 35 days in dry weather or 60 days in extremely dry weather; WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); PHI 7 days; FRAC Code M1
- Copper Oxide + Dithianon (110 g + 30 g)/20 L in water (Such as Cobox 50 WP and Delan 500SC). General Restrictions: In very wet weather and during berry expansion stage, it is very important to have a tank mix of copper oxide + dithianon; Spray interval 14 days during wet weather; Copper Oxide: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); Dithianon: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); PHI 7 days; FRAC Code M1

Images.Caption: Green coffee berries with disease (Rose Kamau, MoA)
Infected berries (Rose Kamau, MoA)

Authors.Surname: Nancy Murage (Ministry of Agriculture – District Crops Development Officer), Dora Kilalo Dr. (Nairobi University), Alfayo Ombuya (KEPHIS), Willis Ochilo (CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Prune and remove old branches and leaves so as to enhance aeration
- Avoid planting host plants such as avocados, guavas, pineapples, citrus, etc.as wind breaks
- Improve shade by sparsely planting shade crops such as Graveillia spp., Leucena spp., or Macadamia spp. to encourage natural enemies

- Scout immediately after transplanting and later, on a weekly basis
- Inspect for presence of shiny pale-green insects on the green wood and leaves (underside) especially along main leaf vein and near tips of green shoots
- Institute control measures when 10 or more leaves are infested with one or more scales

- Spray with mineral oils at 200 mls per 20 lts of water
- Spray with soapy solution (potassium soaps). Add 10-15 tablespoons full of liquid soap in 20 lt bucket of water and spray.
- Introduce natural enemies such as Cryptolaemus montrouzieri and Verticillium lecanii to reduce population of scales in the ecosystem

- Wear protective clothing when handling chemicals
- Follow instruction on the product label such as dosage, pre-harvest interval and appropriate time of application
- Spray only on the affected plants
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Apply with a brush at the base of the stem (1 foot from the base) a 15 cm wide band of a deltamethrin based product such as Decis 2.5 EC, Atom 2.5EC etc at the rate of 10-15mls/20L of water mixed with 15gms of Methylene blue which acts as a marker Mode of action: pyrethroid with contact and residual activity. General Restrictions: WHO II (Moderately hazardous); PHI 3 days; Toxic to aquatic organisms; High risk to bees
- Alternatively use Chlorpyrifos based products such as Dusbarn 4EC at 50-100ml/20L of water, Bullet 48EC at 40mls/20L of water etc. Add 15g Methylene blue as a marker Mode of action: Organophosphate. General Restrictions: WHO II (Moderately hazardous); Toxic to aquatic organisms, bees and livestock; PHI 14 days; Dangerous to some beneficial insects

Images.Caption: Green scales on leaf (United States National Collection of Scale Insects Photographs Archive, USDA ARS, Bugwood.org)
Scales on Coffee stem, note the presence of ants. (Teresia Kodwaran, West Pokot County)

Authors.Surname: Kagai K.K (MOA), Oyoo J.(KALRO), Gachini G.N. (KALRO) and Otipa M (KALRO), Judith Oyoo (KALRO), Peninah Munyao (MOALF) and Wilson Nabakwe (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid burning of crop residue in the cropping area
- Incorporate organic materials such as compost manure (400kg/acre) in the soil to avoid poor drainage or cracking of the soil when dry
- Construct drainage canals to avoid water logging on the farm
- Leave the farm fallow for at least 1 season
- Always test your soils for iron levels and pH, 1-2 months before planting
- Carry out yearly monitoring of soil PH. If it is above 7 take action

- Look for: yellowing and interveinal chlorosis on new emerging leaves of the plant with old leaves still green. stunted chlorotic tomato plants. Start direct control when you notice 1-2 new leaves are showing bright yellow colour.

- Use commercial organic fertilizer Yad bio-vitalizer (contains 15637ppm) at a rate of 300kg/acre(750 kg/ha)
- Incorporate organic materials such as Tithonia leaves and soft branches, compost or farmyard others in soil at planting at the rate of 0.5 kg/m2 (2 tons/acre)

- Apply inorganic fertilizers (iron sulphate, Mavuno, YaraMila or cereal) during planting at recommended rates after soil testing. Spray foliar feeds (Iron sulphate, Bayfolan, Wuxal) as per instructions and repeat after 14 days if iron deficiency is severe. General Restrictions: Always wear protective clothing when applying fertilizers. Always follow instructions on the label such as dosage, timing of application, maximum number of applications and protective clothing. Dispose excess fertilizer properly to avoid aquatic contamination. Store mineral fertilizers at dry conditions and separate from pesticides

The old leaves are green while and the younger leaves are bright yellow (Source:biology.clemson.edu)
Advance stages of chlorosis in tomatoes (Source:www.yara.us)

Authors.Surname: Gekone J. Maina (MoA), MaryLucy Oronje (CABI), Cyrus Njoroge (MoA), Dora Kilalo (UON)

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant varieties e.g. Rio grande, Tengeru and Meru.
- Transplant disease-free seedlings.
- Rotate tomatoes with crops like beans, maize, cowpeas, onions, sweet potatoes and carrots.
- Do not plant tomatoes next to an already infected field)
- Disinfect all cleaning tools in Sodium Hypochlorite (Jik) at a rate of 5mls in 1litre of water before re-using
- Stake and prune tall varieties for aeration to reduce chances of developing a micro-climate for disease causing agents
- Avoid planting during wet and cool periods because such conditions favour development of disease

- Scout on a daily basis for brown uneven patches on leaves and stems that eventually dry up and die
- Take action when one plant shows symptoms of the disease

- Remove old crop residues and infected plants and destroy by burning
- Use dry mulch to avoid spread of disease splashing

- Follow pesticide label instructions
- Ensure you use protective clothing when spraying
- Do not empty into water drains
- Always use products registered by PCPB

- Mancozeb such as (Oshothane at the rate of 50g/20l of water Derazeb 80 WP at the rate of 40-80g/20l water). General Restrictions: WHO class U (unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use); PHI 7 days
- Copper oxychloride such as cobox WP at the rate of 40-80g per 20l . General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous) ; PHI 7 days
- Metalaxyl at a rate of 50gms/20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous); MRLS 0.5mg/kg1

Images.Caption: Brown patches on infected leaves (photo: E. Boa, CABI)
Brown patches on infected stem and branches (photo: E. Boa, CABI)

Authors.Surname: Miriam Otipa (KARLO),  Peter M. Kodwaran (MOALF), Irene Mwendandu (MoALF), Nancy Murage (MoALF), Philip Wendot (UoN), Paul Kiige (MOALF), Miriam Otipa (KARLO).

Sections.Value:
- Practice crop rotation with non-host plants such as maize, sorghum or millet
- Conserve natural enemies such as parasitic wasps and ladybird beetles by providing hedge rows of flowering plants around the farm
- Avoid using broad spectrum insecticides early in the cropping season to preserve natural enemies
- Do not plant a new crop next to a previously infected crop
- Use a Tephrosia hedge to repel leaf miners from the crop
- Apply mulch on the ground to prevent pupae getting to the soil for further development

- Examine the foliage for signs of tunnelling or mining
- Examine the foliage for stippling damage symptoms caused by the act of laying / ovipositing eggs
- Use yellow sticky traps to monitor for adults
- Look out for small black and yellow flies near the crop or on the leaves
- Look for necrotic leaf tissue, shrivelling and defoliation of heavily infested crop
- Look for sunburned fruits as a result of defoliation
- Look out for dead young plants under heavy infestation

- Rogue the affected seedlings in nursery or defoliate the affected leaves. Dispose by burying 30 cm deep/burning to kill larvae
- Destroy leaf miner pupae and crop residue by deep tilling soon after harvest, soil solarisation and flooding
- Hand pick and destroy mined leaves especially in low infestation and those with the larvae still in the tunnel
- Use a yellow basin half filled with water/ yellow sticky trap to attract and kill adult leaf miners
- Spray neem (azadirachtin) at a rate of 50ml in 20 litres of water

- Read and follow instructions on the label.
- Dispose properly to avoid aquatic contamination

- Spray abamectin insecticides e.g Dynamec or Abalone 18 EC at a rate of 10ml in 20 litres of water. Translaminar properties; limited systemic activity as well as contact and stomach action. IRAC 6. General Restrictions: Not classified by WHO. PHI 7 days. MRL 0.02
- Spray bifenthrin e.g Brigade EC at a rate of 20ml in 20 litres of water. Non-systemic with contact stomach action. Pyrethroid; IRAC 3A. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). PHI 3 days. MRL 1.0 mg/Kg
- Drench with imidacloprid e.g Confidor 010 UL at a rate of 10ml in 20 litres of water. Neonicitinoid; IRAC 4A. Systemic insecticide with translaminar activity and with contact and stomach action. General Restrictions: WHO Class II, MRL 0.5 mg/Kg, Spray early morning or late evening to avoid harming bees
