Leaf miner damage by maggots in leaf (A.M. Varela)
Leafminer pupae (Merle Shepard et al, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Stephen Kiritai, K.  Kagai and Benson Ngigi (MOALF), Wilson Nabakwe (MOALF), Peninah Munyao (MOALF) and Judith Oyoo (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Practice crop rotation with non-host plants such as maize, sorghum or millet
- Conserve natural enemies such as parasitic wasps and ladybird beetles by providing hedge rows of flowering plants around the farm
- Remove plant debris so that they are not a reservoir of the pest
- Plant Tephrosia hedge round the farm to repel leaf miners from the crop
- Apply mulch on the ground to prevent pupae getting to the soil for further development

- Scout for small yellow and black flies hovering around the crop
- Use yellow sticky traps to trap adults
- Check on seedlings in the nursery for tunnels and oviposition marks before transplanting in the field
- Look for white puncture marks, shivelling , yellowing and tunnels or irregular mines on leaves caused by adult laying eggs on the leaves
- Start direct control when high infestation of over 30% of leaf surface is observed

- Uproot the affected seedling in nursery, pluck the affected leaves and bury 1m deep or burn
- Use a yellow basin half filled with water/ yellow sticky trap to attract and kill adult leaf miners
- Spray neem based biopesticides (Azadirachtin eg Neemark EC, Neemaj Super -3000 and Neemroc EC) at the recommended rates

- Spray early morning or late evening to avoid harming bees
- Read and follow instructions on the label
- Dispose properly to avoid aquatic contamination

- Spray abamectin (eg Abalone 18EC, Agrimec 18EC,Amazing top 20g/kg +Acetamiprid 80g/kg, Dynamec) at the recommended rates. Translaminar properties; limited systemic activity as well as contact and stomach action. IRAC 6. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (moderately hazardous). PHI 7 days
- Spray bifenthrin at a rate of 5ml in 20 litres of water. Non-systemic with contact stomach action. Pyrethroid; IRAC 3A. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). PHI 3 days. MRL-0.2
- Drench with imidacloprid ()at the recommended rates. Neonicotinoid, IRAC 4A. Systemic insecticide with translaminar activity and with contact and stomach action. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous)

Images.Caption: Leaf with leaf miner (A.M. Varela, icipe)
Leaf miner adult (Central Science Laboratory, Harpenden Archive, British Crown, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Stephen Kiritai (MOA), Kenneth Kagai (MoA), Benson Ngigi (MoA), Margaret Mulaa (CABI), Edward Okonjo (Dudutech), Hannah Oduor (MOALF), Martha Kariuki (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid planting in areas with a history of head smut because the spores survive in the soil for a long time
- Plough deep to bury surviving spores
- Plant clean and disease-free maize seeds because the disease can be seed borne
- Plant resistant/tolerant varieties e.g. KH500-21A and WH699
- Plant early at the onset of the rains to encourage crop establishment
- Avoid feeding livestock with infected materials because it can be transmitted through manure
- Use recommended rates of nitrogen fertilizer (100kg calcium ammonia nitrate) per acre. The disease is more severe in unfertile soils

- Begin monitoring just before tasselling because plants are infected systemically and the disease only becomes visible at flowering or ear formation
- Look for: Abnormal/ malformed tassels before the spores open. Masses of black spores in the tassels and ears
- Take action as soon as one infected plant is observed

- Remove plants infected with smut
- Destroy the infected plants by burning or burying away from the maize farm

- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into water drains.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides by PCPB

- In areas with high incidence buy treated certified seed or treat seed with one of the following: General Restrictions: Read label carefully and follow instructions. WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). Do not graze or feed livestock on treated crops for 6 weeks. Do not use treated seed for food or feed. Use gloves and masks when treating seed
- Tebuconazole (3g per kg seed) e.g Raxil FS 025. Systemic. FRAC Code 3. General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous). Do not graze or feed livestock on treated crops for 6 weeks. Do not use treated seed for food or feed. Use gloves and masks when treating seed. MRL 0.1mg/kg(Sweet corn). MRL0.01mg/kg(Maize)
- Carboxin e.g Anchor 200 FS (1.5g per kg seed). Systemic. FRAC Code 7

Images.Caption: Maize head smut (R. L. Croissat, Colorado state University, Bugwood)

Authors.Surname: Oyoo J (KARI), Otipa, M (KARI), Gachini G.N.(KARI) and Kagai K.K. (MOALF), Miriam Otipa (KARI)

Sections.Value:
- Test your soil for nitrogen levels 1-2 months before planting.
- Practice soil conservation and carry out cultural practises to prevent erosion.
- Apply lime and manure to improve water holding capacity and minimize leaching of nitrogen.
- Keep the field weed-free to reduce nutrient competition
- Rotate and intercrop with leguminous nitrogen-fixing crops e.g. beans, cowpeas, soya bean, etc.
- Plant early to take advantage of the nitrogen flush
- Apply compost or mulch to preserve microorganisms and other useful organisms that assist in nitrogen cycling
- Use nitrogen-fixing agroforestry such as Leucaena, Calliandra, Sesbania spp. and alley crops with deep roots to help intercept leached Nitrogen
- Plant varieties that utilize N more efficiently such as KDH4, KDH5, KDH6, WH003 (0-1000 masl), WS102 and WH002 (0-1200 masl)

- Test soil for N levels yearly
- Look out for affected plants in the field with: Yellow colouration in V shaped pattern from the stem which progresses from the leaf end to the stem. Yellow colouration that progresses from the lower to upper leaves. Stunted crops showing chlorotic symptoms. They may occur in patches or in the whole field
- Take action when the V shaped yellow colouration appears on the leaf

- Use bio-slurry from biogas digesters and from animal sheds at the rate of 1 litre/square metre (4000L/acre)
- Use organic fertilizer (eg compost, farm yard manure) at the rate of 4 tons per acre
- Use Yad bio-vitalizer organic fertilizer at a rate of 750 kg/ha
- Leave the farm fallow for at least 1 season
- Incorporate Tithonia diversifolia in soil at a rate of (2 tons/acre)

- Apply inorganic basal fertilizer with N during planting as recommended after soil testing (DAP, NPK, Mavuno, YaraMila cereal). General Restrictions: Use rates recommended after soil testing. When applying fertilizers always wear protective clothing. Excessive use can lead to eutrophication in water bodies affecting aquatic animals. Inappropriate application can lead to undesired changes in soil pH and scorching of the plant
- Top dress with N fertilizer in 2 splits per crop at knee high and flowering (CAN, AS, Urea, NPK)

Images.Caption: Chlorotic symptoms on lower leaves of maize (Photo: Dr Prakash Kumar, in Nutrient Deficiencies of Field Crops: Guide to Diagnosis and Management, CABI UK”
Nitrogen deficient maize plant. (Photo: Dr Prakash Kumar, in Nutrient Deficiencies of Field Crops: Guide to Diagnosis and Management, CABI UK”

Authors.Surname: Peter M. Kodwaran, Irene Mwendandu, Nancy Murage (MOALF), Margaret Mulaa and Dora Kilalo

Sections.Value:
- Practice a three year rotation with non-host plants such as millet and sorghum
- Plant crop in areas with a temperature range of 18-30°C,
- Avoid planting during wet conditions which favour disease development
- Plant tolerant varieties such as, Bombay Red, Red Creole or Red Comet F1
- Plant using certified seeds from reliable stockists
- During land preparation remove weeds especially those of the Allium family such as wild onion

- Look out for: Small white lesions on the leaves or stalks developing into elliptical (Oval) purplish areas. Wilting of the leaves leading to death. Yellowed and collapsed leaves 3-4 weeks after attack. Yellow to reddish watery rot at the neck of the bulb
- Start remedial measures immediately after the first signs appear.

- Remove infected plants parts and dispose by burning
- Stop irrigating the crop as harvest time approaches
- Sort and cure the bulbs to separate infected and the non-infected onions. Store in dry aerated stores

- When using a pesticide (even a botanical home-brew), always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Routinely spray with Mancozeb based products such as Dithane M45 WP, Sancozeb 80wp at the rate of 50g in 20L of water. FRAC Code M3. General Restrictions: WHO class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). Repeat spray after every 14 days. 3-4 sprays are adequate per season. PHI 7 days
- Propineb 70%+Cymoxanil 6% based products such as Milraz WP 76 at a rate of 40-50ml in 20L). FRAC Code M3 . General Restrictions: Propineb: WHO class U (Unlikely to cause harm in normal use). Cymoxanil: WHO class III (Slightly hazardous). PHI 7 days. Repeat spray after every 14 days.3-4 sprays are adequate per season

Images.Caption: Sunken spots on the leaves. (Photo: Howard F. Schwartz, Colorado State University, Bugwood.org)
Purple sunken  spots on affected crop (Photo: Howard F. Schwartz, Colorado State University, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Kagai K. K. (MOALF), Oyoo J. (KALRO), Otipa M. (KALRO) and Gachini G. N. (KALRO), Wilson Nabakwe (MOALF), Esther W. Macharia (KALRO), Judith Oyoo (KALRO ) and Peninah () Munyao (MOALF) and  Otipa M. (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Always test your soil for potassium levels 1-2 months before planting.
- Practice soil conservation measures (construction of fanya juu terraces and gabions, use of cover crops, mulching and drip irrigation) to prevent erosion of top soil that is rich in soil organic matter and nutrients
- Improve water holding capacity in the field by application of lime and manure to minimize leaching of potassium
- Avoid burning crop residue on the land after harvest
- Use organic manures such as Farm Yard Manure, compost or plant residues at planting at the rate 400kg/acre
- Remove weeds from the crop area to reduce competition for nutrients
- Lime the soil after soil test recommendation at least 2 weeks before planting/transplanting

- Look for: Young emerging leaves which are blue green in colour or bronze with yellow and brown margins. Curling leaves with inter-veinal scorching and necrosis. Fruits ripening unevenly and may have green patches near the stock and have a white hard core. Plants with woody stems.
- Initiate direct control when the colour of the leaves change to blue-green or bronze.

- Apply wood ash at 1kg per 15 m2 ( 270 kg/acre) on noticing the symptoms
- Apply banana peels processed or raw when symptoms are seen
- Apply sea weed extract( eg “Nhance“) as per instructions on the package )
- Incorporate leaves, soft branches and flowers of Tithonia diversifolia in soil at a rate of 2 tons/acre or 0.5 kg/m2 to provide NPK 10:1:10.
- Incorporate organic fertilizer, Yad Bio-vitalizer (1.9% N, 0.8% P and 4.9% K) at the rate of 300kg/acre at planting

- Apply muriate of potash, potassium nitrate, N:P:K or Mavuno fertilizers as per soil test recommendations. Spray Bayfolan plus 11-8-5 from the third week , every 2 weeks till fruit set. Apply YaraMila such as 16-16-16 or 15-15-15 at a rate of 25g/m2 at transplanting and at flowering. General Restrictions: Always wear protective clothing when applying fertilizers. Always follow instructions on the label such as dosage, timing of application and maximum number of applications. Dispose excess fertilizer to avoid aquatic contamination as recommended by PCPB. Always store mineral fertilizers at dry conditions and separate from pesticides

Images.Caption: Leaves turn  blue green in colour (Source:Southbournegardens.com)
Marginal  death of tissue along the leaf edge of the older leaves (Photo by: Epstein and Bloom 2004)

Authors.Surname: Nancy W. Murage (MOA), Peter M.Kodwaran (MOA), Irene Mwendandu (MOA), Dora Kilalo (UON), Edward Okonjo (Dudutech), Hannah Oduor (MOALF), Martha Kariuki (MOALF), Pauline Murithi (MOALF) & Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Do not establish papaya crop in high humidity areas with temperatures below 24°C
- Plant in rows parallel to prevailing wind and avoid overcrowding to increase air movement in the canopy
- Avoid overhead irrigation to reduce humidity which promotes disease spread
- Avoid intercropping with susceptible crops such as cucumber or pumpkin

- Look out for:
- Water soaked spots with white powdery patches mainly along the leaf veins, leaf petioles, flower pedicels, and at peduncles on the stem, on lower and upper sides of the leaves
- Signs of necrotic and scotched leaves
- Circular white patches on the surface of fruits
- Signs of leaf defoliation
- Take action when disease symptoms are observed on one plant

- Collect and dispose of any fallen leaves by burying or burning
- Do not use the collected leaves for composting
- Spray using baking powder, neem extracts and white mineral oil plus soap solution are alternatives for control
- Water the crop early in the day at the root zone

- Read the label and follow manufacturer’s instructions carefully before use
- When using a pesticide always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains
- WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Dust with Sulphur 80%w/w at a rate of 30g/10ltrs water, e.g Thiovit Jet, Cosavet DF, Flosul Plus, Wetsulf WP; FRAC code M2. General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous); Apply at 15 days intervals
- Spray with Triadimefon at a rate of 40gm/20ltrs water 10-14 day intervals, e.g.Bayleton WP 25, Edimefon 25 WP; FRAC code 3 . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); PHI 14 days

Images.Caption: (Photo by: Scot Nelson, Flickr)
White Powdery spots on papaya leaves (A. M. Varela, icipe)

Sections.Value:
- Remove and burn or bury all crop residues at the end of the growing season
- Practice intercropping with sorghum or maize
- Avoid crop rotation with host plants (i.e. Phaseolus and Vigna spp.)
- Encourage natural enemies that feed on cocoons, larvae and adults such as robber flies, damsel bugs, assassin bugs, centipedes and ground beetles by reducing chemical use

- The striped bean weevil is not consider a major field pest, but if you had weevil damage in the previous year, monitor weekly
- Adults or grubs, or signs of their presence:
• Grubs are C-shaped, white, 10 mm long and do not have legs. They bore and feed inside the stem causing cankerous swellings or galls
• Adults are 10-15 mm long, dark brown with white/yellow stripes and will chew the leaves
• Pupae are attached to the plant by an earthen cell or enclosed in the swollen stem
• Affected plants show stunted growth, lodging and may eventually die
• During harvesting, stems break easily

- Collect adult weevils manually and destroy them
- Remove and burn or bury infected plants

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult A. leucogrammus (A.M. Varela, icipe)
Damaged plant showing a larva inside of the stem (A.M. Varela, icipe)

Authors.Surname: Miriam Otipa (KARI), Eunice K. Ringera (KEPHIS), Margaret Mulaa (CABI), MaryLucy Oronje (CABI), Esther macharia  (KALRO), Boniface N. Ndung’u (MOA)

Sections.Value:
- Remove or deep plough to incorporate previous crop residue in the soil to kill thrips.
- Plant tolerant varieties (e.g Paulista)
- Practice soil solarisation before planting to kill the pupa.
- Plant in well prepared fertile seedbed to promote crop vigour
- Plant barriers of Mexican marigold followed by sunflower. (Mexican marigold attracts thrips from beans. Sunflower hosts Orius spp. which feeds on thrips)
- Intercrop with onion, garlic, spider plant or coriander to repel the thrips
- Preserve natural enemies such as lady bird beetles, Orius, hover flies and Aphidius to help manage thrips.
- Keep the fields free of weeds and alternative hosts such as wild mustards

- Randomly check for thrip damage at the growing tips of the plants before flowering stage
- Look for thrips early in the morning before sunrise (i.e. before 9.00am) since they tend to hide inside the flowers or underneath the leaves in high temperatures
- Use blue sticky traps to capture adults
- Shake the flowers on a white piece of paper to check for presence of adult thrips
- Examine leaves for larvae (silvery appearance of the leaves) to act early
- Take action when you notice at least 3 thrips per plant

- Place blue sticky traps above the vegetative parts of the plants to kill/ reduce their numbers
- Spray with Azadirachtin based products such as Achook EC, Nemros etc. at 20ml/20L

- Good spray coverage is essential as thrips hide underneath the flowers and leaves;
- Use recommended rates of insecticides and rotate between chemicals to prevent resistance build-up;
- Apply chemicals early in the mornings or late in the evenings and NEVER on sunny weather to prevent chemical evaporations and thus losses;
- Apply insecticides at 50% flowering on the crop; then follow alternating with botanicals after every 8 days to avoid chemical residues on the harvested beans;
- Observe Pre-Harvest Interval (PHI) as indicated on the product label; Wear protective clothing when handling chemicals

- Spray with Imidacloprid based products such as Confidor 200SL, Imaxi 200SC, TATA MIDA 200SL etc. at a rate of 10mls/20L of water; Apply as seed dressing; Mode of action: Neonicotinoid. Systemic insecticide with translaminar activity and with contact and stomach action. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); PHI 3 days
- Spray with Deltamethrin based products such as Atom 2.5EC, Decis 2.5EC, Farm-X etc. at a rate 10ml-15ml/20L of water. Spray after flowering; Mode of Action: Pyrethroid. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); PHI 1 day
- Spray with Lambda Cyhalothrin (such as Karate 2.5 % WG at 20gms/20L of water, Tata Umeme 2.5 EC at 15-20ml/20L of water etc; Mode of Action: Pyrethroids. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); PHI 3 days

Images.Caption: Adult female thrip (University of California)
Silvery area caused by Thrip damage on french bean podge (A.M. Varela, ICIPE)
Adult thrips on bean flower (Ko Ko Maung, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Martha Kariuki(MOALF),Wilson nabakwe(MoA), Samuel Mburu (MOALF, Dr. Dora Kilalo (UON) Kenya Agricultural Research Institute, P.O.Box 14733-00800, Nairobi, Kenya Samuel Mburu (MOALF) and Eunice Sakong (MOALF).

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant varieties e.g. Eagle 10 from KALRO- Njoro.
- Plant early maturing varieties e.g. NGAMIA, DUMA, KENYA PAKA
- Use certified seed from reliable sources.
- Observe field hygiene by removing residual from previous crop.
- Practice crop rotation with crops that are not in the grass family such as beans, cucurbits, pigeon peas
- Avoid walking through the field during the wet season to prevent disease spread from one plant to the other.
- Avoid planting new wheat crop next to an infected or old wheat field.

- Look for elongated reddish brown spores mainly on stem and leaf
- Inspect the wheat field weekly and consider direct control as soon as 5-10% lower leaf area is affected.

- Use barberry which reduces the genetic variation in the fungal population by eliminating the sexual cycle.
- Remove and burying infected plant materials and below 50 cm in the ground.
- Start working from the healthy part of the field before moving to the infected part

- When using a pesticide always wear personal protective equipment.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).

- Azoxystrobin 200g/L + cyproconazole 80g/L e.g. amistar xtra 280 SC at the rate of 160ml/20liters of water. General Restrictions: PHI 21 days. Azoxystrobin WHO class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use) and cyproconazole WHO class II (moderately hazardous).
- Propiconazole e.g Propimax 25 EC (rate of 58 ml per acre for low infection and 114 ml per acre in high infection) or Stratego 250 EC at 200ml per acre . General Restrictions: PropiconazoleWHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). PHI 28 days, REI 21-28 days. Do not allow livestock to graze within the treated area for 7 days after spraying.

Images.Caption: Stem rust (photo by Idah Paul, Small Grain Institute, Bugwood.org)
Wheat infected with rust  (photo: Donald Groth, Louisiana State University AgCenter, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Miriam Otipa (KARI), Rose Kamau (MOA), Maina Gekone (MOA), Nancy Murage (MoA), Dora Kilalo Dr (Nairobi University), Alfayo Ombuya (KEPHIS), Willis Ochilo (CABI), Eunice Ringera (KEPHIS), Margaret Mulaa (CABI), Mary Lucy Oronje (CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Carry out soil testing to determine the presence of bacterial wilt before planting
- Avoid planting crop in infested soil
- Rotate with non-solanacea plants e.g. maize, beans, garden peas, cabbage, and sweet potatoes to reduce the bacterial inoculum
- Plant tolerant and certified varieties if available.
- Avoid planting in low wet areas that are prone to run-off
- Destroy alternative hosts of Solanaceae family growing near the tomato crop, such as night shades and Irish potato
- Clean all farm implements before moving from one field to the next

- Begin scouting for presence of bacterial wilt symptoms throughout the growing crop cycle
- Look out for rapid wilting of the entire plant without yellowing
- Look out for dropping of vegetative parts of the entire plant. Infected plants are still green but have lost turbidity even after watering
- Cut the stem of the affected plant and check for a darkened water soaked appearance
- Cut the affected stem place in a glass of water and check for a milky slimy ooze to confirm presence of bacterial wilt
- Initiate disease control immediately after one plant is affected

- Uproot and destroy by burning and burying all infected plants.
- Diseased plants should be carried away in a container to avoid spilling the affected soil
- Apply wood ash in the affected holes after uprooting plants

- When using a pesticide always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains
- WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Bacterial diseases have no known cure. However the use of Copper based fungicides have been found to suppress further spread of the disease in the field. The following fungicides can be used to minimize bacterial infection in Tomato (copper oxychloride or copper hydroxide at 60gm/20 of water) e.g Amicop 50WP, Cobox 50WP, Cuprocaffaro Micro 37.5 WG Kocide etc). General Restrictions: WHO II (Moderately hazardous) PHI 7 days FRAC code M1Toxic to aquatic organism
- Disinfect all farm implements/tools after they have been used in fields with bacterial wilt. Dipping of farm tools in a Jik solution (500ml for every 10 litres of water) for at least 5 minutes is recommended

Images.Caption: Rapidly wilting plant due to bacterial with (A. Massawe)

Authors.Surname:
Miriam Otipa (KARI), Gekone J. Maina,(Ministry of Agriculture), MaryLucy Oronje (CABI), Cyrus Njoroge (MoA), Dora Kilalo (University of Nairobi),  Edward Okonjo (Dudutech), Hannah Oduor (MOALF), Martha Kariuki (MOALF), Thomas Kwambai (KALRO), Keneth Kagai (MOAL&F) and Jacob Ndungu (MOAL&F)
P.O BOX 1433-30200, Kitale, Kenya

Sections.Value:
- Use clean planting materials
- Avoid use planting bits and suckers from areas infested with silvering thrips
- Keep the banana field free of weeds
- Cover the bunches with blue polythene bags to prevent thrips infestation
- Conserve natural enemies e.g. lacewings, ladybird beetles and predatory bugs
- Discard old pseudo-stems to avoid pest build-up
- Destroy all volunteer banana plants and old neglected plantations that can harbour the thrips
- Remove the male floral parts 8-11 days after fruit formation
- Grow a hedge around the orchard e.g. Tephrosia spp.
- Prevent micro-climate suitable for the thrips by using the appropriate spacing and stool management

- Monitor crop from flowering. Tap flowers on a white paper to detect presence of thrips
- Examine five immature (one third to half filled) bunches per hectare for thrips after every two weeks before executing any control measures
- Check for silvery or brown patches on fruit, sometimes with cracks
- Consider direct control (yellow) if the damage becomes excessive
- Remove infested flowers and foliage from the field

- WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)
- When using a pesticide always wear protective clothing
- Spray early morning or late evening to avoid harming bees
- Dispose properly to avoid aquatic contamination

- Spray Spinozad (a bacterial derivative) at a rate of 4 mls in 20 litres of water to control thrips. Spinosyn; IRAC 5. Active by contact and ingestion. General Restrictions: WHO class III (Slightly hazardous). MRL 0.7 mg/kg
- Protect the banana bunch by covering it with treated plastic bags. Dip bags in 60 ml of pyrethrin in 20 litres of water. Alpha cypermethrin (Albaz) at 5 mls in 20 Litres. IRAC 3. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). MRL 0.05 mg/kg. PHI 7 days. WHO Class II(Moderately hazardous). MRL 0.3 mg/kg PHI 3 days
- Spot spray with pyrethrin at a rate of 60 ml in 20 litres of water. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). PHI 7 days

Images.Caption: Severely affected banana bunch with rusty cracked fingers (Maina Gekone, Crops Officer, MoA, Trans-Nzoia East Kenya)
Banana silvering thrip damage on banana fruits (Photo: A. M. Varela, icipe)

Authors.Surname: Nancy Murage (MoALF), Dora Kilalo Dr. (Nairobi University), Alfayo Ombuya (KEPHIS), Willis Ochilo (CABI), Esther macharia  (KALRO), Boniface N. Ndung’u (MoALF)  Miriam Otipa(KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant tolerant variety such as Mwezi moja
- Plant at the onset of rains (bean fly numbers tend to be low during the early stages of growing season and increase with time)
- Mulch with rice straw or cut grass. Earth up the soil around the stem base to enhance adventitious root formation and tolerance to damage
- Uproot volunteer crops to break the BSM cycle
- Avoid overlapping bean crop during the rainy season (i.e. only one crop per rainy season)
- Seed dress with a insecticide (see direct control column)
- Avoid planting beans near alternative host plants such as cowpea, soybean and other leguminous crops
- Practice good field sanitation by removing crop residues

- Start scouting for presence of pest 2-3 weeks after germination by inspecting the leaves and stem base for symptoms
- Look out for: - swelling and cracking on the base of the stem - oviposition marks on the leaves - larvae and pupae in the stem base (root collar)
- Institute control measures when 5-10% of the plant population has been infested

- Use botanical insecticides such as neem: - 100 g of dried leaves in 1 litre warm water (30°C) Kept for 12 hours then filter and spray
- Uproot infested plants and destroy by burning

- Note that the larvae are inside the stems and cannot be reached by sprays. Purchase of seed dressed with pesticides that enter germinating plants can protect against bean fly. Do not use treated seed as food or feed
- Wear protective clothing when handling chemicals
- Follow instruction on the product label such as dosage, pre-harvest interval and appropriate time of application.
- Always consult with PCPB list of registered pesticides

- Diazinon based products (such as Diazol EC, Domain etc.) at a rate of 40mls/20L of water Mode of action: Organophosphate . General Restrictions: WHO Class II: Moderately hazardous PHI 14 days
- Acephate based products (such as ACE WSP, ASATAF etc.) at a rate of 10mls/20L of water Mode of action: Organophosphate. General Restrictions: WHO Class II: Moderately hazardous PHI 7 days
- Imidacloprid based products (such as Confidor 200SL, Imaxi 200SC, TATA MIDA 200SL etc.) at a rate of 10mls/20L of water Apply as seed dressing Mode of action: Neonicotinoid. General Restrictions: WHO Class II: Moderately hazardous PHI 3 days

Images.Caption: Maggots in bean plant stem (CIAT-Tanzania)
Wilted bean tap root resulting from bean stem maggots (CIAT-Tanzania)
Bean stem fly (CIAT-Tanzania)

Authors.Surname: Peter M. Kodwaran (MOALF), Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Irene Mwendandu (MOALF), Nancy Murage (MOALF), Dora Kilalo (University of Nairobi), Rahab Magotii {KALRO}, Cyrus Njoroge (MOALF),Gekone J.Maina (MOALF), Miriam Otipa (KALRO).

Sections.Value:
- Test your soil for calcium levels 1-2 months before planting
- Water regularly at least three times per week to ensure an adequate amount of moisture.
- Mulch using maize stover, wheat straw or dried grass to conserve soil moisture
- Harden seedlings for 2 weeks before transplanting

- Look for: Small water-soaked sunken spots at the blossom ends of the fruits which enlarge and darken as the fruits mature
- Carry out soil analysis annually to determine calcium levels in Certified Laboratories such as KALRO.
- Test the soil moisture by picking and pressing soil between the fingers. If the soil particles do not stick to each other, it shows the soil is dry, initiate direct control

- Boost calcium levels in the soil by adding crushed egg shells (12g of egg-shells/plant), bone meal (250g/hill) in the planting hole
- Regularly water the crop to ensure adequate moisture for steady growth
- Remove fruits that have this disorder to avoid secondary infections
- Enrich soil with organic matter or use mulch to retain moisture especially during the flowering and fruiting stage

- When applying fertilizers always wear protective clothing.
- Follow instructions on the label such as dosage, timing of application and maximum number of applications
- Dispose of excess fertilizer properly to avoid aquatic contamination

- Liming with calcium carbonate at 150 g per m2 once after every 3 years is important.
-  Top-dress with calcium ammonium nitrate (26%N) at knee high at a rate of 40kg/acre then at flowering 80kg/acre. Ensure adequate soil moisture during application.
- Spray with calcium nitrate or calcium chloride at 30g in 20 litres of water every 7-10 days until 3- 4 applications prior to on-set of symptoms when fruits are about 2cm in diameter

Images.Caption: Round –brown water-soaked spots on the Blossom end of the fruit. (Photo: CavinB, via Flickr)
Dark brown sunken spot on the blossom end of an affected crop. (Photo by Scot Nelson)

Authors.Surname: Eunice K. Ringera (KEPHIS), Margaret Mulaa (CABI), MaryLucy Oronje (CABI), Edward Okonjo (Dudutech), Hannah Oduor (MOALF), Martha Kariuki (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant varieties like Dwarf Cavendish, Giant Cavendish, Apple, Lacatan, Valery, Poyo, FHIA 17, FHIA 23.
- Avoid fields with a history of Fusarium wilt
- Use clean suckers from healthy plants or use tissue cultured materials
- Avoid movement of infected materials to uninfected sites
- Sterilize working tools by dipping them for one minute into 10% sodium hypochlorite (Jik) solution for at least 5 min.
- Before planting dip planting materials in a fungicide solution (see yellow direct control)
- Avoid runoff water from diseased areas as fungus can be spread by the water

- Continuously monitor for light yellow colouration on the lower leaves, mainly around the margins. The yellowish colouration progresses from older to younger leaves leading to wilting of the whole plant
- Cut a cross section of infected stem and check for pale yellow, dark red or black colouration. The pseudo-stem shows f brown, red or yellow ring like lines
- Look for leaves of infected plants which collapse and droop towards the pseudo-stem sometimes with the top leaf remaining upright.
- Uproot the affected banana stools in the farm, shred/cut into pieces and burn or bury.

- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)
- Keep unprotected persons, livestock and pets out of treated areas for at least 24 hours
- Allow several weeks to dissipate

- Dip stools before planting with:
- Carbendazim 10g/10litres water (Rodazim, Pearl). General Restrictions: FRAC code 1 WHO class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use) MRL 0.2 mg/kg PHI 14 days
- Trichoderma (Trianum P11.5 WP, Root Guard). General Restrictions: FRAC code 1
- Propamocarb 30-50ml in 20L (e.g. Previcur N). General Restrictions: FRAC code 28 WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use) MRL 5 mg/kg PHI 3 days

Brown red ring like lines (Rose Kamau, MoA Kenya)
Collapsed and drooping dried leaves (Thomas K. Kwambai, KALRO,  Kenya)

Factsheets.Title: Fusarium Wilt or Panama Disease on Banana

Authors.Surname: Maina Gekone (Ministry of Agriculture), Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Rose Kamau (Ministry of Agriculture), Hannah Oduor (MoALF), Martha Kariuki (MoALF), Edward Okonjo (Dudutech)

Sections.Value:
- Practice strict crop rotation for at least 2 seasons with non-cereal crops like beans, garlic, onions and vegetables
- Plant certified seeds
- Plant maize only during the long season.
- Avoid continuous planting of maize crop to stop the persistence of virus and possible vectors.
- Avoid moving plants from infected regions to non-infected regions to reduce spread of disease
- Plant early with fertilizer and manure to enhance crop nutrition and vigour
- Keep the field free from weeds which may be alternate hosts to the vectors

- Inspect the field every 3 to 4 days for: - Chlorotic mottle starting from the base of young leaves. - Necrosis of leaf margins progressing to the mid rib leading to drying of the whole leaf - Dwarfing and premature aging of plants
- Inspect the field for vectors: - Use yellow sticky traps for beetles and grasshoppers - Use blue sticky to trap thrips - Examine plants early in the mornings before 11.00 am and after 3.00 pm as thrips tend to hide underneath the leaves in high temperatures
- Act immediately when symptoms are noticed on one plant

- Spray then uproot and destroy plants with typical symptoms. (see direct control yellow) Burn or bury 1m deep
- Farmers can use the maize stalk to make the silage but should destroy all infected cobs by burning or burying 1m deep to avoid mycotoxin contamination.

- When using a pesticide always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Imidacloprid 6-10ml/20L to control maize thrips and leaf hoppers (vectors) e.g Tata Mida 200 SL; Mode of Action: neonicoteinoid; IRAC code 4A. General Restrictions: WHO II (moderately hazardous)
- Lambda-cyhalothrin 65ml/20L water to control maize thrips and leaf hoppers (vectors) e.g Duduthrin 1.7 EC; Mode of Action: pyrethroid, quick active contact and stomach action; IRAC code 3. General Restrictions: WHO II (moderately hazardous); Flammable; Apply twice in a planting season

Images.Caption: Chlorotic and mottling mosaics on maize (Mirium Otipa, KARI)
Severe necrosis on affected maize (Rose Kamau, MoA)

Factsheets.Title: Maize Lethal Necrosis Disease on Maize
ScientificNames: Sugar cane mosaic virus and Maize chlorotic mottle virus

Authors.Surname: Stephen Kiritai (MoALF), Kenneth Kagai (MoALF),  Benson Ngigi (MoALF), Margaret Mulaa (CABI), Edward Okonjo (Dudutech), Hannah Oduor (MoALF),, Martha Kariuki (MoALF)

Sections.Value:
- Plough deep to bury surviving spores
- Practice crop rotation with non-cereal plants such as cassava and sweet potatoes
- Plant clean and disease-free maize seeds because the disease is also seed borne
- Plant resistant/ tolerant varieties e.g., WH699
- Plant at the onset of the rains for good crop establishment
- Avoid feeding livestock with infected materials because the spores can be transmitted through manure
- Do not use higher rates of manure and nitrogen because disease incidence is higher in soils that contain a lot of nitrogen
- Avoid injuring roots, stems and leaves during ploughing because it creates entry point for disease
- Eliminate volunteer host plant, eg. sorghum and finger millet

- When plant reaches knee height check weekly for the presence of whitish grey tumor- like galls/ swelling on: tassels, husks, ears/kernels, stalks, leaves, prop roots
- Take action as soon as one infected plant is observed

- Cut out and destroy the gall before the smut ruptures
- Destroy infected plants by burning or burying away from the maize farm

- When using a pesticide always wear protective clothing.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains.
-  Always consult recent list of registered pesticides by (PCPB)

- Chemical control is not very effective. Seed dressing is the most effective management option with the following:
- Carboxin 15%+Thiram 13% (e.g Vitaflo 280) 1.5g per kg seed. FRAC Code 7. Thiram is a broad spectrum surface contact fungicide. General Restrictions: Carboxin: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous). Thiram: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). Do not graze or feed livestock on treated crops for 6 weeks.

Images.Caption: Maize with smut (M Mulaa, CABI)
Common smut of maize (Photo: CABI)

Authors.Surname: Martha Kariuki (MOALF), Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Samuel Mburu (MoALF), Wilson Nabakwe (MoALF), Dora Kilalo (UON),  Pauline K. Murithi (MoALF)

Sections.Value:
- Collect and destroy all scattered stones and fallen fruits. Chop them finely or bury them deeply (about 50 cm deep) before planting
- Avoid movement of fruits from areas known to have mango seed weevils to areas where young orchards, free of seed weevil, have been established
- Apply sticky bands at the upper end of tree trunks when the trees start flowering to help reducing migration of weevils to branches for egg laying

- Check every two weeks to observe adult activity and behaviour on the trees and fruits
- Inspect under rough bark, on the trunk and main leaders for adult weevils
- Inspect new flushes for feeding damage on leaves
- Look for the presence of eggs on fruit manifested by small, dark, crescent-shaped marks on the fruit skin
- Cut fruit and seeds at harvest to look for larvae
- Check for entry marks on the fruits
- Start control measures when the pest is observed
- Remove all infested fruits and debris from the field and destroy by burning or burying 50cm deep

- Note: Wear protective clothing when handling chemicals
-  Follow instruction on the product label such as dosage, pre-harvest interval and appropriate time of application

- Spray with Malathion based products e.g Marathon 50EC and Malaton 50EC at 40-50 ml in 20 litres of water. Non-systemic with contact stomach and respiratory action. Organophosphate; IRAC 1B. General Restrictions: WHO class III (Slightly hazardous). PHI 7days. Thoroughly wet the bark of the trunk by spraying
- Spray with Deltamethrin based products such as Farm-X, Atom 2.5EC, and Decis 2.5EC at 10-15 ml in 20 litres of water. Non-systemic with contact stomach action. Pyrethroid; IRAC 3A. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI 3 day. Use a maximum of 3 sprays per season
- Spray with Bifenthrin based products e.g Biferan 25EC, Seizer 80SC, Talstar at 20ml in 20 litres of water. Non-systemic with contact stomach action. Pyrethroid; IRAC 3A. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). PHI 3 days
- Spray with Bacillus thuringiensis at 5-20 grams per 20 litres of water. Bacterium, IRAC 11. Stomach poison. General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous)

Images.Caption: Adult mango seed weevil (Monique Hunziker, Biovision)
MSW larva (AM Varela, icipe)
MSW pupa (Varela, icipe)

Authors.Surname:
Miriam Otipa(KALRO); Rose Kamau(Ministry of Agriculture); Maina Gekone (MoA), Thomas Kwambai (KALRO), Keneth Kagai (MOAL&F) and Jacob Ndungu (MOAL&F)
KALRO,  P.O.Box 57811, Nairobi, Kenya

Sections.Value:
- Use clean planting materials e.g. clean suckers or tissue cultured bananas
- Use tolerant varieties e.g. FHIA 17, FHIA 23
- Apply heavy mulch with organic waste e.g. maize stover to reduce nematodes in the soil
- Clean farm tools and equipment after use to reduce movement of infested soil
- Construct soil conservation structures such as terraces and practice contour farming
- Rotate crops with legumes e.g. beans, peas and brassicas such cabbages, Kales etc. for at least 2 years. Avoid planting spinach, capsicum and eggplant during this period.
- Ensure that the field is weed free
- Before planting, solarise the soil using polythene paper (gauge 150)
- Dip suckers in hot water (50-55°C) for 20 minutes after trimming all the roots and pairing (cutting) 1 cm tissue around the corm until you get the white tissue

- Monitor for 1. Uniform yellowing or chlorosis of the lower leaves 2. Root-rotting, plant toppling and wilting of plants even if there is adequate moisture in the soil 3. Presence of small galls on the roots of the plant 4. Brown lesions and tunnels within rhizomes 5. Clumping of lateral roots on the plants
- Sample soils and test for presence of nematodes
- Initiate control measures when1-2 plants show signs of infestation

- Apply green Tithonia or Mexican marigold (Tagetes spp.) as green manure. This is antagonistic to nematodes
- Drench the stools or suckers using Azadirachtin (eg Achook EC, Neem cake, Nematon, Nimbecidine) at the rate of 600 ml/20 L. (app. 200 ml/stool of the mixture)
- Peel the outer layer of diseased corms and coat with nematicides (Azadirachtin at a rate of 600ml/20Ltrs) coated in mud or left in the sun for 14 days
- Uproot the infected plants and destroy by burning or burying (1m deep)

- When using a pesticide (even a botanical home-brew), always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Fumigate the field by using 32.7% Metam-sodium (Metam Sodium). General Restrictions: Metham-sodium should only be applied by professionals such as agents of Jaunco company limited - WHO II (Moderately hazardous) - Maximum of 3 sprays - Wear protective clothing - Follow manufacturer recommendations on pre-harvest interval of 14 days during wet weather

Images.Caption: Example of a banana nematode. (Miriam Otipa, KARI)
Toppling of severely affected plant. (Miriam Otipa, KARI)

Authors.Surname: Peter M. Kodwaran, Miriam Otipa (KARI), Irene Mwendandu, Nancy Murage ( MOA), Dora Kilalo (University of Nairobi), Eunice Sakong (MOALF), Samuel Mburu (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO).

Sections.Value:
- Rotate cowpeas with non-legumes such as maize, cabbages and pumpkins
- Remove crop residues and dispose of by burning
- Sow early and use short season varieties such as M66, K 80, KVU-27.
- Avoid close plant spacing that is less than 120cm x 30cm
- Intercrop with maize, pearl millet or sorghum to offer a non-host alternative in the field.
- Frequently weed to remove host plants such as volunteer legumes

- Look for:
• Brown spots on older pods, holes on the flowers, buds or pods
• Flower and young pod drop
• Brownish grey moths which have orange prothorax, with white stripe on anterior margins on their forewings
• Pupae which are brown in colour on the leaves, pods and soil
• Greenish larvae with a brown head and two pairs of dark spots on the back of each segment
• Signs of webbing on flowers and pods
- Take action when 5% of crop is affected

- Spray neem oil at 40ml/20L of water
- Collect infested pods and destroy the borers by crushing
- Install bird perches at 20 perches per acre.

- When using a pesticide always wear personal protective equipment.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).

- Apply Bacillus thuringiensis, e.g Biolep WP, at a rate of 25g per 20 litres of water (Stomach poison; Bacterium, IRAC 11). General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous)
- Spray deltamethrin based products e.g Farm-X, Atom 2.5EC and Decis 2.5EC at a rate of 10-15 mls in 20 litres of water,repeat aftert 7 days if problem persists (Non-systemic pesticide with contact and stomach action; Pyrethroid, IRAC 3A. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous); PHI 3 days
- Spray cypermethrin based products e.g Debush EC at the rate of 100mls/20L of water. Repeat after 10 days if problem persists; Non-systemic pesticide with contact and stomach action; Pyrethroid, IRAC 3A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous); PHI 1 day

Images.Caption: Pod borer (Ooi P. Courtesy of EcoPort, www.ecoport.org)

Authors.Surname: Nancy Murage (MOA), Dora Kilalo Dr. (Nairobi University),Miriam Otipa (KARI),  Alfayo Ombuya (KEPHIS), Willis Ochilo (CABI), Judith Oyoo (KALRO), Wilson Nabakwe (MOALF), Peninah Munyao (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid planting new crops next to an infested tomato
- Avoid continuous cropping of tomato and solanaceous plants (e.g. eggplant, capsicum and Irish potato)
- Plant tolerant varieties e.g. Rossol
- Remove residues of previous crop and alternative hosts such as weeds
- Interplant tomato with repellents such as garlic, basil or onion
- Intercrop with pigeon peas and spider plant which are host plants for predatory mites of red spider mites
- Clean stakes and twine with water and soap and dry in the sun for one week using on a new crop
- Avoid water stress. Irrigate the crop regularly and apply mulch to reduce water evaporation

- Inspect the crop regularly to determine the presence and level of infestation during the growing period
- Assess leaves on the underside of lower leaves and main vein for little yellow speckles. Check for tiny oval shaped mites about pinhead in size
- Inspect whorl leaves for spots and fine webbing of brown or silvery colour as a result of RSM feeding or and white speckling on fruits
- Take action when one plant in 20 shows signs of infestation

- Use Azadiractin (Neemark EC, Neemraj Super-3000or Neemroc EC) 3-4 times per season. Start to spray 15 days after transplanting (2.5 to 3 L per Ha)
- Spray 2% mineral oil (85 ml in 4 L of water) once every six weeks
- Use garlic oil spray (85 g fine chopped garlic soaked one day in 50 mls mineral oil plus 10 mls soap, stir and add 1 L water). Spray twice per season
- Spray Phytoseiulus persimilis, Amblyseius californicus at the recommended rates

- Note: Always wear protective clothing when handling chemicals
- Follow instruction on the product label such as dosage, pre-harvest interval and appropriate time of application
- Always dispose excess chemicals properly in designated areas
- Store chemicals in safe well ventilated stores with good security

- Sprays with Abamectin e.g Dynamec 1.8 EC and Avid 1.8 EC at recommended rates. General Restrictions: Not classified by WHO; Toxic to aquatic organisms; avoid applying near water ways; High risk to bees. Don’t apply during flowering
- Spray with Bifenthrin e.g Biferan 25EC, Seizer 80SC, Talstar at recommended rates. General Restrictions: WHO II (Moderately hazardous); PHI 3 days; Highly toxic to bees; Toxic to aquatic organisms
- Spray with Sulphur. General Restrictions: WHO III (Slightly hazardous); Broad spectrum acaricide; Sulphur is attractive to livestock hence keep livestock away
- Spray with Amitraz e.g Kilitac 20 EC and Mitac 20 EC at recommended rates. General Restrictions: WHO II (Moderately hazardous); Spray only once on the underside of the leaves especially after staking and pruning

Images.Caption: Extensive webbing on a tomato plant in a greenhouse (RSM project, ICIPE)
Adult red spider mite. (Gilles San Martin, via Flickr)

Authors.Surname: Cyrus Njoroge, Peninah Munyao (Ministry Of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries), Maureen Kuboka (Koppert Biological Systems) Tel.: +254 26291737; +254 01771088; +254 20348487, email: Njorogecyrus47@yahoo.com; munyaopeninah@gmail.com; MKuboka@koppert.co.ke.

Sections.Value:
- Provide adequate drainage in flat areas
- Keep the field dry by planting avocados 6m by 6m apart

- Look for round, sunken black/or brown spots with rotting grey centre on the fruits and leaves
- Take action when 5% of the trees are infected

- Prune trees at start of the dry season to reduce shading and the amount of diseased material on the tree and in the fields
- Remove diseased leaves and fruits from the field
- Disinfect farm implements (Jik 500ml/20L) after working from one field before proceeding to the other
- Spray with neem based product (Trilogy 70EC @ 1:100 ratio trilogy:water)

- Azoxystrobin + Difenoconazole based products e.g. Ortiva. Usually 20ml per 20 litres of water. Spray early in the morning or late in the evening to minimize pesticide drift. Avoid spraying two hours before rainfall. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (Slightly hazardous); Pre-harvest interval (p.h.i.) 14 days; max 3 sprays per season. Toxic to aquatic organisms.
- Difenoconazole based products e.g. Score. Spray early in the morning or late in the evening to minimize pesticide drift. Avoid spraying two hours before rainfall. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (Slightly hazardous); Pre-harvest interval (p.h.i.) 14 days; maximum 2 sprays per season.

Sunken black spots with rotting grey centre with on ripened avocado fruit (Photo by A. Seif, ICIPE)

Authors.Surname: Rahab Magoti (Kenya Agriculture Research Institute), Tel.: 0728599728, email: rahabmagoti@gmail.com, Eunice Sakong (Ministry of Agriculture Kenya) Tel: 0712117520, email: eunicesakong@yahoo.com, Samuel Mburu (Ministry of Agriculture Kenya) Tel: 0711247665, email: SAmbru76@yahoo.com, Miriam Otipa, Kenya Agricultural Livestock Research Organization, 0710808312, otipamj@gmail.com

Sections.Value:
- Use less susceptible varieties e.g., Tommy Atkins, Madoe, Keitt, Vandyke, Matthias, Sabine and Sabre
- Cut out dead branches, twigs and leaves and remove them from the mango orchard

- Scout for the disease weekly. On leaves and fruits look for small and irregular yellow, brown or dark brown to black lesions
- Look for brown or black spots on young flowers which wither and die
- Dip newly harvested fruits in hot water (50-55°C) for 5-10 mins to minimize anthracnose infection

- Copper Oxychloride: (Samaya Kop 50WP- 80g/20Lt water). General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (moderately hazardous). Re-entry: when the chemical spray dries up
- Azoxystrobin + Difenoconazole based products e.g. Ortiva. Usually 20ml per 20 litres of water. Spray early in the morning or late in the evening to minimize pesticide drift. Avoid spraying two hours before rainfall. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (Slightly hazardous); Pre-harvest interval (p.h.i.) 14 days; max 3 sprays per season. Toxic to aquatic organisms
- Difenoconazole based products e.g. Score. Spray early in the morning or late in the evening to minimize pesticide drift. Avoid spraying two hours before rainfall

Authors.Surname: Kenya Agriculture Research Institute, Tel.: 0728599728, email: rahabmagoti@gmail.com, Eunice Sakong (Ministry of Agriculture Kenya) Tel: 0712117520; Ministry of Agriculture Kenya, Tel: 0711247665, email: SAmbru76@yahoo.com

Sections.Value:
- Avoid injuring the plant while weeding.
- Weed frequently to remove alternate host to disease.
- Practise crop rotation with legumes, maize, onions and cabbage.
- Plant in well drained soils and avoid over watering plants.
- Keep the nursery weed free.
- Use limestone to increase soil pH to 6-7.
- Control nematodes that may injure plant roots.
- Avoid injuring roots during field operations.
- Use clean/ disinfected farm tools during field operations to prevent spread of disease.
- Use organic manure to suppress bacterial wilt pathogen.

- Daily look for sudden wilting and death of the entire plants without any yellowing or spotting of leaves.
- Look out for dropping of vegetative parts of the entire plant. Infected plants are still green but have lost turbidity even after watering.
- Take action when one plant is infected.

- Prune affected plant parts and destroy them by burning.
- Sterilize working tools with jik at a concentration of 500ml in 10lts of water Remove and destroy by burning affected plants.
- Solarise soil using transparent plastic paper for 8 weeks to destroy the bacterial inoculum in the soil.

- Use pre-plant soil disinfectant Metam Sodium 51 liquid soluble (510g/L) Rate of use @ 240-360 L/Acre. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (moderately hazardous). Re-entry period is 48 hours under field conditions and 7 days in green house.
- Spray with copper oxychloride based products (isacop 50 WP at a rate of 50-60g/ 20L water, Captan 80WP at 2kg/1000litres). General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (slightly hazardous); Don’t contaminate the environment.

Images.Caption: Wilted Eggplant affected by bacterial wilt (Photo: Dr. Wayne Nishijima, CTAHR)
Effects of bacterial wilt on eggplant (Scot Nelson, CC BY NC-SA)

Authors.Surname: Paul Kiige (MOALF), Eunice Ringera (MOALF) , Philip Wendot (UON) and Benson Masinde (MOALF), Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant certified disease-free seeds.
- Practise deep ploughing during land preparation to incorporate the diseased plant materials into the soil.
- Practise a 2-3 season crop rotation with maize, potatoes.
- Do not walk/move in bean fields when the land is wet.

- Look out for grey or brownish irregular spots which later turn brown or black and assume an angular shape on leaves and pods.
- Take action when 5% of plants with angular spots are detected in the field.
- Uproot and burn heavily infected plants to avoid spread of the pathogen.

- Spray using azoxystrobin, e.g. Ortiva at the rate of 20mls in 20 litres of water, or AMISTAR TOP 325 EC at the rate of 15 mls in 20 litres of water. General Restrictions: Who class U (unlikely to present acute hazard). Spray using azoxystrobin (Ortiva at the rate of 20mls in 20 litres of water, or AMISTAR TOP 325 EC at the rate of 15 mls in 20 litres of water)
- Spray using mancozeb based products (Farmcozeb at a rate of 50g in 20 litres of water, Melthane super at a rate of 50g in 20 litres of water. General Restrictions: WHO class U (unlikely to present acute hazard). Spray every 2-3 weeks to protect the new growths and developing pods.
- Spray triadimefon based products e.g. Bayleton at the rate of 10 grams in 20 litres of water, Ramsom 600WP at a rate of 12g/20 litres water. General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous) and PHI 14 day, MRL 0.3mg/kg. Spray twice in a growing season

Authors.Surname: Cyrus Njoroge, Peninah Munyao (Ministry Of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries), Maureen Kuboka (Koppert Biological Systems) Tel.: +254 26291737; +254 01771088; +254 20348487, email: Njorogecyrus47@yahoo.com; munyaopeninah@gmail.com; MKuboka@koppert.co.ke

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant/tolerant varieties e.g. Gloria F1
- Plant certified disease free seeds
- Establish seedbeds in soils that has never been planted to crucifers
- Avoid working in wet soil
- Control run-off water from infected areas to clean areas to avoid spreading of the fungus
- Avoid transplanting any seedlings from a nursery that shows even the slightest infection
- Disinfect farm implements in a jik solution of 500ml in 10L of water
- Practice 4 year rotation since the fungus remains in the soil for at least 3 years
- Do not compost infected plants

- Look out for light brown, sunken areas with a purplish margin on the stem near the soil line
- Check for ash grey spots mixed with tiny black spots on the leaves and stems
- Threshold: take action when at least one plant shows disease symptoms

- Uproot infected plants and burn
- Work from disease free areas before proceeding to the affected parts of the field
- Dip seedlings in bio-pesticides such as Trichoderma (Trianum-P or Trichotech) at a rate of 15g in 5L and 2.5g in 20L of water respectively as this increases the resistance of plants to stress caused by diseases and increases nutrient uptake

- Spray seedlings with Metiram Complex 80% based products (Polyram DF and many others). Usually 50g per 20 litres, but read product label. . General Restrictions: WHO class U. Pre-harvest interval (p.h.i.) 7days. Restricted; re-entry interval (r.e.i.) 1 day after spray. Maximum 2 sprays per season. Has potential for ground water contamination.
- Spray seedlings with Copper oxychloride based products (Cupracaffaro 50g/20L of Water, Cupravit). General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous).Pre-harvest interval (p.h.i.) 0 days; Restricted; re-entry interval (r.e.i.) 2 days after spray. Max 2 sprays per season. Has potential for ground water contamination

Images.Caption: Sunken brown areas on a cabbage stem (Photo by R. Wick, University of Massachusetts)
Ash grey spots mixed with tiny black spots on the leaf (Photo by Sheppard JW, EcoPort, www.ecoport.org)

Authors.Surname: Cyrus Njoroge, Peninah Munyao (Ministry Of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries), Maureen Kuboka (Koppert Biological Systems) Tel.: +254 26291737; +254 01771088; +254 20348487, email: Njorogecyrus47@yahoo.com; munyaopeninah@gmail.com; MKuboka@koppert.co.ke., Miriam Otipa KALRO-14733-00800, email otipamj@gmail.com, Esther Macharia KALRO -Njoro, machariawarau55@gmail.com

Sections.Value:
- Keep the nursery and field free of weeds that may act as alternate host to the cutworm
- Plough before transplanting during the dry spell to expose the cutworm to the natural enemies
- Remove and burn crop debris before planting

- Look out for cut and fallen transplants/ seedlings in the farm or collapsed or crippled plants at the base of a row
- Dig around the base of the cut stem about 5cm deep to find a stout soft bodied grey/black caterpillar with greasy appearance
- Use light traps to trap adult moths that are dark grey to brown with varying mottled patterns (spots) on forewings
- Consider direct control when there are more than 5 larvae in the farm

- Dig around the crippled plant to get the cutworms and mechanically kill them
- Flood the area to suffocate the larvae in the soil if you are growing kale in deep soils
- Mix equal quantities of sawdust, bran and molasses with enough water to make mixture sticky and spread around the base of the plants in the evenings
- Drench at seedling and at transplanting stage with Azadrachtin 0.03% (e.g. Nimbedicine EC), Nematech WG, a biocontrol agent (entomopathogenic nematode) to reduce infestation drastically

- Spray with Alpha-cypermethrin –based products (e.g. Tata Alpha 10 EC-5ml/20 litres water, ALBAZ 10 EC; ALFACYPER M EC; ALFAGOLD 100 EC; and many others). Follow label instructions on rates and safety. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (moderately hazardous). PHI 3 days. Apply a maximum 2 sprays per season. This class of pesticides has high risk to bees hence should be avoided and replaced with a more friendly product, III or IV. The products are toxic to aquatic organisms. Does not work well in hot weather
