Black cutworm larvae (Photo by John L. Capinera, University of Florida)
Adult cutworm moth (Photo by John L. Capinera, University of Florida)

Authors.Surname: Rahab Magoti (Kenya Agriculture Research Institute), Tel.: 0728599728, email: rahabmagoti@gmail.com, Eunice Sakong (Ministry of Agriculture Kenya) Tel: 0712117520, email: eunicesakong@yahoo.com, Samuel Mburu (Ministry of Agriculture Kenya) Tel: 0711247665, email: SAmbru76@yahoo.com

Sections.Value:
- Use certified seeds.
- Crop rotation for 3 years with maize, onions, spinach, sweet potatoes and beans. The seedbeds should be situated in areas that have not had previous cruciferous crops.
- Plant on raised beds to reduce moisture content in the root zone and provide appropriate drainage.
- Locate seedbed on well-drained soil and avoid excessive irrigation.
- Avoid field operations when it’s wet.
- Keep nursery/field weed free.
- Use clean plastic or wooden trays to raise seedlings.
- Use a low seed rate in seed beds as overcrowding of seedlings favours the disease.

- Carefully examine seedlings for lesions on the lower stem or near the soil line which results in wire stem appearance.
- Plants must be monitored throughout the cropping cycle.
- Look for weak plants showing rapid wilt and collapse followed by rotting of seedlings.
- Take action after one seedling is affected.

- Discard all seedlings with wire stem, and discoloured roots when transplanting and plants with bottom rots, head rots and root rots.
- Stop watering for a while if damping off occurs to allow soil to dry around the plants.
- Solarise seed bed soil for 8 weeks using transparent plastic paper.
- Drench with Trichoderma based products eg Trianum at 1:5 (trianum to water), Rootguard, Trichotech, Ecot.

- Spray the seedling after transplanting using either of the following fungicides: Metalaxyl+ Mancozeb (Amidil 50g/20L or Ridomil Gold- 50g/20L water). General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (moderately hazardous); PHI 14 days
- Drench using Propamocarb hydrochloride based products eg Previcur at 30-50ml/20L, Propeller at 60-120ml/20L at seedling stage and twice when crop matures. General Restrictions: WHO Class U (unlikely to present acute hazard). PHI 3-7days

Images.Caption: Damping off on a cabbage seedling (source MOA, Kenya)
Cabbage seedlings, above are healthy & below affected by damping off (Source Yates New Zealand

Authors.Surname: Paul Kiige (MOALF), Eunice Ringera (KEPHIS), Philip Wendot  (UON), Benson Masinde (MOALF), Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Rotate with non-brassicas such as onions, maize and beans for at least one season.
- Remove crop debris including weeds at least 4 weeks prior to sowing to reduce diamondback moth (DBM) population.
- Plant seedling beds away from production fields.
- Transplant only healthy seedlings free of eggs, caterpillars and pupae of the diamondback moth and other pests.
- Use insect-proof screens in case seedlings are planted in the greenhouse.
- Intercrop with tomato or chilies.

- Scout for pale yellowish green to green cigar shaped caterpillars.
- Scout for early arriving DBM and larval damage on seedlings.
- Detect DBM adults using pheromone traps.
- Scout for chewed windows or holes on leaves.
- Look out for DBM larvae which when disturbed, will rapidly wriggle their bodies back and forth.

- Use overhead irrigation which dislodges the pest from the plant surface.
- Plant trap crops such as mustard and rape at the edges of the field to reduce DBM attack.
- Crush larvae manually if noticed when numbers are few.
- Cover the crop using agronets (from KALRO-Kabete) to control attack by insect.
- Spray with NEEMROC 0.03% EC (Azadirachtin 0.03% w/w (32% neem oil) at 1L/ Acre.

- LEGACY 5% EC. Lufenuron 50g /L. General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous) Yellow colour band; REI- when spray dries; French beans: MRL 0.02mg/KG PHI-3 days; Cabbages: MRL-0.2mg/KG PHI-3 days.
- TATA UMEME 2.5 EC. Lambda-Cyhalothrin 25g/L at 15-20 ml /20L. General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous)

Images.Caption: Adult diamondback moth, Plutella xylostella (Linnaeus). (Photo: by Lyle Buss, University of Florida)
Cabbage damaged by diamondback moth (Photo: © A. M. Varela, icipe)
Larva of the diamondback moth, Plutella xylostella (Linnaeus). (Photo by Lyle Buss, University of Florida)

Authors.Surname: Cyrus Njoroge, Peninah Munyao (Ministry Of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries), Maureen Kuboka (Koppert Biological Systems) Tel.: +254 26291737; +254 01771088; +254 20348487, email: Njorogecyrus47@yahoo.com; munyaopeninah@gmail.com; MKuboka@koppert.co.ke., Miriam Otipa KALRO-14733-00800, email otipamj@gmail.com

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant varieties e.g. Crimsom sweet, Royal sweet and Palomar
- Plant certified seeds
- Use disease free transplants
- Rotate with non-cucurbits like beans, potatoes, maize for 7 – 10 years
- Maintain soil fertility (Calcium, Phosphate and Potassium deficiencies induce a higher incidence of the disease)
- Work from disease free areas before proceeding to the affected parts of the field
- Control run-off water from infected areas to clean areas to avoid spreading of the fungus
- To slow down the disease keep the soil pH between 6.5 - 7

- Scout for damping off of the seedlings
- Check for brown staining of the infected stem when cut longitudinally
- Look out for wilting in individual runners and not entire plant
- Check for greying or chlorosis of foliage during early stages of the disease
- Take action when one plant is infected

- Disinfect farm implements in a jik solution of 500ml in 10L of water
- Solarisation of the soil may be effective in killing Fusarium spores, but the soil needs to be heated for 8 weeks.
- Use of Trichoderma (e.g. Trianum-P or Trichotech) at a rate of 15g in 5L and 2.5g in 20L of water respectively increases the resistance of plants to stress caused by diseases and increases nutrient uptake

- Use Carbendazim based products like Bavastin at rate of 20g in 20L of water, P.H.I: 14 days. General Restrictions: WHO class IV (unlikely to present acute hazard), Highly toxic to aquatic organisms, Continuous use may result to resistance

Images.Caption: Brown staining of the roots and stem (Photo by Dan Egel, Purdue University)
Wilting of the leaves (Photo by X.G. Zhou & K. L. Everts)

Authors.Surname: Rahab Magoti (KALRO), Eunice Sakong (MoALF), Samuel Mburu (MoALF), Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Peninah Munyao (MoALF), Wilson Nabakwe (MoALF)

Sections.Value:
- Intercrop onions with trap crops e.g. carrots, cucurbits, kale, spider plant and flowers like carnations.
- Maintain a healthy onion crop as it will tolerate thrips.
- Avoid planting onions near an existing infested field.
- Mulch onion fields as this helps reduce thrips population.
- Use overhead irrigation where possible to reduce thrips populations.
- Remove and destroy volunteer onion plants and debris that may harbour thrips.
- Grow onions under agronet, 0.4mm mesh size to reduce infestation.

- Scout for small light greenish, sometimes grey-greenish, thin larvae when onion is at 4-5 leaf stage.
- Continue inspecting weekly especially on the underside of the leaves and the neck.
- Look for silvery leaf spots and patches and excreta of thrips visible as small black dots on leaves.
- Inspect seedlings when transplanting for any possible thrips infestation in leaf folds.
- Use yellow or blue sticky traps to monitor the adult.
- Take control measures when 1 – 2 thrips per leaf are found.

- Discard any infested seedlings during transplanting.
- Remove heavily infested plant material and burn.
- Use yellow or blue sticky traps to trap the adults.
- Apply soapy sprays (mix 5 teaspoon full of soap powder or chopped bar soap with cold water in a ten-litre bucket and stir until dissolved. Spray the solution on the infested plants whenever there are thrips).
- Spray neem based products like Neemroc EC and Nimbecidine (Azadiractin). Use 1 litre per acre (10 plastic bottle tops per 20 litres of water).
- Apply Bacillus thuringiensis var. kurstaki (e.g. Bio T Plus)

- Spray with Spinosad (tracer 480 SC) at the rate of 4ml per 20litres of water. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (slightly hazardous)
- Spray with lambda-cyhalothrin based products eg Triger 5% EC at the rate of 7ml per 20L of water; Duduthrin 1.7EC at the rate of 65mls per 20L of water; Karate 2.5 WG at the rate of 20gms/ 20liters. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (moderately hazardous). PHI 7days
- Spray with Imidacloprid containing products. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (moderately hazardous). PHI 3days

Images.Caption: Thrips at adult & larva stage (Photo: Alton N. Sparks, Jr., University of Georgia, Bugwood.org)
Onion leaf infested with thrips (Photo: Whitney Cranshaw, Colorado State University, Bugwood.org)
White to silvery patches and streaks on leaves as a result of thrips feeding injury (Photo: Diane G. Alston, Utah State University)

Authors.Surname: Paul Kiige, Eunice Ringera,(KEPHIS), Philip Wendot (UON), Benson Masinde (MOALF), Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant pawpaws in areas where there is no virus.
- Plant in isolation. Avoid planting or rotating pawpaws with squash, pumpkin, cucumber, and melons.
- Avoid mechanical injury to pawpaw trees.

- Scout for prominent mosaic and chlorosis on the leaf lamina, and water soaked oily streaks on the petioles and upper part of the trunk.
- Look out for distortion of young leaves which also results in the development of a shoestring appearance that resembles mite damage.
- Look out for dark green streaks and rings on the leaf stalks and stems.
- Scout for stunting of pawpaw trees.
- Scout for bumps and distinctive ringspot patterns consisting of concentric rings and spots or c-shaped markings.

- Early detection of infected plants and prompt removal of diseased trees can check spread.
- Use yellow coloured traps to attract and kill adult aphids.
- Spray soap solution (potassium soaps)-Add 10-15 table spoons of liquid soap in 20lt bucket and spray. Avoid powdered detergents because they can burn plant leaves.
- Spray with botanical extracts e.g. mixture of garlic, neem, red chilli pepper and soap (Take 50g mixture in 2lts of water, boil for 15 minutes, allow to cool, then spray).

- Spray Pyrethrin (75g/l) e.g. (Pyerin EC 60ml in 20 lts of water. Apply on first signs of infestation and repeat fortnightly until symptoms disappear). General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI of 1 day
- Spray with Thiamethoxam based products e.g. (Actara). Usually 4g per 20 litres of water, but read product label. Neonicotinoids group of pesticide. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (Slightly hazardous), Pre-harvest interval (PHI) 7 days; restricted, Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects

Images.Caption: Pawpaw tree infected by PRSV(Photo: www.apsnet.org/edcenter/intropp/lessons/viruses/Pages/PapayaRingspotvirus.aspx
Pawpaw fruit affected by PRSV (Photo: www.apsnet.org/edcenter/intropp/lessons/viruses/Pages/PapayaRingspotvirus.aspx)

Authors.Surname: Anne W. Kimani (UoN) Tel.: +254720 452 066, email: wangoanne@gmail.com; :Boniface N. Ndung’u (MoALVF) Tel: +254 723 377 341, email: bngaroga@yahoo.com; :Jacob Ndung’u(MoALVF); Tel: +254 724 507 901 email: ndungujac@yahoo.com

Sections.Value:
- Avoid injuring the stem while weeding
- Weed frequently to remove alternate host to the disease
- Boost the health status of the crops by using recommended fertilizers (TSP 125g / hole at planting; and CAN 125 g per plant in 2-3 splits per year as a top dress. Add manure 10-15 kg per plant per year)
- Or apply fertilizer-Yara mila at100g/hole at planting,100g after 30days and 100g thereafter in 2 splits

- Check for:
- Brown lesions or injuries on the stem
- Collapsed shoots above the wounded areas
- Dieback of the stem or branch from the tip towards the base of the plant
- Take action when one plant is infected

- Prune affected plant parts and destroy them by burning
- Sterilize working tools with jik at a concentration of 500ml in 10lts of water

- Spray with Mancozeb (Farmcozeb at a rate of 50gm/50lts water, Rovral Flo 250 C 1 litre/ hectare or Tpsin M 70g/5 litres or Bavistin 50DF 5litres/20L). General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (slightly hazardous), Pre-harvest interval (p.h.i.) 3 days, MRLs 0.2 mg/kg
- Spray with Copper oxycloride (Isacop 50 WP at a rate of 50-60g/ 20L water, Captan 80WP at 2kg/1000L). General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (slightly hazardous), Don’t contaminate the environment
- Spray with Metalaxyl-M 40g/Kg + Mancozeb 640g/Kg based products (Ridomil Gold at a rate of 50gm /20 litres of water) . General Restrictions: Metalaxl WHO class II (moderately hazardous)

Images.Caption: Passion fruit die back (Photo: M. Otipa KARI)
Passion fruit die back (Photo: M. Otipa KARI)

Authors.Surname: Stephen Kiritai (Ministry of Agriculture), Kenneth Kagai (MoALF), Benson Ngigi (MOALF), Dora Kilalo (University of Nairobi)

Sections.Value:
- Test your soil for Phosphorus levels and pH conditions 1-2 months before planting. Ensure that pH levels in the soil are appropriate to allow easy take-up of phosphorus by plants (pH 6 – 8). Avoid acidic soils
- Practice soil conservation measures to prevent erosion of top soil which is rich in soil organic matter and nutrients
- Improve water holding capacity in the field by application of soil amendments such as lime and manure
- Ensure weed-free field to reduce nutrient competition
- Look out for affected plants in the field with: Purple colouration on younger leaves. Yellowing on older leaves moving upwards

- Use bio-slurry from biogas digesters animal shed at the rate of 1 litre/square metre
- Use organic fertilizer from compost or farm yard manure at a rate of 10 tons per hectare
- Use bone meal to improve the Phosphorus levels in the soil
- Use Yad Bio-Vitalizer organic fertilizer at a rate of 750 kg/ha
- Band or spot apply phosphorus fertilisers particularly on strong phosphorus fixing soils

- Top dress with P fertilizer in 2 splits per crop at knee high and flowering. General Restrictions: Use the recommended rate of fertiliser after soil testing. When applying fertilizers always wear gloves. Avoid application of P-fertilizers close to waterways thus affecting aquatic animals. Inappropriate application of fertiliser can lead to undesired changes in soil pH and sometimes scorching of the plant

Images.Caption: P deficiency in maize  Chlorotic symptoms on lower leaves of maize (Photo: courtesy of the International Plant Nutrition Institute)
Yellow colouration in V-shaped  pattern (Photo: South Dakota State University)

Authors.Surname: Paul Kiige, Eunice Ringera (KEPHIS),Philip Wendot (UON) A, Benson Masinde (MOALF), Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant varieties such as Nerica 1, 4, 10 and 11 for upland areas; SC 213, NIBAM 108, NIBAM 109, NIBAM 110, IR-025, and N221.
- Plant early to avoid late season blast pressure.
- Flood the field as often as possible.
- Avoid excessive use of nitrogenous fertilizers.
- Destroy infested crop residue before planting.
- Practise proper water management.

- Examine plants in several locations throughout the field for the presence of leaf lesions.
- Scout for diamond-shaped elongated lesions with a gray or white center and brown or reddish brown border on the leaves, nodes, panicles and collar of the flag leaves.
- Look out for a bleaching whitish colour on the head on the lower portion of the panicle.
- Look out for a rotten panicle neck caused by a broken neck condition.
- Burn or compost diseased tissues

- Trifloxystrobin 100 g/L + and Tebuconazole 200g/L. NATIVO SC 300. Rate: 5-10ml/L. General Restrictions: Trifloxistrobin WHO class U (unlikely to present acute hazard), Tebuconazole WHO II (moderately hazardous). NATIVO SC 300: Blue colour band. MRL 2.0mg/Kg trifloxystrobin 0.2mg/Kg , PHI = 40 days. Tebuconazole, 2.0 g/Kg. MRL = 2.0mg/Kg
- Difenoconazole (Score 250 EC). Rate: 20ml in 20L. General Restrictions: PHI- 14days. WHO class II (moderately hazardous)
- Apply 20g of Benomyl 50% WP in 15l of water for seed treatment before sowing. General Restrictions: WHO class U (unlikely to present acute hazard)

Images.Caption: Symptoms of rice blast (Photo: R.K. Webster, ARS-USDA)
Rice leaves infected by blast. (Photo: IRRI)

Authors.Surname: Anne Kimani (UoN) Tel.: +254720 452 066, email: wangoanne@gmail.com; Boniface N. Ndung’u (MoALVF) Tel: +254 723 377 341, email: bngaroga@yahoo.com. Jacob Ndung’u (MoALVF) Tel: +254 724 507 901 email: ndungujac@yahoo.com, Miriam Otipa (KALRO) Tel: +254 710808312

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant/tolerant varieties e.g. Kilele F1, Prostar F1 and Tylka F1.
- Use disease and pest free seedlings by raising them in a protected nursery.
- Ensure the field and nursery are free of weeds and volunteer crops.
- Rotate with non- Solanaceae crops e.g. maize, onions. Avoid beans which are hosts of the virus.
- Remove and burn potential volunteer hosts like tomato, black night shade, pepper and beans.

- Scout for plants showing bushy appearance, stunted and upright growth. Sooty mould may appear on the produce due to honey dew secretions.
- Check for small leaves that curve upright showing strong crumpling and interveinal chlorosis.
- Look for flower abortion, small dry fruits and reduced fruit production.
- Check for whitefly adults, nymphs and eggs on the underside of the leaves.
- If there are more than 1 adult per plant in the nursery or 5 nymphs/ 10 leaflets consider direct control.

- Rogue out infected plants and bury deep.
- Use yellow sticky traps or a 2m x 75cm yellow sheet coated with Vaseline to trap whiteflies.
- Spray with 5 table spoonfuls of dish washing soap in 20 litres of water.
- Use Beauveria bassiana products to control whiteflies (e.g. Biobassiana).
- Spray Neem extract maximum of 3 times in a season (50-60 ml /20 litres water). Or use 20 – 50 g neem seed cake / litre water.
- Use Encarsia formosa products (Encartech). Minimum 2000 adult parasitic wasps/ 400ml (WHO U).

- Foliar spray with Buprofezin 400g/l based products (Apply at a rate of 20ml/20litres water). General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (slightly hazardous). PHI- 3 days, max 3 sprays per season. It is toxic to fish and aquatic invertebrates but no harm to honey bees.
- Foliar spray with Imidacloprid 700g/kg (Confidor at a rate of 5g/20litres of water). General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (moderately hazardous).
- Alpha cypermethrin 100g/ litre (Alpha kill at a rate of 5ml in 20 litres of water). General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (moderately hazardous). PHI 21 days

Images.Caption: Small upright curved leaves  showing  interveinal chlorosis. Source: Queensland Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries
Whiteflies (adults) on Tomatoes Source: Queensland, Department  of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries
Pirate bug feeding on whitefly nymphs. Source Jack Dykinga USDA

Authors.Surname: Anne W. Kimani (UoN) Tel.: +254720 452 066, email: wangoanne@gmail.com; Boniface N. Ndung’u (MoALVF) Tel: +254 723 377 341, email: bngaroga@yahoo.com; Jacob Ndung’u(MoALVF); Tel: +254 724 507 901 email: ndungujac@yahoo.com, Miriam Otipa, Kenya Agricultural Livestock Research Organization, Tel +254 710808312, otipamj@gmail.com

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant varieties e.g. new rose coco, miezi mbili and red kidney.
- Plant certified seed from certified dealers.
- Remove and burn crop debris.
- Plough deep and bury crop residues to enable breakdown of infected plant debris.
- Rotate with non leguminous crops e.g. maize, cabbages for 2 - 3 seasons.
- Ensure proper crop nutrition to keep plant vigour.
- Keep the field free of weeds and volunteer plants.
- Use furrow or drip irrigation to avoid spread of the disease when leaves are wet.
- Avoid field operations when the leaves are wet
- Disinfect plant implements when moving from one field to the other.
- Use proper spacing (50cm x 10cm) to ensure air circulation
- Intercrop beans with maize to prevent spread of the disease from one row to the other.

- Look for small angular water soaked reddish brown spots that enlarge and turn necrotic on leaves surrounded by a bright yellow halo.
- Look out for small water soaked lesions which become sunken and dark red-brown on pods.
- Check for yellow or brown spots on seeds near the hilum. Under severe infection, seeds appear shrivelled. A yellowish bacterial ooze is released from the lesions under humid conditions.

- Remove and burn infected plants.
- Practise soil solarisation to kill bacterial inoculum in the soil. Cover your soil with a transparent plastic paper for 4 weeks during hot seasons to kill the bacteria in the soil.

- Avoid introducing bacterial infections to farms because they are difficult to eradicate completely from the soil once introduced.
- WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes.

- Spray copper oxychloride WG (eg Cupro Caffaro Micro 37.5 at a rate of 50gm/20lts water and Isacop 50WP at a rate of 50-60g/20litres of water). Spray early in the morning or late in the evening to minimize pesticide drift. Avoid spraying two hours before rainfall. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). Irritant to the eyes. Re-entry: when the chemical spray dries up

Images.Caption: Bacterial blight symptom on leaf (Photo: P.H. Goodwin, CPC)
Reddish brown sunken lesions on pods. (photo: Mauritius Sugar Industry Research Institute, CPC & H.F. Schwartz)
Yellow or brown spots on  seeds. (Photo: V.R. Wallen - Agriculture Canada (CA))

Authors.Surname: Cyrus Njoroge, Peninah Munyao (MoALF), Maureen Kuboka (Koppert Biological Systems), Esther Macharia (KALRO), Boniface N. Ndung’u (MoALF), Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Conserve natural enemies e.g. by avoiding spraying broad spectrum insecticides
- Cover plants with agro nets (size 400 µm) to exclude the pest from crop
- Apply adequate manure to ensure high plant vigour
- Grow plants with repellent effects on the aphids
- Smoking once a week can prevent the pest from colonizing beans: use dry cow dung and green herb/shrub leaves to make smoke, which should be on the direction of wind to ensure full coverage of the smoke in the farm
- Plant mixed bean varieties, this can drastically prevent aphid infestation levels

- Scout for attendant ants climbing up and down bean plant. Keenly you will see the immobile aphids on the underside of leaves or stems. Sometimes the aphids have wings (these are starting to settle on the crop)
- Scout for slow moving grey to blackish insects that are normally in colonies on underside of leaves as well as on soft new shoot tips or buds.
- Look for sticky, honeydew that is covered in a black sooty mould on lower foliage
- Threshold: Examine 20 to 30 plants randomly in the field. If 2 or 3 of those plants have at least two aphid colonies institute control measures.

- Spray the infested areas of a plant with a strong jet of water to keep aphid numbers down
- Spray both sides of the leaf with soapy water (1 ml/1 l water). Spray early in the morning or evening so that the spray does not dry quickly.
- NB: Sprays should be done on the underside of leaves: invert the nozzle to ensure proper coverage
- Biocontrol products such as Aphidius spp. (which can be purchased locally in biontrol companies in Kenya)
- Apply botanical pesticides such as neem

- When using a pesticide always wear protective clothing.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval.
- Do not empty into drains; deposit containers on places constructed by MOALF for dubbing
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray with Alpha-cypermethrin –based products (ALBAZ 10 EC; ALFACYPER M EC; ALFAGOLD 100 EC; and many others). Follow label instructions on rates and safety. Spray Lambda-cyhalothrin containing products (e.g. Karate). General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (moderately hazardous). PHI 3 days. Apply a maximum 2 sprays per season. This class of pesticides has high risk to bees hence should be avoided and replaced with a more friendly product, III or IV. The products are toxic to aquatic organisms. Does not work well in hot weather.
- Apply Acetamiprid containing products e.g. AMAZING TOP 100 WDG. Spray with Thiamethoxam based products e.g. Actara. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (slightly hazardous). PHI 7 days. Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects. Avoid using product with similar mode of action for more than 3 times in a season; resistance will develop

Images.Caption: Bean aphids (Photo by Ben Sale, CC BY)
Heavy attack of black aphids on a bean plant (Photo by A.M. Varela, icipe)
Aphids on bean pod (Photo by Stephen Dalton)

Authors.Surname: Rahab Magoti (Kenya Agriculture Research Institute), Tel.: 0728599728, email: rahabmagoti@gmail.com, Eunice Sakong (Ministry of Agriculture Kenya) Tel: 0712117520, email: eunicesakong@yahoo.com, Samuel Mburu (Ministry of Agriculture Kenya) Tel: 0711247665, email: SAmbru76@yahoo.com

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant maize varieties e.g. EMB 0702 for medium altitude, MTPEH 0701, M/0702 coast region.
- Harvest early, 3 weeks after attaining physiological maturity.
- Clean and treat and/or fumigate the store using the pesticides thoroughly between harvests. (See Direct Control).
- Remove and burn infested residues before the new stock is stored.
- Immerse used sacks in boiling water to eliminate residual infestations.
- Maize should be stored while threshed.

- Look for small (4mm) beetles with a uniform dark brown to black colour roaming on grains.
- Look for exit holes on grains.
- Inspect stored grains weekly for signs of infestation.
- Look for tunnels through stored maize grain or dried cassava chips resulting in large quantities of dust.
- Consider direct control when 1 insect is noticed.

- Place sticky traps in susceptible areas in the store.
- Sun dry and sieve infested grains before packing.
- Use metal silos and or hermetic bags for storage of grains.

- When using a pesticide always wear protective equipment. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains.
- Clean grains before consumption.
- Always important to consult expert if the problem persist. Resistance development should be immediately and urgently reported to nearest Agriculture staff; Crop Health sub unit Head at KALRO HQ.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).

- Spray store surfaces well before use Pirimifos-methyl (Actellic 25 EC – 200ml/10litres of water). General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (moderately hazardous). PHI 4 days
- Dust grains with Pirimifos-methyl based products (Actellic Super 50g/90kg of maize, Malathion + permethrin (Skana Super 50g/90 kg maize) or dust Fenithrothion + fenvalerate (Sumicombi 1.8%- 30g/90kg maize). . General Restrictions: All in WHO toxicity class II (moderately hazardous).
- Spinosad (spintor dust – 50g/ 90Kg). . General Restrictions: Spinosad spintor dust in class III (slightly harzadous)

Images.Caption: Larger Grain Borer (photo: NRI/MAFF).
Exit hole on Maize grain damaged by LGB (photo: M.O.A Kenya)
Maize cob infested by LGB (photo: J. Maundu, icipe)

Authors.Surname: Cyrus Njoroge, Peninah Munyao (Ministry Of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries), Maureen Kuboka (Koppert Biological Systems) Tel.: +254 26291737; +254 01771088; +254 20348487, email: Njorogecyrus47@yahoo.com; munyaopeninah@gmail.com; MKuboka@koppert.co.ke. Miriam Otipa (Kenya Agricultural Research Institute 14733-00800, +254 710808312, Tel:  otipamj@gmail.com)

Sections.Value:
- Plant certified, tolerant/ resistant varieties, e.g. Pan 5195, PH 4, FS 650, Duma 43 and PAN 67
- Plant early in the season at the onset of rains or dry plant
- Keep the field free from weeds, particularly grass weeds
- Rotate maize with non-grass crops like potatoes, cabbages, beans, etc.
- Avoid overlap of two maize crops

- Inspect often (3 times per week)
- Scout for white to yellowish streaking on the leaves
- Check for very narrow, more or less broken streaks on both sides of the leaves running parallel along the leaves
- Check for jumping/ leaping insects
- Threshold: take action when at least one plant shows disease symptoms

- Uproot infected plants and feed to livestock or burn
- Control vectors such as leafhoppers by digging a trench between maize fields and Napier

- Note: For control of the vector, apply insecticides (but only if applied across the area by all farmers)
- When using a pesticide always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains.
- WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides.

- Spray using Alpha-cypermethrin –based products (ALBAZ 10 EC; ALFACYPER M EC; ALFAGOLD 100 EC; ALFAPOR 10% EC and many others). Usually 20-30ml per 20 litres of water, but read product label. Pyrethroid group of pesticide group. Spraying should start 1 month after planting or when leafhoppers are seen on the crop or when one plant show symptoms. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (moderately hazardous). Pre-harvest interval (p.h.i.) 3- 7days; Restricted re-entry interval (r.e.i.) 3 days after spray. 2 maximum sprays per season. High risk to bees, very toxic to aquatic organisms. Does not work well in hot weather

Images.Caption: White to yellowish streaking on the leaves (Photo by CIMMYT)
Streaking on maize (Photo by IITA)

Authors.Surname: Anne Kimani (UoN) Tel.: +254720 452 066, email: wangoanne@gmail.com; Boniface N. Ndung’u (MoALVF) Tel: +254 723 377 341, email: bngaroga@yahoo.com. Jacob Ndung’u (MoALVF) Tel: +254 724 507 901 email: ndungujac@yahoo.com, Miriam Otipa (KALRO) Tel: 254 710808312 email otipamj@gmail.com

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant varieties e.g. SC213
- Remove the infested plants at the time of up-rooting the nursery
- Apply nitrogenous fertilizers in splits to avoid nitrogenous environment that favour pest population build-up
- Plant at the same time as other farmers. Late planted crops suffer more damage from pest build-up from earlier planted crop
- Harvest crop at ground level to remove the larvae in stubble and flood the area
- Destroy rice stubbles after crop harvest because they harbour the pest
- Preserve beneficial insects by avoiding the use of toxic sprays
- Observe closed seasons to control the pest

- Scout weekly (20 days after sowing of nursery)
- Look out for egg masses on the underside the leaf
- Check for white heads at reproductive stage and dead hearts or drying of the central tiller during vegetative growth.
- Check for caterpillars boring at the base of the plant during vegetative stage and on old crop boring on upper nodes feeding towards the base
- Look for tiny holes on stems and tillers.
- When there is more than 1 moth or 1 egg mass/m2 in the nursery, 5% dead hearts or one egg mass or one moth/m2 from planting to pre-tillering and 1 egg mass or 1 moth/m2 at panicle initiation to booting, consider direct control.

- Hand pick during transplanting or in the nursery and destroy egg masses.
- Remove and burn severely infested plants/heads.
- Raise irrigation water level to submerge the eggs.
- Use light traps to control the pest.
- Control using entomopathogenic nematodes which are effective against the pest.

- Requires a systemic insecticide
- If the measures mentioned under Prevention fail, use less toxic insecticides
- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains.
- WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes.

- Spray with Imidacloprid (Confidor 70WG at a rate of 5g/20 litres water). General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class II (moderately hazardous)
- Spray with Acetamiprid (Twiga Ace 20 SI at a rate of 8mls/20ltrs of water). Apply once per season . General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous). Toxic to fish and aquatic invertebrates. Toxic to natural enemies

Images.Caption: White heads after stem borer attack (Photo: IRRI Rice knowledge bank)
Rice stem borer larvae (Photo: IRRI Rice Knowledge Bank)
Rice stem borer  moth (Photo: IRRI Rice Knowledge Bank)

Authors.Surname: Martha Kariuki (MOALF), Hannar Oduor, (MOALF), Edward Okonjo (DUDUTEC), Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant varieties e.g. Rio grande, summerset f1, zeal f1, hytec36.
- Plant certified/clean seeds.
- Rotate with non-Solanaceae crops e.g. onions, beans, maize for at least 2 seasons.
- Prepare the nursery away from an existing tomato field.
- Plant tomatoes seedlings at a spacing of 90cm*60cm to allow for good aeration.
- Stake and prune indeterminate varieties.
- Avoid overhead irrigation to avoid the spread of the disease.
- Destroy crop debris after harvest by ploughing under all crop residues and burning.

- Scout for brown circular leaf spots on the upper part of the leaves starting from the older leaves to the younger ones.
- Continue inspecting weekly, especially on the underside of the leaves.
- Check for brown to black circular rings on the fruits and premature fruit fall.
- Consider direct control when prolonged leaf wetness (85% per day) due to dew, rainfall and irrigation.

- Remove the leaves of the affected plants and bury them (1m deep) or burn.
- Use of fermented marigold.
- Spray with onion bulb extract.

- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains. WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).

- Spray Mancozeb (Oshothane, Fantic, Dithane M45) at the rate of 50ml/20l water. Spray Oshothane every 7 days and alternate with Dithane M45 to prevent development of resistance. General Restrictions: WHO class U (unlikely to cause acute harm). PHI 7 days
- Spray Copper hydroxide (Vitra40wg, Champflo) at 50g/20l of water. Start spraying when you notice brown spots on the leaves. General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous). PHI 7 days

Images.Caption: Brown circular leaf spots on upper part of leaves (Photo courtesy of Elemson University USDA)
Brown circular rings on the fruits (Photo: University of Florida)

Authors.Surname: Stephen Kiritai (MoALF), K.  Kagai (MoALF), Miriam Otipa (KALRO) and Benson Ngigi (MoALF), Dora Kilalo (University of Nairobi) Esther macharia  (KALRO), Boniface N. Ndung’u (MoALF)

Sections.Value:
- Keep the field free of weeds throughout the cropping season as they act as alternate hosts for whiteflies
- Cover plants with agro nets (size 400 µm) to exclude the whiteflies from the crop
- Plant repellent crops like coriander and Mexican marigold around the edge of the field to repel the white flies
- Plant in well prepared fertile land to promote plant vigour
- Conserve natural enemies (e.g. parasitic wasps) by avoiding chemical sprays during flowering

- For early detection, look out for whitish- brown eggs and /or whitish adults on the underside of young leaves
- Look for a cloud of over to 3-5 white insects that resettle soon after the plant is shaken
- Check for yellowing symptoms on lower leaves of the plant
- Start control measures as soon as the pests are observed on the crop

- Mount yellow sticky traps to trap adults- 4 traps/300m2 at 50cm above the ground
- Spray Azadirachtin 0.03% (50 ml/20L water) when symptoms appear
- Spray with pepper at rate of 30 chopped peppers put in 1 litre warm water. Soak for 1 day, dilute in 10 L water

- Alternate active ingredients to prevent development of resistance
- Wear protective clothing
- Spray early morning or late evening to avoid harming bees.
- Read and follow instructions on the label
- Dispose properly to avoid aquatic contamination

- Drench with imidacloprid based products e.g. Confidor 200SL, Imax 200SL,and Tata Mida 200SL at a rate of 10mls in 20 litres of water. Neonicotinoid, IRAC 4A. Systemic insecticide with translaminar activity and with contact and stomach action. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). PHI 3 days
- Spray lambda-cyhalothrin based products e.g. Karate 2.5WG at 20gms/20L of water and Duduthrin 1.7EC at 60ml/20Lof water. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). PHI 3 days. Toxic to fish and aquatic invertebrates
- Spray alpha-cypermethrin based products e.g. Bastox 100EC at 6ml/20L of water Tata Alpha 10EC at a rate of 6ml per 20 litres of water. General Restrictions: WHO Class II(Moderately hazardous), PHI 3 days

Images.Caption: Adult whiteflies (Ian Bedford, CABI)
Adult white flies on the underside of the leaf (A.M. Varela, ICIPE)

Authors.Surname: Stephen Kiritai (MOALF), Miriam Otipa (KALRO), K.  Kagai (MOALF), Benson Ngigi (MOALF), Margaret Mulaa (CABI), Paul Kiige (MOALF)and Judith Oyoo (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Use white/black inert plastic mulch 10-20 days after transplanting which attracts and kills white flies
- Use organic mulch after transplanting for irrigated crop
- Use a shade net (size 400 µm) / tunnel for 3-5 weeks while in nursery to prevent attack by white flies
- Conserve natural enemies (wasps, ladybirds) by mulching or leaving a natural hedge of flowering plants (e.g. Tithonia, Lantana) along the edges to offer them refuge
- Transplant shortly after or during the rainy season
- Plant repellent crops such as coriander or Mexican marigold after 3-4 rows of tomato to repel the white flies
- Plant trap crops such as tobacco, beans and maize around the field from which spot chemical control can be done
- Keep the field weed-free throughout the cropping season since weeds act as alternate hosts

- Look for:
• Whitish- brown eggs and/or whitish adults on the underside of young leaves.
• A cloud of over 3-5 white insects that resettle soon after the plant is shaken.
• Yellowing on upper leaf surface.
- Start direct control if 3 adult white flies are present when plant is shaken during the early stages of the crop

- Use of yellow sticky traps to bait adults- 4 traps/300m2
- Spray Azadirachtin 0.03% (50 ml/20L water) 15 days after transplant
- Use liquid soap spray at rate of 3 table spoons per litre of water
- Use hot pepper spray at rate of 30 chopped peppers in warm water. Soak for 1 day, dilute in 10 L water and add 20 drops of liquid soap before spraying.
- Spray with natural enemies like Encarsia formosa and entomopathogenic fungi like Beauveria bassiana,and Lecanicillium lecanii

- Wear protective clothing and follow instructions on the product label
- Spray early morning or late evening to avoid harming bees.
- Dispose properly to avoid aquatic contamination
- Alternate active ingredients to prevent development of resistance
- WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes. Always consult recent list of registered pesticides

- Drench with imidacloprid at a rate of 5g in 20 litres of water. Neonicitinoid, IRAC 4A. Systemic insecticide with translaminar activity and with contact and stomach action. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI 3 days, MRL-0.5
- Spray lambda-cyhalothrin 5% at a rate of 7ml per 20 litres of water. IRAC code 3. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). PHI 3 days. MRL-0.01
- Spray alpha-cypermethrin 10EC at a rate of 5ml per 20 litres of water. IRAC code 3. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI 3 days. MRL-0.2

Images.Caption: Adult Whitefly (Ian Bedford, CABI)
Whiteflies colonizing leaves (A.M. Varela, icipe)

Authors.Surname: Oyoo J (KARI), Miriam Otipa(KARI), Kenneth Kagai (MoA), Benson Ngigi (MOA), Dora Kilalo (University of Nairobi), Hannah Oduor (MOALF), Martha Kariuki (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Always test your soil for zinc levels 1-2 months before planting
- Do not plant maize in inappropriate agroecological zones such as in the tea zone and avoid soils with pH less than 7
- Lime the soil at the recommended rates after soil testing to raise the pH to above 5
- Use organic manures (e.g. farmyard manure, green manure etc) to provide organic matter Apply compost or mulch to preserve microorganisms and other useful organisms that assist in zinc release.
- Avoid excessive application of phosphorus fertilizers
- Leave the farm fallow for at least 1 season
- Protect the soil from erosion (see Direct control green column)
- Rotate your crops seasonally with plants that have a low zinc requirement, such as wheat

- Three weeks after planting Look out for:
• Yellow to white broad band occurring on both sides of the midrib from the leaf stalks on younger leaves.
• Maize plants with shortened internodes throughout the cropping season.
• Take direct control when the yellow –white band is seen on younger leaves

- Use bio-slurry from biogas digesters at the rate of 1 litre/square metre (4000L/acre)
- Use organic fertilizer (e.g. compost or farmyard manure (4 tons per acre)
- Use Yad bio-vitalizer organic fertilizer at a rate of 750 kg/ha (300kg/acre)

- Apply inorganic basal fertilizer with Zinc (such as zinc oxide or zinc sulphate, to correct deficiency. Spray with foliar feed (eg Bayfolan Plus ) on plants with symptoms (see Monitoring column). . General Restrictions: Use rates recommended after soil testing. When applying fertilizers always wear protective clothing. Store mineral fertilizers at dry conditions and separate from pesticides

Images.Caption: Photo of Maize with symptoms of Zinc deficiency (Courtesy of IPNI)

Sections.Value:
- Maintain good irrigation of the orchard as mites are favoured during dry, dusty and hot weather
- Balanced fertilization and adequate pruning to maintain tree vigour
- Avoid the use of pesticides that affect both natural enemies and predatory mites or thrips

- Collect 10-40 leaves weekly from 10 trees in and around the canopy. For each tree, monitor mites, predators and symptoms
- Symptoms:
• Leaves: silvery appearance
• Loss of tree vigour
• Defoliation
- If the presence of predatory mites or thrips is sufficient to control phytophagous mites, no control is needed
- Take control measures if 10 to 20 mites/leaf are found and predator levels are low

- When mites populations are low, treatments are not needed as they are controlled by natural enemies
- In the case of major infestations, apply insecticidal soap or horticultural oil every 5-7 days until the density of mites decrease. Avoid application at temperatures above 26 °C which cause leaf scorch

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult P. ulmi on damaged leaves (Horticulture Research International)
Infestation on leaves and damage caused by T. urticae (Whitney Cranshaw, Colorado State University, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant or partially resistant varieties
- Eliminate fruits and remains of diseased crops
- Winter pruning to eliminate tree buds
- Sowing density, weed control and pruning to improve aeration/ventilation

- Start monitoring for symptoms a month after the beginning of flowering:
• The leaves are thickened, shrunk and curled. They have a green to red color depending on the variety
• The diseased leaves turn powdery gray in color. Then they turn black, fall and are replaced by new leaves
• Attack starts on new leaves but can flowers and fruits can be affected as well (yellow to red in color)
• Thicker buds
• Witches broom effect
• Whole plant: extensive defoliation, stunting, loss of vigor, death
- In the case of outbreaks, eliminate affected tree buds and deformed fruits through thinning

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Symptoms on leaves (Thorsten Kraska, University of Bonn, Germany)
Infected leaves turning black (Eric Boa)
Symptoms on fruits (Alan L. Jones)

Authors.Surname: Samuel Mburu. Martha Kariuki (Ministry of Agriculture, Mwala and Nakuru, respectively),  Dora Kilalo (UoN), Eunice Ringera (KEPHIS), Ann Kimani (UoN)

Sections.Value:
- Improve soil water holding capacity by applying mulch and organic manure at the rate of 1 debe (18kg) per hole
- Practice good field sanitation e.g. remove and burn infested crop residues immediately after harvest, keep fields weed free
- Use of mechanical barriers e.g Lantana camara hedge rows
- Establish nurseries away from infested crops and avoid planting next to infested fields

- Scout weekly to check for the red spider mites infestations
- Look on the underside of affected leaves for mites (tiny moving specks that are red or yellow-greenish) and whitish particles (shed skins of mites)
- Tap leaf on white paper to see the mites
- Monitor for cluster of yellow spots on leaves which appear chlorotic
- When a few yellow spots and a few spider mites (5-7) are seen on three leaves per plant consider direct control

- Remove and burn all infected plants parts
- Irrigate the crop regularly to reduce heavy mite infestation
- Use neem (azadirachtin) at 20-50ml in 20 litres of water 3-4 times per season
- Use Phytoseiulus persimilis (Phytotech packaging. 2000 mites/400mls carrier material, Application is 1 million mites/ha i.e. 500 botlles/ha or 100 dudus/M2
- Use Amblyseius californicus (Amblytech) 2000 mites/400mls carrier material. Apllication -75000- 150000 dudus/ha or 7.5-15 mites /M2

- When using pesticides, read and follow instructions on the label. Alternate active ingredients to prevent development of resistance. Wear protective clothing. Spray early morning or late evening to avoid harming bees. Avoid aquatic contamination

- Dust with sulphur- Don’t use sulfur if temperatures exceed 32°C, and don’t apply sulfur within 30 days of an oil spray. General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous)
- Abamectin at a rate of 10ml in 20 litres of water or 0.5 litres per hectare e.g. (Dyanamec 1.8 EC, IRAC 6. General Restrictions: Not classified by the WHO. PHI 3 days
- Malathion at a rate of 40-50ml in 20 litres of water. Non-systemic pesticide with contact, stomach and respiratory action. Organophosphate, IRAC 1B. General Restrictions: WHO Class III. PHI 7 days. Use a maximum of 3 sprays per season
- Amitraz 200g/lt e.g. Mitac 20 EC at the rate of 40-60mls per 20lt, 2-3 lts/ha. IRAC19. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). PHI 14 days
- Permethrin. Non-systemic pesticide with contact, stomach action as well as a slight repellent effect. Pyrethroid, IRAC 3A. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). PHI 7 days

Images.Caption: Yellow spots on leaves caused by red spider mites (Dora Kilalo)
Red spider mite on papaya (David Cappaert, Michigan State University, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Gekone J. Maina (MoAL&F), Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Mary Lucy Oronje (CABI), Cyrus Njoroge (MoAL&F) P.O Box 1433-30200, Kitale, Kenya, Dora Kilalo (UoN)

Sections.Value:
- Use tolerant varieties such as Grande Naine
- De-sucker banana stools to maintain 3-4 plants per stool
- Prune banana plants and shade trees to reduce humidity which may create favourable conditions for disease development
- Remove floral remains on tip of fingers manually 8-11 days after bunch formation
- Remove the male bud 15 cm below the last hand (when the fingers have folded in)
- Harvest at maturity to reduce susceptibility to the disease
- Store in a cool dry place to reduce the incidences of the disease
- Minimize bruising of the fruits during harvesting and transportation

- Look out for: a black necrosis spread from the flower into the tip of immature fingers which appears like a cigar-end.
- Act after the first infestation is noticed.

- Remove collapsing, dying and dead leaves and burn to reduce inoculum levels.
- Remove and bury infected fingers to prevent spread of fungus.

- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing. Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray affected bunches with fungicides such as:
- Mancozeb (Dithane M45 at a rate of 60gms/20L of water). FRAC code M3. General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). PHI 7 days
- Thiophanate methyl (Topsin M SC at a rate of 15mls/ 20L of water). FRAC code 1. General Restrictions: WHO Class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use). PHI 7 days

Images.Caption: Necrotic  tissue on fruit tips covered with fungal mycelia that resembles the greyish ash cigar end. (Photo: Maina Gekone, Crops Officer, MoA, Trans-Nzoia East, Kenya)
Advaced damage showing greyish ash cigar end on banana fingers. (Photo: Thomas K. Kwambai, KALRO, Kenya)

Sections.Value:
- Eliminate excessive vegetative shoots (where pest spreads from)
- Thin the crown to permit better air circulation but avoid severe pruning as this causes heavy sprouting
- Avoid excessive application of nitrogen that causes an exaggerated sprouting of the trees resulting in increasing the attack
- Avoid harmful or non-selective insecticides for natural enemies (ladybirds, lacewings, hoverflies and parasitoids)
- Control weeds in the nursery surroundings to reduce the presence of overwintering stages

- Monitor whitelfies throughout the year, especially during the sprouting season
- Note the presence of eggs, insects, symptoms, ants and parasitoids in 4 young shoots per tree (from 1% of the trees of the orchard):
• Adults are winged insects that are 2 mm in length and white in colour. Its body is covered with wax. They feed on the sap of the leaves. The females lay their eggs on tender shoots.
• Nymphs are flat and oval, and are covered with fine waxy filaments
• The eggs, nymphs and adults are located on the underside of the young leaves
- Symptoms:
• Fruit: development of sooty mould caused by honeydew secretion
• In case of intensive attack: growth inhibition of the twigs, loss of vigour and decreased production and photosynthetic capacity resulting from the abundant production of honeydew, sooty mold and woolliness
- Take control measure when the infestation level exceeds 20% of attacked shoots (or 20-30 nymphs/leaf in orange and lemon, and 5-10 nymphs/leaf in mandarin) and parasitism rate is below 60%

- In the absence of natural enemies, release parasitoids (ej. Amitus spiniferus, Cales noacki, Eretmocerus paulistus, Encarsia spp.). Collect leaves in another orchard with parasitized nymphs and put them in paper bags with holes of 2-4 mm. Hang the bags into the canopy of the most affected trees.
- It is recommended to apply soapy solutions for their important braking action and because of the little effectiveness of the insecticides against this pest
- Apply mineral oils 0.5% (commercially available) on attacked shoots
- Apply organic registered agricultural soaps on attacked shoots to eliminate adults, nymphs, honeydew and wax filaments on the nymphs to enhance the action of natural enemies. Repeat washes every 15 days during the dry season and monthly during the sprouting season.
- During the rainy season, washes are not necessary as the rains cause high mortality, especially adults on young leaves
- In general, it is recommended to avoid the use of insecticides considering that natural enemies are very effective and the effect of insecticides is moderate. Besides eliminating natural enemies, insecticide applications subsequently result in more intense attacks of the pest

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Nymphs of A. floccosus (J. Catalán, http://gipcitricos.ivia.es)
Orange twigs affected by A. floccosus (A. Urbaneja, http://gipcitricos.ivia.es)

Authors.Surname: Benson W. Masinde  (MOALF) Maurice Okeno (MOALF) , Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Apply nitrogenous fertilizers moderately because too much makes the plant soft and juicy, making it attractive to aphids
- Grow strong smelling repellent plants like onions, garlic and Mexican marigold near the crop.
- Remove and destroy crop remnants (residues) immediately after harvest.

-  Look at lower leaves, stems or growing points for soft bodied insects, found in small groups.
- Look for curled, wrinkled or cupped leaves of infested crops
- Monitor the presence of aphids early in the morning after transplanting and when weather conditions are cool and dry
- Start control measures when 1-2% of plants are infested

- Remove and destroy infected plants in the field.
- Conserve natural enemies like ladybirds, and parasitic wasps.
- Use yellow coloured traps to attract and kill adult aphids
- Apply 2.5 teaspoons of NPK fertilizer per each plant.
- Spray soap solution (potassium soaps)-Add 10-15 tablespoons of liquid soap in 20lt bucket and spray. Avoid powdered detegents because they can burn plant leaves.
- Spray with botanical extraxts e.g. mixture of garlic, neem, red chilli pepper and soap. Take 50g mixture in 2lts of water, boil for 15 minutes, allow to cool, then spray.

- Wash your hands after handling the pesticides.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max. number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty pesticide containers or throw.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB). Wear protective clothing while applying extract or pesticides

- Spray Pyrethrin (75g/l) e.g (Pyerin EC 60ml in 20 lts of water.) Apply on first signs of infestation and repeat fortnightly until symptoms disapear). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) and PHI of 1 day
- Spray Thiamethoxam. 250g/Kg e.g (Actara 25 WG at 10 g in 20lts of water for foliar spray and 160g/acre for drenching.). General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous) and PHI of 3 days.
- Spray Lambda-cyhalothrin. 17.5g/L (Duduthrin1.7 EC and Karate 17.5 EC at a rate of 60ml in 20 litres of water.). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) and PHI of 3-7 days.

Images.Caption: Green adult wingless female, oval bodied 1-2 mm body length. (Photo: Magnus Gammelgaard)
A colony of aphids on underside leaf of a vegetable (Photo: Peter Scott)
A stem infested with Black aphids (Photo: Whitney Cranshaw, Colorado State University, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Jonathan M. Gekone (MOALF), Stephen Koech (KALRO) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Remove all branches touching the ground
- Apply a 20cm band of a sticky substance such as petroleum jelly on the tree trunks, 15cm from the ground

- Look out for:
- Mealy white masses between clusters of berries and flower buds
- Sooty moulds on the upper surface of leaves
- Inspect at any time of the day especially during dry spells
- Take action when one plant is affected

- Encourage presence of biological control agents such as parasitic wasps (Anagyrus kivuensis), lacewings and ladybirds that eat the bugs.
- Spray soapy solution made by dissolving a finger sized piece of bar soap in 20 litres of water
- Apply 1-2% vegetable oil such as neem oil on the infested plant

- Use protective gear when using a pesticides
- Follow the instructions on the product label before using any pesticide
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).
- After using pesticides, do not throw empty containers carelessly especially into water ways.

- Spray Chlorpyrifos containing insecticide such as Bullet 48EC or Sulban 48EC at a rate of 40mls/20L of water on the soil around the tree to kill ants. . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) and PHI 14days, MRL1mg/kg
- Spray Malathion containing insecticide such as Marathon 50EC or Oshothion 50EC at a rate of 50 mls/20L of water if the problem persists on the infested plant. General Restrictions: WHO class III (slightly hazardous) and PHI 7 days,
- . General Restrictions: Spray only infested trees

Soot on coffee leaves (Photo: FAO Regional Office for Asia and the Pacific, 2005.)
An oval shaped nymph stage of the mealybug (Photo: Rob Reeder, CABI)

Authors.Surname: Jonathan M. Gekone (MOALF), Stephen Koech and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant variety such as GLP1004 ("Mwezi Moja")
- Plant early when pest population is low in a weed-free farm
- Earth-up during weeding to enhance adventitious root formation for improved tolerance of crop
- Use certified seed from registered agro-dealors
- Avoid overlapping bean crops in the season to reduce build-up

- Scout for symptoms of the pests on leaves and stem immediately after germination. Look out for:
- Small and shiny black insect flies with clear wings and oviposition marks on the leaves.
- Swollen and cracked stem at the base.
- The presence of larvae and pupae on the cracked and swollen stem
- Take action when one in twenty plants (5%) is affected.

- Uproot and destroy infested plants by burning.
- Spray using Azadirachtin (Neem) based products such as Achook at a rate of 20mls/20L of water

- Use protective gear when using a pesticides
- Follow the instructions on the product label and safely dispose empty containers
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).

- Spray using Imidacloprid based insecticides such as Imaxi 200SC or Confidor 200SL at a rate of 10mls/20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) and PHI 3days
- Spray using systemic insecticides e.g Thiamethoxam based products such as Actara 25WG at a rate of 80gms/20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO class III (slightly hazardous) and PHI 7 days,

Factsheets.Title: Beanfly (Bean stem maggot) in Common Bean

Authors.Surname: S. Mburu (MOA). M. Kariuki (MOA), D. Kilalo (UON), M. Gikone (MOA), C. Njoroge(MOA), N.  Murage (MOA), I. Mwendandu (MOA), P. Kodwaran (MOA), S. Kiritai(MOA), K. Kagai (MoA), B. Ngigi (MOA), MaryLucy Oronje (CABI), Margaret Mulaa (CABI), Eunice Sakong (MOALF) and Samuel Mburu (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Remove neglected (unmanaged) host plants like guava, chillies, citrus, melons, coffee, mangoes, wild fruits to reduce pest population
- Prune regularly to improve aeration.
- Bag fruits using old newspapers measuring 15x22 cm to prevent fruit flies from laying eggs on fruits
- Harvest early when crop is mature and green because over-ripened fruits attract fruit flies
- Preserve the natural enemies like ants, rove beetles, birds and parasitic wasps by planting hedge rows
- release poultry in the orchard to feed on pupa at the base of plants

- Regularly scout when fruit starts setting
- Look on fruit surfaces for small holes, punctured fruit, black lesions, soft spots, rotting, maggots and discolouration
- Monitor for fruits with oozing sap
- Use food traps e.g. waste brewers’ yeast 45ml/L of water or ripe fruits as bait to monitor presence of fruit fly
- Look for pupae 2-5 cm beneath host plant and take action to control as soon as fruit flies and damage symptoms are observed.

- Use traps and baits. The traps should contain ½ cup (150 ml) of vinegar mixed with water and 4-6 drops liquid soap or 50-10020-20ml/ acre of vinegar)
- Trap flies using commercial pheromone traps - Methyl Euginol (Bactrolure liquid) at 20 traps per acre.
- Spay neem extracts e.g Achook 0.15% EC at 20 ml in 20 liters of water.
- Remove infested fruits (e.g. those with dimples and oozing sap) twice a week and destroy by. burying about 60cm deep, tying in black plastic bag and leaving in sun for 3 days, or. putting in boiling/hot water to kill larvae and then feed to poultry or pigs
- Store harvested fruit in cool place or cold storage for 5 days.
- Flood around the base of trees with water weekly to kill pupae

- When using a pesticide always wear personal protective equipment.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).

- Spot treat affected trees with poison baits of molasses with deltamethrin (Decis 2.5 EC) or bifenthrin (Brigade 25EC or defender 2.5% EC) or Buprofezin (Applaud 40% SC). General Restrictions: Bifenthrin and deltamethrin: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). Buprofezin: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous). PHI 3 days.
- Use pyrethrin extract (e.g. Flower DS) at a rate of 60ml per 20 litres of water every 5 days to two weeks depending on infestation severity. Start applications shortly after flowering. General Restrictions: Pyrethrin extract: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous). Neem extract: WHO Class U (unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use), PHI 8 hours.

Images.Caption: Adult fruit fly (photo by R. C. Copeland, icipe).

Sections.Value:
- To ensure that trees do not suffer from moisture or nutrient stress during dry season, adopt good soil management practices that increase N fixation and humus content, decrease soil temperature and weed establishment, and prevent soil erosion by:
• Using leguminous cover crops in unshaded widely spaced coffee (more suited to robusta areas)
• Or by mulching the topsoil with organic residues (e.g. Napier or Guinea grass, banana, maize or sorghum). Apply at least 10 cm at the end of the rainy season, leaving a gap around stem bases
• Intercropping with permanent, perennial or annual crops (e.g. beans, pigeon pea or sorghum)
• Providing good irrigation to plants; plants under stress are very susceptible to direct thrip damage
- Cover crops and intercrops generally enhance pest and disease management (improving soil microbial status and providing a habitat to natural enemies (e.g. lacewings, pirate bugs, spiders, ground beetles)), but make sure that they don't compete with coffee for moisture and nutrients or damage coffee roots
- Establishing windbreaks to reduce thrip populations spread by wind

- Monitor regularly for thrips and symptoms, especially during periods of drought and high temperatures
- Monitor the underside of the leaves for grey-brown adults, 1-1.5 mm in length with fringed wings, and yellow wingless nymphs
- Symptoms are seen on the upper surface: irregular grey or silvery patches covered by numerous tiny black spots
- Heavy infestation: thrips are found on the upperside of leaves, berries and green shoots and leaves dry up and fall off
- Thrips can be monitor easily by shaking leaves on a white piece of paper or by using coloured (blue, yellow or white) sticky traps or water traps in the nursery or field
- Take action when 20% of the inspected plants have thrips

- Use natural enemies (if available) following local recommendations for compatibility between biopesticides:
• Spray the underside of the leaves with a solution of Beauveria bassiana early, before large thrips populations build up
• Spray the underside of the leaves with a solution of neem-based products
• Release Amblyseius californicus, a predatory mite
• Release Orius jeanneli, a predatory bug

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Adult female of Heliothrips haemorrhoidalis, also attacking coffee (Yu Yan-Fen)

Authors.Surname: V. Momanyi, B. Ita, W. Kouko

Sections.Value:
- Only use certified seed to avoid introduction through contamination. If using your own stock of seeds, ensure that they are clean. Use weed free fields
- Clean equipment and farm machinery to prevent seeds being spread
- Do not accept potentially contaminated materials, e.g. fill dirt, hay or soil
- Control established populations near waterways to prevent spread during flooding and storm events
- Thoroughly prepare the seed bed under dry conditions to reduce infestations by ploughing and turning the soil
- Use well decomposed farmyard manure
- Before planting seed, prepare seed bed and wait for the first rain showers to promote weed germination then control by use of a post-emergent herbicde (glyphosphate) when weeds are 2-3 weeks old.

- Annual grass, spreading or stiffly erect, tufted or reclining at base; 0.3-2 m high. Leaves dark green, linear and flat; 10−65 cm long and 5-30 mm wide. Inflorescences branched, upright or nodding (10−25 cm long) with flowerheads ('branches', ca. 5cm long).
- Regularly inspect fields, biweekly and in particular during and shortly after the wet season, and consider direct control when present
- Look our for it in wetlands and along waterways. Water and storm events can spread seeds

- Hand-pull or use a hoe to remove weed before flowering
- If weed has already appeared, plant cowpeas and beans to supress the weeds between the rows of rice by providing soil cover
- Plant rice in rows with spacing of 25 by 15 cm for the variety Merica, and 25 by 20 for the variety Dourado precoce. This makes weeding easier

- Use of chemical herbicides may lead to the development of herbicide resistance.
- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

- Use glyphosate before planting rice when there is a heavy infestation. Concentration 360 a.i./L at the rate of 2 lt/ha. General Restrictions: Glyphosphate: WHO class III (slightly hazardous)
- Use post-emergent herbicide such as Satunil (40% thiobencarb w/w+propanil 20% w/w) or fenoxaprop.Broad application of Satunil at a rate of 2.5L/ha. General Restrictions: Fenoxaprop: WHO Class III (slightly hazardous); Thiobencarb: Class II (moderately hazardous); Propanil: Class II (moderately hazardous)
