Young plant at tillering (© Tomas Marquez/DuPont)

Factsheets.Title: Control of Barnyard grass in Upland Rice

Sections.Value:
- Use only healthy disease-free seedlings from reliable sources
- Use of tolerant/resistant varieties
- If TSWV and thrip populations are very high throughout the area, consider planting a non-susceptible crop
- Seedling beds should be isolated from ornamental plants and susceptible crops (peppers, potatoes, tobacco, peas, lettuce and groundnuts)
- TSWV is transmitted and spread by thrips. Control thrips to avoid the virus spreading in the crop:
• Keep the inside and outside of the nursery free of weeds
• In the fields, start weeding 2 weeks prior to transplant but encourage grassy vegetation (e.g. wheat or barley) surrounding fields as they are poor hosts for TSWV and do not support vector species of thrips
• Cover the soil with an aluminised plastic film or mulch with dry grasses
• Use mesh netting (40-mesh or higher) to protect transplants from thrips
• Intercrop tomatoes with garlic or onions
• Encourage the presence of natural predators such as mites, lacewings, thrips or pirate bugs by decreasing the amount of insecticides used
• Maintain a 10 m plant-free border around the crop to help preventing the spread of TSWV
- Do not rotate with susceptible crops such as peppers, potatoes, tobacco, peas, lettuce and groundnuts
- Remove and destroy old tomato plants and other host crops after harvest

- Monitor regularly from nursery to harvest stage for symptoms:
• Plants show bronzing, curling, necrotic streaks and spots on leaves
• Dark-brown streaks appear on leaf petioles, stems and growing tips
• Growing tips of infected plants may die back
• The ripe fruit shows large spotting (about 1 cm) or red and yellow bands
• Infected plants are small and stunted
• Sometimes affected plants are killed by severe necrosis
- The presence of thrips in the crops should be monitored using yellow or blue sticky cards and visual monitoring
- Take control measures when five thrips or more are found on the sticky traps

- If infected plants are detected in nursery or fields, remove and destroy immediately
- Trap thrips using yellow sticky traps
- Generally insecticides are ineffective in reducing virus transmission because very little time is required to transmit the virus

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Leaf spots (Paul Bachi, University of Kentucky Research and Education Center, Bugwood.org)
Ringspots on stem tissue (Gerald Holmes, California Polytechnic State University at San Luis Obispo, Bugwood.org)
Ringspots on fruit (Gerald Holmes, California Polytechnic State University at San Luis Obispo, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Don't use varieties susceptible to the disease
- Plant trees with sufficient space between them to allow air circulation in the orchard
- Remove dead branches, twigs and leaves from the tree on a regular basis if they are entwined, as the fungus lives on them
- The fungus also lives on rotten fallen fruits and dead or dying leaves; remove fallen fruits and leaves from the orchard
- Balance nutrients; apply composted manures
- To improve ventilation in the tree canopy, prune branches and low limbs to at least 60 cm off the ground at the start of the dry season
- Control insect pests such as fruitspotting bugs and fruit flies to reduce the incidence of the disease, as wounds created by insects enhance the damage
- Handle fruit carefully during and after harvest to avoid causing injuries that increase the risk of infection

- Monitor 10 marked trees/ha per week during rainy season for symptoms
- Fruits:
• Symptoms develop after harvest and during ripening
• Small, light-brown circular lesions first appear on fruits. Eventually the lesions enlarge and become dark-brown or black and slightly sunken in the centre
• In wet weather, salmon-coloured spore masses may be produced in the centre of the lesions
• Infected young fruits may drop from trees
- Leaves:
• Symptoms rarely develop on leaves but if affected, small black spots are formed
- The disease is favoured by high humid conditions (> 95%) and temperatures between 10 °C and 30°C (optimal at 25°C)

- Cool fruits to 5°C as soon as possible after harvest (within 6 hours) and control post-harvest temperature and conditions (cold and dry)
- Collect and destroy affected fruits

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Fruit affected by anthracnose (Scot Nelson)
Fruit affected by anthracnose (Florida Division of Plant Industry Archive, Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, Bugwood.org)
Late stage of anthracnose showing the fungal spore mass in the centre of the lesion (A.A. Seif, icipe)

Sections.Value:
- Before storing new maize, clean and disinfect the storage area, removing and burning all residues
- To eliminate residual infestation, immerse used sacks in boiling water or use new bags to store maize
- Harvest early (when the black layer has formed between the tip of the maize and the cob) before the larger grain borer infests the grain
- When harvesting and storing, check that maize is free of pests, and store only clean cobs
- Shell and dry the maize until it is very dry (less than 12% moisture)
- Store maize with dried lantana or eucalyptus leaves to repel the larger grain borer
- Use airtight, sealed containers
- Do not store grains for a long period. Infestation is usually low if grains are sold or used within three months

- Monitor weekly the stored produce for damage (e.g. holes in the grains, frass and dust) and adults or larva. Infestation at low levels is not obvious, so it is important to sample and carefully examine the grains.
- Inspect holes and cracks where adults can hide.
- Use a box sieve with a mesh of 1 to 2 mm to separate the insects and the grains
- Bags can be emptied in a thin layer onto a sheet in the shade to examine the content
- If any adults or larva are found, the infested produce has to be removed from the storage and destroyed
- Use pheromone traps:
• Flight traps e.g. funnel, delta or wing traps
• Place at 100 m away from the storage area or the standing maize crop
• Position 1 to 2 m from the ground

- Use natural enemies, e.g. the beetle Teretriosoma nigrescens, a specific predator
- Apply an ash-chili mixture to protect maize. Mix 2 kg of wood ash with 1 tablespoon of fine chili powder. Mix 1 part of ash-chili mixture with 4 parts of dried maize grain
- Mix 1 kg of diatomite powder per bag of maize or grain
- Mix finely crushed laterite (common red soil of the arid tropics) with grains in grain stores or sealed clay pots

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult Prostephanus truncatus (Pest and Diseases Image Library-University of Georgia, Bugwood.org)
Damage made by the larger grain borer (CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Use certified disease-free seeds
- Plant resistant or tolerant varieties
- To reduce initial inoculum, use tillage methods that promote decomposition of crop debris, as the fungus survives in and on plant debris
- Practise crop rotation with non-grass crops and eliminate weedy grass hosts
- On sorghum, increased levels of nitrogen increase the development of the disease. Avoid high levels of nitrogen fertilization
- Crop rotation for 1-2 years with soybeans, beans and sunflower. Do not practise crop rotation with maize

- Monitor regularly for symptoms during optimal conditions of high humidity and moderate temperatures (18-27 °C)
- Leaves:
• Initially slightly oval, small, water-soaked spots appear. The spots grow into elliptical (with pointed ends) brown lesions until nearly as wide as the leaf
• The margin is red-purple and during warm, humid weather, greenish black fungal sporulation is produced in the centre of the lesions
• In the final stages, lesions are tan to grey, may merge and lead to complete burning of the foliage
• Lesions develop first on lower leaves and progress upwards
- Seedlings: small reddish-purple or yellowish-brown spots usually develop on the leaves
- Under warm, humid conditions the disease may cause serious damage by killing all leaves before plants have matured
- Symptoms on resistant cultivars are reduced to small chlorotic or necrotic spots
- S. turcica on sorghum forms larger and fewer lesions than Cochliobolus heterostrophus (southern leaf spot), mostly on the leaves but also on the stalks. Cercospora, Colletorichum, Ascochyta can also cause similar leaf disease symptoms
- Act when the first lesions appear on the leaves
- There are no direct control measures for this disease

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Large elliptical leaf blight lesions on sorghum (Courtesy EcoPort: David C. Nowell)
Typical shape and colour of a S. turcica lesion on a sorghum leaf (Courtesy EcoPort: David C. Nowell)
Early water-soaked lesion near the base of the leaf without a pigmented margin (Courtesy EcoPort: David C. Nowell)

Sections.Value:
- Sow early (before the onset of rains) so that ears appear before the peak period of aphid populations
- Provide adequate nutrients to soil with manure to grow healthy plants
- Provide adequate irrigation during the silk stage to reduce or eliminate aphid damage
- Eliminate weeds and host plants, such as Johnson grass, from around the farm
- Practise crop rotation with non-cereal crops e.g. beans, cowpeas, etc.
- Encourage natural enemies such as parasitic wasps, lady beetles, syrphid fly larvae and lacewings by reducing the amount of chemicals used in the field

- Monitor protected locations on the plant (i.e. within the whorl, in the curl of the leaves, upper part of the cornstalk) during whorl stage for dark green to bluish-green nymphs and adults
- Infestation usually starts on the leaf whorls, unemerged heads and tassels. The most severe damage occurs between late-whorl and pollination stages
- In heavy infestation, feeding may cause leaf curling, wilting and yellow mottling, and stunting of the whole plant
- Abundant production of honeydew by aphids results in sooty mould growth, and tassels and upper leaves may become completely covered preventing pollen release
- Ants are attracted by honeydew secretions; monitor ant activity at the base of the plants
- R. maidis is not of major importance and often doesn't need control, unless transmitting viruses (it is a vector of maize dwarf mosaic virus and maize leaf-fleck virus)
- Act only if 50 % of the plants monitored have more than 100 aphids/plant, and plants are under drought stress
- If available, release biological control agents such as Aphelinus varipes, Lysiphlebus testaceipes and L. mirzai

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult R.maidis (H. Banziger)
Maize aphid infestation (Department of Plant Pathology Archive, North Carolina State University, Bugwood.org)
Maize aphid infestation in tassel (Eric Burkness, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Use certified disease-free seeds
- Use resistant cultivars
- As the disease is seed borne, avoid harvesting diseased grain and contaminating grain used for seed with spores

- Seedling infection occurs between seed germination and seedling emergence, but the disease is apparent only after heading
- Severity of infection is influenced by soil temperature and soil moisture. Severe smut infection generally occurs when soil temperature ranges from 18-23 °C and soil moisture is 15-20 % during the infection period
- Monitor after heading for symptoms
• Individual grains of sorghum become misshapen as they develop and are filled with dark smut spores on maturity. The smut sori (cone-shaped gall) is inside the seed coat
• The panicle may be reduced to a few twisted, distorted branches covered with large, superficial smut sori. In some cases, the panicle branches may be completely destroyed, leaving only the distorted central rachis covered with sori
• Infected plants are generally the same height and size as healthy plants
- Remove the smutted heads and bury in soil or burn

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Sorghum smut (Courtesy EcoPort (http://www.ecoport.org): Jürgen Kranz)
Sorghum smut (Courtesy EcoPort (http://www.ecoport.org): Jürgen Kranz)

Sections.Value:
- This disease complex is caused by dual infection of the SPCSV transmitted by whiteflies and the SPFMV transmitted by aphids. Control disease vectors in the crop:
• Use only clean planting material; avoid collecting cuttings from very old crops
• Use resistant or tolerant varieties
• After harvest, remove and destroy vines, leaves, and all of the roots (feed to livestock, or burn, bury or compost them)
• Crop rotation; the disease only affects sweet potato. Rotate with any other crop the next season
• Plant new sweet potato crops at least 15 m away from the old crop
• Use natural barriers, such as maize, to isolate the new crop from old affected plots

- Look for symptoms regularly:
• Leaves: production of small, narrow and crinkled leaves, often with distorted edges, chlorotic mosaic and/or vein-clearing
• Plant: overall pale appearance and severe stunting
- Act as soon as vectors or disease symptoms are seen in the field

- Remove infected plants as soon as they appear in young crops and burn or feed them to livestock
- Destroying diseased plants by roguing helps to reduce and eliminate sources of the virus and limits the spread by insects
- Control whiteflies and aphids using a combination of techniques:
• Spray a solution of neem oil and soap (160-200 cc neem: 100 g soap in 20L of water) on the undersides of the leaves in the early morning or late evening
• Release predators as Chrysoperla spp. or parasitoids such as Aphidius colemani (to control aphids)
• Use yellow sticky traps (1 per 10 to 20 m2) to reduce the amount of winged aphids and adults whiteflies spreading from older crops or from the edges of the field
- Disease management practices work better on large areas and where the whole community is involved

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: SPVD-affected plant (left) showing small, pale green misshapen leaves with a healthy plant (right) (Dr Richard Gibson/Natural Resources Institute, University of Greenwich)
Whiteflies Bemisia tabaci, vectors of SPCSV (Ian D. Bedford)

Values.Value: Potyvirus sweet potato feathery mottle virus

Factsheets.Title: Sweet Potato Virus Disease (SPVD)
ScientificNames: Complex of sweet potato chlorotic stunt virus (SPCSV) and potyvirus sweetpotato feathery mottle virus (SPFMV)

Authors.Surname: V. Mwaja (Chuka University), J Maina, H. Mwangi, V. Momanyi, B. Ita, W. Kouko (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Only use certified seed to avoid introduction through contamination. Use clean farmer seed. Use weed free nursery
- Clean equipment and farm machinery to prevent seeds being spread
- Do not accept potentially contaminated materials, e.g. fill dirt, hay or soil
- Control established populations near waterways to prevent spread during flooding and storm events
- Prepare the soil by turning under dry conditions to reduce infestations
- Use well decomposed farmyard manure
- Use water from a source free of the weed for watering and flooding
- Before planting seed, prepare seed bed and wait for the first rain showers to promote weed germination then control by use of a post-emergent herbicde (glyphosphate) when weeds are 2-3 weeks old

- Annual grass, spreading or stiffly erect, tufted or reclining at base; 0.3-2 m high. Leaves dark green, linear and flat; 10−65 cm long and 5-30 mm wide. Inflorescences branched, upright or nodding (10−25 cm long) with flowerheads ('branches', ca. 5cm long).
- Regularly inspect fields, at least biweekly and in particular during and shortly after the wet season, and consider direct control when present
- Look our for it in wetlands and along waterways. Water and storm events can spread seeds

- Hand-pull when weed before flowering
- Flood rice fields with 15-22 cm of water, to prevent weeds developing, until the dough stage. Flooding with 2-3 cm water will offer limited control

- Use of chemical herbicides may lead to the development of herbicide resistance.
- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

- Use glyphosate (2 lt/ha) before planting rice when there is a heavy infestation. Concentration 360 a.i./L. General Restrictions: Glyphosphate: WHO class III (slightly hazardous)
- Use post-emergent herbicide such as Satunil (40% thiobencarb w/w+propanil 20% w/w) or fenoxaprop. Apply Satunil at a rate of 2.5L/ha as a post emergent foliar application in the field. General Restrictions: Fenoxaprop: WHO Class III (slightly hazardous); Thiobencar: Class II (moderately hazardous); Propanil: Class II (moderately hazardous)

Images.Caption: Echinochloa crus-galli inflorescence (© Michael Becker, Wikimedia)
Young plant at tillering (© Tomas Marquez/DuPont)

Authors.Surname: V. Mwaja (Chuka University), J. Maina (KALRO), H. Mwangi (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean pasture seed to reduce the chance of contamination
- Remove all existing hedges by cutting and digging out the roots (15cm depth) from farms

- Perennial woody shrub, 2-5m high, erect or scrambling. Branches with small thorns. Leaves are yellow-green to green, rough, 2-12cm in length. Flowers multicolored (yellow, orange, white, pale violet, pink or red), in dense clusters ca. 4 cm across. Fruits are round, fleshy, 2-seeded, each 5mm wide, green turning purple then blue-black. Arranged in dense, round clusters
- Removal of small infestations may be possible by cutting and digging out the roots (15cm depth)

- Use of chemical herbicides may lead to the development of herbicide resistance.
- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

- Cut the hedge to the soil level and allow for respouting during the rainy season. Apply glyphosate to the active growing shoots/sprouts at 6L per ha after 4 weeks. General Restrictions: Glyphosate: WHO Class III (slightly hazardous)
- Apply 2,4-D amine, at 2L/ha foliar application to actively growing stage, followed by digging out the roots. General Restrictions: After using 2,4-D in established pastures, allow 48 hrs before returning livestock. 2,4-D: WHO Class II (moderately hazardous)
- Cut the top of Lantana, and apply Tordon (Picloram 65g/L + 2,4-D 240g/L) mixed with diesel using low pressure sprayer targetting the stump to kill the roots and avoid drifts . General Restrictions: Tordon: WHO Class II (moderately hazardous)

Images.Caption: Lantana flower and leaves (© CABI)
Lantana infestation (© Dan Clark, USDI National Park Service, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: V. Mwaja (Chuka University), J. Maina (KALRO), H. Mwangi (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Prevention particulaly important as difficult to contol. Seeds considered unimportant;tubers are the main means of spread
- Clean tools and farm machinery to prevent tubers being spread
- Do not accept potentially contaminated materials, e.g. soil on planting stock
- Control established populations near waterways to prevent spread during flooding and storm events
- Promote cover crops such as legume crops like alfalfa to suppress establishment

- Erect, perennial sedge (30-60 cm high), with extensive underground network of tubers. Tubers dark brown/black, irregular shaped, 1-2 cm long at maturity, with several buds. Leaves linear with distinct midrib, 7 mm wide. Flowering stems 3-sided, erect. Inflorescence with several unequal 'branches', each 2-6 cm long, emerging from the tip of the stem; each with 3-8 purplish-brown flowerheads.
- Regularly inspect fields, at least fortnightly and in particular during and shortly after the wet season, and consider direct control when found
- Look our for it in low spots, wetlands and along waterways. Water and storm events can spread tubers
- Regular monitoring at least fortinightly at beginning of every growing season. (over 10 sedge plants /m2 control with glyphosate)

- Tubers and rhizomes in the soil can be destroyed by dessication (most effective in dry soil) or exhausting food reserves. Cultivate every 2-3 weeks until crop canopy forms: the weed is shade intolerant
- Place organic mulch over areas where the weed is expect to grow: provides temporary suppression
- Black polyethylene sheet can be used in high value crops as a barrier or for soil solarization
- Tillage must be deep (>12cm) in order to disturb as many of the rhizomes and tubers as possible. Do this under dry conditions so the exposed rhizomes dessicate. Fortnightly spot weeding should be carried out
- Use Delayed Planting: before planting seed, allow the weed to emerge after the rains/irrigation for early control with post emergence herbicide
- Use Bromacil at recommended rate (2 lt/ha) to be used to suppress the weed until crop canopy develops to suppress the weed.

- Use of chemical herbicides may lead to the development of herbicide resistance.
- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

- Most effective herbicide is glyhposate, applied post-emergence at the flowering stage, at 3L/ha (480g a.e. IPA salt). Repeated applications when you see the weed within a season, to eliminate weed in an area, at 2L/ha (480g a.e. IPA salt). General Restrictions: Glyphosate WHO Class III (slightly hazardous)
- Bromacil: WHO Class U (unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use)

Images.Caption: Cyperus rotundus inflorescence (© S.D. Sawant)
Plants with underground tubers, basal bulbs, rhizomes and fibrous roots (© S.D. Sawant)

Authors.Surname: Amata R.L. (KALRO);  Ringera E. (KEPHIS) and Otipa M. J. (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant clean certified seeds/seedlings from reliable sources (Contact KALRO & Practical Training Centre )
- Practice field sanitation and weed control (nightshade, horse nettle, jimsonweed)
- Grow own clean seedlings to avoid importing diseased seedlings purchased from unreliable sources.
- Rotate for 3 years with maize, wheat, onions. Do not rotate with pepper, tomato, eggplant, or potato.
- Plough the field immediately after the final harvest to hasten the breakdown of crop residue.
- Avoid overhead irrigation and minimize splashing water which can further spread the inoculum
- Avoid working in fields when the plants are wet and work on infected areas last

- Look out for :
• Small, dark brown or black circular spots that may be surrounded by a yellow halo
• Fruit lesions that are initially small and dark brown in color.
• Older spots that are black, slightly raised and measure up to 0.3 inch (7.5 mm) in diameter
• Spots on immature fruit are at first slightly sunken and surrounded by a water-soaked halo, which soon disappears
- Take action when one plant in the entire farm shows disease symptoms
- Additional crops affected: tomato, pepper

- Uproot all infected plants and destroy by burning
- Remove infected crop debris and weeds since they act as additional source of inoculum.

- Use protective clothing when handling insecticides
- Follow product label instructions
- Rotate insecticide classes to reduce resistance.
- Ensure proper spray coverage of flowers and foliage

- Spray with copper based fungicides e.g. copper oxichloride (Amicop 50WP and Cobox 50WP at 60g/20L of water) and copper hydroxide (Cuprocaffaro Micro 37.5 WG and Kocide DF at 50g/20L of water) to minimize bacterial infection. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI 7 days
- Disinfect farm tools between plants and farms (use 50 ml JIK in 1 litre of water)

Images.Caption: Bacterial spot of tree tomato (Source: Ruth Amata)
Leaf spots on leaves (Ruth Amata)

Authors.Surname: Koech, S.,  Mbevi, B. and Otipa M. J. (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Work/rake the soil lightly to expose eggs and nymphs (crawlers) to predators or extreme temperatures
- Avoid excessive watering / nitrogen fertilizers as mealybugs like soft growths and high N2 levels
- Maintain good sanitation by getting rid of old plant materials and prunings that may harbour mealybug eggs

- Regularly inspect the vineyard for early detection and initiate control immediately when you notice mealybugs as they will have already laid eggs in the soil.
- Look for:oval-shaped flightless bugs that have cottony white powdery appearance and sooty moulds as a result of excreted honeydew around stems and leaf nodes
- Look for typical discolured and deformed leaves as a result of mealybug infestation
- Additional crops affected: banana, citrus, cacao, corn, grape, mango, potato, soyabean, etc.

- Spray organic insecticidal soap which weakens the insects' protective waxy cover exposing them to adverse conditions e.g. Savona from Koppert
- Control ants using gummed banding to break the symbiotic relationships thus exposing mealybugs to predators
- Spray dishwashing soap to suffocate the bugs/remove their waxy layer
- Spray neem based products e.g. Achook 1.5% at 20-50mls in 20L, 3-4 times/season or Nimbecidine at 50mls in 20L, repeated fortnightly.
- Spray with strong stream of water to dislodge / kill the bugs repeatedly daily.

- Use protective gear
- Follow label instructions on the product
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides
- Ensure safe disposal of empty containers

- Spray Thiamethoxam based product eg Actara 25WG at the rate of 8g/20L, repeated at fortnightly interval if pest re-occurs . General Restrictions: Chemicals should only be used when zero tolerance for this pest is required. The product is toxic to bees &fish. WHO class III, Slightly hazardous; PHI 7 days.
- Spray Imidachloprid based insecticides e.g. Confidor 200SL at the rate of 10mls/20L of water etc. General Restrictions: Imidachloprid WHO class III, Slightly hazardous; PHI 7 days; MRLs 2mg/kg

Images.Caption: Adult female passion vine mealybug on leaf (A.M Varela ICIPE)
Cottony looking Passion vine meally bug colony (Joel E. Miles, Office of Environmental Response and Coordination, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Amata R.L. (KALRO)  Ringera E. (KEPHIS) and Otipa M. J. (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Provide good air circulation through increased crop spacing, weeding and thinning crowded plants
- Avoid low-lying, shaded areas prone to heavy fogs and dews
- Irrigate in mid-morning, so plants dry rapidly, to reduce the likelihood of infections
- Practice crop rotation with maize, common beans and "njahi". Avoid intercropping with susceptible crops such as cucumber or pumpkin

- Look out for :
• Pale white spots on leaves, stems and petioles, which later enlarge to form white powdery appearance.
• White powdery colonies on either side of leaf. Older leaves are affected first.
• Watch closely for signs of powdery mildew as new shoots begin to develop on perennial plants
- Spray when 1 colony is found in 45 scouted leaves
- Other crops affected: cucumber, pumpkin, courgettes, eggplants, tomatoes, kale

- Collect and dispose of any fallen leaves by burning (never use diseased plant materials for composting)
- Reduce disease spread through overhead irrigation as it washes spores off the plant which dies on landing in water.
- Apply Bacillus subtilis BS-01x10 to power 10 cfu/ml (Real Bacillus subtilis), before disease onset and repeat fortnightly until mid harvesting time
- Spray using baking powder solution at 1 teaspoon in 1L water

- Use protective clothing when handling insecticides
- Follow product label instructions
- Ensure proper spray coverage of flowers and foliage
- Alternate fungicides with different modes of action to prevent pathogen populations from developing resistance

- Spray Bupirimate 250EC (e.g Trustmate 250EC, 40-60ml per 20L of water. 2-3Lper hectare; 7-14 days after disease onset), fortnightly. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI 0, REI 12 hours
- Spray Sulphur 80% w/w at 30g/10ltrs water, e.g. Thiovit Jet, Cosavet DF, Flosul Plus, Wetsulf WP; FRAC code M2. Apply fortnightly after disease onset until mid harvesting time. General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous); Apply fornightly after disease sets in

Images.Caption: Pale white spots on leaves (Source: www.maine.gov.dacf)
White powdery colonies on cucurbit stem (Source: Plantdoctor.eastwestseeds.com)

Authors.Surname: V. Mwaja (Chuka University), J. Maina (Kenyan Agriculture & Livestock Organisation), H. Mwangi (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean pasture seed to reduce the chance of contamination
- Avoid movement of livestock through infested areas to prevent spread of seed
- Prevent water runoff from infested land to non-infested land
- Maintain a regular weeding regime before the plants grow big in order to facilitate uprooting
- Remove Prosopis from roadsides, wastelands, field boundaries and other areas that serve as source of infestation

- Perennial,woody shrub 3-5m or tree growing up to 15m height. Bark rough grey-green, becomes scaly with age. Often multi-stemmed, especially following cutbacks, with abundant large and very sharp thorns (up to 5cm). Leaves doubly-divided composed (6-8cm long), 12-25 pairs of oblong leaflets per leaf. Flowers fragrant golden-yellow, dense spikes about 5-10cm long. Fruits cylindrical or slightly irregularly curved green pods which turns yellow upon ripening (10-20cm long) containing 10-20 hard oval or elliptic, brown seeds
- Regularly check edges of waterbodies, grazing areas and animal gathering areas and consider direct control if present
- Check for growth of trees where there are animal dropping/dungs since seeds pass through animal dungs and germinate
- Check fields for infestation and consider direct control during when observed in the field

- Hand pulling is effective on seedlings up to 20cm in height
- Cutting is effective before seed production. Application of glyphosate to the cut stump may prevent re-sprouting
- Uprooting trees or cutting 10-15cm below ground to remove crown in order to prevent coppices
- Follow up weeding consistently to achieve longer term control

- Use of chemical herbicides may lead to the development of herbicide resistance
- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval

- Glyphosate (6l/ha) can be used as a spot treatment to prevent re-sprouting after cutting the stumps. General Restrictions: Glyphosate WHO Class III (slightly hazardous)
- Apply 2,4 -D amine, at 2l/ha foliar application to actively growing seedlings. General Restrictions: 2,4-D WHO Class II (moderately hazardous)
- Cut the Prosopis and apply Tordon (Picloram 65g/l + 2,4-D 240g/l) mixed with diesel using low pressure sprayer targeting the stump to kill the roots. General Restrictions: Tordon WHO Class II (moderately hazardous) (Picloram WHO Class U (unlikely to present acute hazard under normal use)); 2,4-D WHO class II (moderately hazardous))
- . General Restrictions: Allow 48 hrs before grazing livestock.

Images.Caption: Coppicing Prosopis (Eschen/CABI)
Dense infestation (Eschen/CABI)

Authors.Surname: B. Ita (Kenya Agricultural & Livestock Research Organisation), W. Kouko (KALRO), V. Momanyi (KALRO).

Sections.Value:
- Use certified seed to reduce chances of field contamination
- Seeds are transported by water - Prevent runoff water from infested land to avoid seed introduction
- Seeds are spread by vehicles, animals, tools and workers - do not graze livestock in affected area, clean tools after work to avoid spread
- Plant resistant/tolerant Sorghum varieties e.g. Serena, Seredo, Serenex, Yatta landraces (MY146, MY 183, MY 95-Z) or ICSV 1112BFNamonimbri and 1S9830
- Apply well composted organic fertilizers and irrigate during dry periods so that plants don’t get stressed
- Practice crop rotation with non-host crops such as legumes, cotton, sweet potatoes, cassava among others and/or practice agroforestry (Sesbania sesban) techniques which provide leaves that mulch

- Additional relevant crops: all cereal crops including sugar cane, Napier grass - fodder crop
- Annual, broadleaved, parasitic herb (30-100cm high); erect, sometimes creeping. Always associated with host in the grass family. Stems are four-sided, branched or unbranched with rough hairs and opposite leaves. Leaves green (2-8cm long), narrow, sparsely covered in rough hairs. Flowers bright pink, rose-red and/or white (1cm long), arranged in spikes (6-10 flowers per spike)
- Look for yellowish blotches in crop foliage about 1 cm long by 0.5 cm wide, even if the weed has not emerged. Uprooting may confirm the presence of young parasite seedlings on the root
- Look for stunted crop growth, curling of leaves and drought stress appearance
- Check for stunting and wilting, at later stages look for weeds with purple flowers. Take direct action after one striga plant is seen

- Striga infestations can be controlled by continous uprooting and burning before flowering and seed setting to reduce seed bank
- Growing trap-crops (those that stimulate suicidal germination but do not host the parasite) such as cotton, groundnuts, cowpeas, soya beans, Desmodium
- Improved soil fertility is a vital key to long-term control, whether by organic, inorganic or green manuring
- Avoid seed set by uprooting, as seeds stay viable for up to 25 years and seed production is prolific
- Hoe or hand weed regularly starting two weeks after germination then weed again six to eight weeks thereafter

- Use of chemical herbicides may lead to the development of herbicide resistance.
- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.
- Apply 2,4-D on emerged weed to reduce Striga seed bank for the coming seasons at a rate of 1 L/ha. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous)

Images.Caption: Purple witchweed infestation (USDA APHIS PPQ - Oxford, North Carolina , USDA APHIS PPQ, Bugwood.org)
Purple witchweed on maize (USDA APHIS PPQ - Oxford, North Carolina, USDA APHIS PPQ, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Paul Kiige (MOALF), Eunice Ringera (KEPHIS), Philip Wendot  (UON) and Benson Masinde  (MOA), Peninah Munyao (MOALF), Judith Oyoo (KALRO), Wilson Nabakwe (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Plant clean seedlings free from infestation of the pest.
- Rotate with non-host crops such as maize, beans and cabbages
- Rogue and destroy by burning all infected crop residues and wild host plants such as Sodom apple.
- Clean all equipment used in transportation of tomatoes such as boxes, crates and trucks using soap and water

- Look out for:
• Silvery brown adult moth.
• Coalesced white to cream necrotic mines on both upper and lower parts of the leaf lamina.
• Green larvae with black head inside the tunnels.
• Silky web produced by the larvae to fold the leaf partially protecting older larval instars.
• Blighted and necrotic leaves on plants due to infestation.
• Puncture marks on fruit calyx with dried black frass at larvae exit hole and on stem.
- Take action once you notice 1-3 moths or larvae per week.

- Physically crush larvae by hand once sign of tunnelling is observed.
- Mass trap with pheromone water traps (e.g. Pherodis at 4 packets per acre supplied by Koppert Biological Systems Kenya, Tutrack found at Kenya Biologics)
- Bury infested fruits and foliage 50-100 cm deep.
- Use black sticky traps (at 24 pieces/acre supplied by Koppert Biological Systems) placed at 15-20 cm above the ground to capture the adults.
- Use screen vents in roofs and on the sides of the greenhouse to reduce insect pest migration.

- Always wear protective clothing when handling agrochemicals.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, maximum number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains.
- WHO class II pesticides might not be allowed in local IPM schemes.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).
- The pest is still new in the country and trials on pesticides are still ongoing

- Spinetoram (Radiant 120 SC at the rate of 180-300 mls/acre or 18-30mls/20L water). General Restrictions: WHO Class III, Blue colour band (Slightly hazardous), PHI 3 days
- Chlorantraniliprole (Coragen 20 SC at a rate of 5ml in 20L of water). General Restrictions: WHO class U, Green colour band (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use), MRL 0.05 Mg/Kg, PHI 3 day
- Flubendiamide (Belt 480SC at a rate of 4 mls per 20L). General Restrictions: WHO Class II, Yellow colour band (Moderately hazardous), PHI 3 days

Images.Caption: Adult Tuta. (Source Marja van der Straten, NVWA Plant Protection Service, Bugwood.org)
Tuta larvae on tomato leaf. (Source: Marja van der Straten, NVWA Plant Protection Service, Bugwood)
Burnt leaf and mined fruit infested by Tuta larvae- (Source Maureen Kuboka)

Factsheets.Title: Tuta absoluta (tomato leaf miner) on Tomato

Authors.Surname: V. Mwaja (Chuka University), J. Maina (KALRO), H. Mwangi (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean seed to reduce the chance of contamination
- Seeds are transported by water - Prevent water runoff from infested land to prevent seed introduction
- Seeds are spread by animals - do not allow livestock into an affected area to avoid spread
- Seeds travel on machinery - clean equipment and vehicles after work in infested areas
- Crop rotation with non-hosts such as linseed, onion, cucumber or carrots, may help to deplete seed bank
- Avoid seed set, as the seeds are very long-lived
- Before planting, cover the soil with transparent plastic for four weeks to kill the weed seeds and germinating young seedlings

- Annual, herbaceaeous, succulent, parasitic plants that lack chlorophyll. 30-50cm tall but can exceed 100cm (especially in Ethiopia). Stems are un-branched, yellowish-brown, often tinged with purple. A root parasite seen only on host roots.
- Look for stunted crop growth and chlorosis

- Light infestations can usually be controlled by hand pulling or hoeing before seed is produced. Then bury them deep, at least 60 cm if possible
- Wash hands after handling the plants to prevent spread of seed

- Use of chemical herbicides may lead to the development of herbicide resistance.
- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

- Use glyphosphate when infestation is severe in order to prevent the estabshment of seed bank. This will kill the weed and the crop. Use 2L/ha. General Restrictions: Glyphosate is WHO Class III (slightly hazardous)

Images.Caption: Flowering shoot (© Chris Parker)
Orobanche minor parasitizing tobacco plant (© Chris Parker)

Authors.Surname: W.O. Kouko, V.N. Momanyi, B.N. Ita (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Only use certified seed to avoid introduction through contamination
- Practice zero tillage in infested fields where possible, to prevent spread of the weed
- Restrict movement of seeds and fragmented rhizomes to uninfested area through cultivation implements (clean after use) and runoff water
- Practice crop rotation with legumineous crops, cassava, cotton and other perrenial crops
- Plant cover crops such as beans, sweet potatoes, pumpkins and Dolichos lablab to prevent spread and suppress the weed

- Perennial grass with long, slender, branching rhizomes which form a dense mat beneath the soil surface. Leaves flat bluish-green colour, up to 15 cm long and 2-8 mm wide. Inflorescences branched with 2 to 25 upwardly pointing, 2-11cm long flower heads ('branches')
- Check for the presence of rhizomes in the fields by digging upto 20 cm. Monitor spread from fallow land or hedges
- Monitor for young seedlings before they establish and mature. Leaves bare a conspicuous membranous legule at the junction of leaf sheath and blade

- Tillage with forked hoe; ensure complete removal of rhizomes
- Mechanical tillage with tractor to expose rhizomes on the soil surface to facilitate desiccation
- Intense use of field by poultry may reduce infestation

- Use of chemical herbicides may lead to the development of herbicide resistance.
- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval.

- Apply Glyphosate (20mL per litre of water), a systemic herbicide, to eradicate couch grass. Apply at 2L/ha. General Restrictions: Prolific growth of annual broad-leaved weeds occur where D. abyssinica has been controlled with glyphosate. Glyphosate is WHO Class III (slightly hazardous)

Inflorescence of East African couchgrass (© Forest and Kim Starr)
Flower and leaf (© Chris Parker)

Authors.Surname: B N Ita, V N Momanyi, W O Kouko (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant certified Maize seed to prevent introduction of weed seeds
- Avoid grazing animals in affected areas to prevent spread of the weed and poisoning of the animals
- Use clean machines and clean water source for irrigation to prevent weed seed spread
- Prevent runoff water from infested land into clean fields by making cutoff drains
- Maintain a regular weeding regime in crops (general crop sanitation)
- Use Basal P and Top dress with nitrogen to boost maize health
- Use properly decomposted manure to avoid introduction of weeds
- Grow legumineous cover crops with maize to cover the soil
- Consider pre-emergence chemical control if there is concern that seed infestation has occurred or if seedlings are present
- Rotation with root, tuber and legumineous crops

- Annual erect broadleaved herb, 0.5-1.5 m high. Leaves pale green and covered with short stiff hairs. Rosette and lower stem leaves deeply divided and large; upper stem leaves are shorter and less divided. White small compact flower heads (about 5 mm across) at the tips of branches, each flowerhead has 5 distinctive "petals".
- Parthenium is prevalent along Kenyan roads, pasture fields and arable land
- Regularly check edges of waterbodies, grazing places and vehicle tracks for rosettes
- Check for rosettes after periods of rain as seeds depend on high moisture to germinate
- Check fields for infestation and consider removal of all germinated Parthenium weeds (even if it is one) per acre

- Continous removal of Parthenium weeds using hand gloves, long-sleeved clothed and a mask to avoid contact with skin and respiratory tract since it causes allergic reactions
- Deeply bury the weed (up to 60 cm) to prevent future additional weed seeds into the soil and stop seed spread
- Conduct continous mechanical/manual weed removal when infestation even if there is one plant/acre
- Uproot plants or remove flowering stems before flowering to prevent seed set
- Avoid removal only by burning, mowing, slashing and ploughing as this may promote spread
- Use and distribute established biocontrol agents such as Zygogramma bicolorata
- Grow competitors, such as Cassia spp. (e.g. C. tora, C. uniflora, C. occidentalis) and Tagetes spp. (e.g. T. erecta)

- Use of chemical herbicides may lead to the development of herbicide resistance
- Always consult with Pest Control Products Board (PCPB) for registered list of availed herbicides
- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval

- Use 2, 4- D amine salt post emergence herbicides to control the weed in maize monocrop applied once at 3 - 4 weed leaf stage. If rains continues and more weeds grow then a second application is necessary (2l/ha). General Restrictions: 2,4-D: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous)
- Use Linuron for pre emergence control of the weed (1.5kg/ha). General Restrictions: Linuron: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous)

Images.Caption: Parthenium weed in flower. (Photo by Arne Witt, CABI)
Lower stem leaves are deeply divided and large. (Photo by Arne Witt, CABI)

Authors.Surname: W O Kouko, B N Ita, V N Momanyi (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Use certified seed to reduce chances of field contamination
- Seeds are transported by water - Prevent runoff water from infested land to prevent seed introduction
- Seeds are spread by animals - do not allow livestock into an affected area to avoid spread
- Seeds travel by vehicles, human beings, animals and on machinery - clean equipment after work in infested areas
- Obtain striga tolerant varieties from the research centre KALRO-Mwea
- Practice crop rotation with non-host crops such as legumes, cotton, sweet potatoes, cassava among others and/or practice agroforestry (Sesbania sesban) techniques which provide leaves that mulch.

- Annual, broadleaved, parasitic herb (30-100cm high); erect, sometimes creeping. Always associated with host in the grass family. Stems are four-sided, branched or unbranched with rough hairs and opposite leaves. Leaves green (2-8cm long), narrow, sparsely covered in rough hairs. Flowers bright pink, rose-red and/or white (1cm long), arranged in spikes (6-10 flowers per spike)
- Look for yellowish blotches in crop foliage about 1 cm long by 0.5 cm wide, even if the weed has not emerged. Uprooting may confirm the presence of young parasite seedlings on the root
- Look for stunted crop growth

- Light infestations can usually be controlled by hand pulling or hoeing before seed is produced
- Growing trap-crops (those that stimulate suicidal germination but do not host the parasite) such as cotton, groundnuts, cowpeas, soya beans, Desmodium
- Improved soil fertility is a vital key to long-term control, whether by organic, inorganic or green manuring
- Avoid seed set, as seeds stay viable for up to 25 years
- Uproot Striga before flowering. Striga is highly prolific, one capsule producing over 500 seeds

- Use of chemical herbicides may lead to the development of herbicide resistance.
- Improved soil fertility is a vital key to long-term control, whether by organic, inorganic or green manuring
- 2,4-D may be used to kill emerged S. hermonthica or to prevent it from maturing and setting seed in rice monocrop (2L/ha). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous)

Images.Caption: Purple witchweed infestation (USDA APHIS PPQ - Oxford, North Carolina, USDA APHIS PPQ, Bugwood.org)
Purple witchweed on maize (USDA APHIS PPQ - Oxford, North Carolina, USDA APHIS PPQ, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: V. Mwaja (Chuka University) ,J. Maina (KALRO), H. Mwangi (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant certified Maize seed to prevent introduction of weed
- Avoid grazing animals in affected areas to prevent spread of seeds and plant fragments and poisoning of the animals
- Use clean machines and clean water source for irrigation to prevent weed seed spread
- Prevent runoff water from infested land into clean fields by making cutoff drains
- Maintain a regular weeding regime in crops (general crop sanitation)
- Use Basal P and Top dress with nitrogen to boost maize health
- Use properly decomposted manure to avoid introduction of weeds
- Intercrop with cover crops such as Dolichos lablab, cowpeas and beans to cover the soil

- Annual succulent herb with tap root, common in annual and perennial crops at the roadside ans on wasteland. Plants are reddish in colour, up to 50cm tall, stems are prostrate, round and hairless; can form dense mats. Leaves thick (2-3cm long) and smooth, clustered at the end of branches. Flowers yellow (8-10mm) with 5 petals. Fruit capsule (4-8mm) containing many small oval, black seeds. Propagated by seed and stem fragments
- Regularly check the farm for small plant fragments and plantlets; control to prevent establishment

- Handweeding with a hoe
- Uproot plants or remove flowering stems before flowering to prevent seed set
- Deeply bury the weed in a pit (approx 1m deep) to prevent future spread

- Use of chemical herbicides may lead to the development of herbicide resistance
- Always consult with Pest Control Products Board (PCPB) for registered list of availed herbicides
- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing and follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval

- Use 2,4-D amine salt post emergence to control the weed in maize monocrop (2L/ha). Apply once at 3 - 4 weed leaf stage. If rains continue and more weeds grow then a second application is necessary. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous)
- Use Linuron (1.5kg/ha) for pre-emergence control of the weed. General Restrictions: Apply once at pre emergence stage (weed and crop). Planting of other crops such as beans will be restricted (6 months). Linuron: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous)
- Bentazon can be used if maize is intercroppped with beans as a broad application or glyphosate for spot treatment of patches. General Restrictions: Bentazon WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), Glyphosate Class III (Slightly hazardous)

Images.Caption: Portulaca oleracea (Photo by Russ Kleinman)
Portulaca oleracea seeds (Photo by discoverlife.org)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant rice cultivars
- Before transplanting, cut the leaf-top to reduce carry-over of eggs from the seedbed to the field
- Practise early and synchronised planting to avoid damage at the most susceptible stages (tiller elongation and panicle extensions), and maintain proper crop spacing
- Avoid excess use of nitrogenous fertilizers as high rates favour population build-up
- Avoid water stagnation in the field
- Conserve natural enemies such as dragonflies, spiders, carabids beetles, parasitic wasps by reducing the amount of insecticides used
- Remove stubble, volunteer rice and wild grasses around nurseries and planting areas
- Harvest crops at ground level to remove the larvae in stubble
- After harvest, burn crop residues or feed to livestock
- Practise crop rotation (e.g. legumes/vegetables)

- Monitor weekly from seedling to harvest for the presence of the insect and damage symptoms:
• Look for egg masses on the leaf tips and on the underside of the leaves
• During vegetative stage, larvae bore at the base of the plants, killing growing points and resulting in deadheart (central tiller dries up and is easily pulled from the base)
• During reproductive stage, larvae bore through the upper nodes and feed toward the base resulting in whiteheads (emerging panicles are whitish and empty)
• Larvae leave tiny holes on the stems and tillers, and frass inside the damaged stems
- Damage may be confused with that caused by rats, neck blast or black bug diseases. To confirm stem borer damage, pull and dissected stems to find larvae or pupae
- Take control measures when 10-15% of plants/m2 show damage 40 days after planting

- Handpick and destroy egg masses at seedbed and transplanting stages
- After transplanting seedlings, place pheromone traps (@3/acre) or light traps (@12/acre) between 7-9pm to control adult moths in the field
- Raise level of irrigation water periodically to submerge the eggs deposited on the lower parts of the plant
- Spread or release natural enemies if available in your country such as the parasitoids Cotesiaspp., Trichogrammaspp., and Pediobius furvus
- Remove and destroy deadhearts and whiteheads
- Plough and flood after harvest to destroy dormant stem borer caterpillars
- Attacks result from infestation by more than one species and IPM programmes should be adapted according to differences in biology and ecology, and local conditions

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult Chilo suppressalis (Merle Shepard)
Scirpophaga incertulas caterpillars (IRRI)
Boring damage of Scirpophaga incertulas causing whiteheads (NBAIR)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant varieties if they are available in the region
- Select varieties that flower early or all flower at the same time as a long flowering period can significantly increase the midge population in an area
- Uniform planting (i.e. planting on the same day and at the same depth) to ensure even flowering, and early planting will reduce the damage caused
- Remove alternative hosts, such as wild sorghum, Johnson grass and Sudan grass, from in and around the field to prevent midge population build-up early in the season
- Plant at a high density to reduce the number of insects per plant or area
- Intercropping sorghum with a legume
- Destroy crop residues after harvest to prevent the pest from carrying over to the following season
- Rotate sorghum with non-host crops or leave the field fallow the next season to break the build-up of the pest in the field
- Conserve habitat (e.g. flowering plants on the borders of field) to build-up populations of natural enemies (parasitic wasps of the Eupelmus, Eupelmidae, Tetrastichus and Aprostocetus families)

- Monitor field weekly during the production season and daily during flowering as populations of midge begin to build-up during that period
• Adult: mosquito-like appearance insect of about 3 mm long with a bright orange body, transparent wings and very long antennae. Count adult on flowering heads at about mid-morning
• Eggs: very small, cylindrical and transparent light-red colour, and are deposited into the flowering spikelets
• Young larvae: colourless, but turn dark-orange as they develop
- Larvae: feed on developing seeds causing malformation of the grain and empty or chaffy heads and blighted or blasted looking panicles (or heads)
• Pupa: a small empty, clear or white pupa casing (or skin) is left attached to the tip of the spikelet and can be seen with the naked eye.
- Squeeze damaged spikelets between fingers to monitor the presence of larvae (they will produce red ooze as the larva or pupa being crushed)
- Take control measures when an average of one adult midge per head is observed after 20-30% of the heads begin to bloom
- Remove and destroy chaffy spikelets to stop the spread of the pest

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Severe S. sorghicola damage (above) (Keith M. Harris)
Adult on sorghum bloom (Alton N. Sparks, Jr., University of Georgia, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Peninah Munyao (MOALF), Mary Mendi (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant certified disease free seeds
- Rotate with non-Solanaceae crops e.g. maize
- Weed to remove alternative hosts of the disease
- Water at the base to keep foliage dry
- Water early in the morning to allow plants to dry if using overhead irrigation
- Harvest fruit promptly to avoid overipening

- Additional relevant crops: eggplant, potato, pepper, curcurbits
- Look out for:
• Small, slightly sunken, water-soaked circular spots on fruit that are starting to ripen
• Enlarged lesion that becomes more depressed, central portion darkens as the disease progresses
• A large rotten area that has resulted due to merging of the lesions
• Yellow spots with tan centre on lower leaves that eventually wilt and turn gray brown
- Take action when disease is spotted on one plant
- Rogue infected plants and bury

- When using a pesticide always wear protective equipment.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).

- Spray with Azoxystrobin based products eg Ortiva @20mls/20L,. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class U: (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use); PHI 28 days; restricted re-entry interval 1 day after spray; Max 2 sprays per season; Toxic to fish, predatory beneficial mites, and soil organisms such as earthworms. Do not pour chemical into river, dams or ponds
- Spray with mancozeb based products e.g. Oshothane @ 50gms/20L of water, Ivory@40-80gm/20L, Farmcozeb@40-80g/20L, Dithane @40-80g/20L. General Restrictions: WHO class III (Slightly hazardous) and PHI 5 days, MRL 3mg/kg,REI 24 hrs
- Spray with chlorothalonil based products e.g. daconil @ 72ml/20L, Twigathalonil @ 40ml/20L, Ranko @ 40g/20L, Koban@40g/20L. Apply as soon as you see the disease at 7 to 14 days interval. Apply as soon as conditions are favourable for disease outbreak . General Restrictions: WHO class U (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use) Very toxic to fish and aquatic organisms, do not spray near water or ditches

Images.Caption: Colletotrichum coccodes (anthracnose) symptoms (Clemson University - USDA Cooperative Extension Slide Series, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Samuel Mburu (MOALF), Eunice Sakong (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Jacob Ndungu (MOALF), Cyrus Njoroge (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Prune to improve air circulation
- Plant at recommended spacing (short varieties at 6m x 6m and tall varieties at 8m x 8m)
- Plant healthy seedlings from certified nurseries
- Maintain clean orchard by removing broken branches and fallen leaves that may be infected
- Keep the orchard weed free to eradicate alternate hosts

- Additional relevant crops: roses, snow peas, mangoes
- Look out for:
• Characteristic powdery, white, spore bearing growth on the lower surface of leaves
• Premature leaf fall for the infected leaves
• Dark reticulate markings which appear from the upper side of the leaf as yellowish area as the white mildew disappears
• Flower abortion in severe infection
- Take action when 5 leaves per shoot are infected

- Remove and destroy all infected plant parts by burning
- Don't apply fertilizer or manure until the problem is corrected as powdery mildew favours young succulent growth/leaves
- Spray weekly with a mixture of one part milk to two parts water

- When using a pesticide always wear personal protective equipment
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)
- Start spraying at onset of flower formation and continue untill fruit formation. Ensure flowers are completely covered by fungicide

- Carbendazim 275g/L + Flusilazole 125g/L e.g. Discovery 400 SC at 8-15 ml/20L of water, Pearl 500 EC at the rate of 20ml/20L of water. General Restrictions: Carbendazim WHO Class U (unlikely to present acute hazard in nomal use), MRL 0.5mg/kg. Flusilazole WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), MRL 0.02mg/kg. PHI 14 days
- Azoxystrobin 250g/L e.g. Ortiva SC at the rate of 20ml/20L water AMISTAR TOP 325 EC at the rate of 15ml in 20L of water). General Restrictions: WHO Class U (unlikely to present acute hazard in nomal use), PHI 14 days, REI 14 days. MRLs 0.7mg/kg
- Difenoconazole 250g/L e.g. Domain 25% EC at the rate of 8-15ml in 20L water. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately Harzardous), PHI 14 days, REI when spray dries. MRLs 0.07mg/kg

Images.Caption: Courtesy EcoPort (http://www.ecoport.org): Kranz J.)

Authors.Surname: Jonathan M. Gekone (MOALF), Stephen Koech (KALRO) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid water logging by planting on raised beds or ridges
- Rotate with leguminous crops such as beans and cereal crops such as maize for three seasons to avoid build-up of the disease innoculum
- Avoid injury of crop while carrying out field operations as these will be form entry points of the disease
- Avoid overhead irrigation to minimize soils splash that spreads disease
- Avoid harvesting during warm and moist weather

- Additional relevant crops: turnip, rutubaga, broccoli and cauliflower.
- Monitor the crop daily by looking for:
• Water soaked lesions which spread rapidly over and into the head, becoming soft, mushy and dark in colour emmiting an offensive smell
- Take action after one plant is affected

- Harvest the healthy crop first and store in a cool, airy and disinfected store
- Remove and destroy by ploughing-in all diseased debries
- Uproot and carry away infected plants in a container to avoid spilling the affected soil.
- Apply wood ash in the affected holes after uprooting plants

- When using pesticides, wear protective gear and follow the instructions on the product label and safely dispose empty containers
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)
- Disinfect all farm tools by dipping in 10% jik solution (3.85% sodium hypochlorite) at 50ml per litre of water for at least 5 minutes

- Spray with copper based fungicides e.g. Copper oxychloride (Amicop 50WP and Cobox 50WP at 60gms/20L of water) and Copper Hydroxide (Cuprocaffaro Micro 37.5 WG and Kocide DFat 50gms/20L of water) to minimize bacterial infection. . General Restrictions: WHO II (Moderately hazardous) PHI 7 days

Images.Caption: Bacterial soft rot on cabbage (Photo: Bernard Sakwa, MoALF, Kenya)

Authors.Surname: Esther Macharia, Eston Njeru and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant certified seed free from bacterial spot pathogen
- Rotate with non-host crops such as maize, beans and peas for at least two seasons
- Remove severely infected plants
- Keep crop weed-free
- Maintain optimal soil fertility to increase crop vigour
- Observe recommended plant spacing to optimize aeration
- Destroy infected plant debris after harvesting

- Additional relevant crops: tomato, potato, pepper, Asian vegetables, melon
- Look out weekly for:
• Small, yellow-brown, water-soaked lesions with brown-black necrotic centres on above ground plant parts
• Leaves with sunken upper surfaces and raised lower surfaces
• Small, circular green lesions on fruit surfaces which turn brown, crack and roughen with age
- Take action when 5% of plants are infected in 100 plants
- Uproot and burn severely infected plants

- Wear protective clothing when handling pesticides
- Carefully follow label instructions
- Dispose pesticide containers responsibly

- Spray bronopol 27% e.g. Enrich BM (P) ® at the rate of 0.25-0.75kg per acre at the onset of disease and repeat forty nightly. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (moderately harzardous): Preventive foliar application
- Spray using copper based fungicides e.g. Kocide 101, Kocide DF or Nordox 75WG, at the rate of 0.7kg to 1.4kg per acre. General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately harzardous). PHI - 1 day. Repeat Spraying forty nightly

Images.Caption: Symptoms of bacterial spot (Photo: Paul Bachi, University of Kentucky Research and Education Center, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Esther Macharia, Eston Njeru and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Locate seedbeds and also grow black nightshade where bacterial wilt has not occurred before
- Do not grow plants below infected sloping fields
- Practice crop rotation every 3 years with non-host plants like onions
- Apply organic manure to suppress the pathogen in the soil to maintain soil PH above 6.2
- Stop run-off water from infected areas from getting into to clean areas by cutting trenches.
- Keep field weed free

- Additional relevant crops: Irish potato, tomato, eggplant, tobacco, banana, peppers
-  Look out for:
• Wilted terminal leaves
• Rapid wilting and death of the entire plant without any yellowing or spotting of leaves
- Cut the stem of the wilted plant across and note the pith with a darkened water-soaked appearance, and a greyish, slimy ooze on pressing the stem
- Whitish bacterial ooze will appear when the cut stem is placed in a glass of water
- Take immediate action when one diseased plant is noticed

- If only a few plants are affected, uproot them and destroy by burning or burying at 2 feet depth
- Ensure workers start working from disease-free areas before moving to affected ones
- Disinfect all farm tools by dipping in 10% jik solution (3.85% sodium hypochlorite) at 50ml per litre of water for at least 5 minutes
- Suspend field operations when the leaves are wet
- Solarize soils by covering with clear polythene in hot weather for 1 month

- Always wear personal protective equipment when handling pesticides.
-  Follow the instructions on the product label, including rate and timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Consult the most recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB) always

- Fumigate soil using Metam sodium at the rate of 1.1L per 12 L water per 10 sq m and cover with 7-15cm of moist soil. General Restrictions: Apply immediately after mixing by a trained techncian. WHO Class II (moderately harzardous) Plant an indicator crop such as lettuce 7 days before nightshade. Enter treated field after 48 hours of application
- spray using copper based pesticides ( Kocide 101, Kocide DF or Nordox 75 WG) at 60gm/20l of water every ten days . PHI -1 day. General Restrictions: WHO Class III ( slightly hazardous), Start spraying copper based fungicides at knee-high if the plants are healthy or or at the onset of first BW symptom on the first plant to suppress the spread of disease

Images.Caption: Wilting due to bacterial infection (www.plantvillage.com)

Authors.Surname: Mary Mendi (MOALF), Peninah Munyao (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Use disease free planting material
- Don't source planting materials from areas that have the disease
- Don’t leave tubers for more than nine months in the soil since chances of getting the virus increase
- Discourage multiplication of susceptible varieties e.g. TME204 and TME14
- Sterilize farm tools using jik 3.85% solution (sodium hypochlorite) at the rate of 50mls in 1 lt of water
- Plant CBSD tolerant varieties e.g. MH95/0183, MM96/4271, MH95/0183, SS4, MM/0293 (KARLO)

-  Look out for:
• Chlorosis with featherly pattern on the mature leaves
• Upper potion of stem with brown streaks with necrotic lesion on the leaf scar
• Fruits with black blotches unevenly distributed over the pericarp
• Misshapen roots with fissures
• Black or brown necrotic lesions in the starch storage organ
- Daily monitor for the presense of white flies since they are the main vectors.
- Take action when one whitefly is noticed

- Uproot and burn infected plants
- Intercrop cassava with maize, beans or sunflower as trapcrops for the whiteflies, a key vector of CBSD
- Disinfect farm tools using jik 3.85% solution (sodium hypochlorite) @ 50mls in 1 lt of water
- Spray using Neemros (0.05% azadirachtin) at the rate 20-50ml/20lts and Neem EC (0.03% azadirachtin)
- Spray using Pyagro 4 EC (60ml/20 per 0.5 acre) from natural pyrethroids

-  When using a pesticide always wear protective equipment
-  Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray with alpha-cypermethrin based products, e.g. alfaguard 5-8mls/20lts, alfix 3-6mls/20lts, tata Alfa 3-6mlr /20lts . General Restrictions: WHO Class II, PHI 3days,
- Spray with Buprofezin based products (Apply 40% SC at the rate of 20-40mls per 20L water). General Restrictions: WHO Class III, PHI 3days,

Images.Caption: CBVS leaf symptoms (CABI)
CBSV constricted tubers (CABI)
CBSV stem (CABI)

Authors.Surname: Gekone J. M (MOALF), Rahab N. (MOALF) Magoti (KALRO), Njoroge C.N (MOALF), Stephen Koech (KALRO) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Remove all plant debris and weeds before planting
- Plough and harrow the field to expose eggs and grubs to predators and desiccation by the sun
- Ensure proper nutrition for a healthy crop for vigorous growth
- Ensure proper drainage to discourage multiplication of the pest
- Rotate with non-host plants such as sunflower, cabbages, Irish potatoes, sweet potatoes, etc.
- Use properly decomposed manure during planting. Cattle should not graze in field as the manure may attract the chafer grubs who will lay eggs in the manure

- Additional relevant crops: sorghum, millet, wheat, Napier grass, tobacco, potatoes, tomatoes, groundnuts, cabbages, etc.
- Look out for:
• white C-shaped larva with a brown head and three pairs of legs in the crop field. Scout for the larvae during the vegatative growth of the plants
• larvae in the soil as they feed on the roots of plants
• wilting of plants, irregular growth of crop, patches of tilted or lodged plants
- Initiate control measures when 2 grubs are found per cubic foot (i.e. 60 x 30 x 15 cm)

- Prune trees around the crop that attract adults beetles. Burn or destroy pruned limbs/stems to kill the adults
- Shake trees that harbour adult beetles for collection and destruction by burning. Visible larvae can also be picked and destroyed as well

- Use protective clothing
- Follow label instructions on the product
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides
- Ensure safe disposal of empty containers
- The below pesticides should be sprayed to the soil near the 1-2 week old maize crop to kill the larvae which stays in the soil

- Chemical control is rarely necessary for chafer grubs. However, one can spray using Chlorpyriphos based insecticides such as Bullet 48EC at 40mls/20L of water and Bulldock Star at 15mls/20L of water . General Restrictions: Chlorpyriphos is WHO class II, Moderately hazardous; PHI 14 days; MRLs 1.0mgs/kg;
- Spray Imidacloprid based insecticides (Tata Mida 200SL at the rate of 10mls/20L of water, Confidor 200SL at the rate of 10mls/20L of water etc.). General Restrictions: Imidacloprid WHO class III Slightly hazardous; PHI 3 days; MRLs 2mg/kg

Images.Caption: Phyllophaga (Dow AgroSciences)

Authors.Surname: Philip Wendot, Judith Oyoo, Paul Kiige (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Maintain optimum shade and soil moisture in the coffee orchard
- Plant coffee at altitude 800 m.a.s.l
- Don’t plant coffee trees with twisted taproots
- Remove crop residues and dispose off by burning during land preparation to reduce infestation on subsequent crop.
- Frequently weed to remove host plants such as volunteer coffee plants

- Look out for:
• Tunnels on the upper part of coffee branches
• Deposition of eggs in the cracks, crevices and the bark of the main stem
• Wilting and yellowing of leaves and death of branches
• Evidence of frass on the ground
- Take action when 5% of crop is affected

- Paste neem leaf extract on the stem twice a year. It should be applied at beginning of season
- Spray the main stem with neem kernel extract. Drench plants using azadirachtin (Achook® or Nimbecidine ®) at the rate of 50 ml in 20 L of water
- Spray 10% lime at a rate of 10 kgs in 100 litres of water.
- Use coffee stem borer Pheromone traps with Kairomone attractants. 8 per hactare
- Poke the lavae with a sharp wire inside the holes
- Prune and uproot the infested plants and destroy by burning
- Spray using entomopathogenic fungi such as Beauveria bassiana and Metarhizium anisopliae

- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing
- Follow the instructions on the product label suchas dosage, timing of application, and pre-harvest interval

- Spray with Fipronil insecticides at onset of rainy season e.g. Regent 50 SC or Mortel 5% SC at the recommended rates. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (moderately hazardous). REI when spray dries. MRL 0.01.

Images.Caption: White stem borer adult (FAO)
Coffee stem borer larva (CABI)

Authors.Surname: Peninah Munyao (MOALF), Mary Mendi (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant certified seeds and clean disease free seedlings
- Use sterile well drained soil mediums
- Mix top soil with thin coating of sand and gravel to improve drainage
- Avoid crowding of seedlings to ensure air ciculation
- Don’t overwater seedlings or leave them seated in water
- Avoid working with the plants when the soils are too wet
- Burn dry trash on a wet seedbed to sterilise it
- Avoid planting in previously affected areas

- Additional relevant crops: celery, cucumber, brassicas
- Look for symptoms daily during first 3 weeks after sowing
- Look out for:
• Sunken necrotic lesion girdling the stem near the soil line eventually leading to collapse and death of the plant
• Thin and tough stem of the seedling (wirestem) resulting in reduced seedling vigour
• Poor germination of seedlings in nurseries
• Fuzzy white substance on the surface of the damp soil
- Take action after one seedling is affected

- Remove and bury any infected seedlings immediately
- Drench with Trichoderma based products e.g. Trianum at 1:5 (Trianum to water), Rootguard, Trichotech, Ecot.

- When using a pesticide always wear protective equipment
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray with metalaxyl+mancozeb based products (e.g. Tata Master@50g/20l,Ridomil Gold 20g/20l, mancolax 200mg/20L. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) PHI 7-14 Days, REI 24 hrs.
- Spray using Propamocarb hydrochloride based products e.g. Previcur N Soluble concentrate @30-50ml/20l, Propeller 722 SL, soluble concentrate @60-120ml/20L. General Restrictions: WHO Class U PHI 3-7 days

Images.Caption: Damping off disease of kale (Edward Owiti - Dudutech IPM Solutions)
Rhizoctonia damping-off, blight and rot (Rhizoctonia solani) on tomato (Clemson University - USDA Cooperative Extension Slide Series, Bugwood.org)
Rhizoctonia damping-off, blight and rot (Rhizoctonia solani) on tomato (University of Georgia Plant Pathology, University of Georgia, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Peninah Munyao (MOALF), Wilson Nabakwe (MOALF), Peninah Munyao (MOALF), Mary Mendi (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Solarize the soil 5-6 weeks before planting the crop
- Plant disease free seedlings from certified nurseries such as KALRO-Thika, JKUAT, Good neighbours and other HCDA registered nurseries
- Plant seedlings grafted to wilt-resistant yellow passion fruit rootstocks
- Rotate passion fruit with maize, beans, cabbage, kales and non solaneceous crops
- Avoid injuring plant stems and roots; these serve as entry avenues for the pathogen
- Plant orchard in well drained soils
- Avoid planting a new orchard near a previously infected one as movement of soil from infected to new site may lead to spread of the disease

- Look for yellowing and drooping of leaves even when the soil has sufficient moisture
- Check for browning and vertical cracking of the collar region of the stem at ground level
- Disect the stem and check for a distinctive browning of vascular tissues
- Look for wilting of plant from the base upwards, defoliation and complete death of plant
- Take immediate action once one plant shows the signs

- Uproot and destroy infected plants by burning or burying
- Sterilize all farm tools especially during pruning with 2% jik solution (500 ml of jik in 20 litres of water)
- Control run off water from infected areas to clean areas to avoid spreading the pathogen
- Start working from disease free areas before proceeding to affected parts of the field
- Dip the roots of young seedlings in a bio pesticide containing Trichoderma e.g. Trianum P @1:5 (1 part Trianum:5 parts of water), Trichotech, during planting

- When using pesticides always wear protective clothing
- Always follow the instructions on the product label such as dosage, timing of application, PHI, maximum number of sprays, re-entry interval, etc.
- Always consult current list of registered pesticides

- Drench the soil with Propamocarb Hydrochloride based products e.g. Previcur N @50ml/ 20lts, Propeller@60-120ml/20L . General Restrictions: WHO Toxicity class U (unlikely to present acute hazard); PHI 7 days. Drench the soils before planting or during the observation of initial disease symptoms
- Drench the soil with Carbendazim + Mancozeb based products such as Saaf WP at the rate of 25g/ 20lts,Sherrif. General Restrictions: WHO Toxicity class III (slightly hazardous) PHI 7 days. Drench the soils before planting or during the observation of initial disease symptoms

Images.Caption: Fusarium wilt of passionfruit (Francis Nduati)
Symptoms on stem. The bark was removed to show the dark discoloration of the xylem (J.R. Liberato, DPI&F, Australia)

Authors.Surname: Samuel Mburu (MOALF) and Eunice Sakong (MOALF), Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Peter Kodwaran (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Rotate green grams with non-legumes such as maize, cabbages and pumpkins
- Remove crop residues and dispose off by burning during land preparation to reduce infestation on subsequent crop
- Sow early and use short season varieties such as N26 and KS 20
- Plant at recommended spacing (45cm x 15cm)
- Intercrop with maize, pearl millet or sorghum to offer a non-host alternative in the field
- Frequently weed to remove host plants such as volunteer legumes

- Additional relevant crops: cowpeas, beans, pigeon peas, dolichos lab lab, garden peas
- Look out for:
• Brown spots on older pods,entry holes on the flowers, buds or pods
• Flower and young pod drop prematurely
• Pupae which are brown in colour on the leaves, pods and soil
• Greenish larvae with a brown head and two pairs of dark spots on the back of each segment
• Signs of webbing on flowers and pods
- Take action when 5% of crop is affected

- Install bird perches at 20 perches per acre. Birds predate on the borers
- Collect infested pods and hand pick and destroy the borers by crushing
- Spray neem oil at 40ml/20L of water (Neemroc EC)
- Apply Bacillus thuringiensis var. kurstaki (e.g. Bio T Plus)

- When using a pesticide always wear personal protective equipment
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray Lambda-cyhalothrin 50g/L (Pentagon 5% EC at 10ml/20L water). General Restrictions: WHO Class II, Moderately hazardous, MRL: 0.1mg/Kg, PHI 5 days, REI: when spray dries
- Spray Profenofos 400g/L +Cypermethrin 40g/L (PROFILE 440 EC at 30ml/20L water). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) PHI 14 days, REI 12 hours
- Spray cypermethrin based products e.g Debush EC at the rate of 100mls/20L of water. Repeat after 10 days if problem persists . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) and PHI 1 day, MRL 0.3mg/kg
