- Spray with Spinosad (tracer 480 SC) at the rate of 4ml per 20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (slightly hazardous). PHI 7 days. Spray before flowering and repeat for weekily during flowering period. Ensure complete plant coverage

Images.Caption: Legume pod borer larva (Ooi P., courtesy of www.ecoport.org)

Authors.Surname: Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Jacob Ndungu (MOALF),Keneth Kagai (MOALF), Benson Masinde (MOALF) and Maurice Okeno (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Plant clean, certified seed free from pests
- Avoid planting in areas previously with alternate hosts e.g. sweet potato, other cucrbits, beans, brassicas, cassava, citrus plants, cotton, eggplant, green gram, mango, okra, papaya, peppers, pigeon pea, sesame, tomato
- Weed regulary to eliminate other hosts

- Additional relevant crops: beans, brassicas, cassava, citrus plants, cotton, cucumber, eggplant, green gram, mango, okra, papaya, peppers, pigeon pea, pumpkin, sesame, sweet potato, tomato, watermelon
- Look out for:
• Whitish-brown eggs and/or whitish adults on the underside of young leaves
• A cloud of 3-5 white insects after shaking the young leaves
• Yellowing symptoms on lower leaves of the trees
• A sticky substance (honeydew) which makes leaves appear shiny and sooty (black)
- The treatment threshold for watermelon whitefly is about 4 adults per leaf in a random 30-leaf sample of healthy leaves

- Use yellow traps to monitor the presence of whiteflies at a rate of 1-4 traps per 300 square metres
- Use reflective mulch (silver, yellow, and white/black plastic mulches) to repel adult whiteflies
- Plant coriander and Mexican marigold around the edge of the field to repel whiteflies
- Spray Azadirachtin 0.03% +Neem Oil based products (Neemroc EC) at a rate of 50mls in 20L of water
- Liquid soap at a rate of 100 ml per 20L can be applied to control the pest. In addition, this dosage can be mixed with a given pesticide to enhance its efficacy

- When using pesticides wear protective clothing, follow the instruction on the product label such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval maximum number of sprays restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray with Lambda-cyhalothrin, e.g. Karate 2.5 WG at 20g in 20L of water or Dududthrin 1.7 EC at 60ml in 20 L of water. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous) PHI 3 days. Toxic to fish and aquatic invertebrate.
- Spray with Alpha-Cypermethrin (Bestox 100Ec at 6 ml in 20 L of water or Tata alpha 10EC at 6ml in 20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO class II, (Moderately hazardous) PHI 3 days

Images.Caption: Silverleaf whitefly (Bemisia argentifolii) (Scott Bauer, USDA Agricultural Research Service, Bugwood.org)
Silverleaf whitefly (Bemisia argentifolii) on melon (Cucumis melo (Alton N. Sparks, Jr., University of Georgia, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Jonathan M. Gekone (MOALF), Stephen Koech (KALRO) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant tolerant vrieties (ICGV-SM89749, ICGV-SM 88710, Uganda stripe)
- Plant early to escape vector build-up
- Rotate with maize and sorghum to decrease vector presence
- Remove all alternative hosts such as Euphobia spp., volunteer groundnuts and all other weeds before planting

- Scout (once a week) for aphids starting 5 days after germination to 50% flowering
- Look out for:
• Yellowing, stunting, and bushy appearance on young plants while in older plants a few branches are affected
• Slight mottling of young leaves and chlorotic older leaves with green veins
- Take action when 10% of plants have 10 aphids (disease vectors) per plant

- Rogue and destroy all infected plants by burning or composting
- Spray against aphids (early or late in the day) with soap solution (1 teaspoonful of dishwashing soap in 4L of water) 2-3 times at 3-4 day intervals
- Place yellow sticky traps to kill winged aphids
- Spray using Azadirachtin (Neem) based products such as Achook at a rate of 20mls/20L of water

- Use protective gear when using a pesticides
- Follow the instructions on the product label and safely dispose empty containers
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray using lamda-cyhalothrin (pyrethroid) products (Duduthrin or Tata Umeme at 60mls/20L water) to control Aphids. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) and PHI 3 days
- Spray against aphids using Thiamethoxam (neonicotinoids), based products (Actara 25WG at a rate of 8gms/20L of water). General Restrictions: WHO class III (slightly hazardous) and PHI 7 days, thiamethoxam toxicity to bees and fish

Images.Caption: Yellowing young leaves (Photo: Eric Boa)

Authors.Surname: Jonathan M. Gekone (MOALF), Stephen Koech and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant varieties e.g. GLP 92 (pinto bean), super rose coco, Miezi Mbili, etc.
- Plant certified seed from certified dealers
- Remove and burn crop debris before planting
- Do a one month soil solarisation to kill bacterial innoculun in known infected soil
- Rotate with non leguminous crops e.g. maize, cabbages for 2-3 seasons
- Ensure proper crop nutrition to improve plant vigour
- Avoid field operations when the leaves are wet
- Intercrop beans with maize to prevent spread of the disease

- Additional relevant crops: lima beans, red kidney beans, snap beans, French beans
- Look out for:
• Small water-soaked spots under the leaves which increase in size to form a characteristic "halo" of yellow tissue around the spot
• Oval greasy water-soaked spots on pods which increase and turn slightly sunken reddish/brown in colour as it progresses
- Take action when one plant is affected
- Remove and destroy by burning or burying (at least 60cm deep) all infected plants and crop residues

- Use protective gear when using a pesticides
- Follow the instructions on the product label and safely dispose empty containers
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)
- Disinfect all farm tools by dipping in 10% jik solution (3.85% sodium hypochlorite) at 50ml per litre of water for at least 5 minutes

- To suppress the disease, spray copper oxychloride (cuprocaffaro micro 37.5 at a rate of 50gm/20litres water or Isacop 50WP at a rate of 60g/20litres of water). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) and PHI 1 day. P.H.I. 14 days, r.e.i. 3 days. Usually applied at 40-80 mg per 20 litres and, 2-4kg per hectare, but double-check with product label. When used too much, copper(II)-ions can accumulate in soil and water, it can burn leaves. Do not use during fruit set

Images.Caption: Bacterial blight of beans (Nilanka Herath, Department of Agriculture, Sri Lanka)

Authors.Surname: Thomas Kwambai (KALRO), Pauline Murithi (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Samuel Mburu (MOALF) and Peter Kodwaran (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Practice crop rotation with non-host plants like maize, sorghum or millet
- Destroy weeds and crop residues by deep ploughing
- Use a Tephrosia hedge to repel leaf miners from the crop
- Avoid high levels of nitrogen fertilization
- Conserve natural enemies (parasitic wasps and ladybird beetles) by providing hedge rows of flowering plants around the farm

- Additional relevant crops: tomato, French beans, soybeans, eggplant, pumpkin.
- Look out for:
• Thin, white, winding lines/tunnels on the leaves of plants
• Small yellow and black flies hovering around the crop
• The larva (maggots) that are often pale green or yellow in colour and can grow up to 3 mm long
• White puncture marks on leaves caused by adult laying eggs and they drop early
• Tunnels/irregular mines on the upper/lower surface of leaves both in the nursery and field
- Use direct control when you spot 7 larvae/plant or on 3 leaflets

- Rogue the affected seedling in nursery or defoliate the affected leaves. Dispose by burying 30 cm deep or burn to kill larvae.
- Destroy leaf miner pupae and crop residue by deep tilling
- Use 1 to 4 yellow sticky cards per 300 square metre field area to capture adult flies
- Spray azadirachtin at a rate of 50 ml in 20 litres of water (neemroc EC)
- Hand pick and destroy mined leaves especially in low infestation and those with the larvae still in the tunnel

- When using a pesticide always wear personal protective equipment
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)
- Chemical control should target the larvae. Spray when larvae are actively feeding on the leaves (in the tunnels)

- Use imidacloprid (confidor 70 WG or EMERALD Gold at 5g/20lt of water). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI 3 days
- Spray Chlorantraniliprole (Corragen 20 SC) at the rate of 2ml per 20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO class U, MRL 0.05Mg/Kg, PHI 3 days
- Abamectin at a rate of 10ml in 20 litres of water or 0.5 litres per hectare e.g. (Dynamec 1.8 EC or Abalone 18 EC or Romectin) at the rate of 10mls per 20lt, 0.5lts/ha. General Restrictions: PHI 3-7 days, MRLS 0.05mg/kg

Images.Caption: Tomato: Leafminers (Liriomyza sp.) (Scot Nelson, flikr.com)

Authors.Surname: Benson ngigi (MOALF), Philip Kibet (Kenyatta University) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plough early in the season to expose pupae in the soil
- Destroy crop debris at the end of cropping season to prevent build up of the leafminers
- Cover the soil with a transparent polythene for 1-2 months before planting to kill pupae in the soil
- Plant pest-free seedlings
- Remove weeds as they serve as a reservoir for leafminers
- Practice crop rotation with maize and other cereals

- Additional relevant crop: cabbage
- Look out for:
• Small dark flies on the leaves
• Irregularly shaped mines on the leaves caused by the larvae
• Black frass within the mines
• Wilting of the leaves in severe infestations
• Transparent/yellowish maggots at the broad end of the mines/tunnels
- Use yellow sticky traps for monitoring adults
- Take appropriate control measures when 5% of leaves are affected by the mines

- Hand pick and burn/compost the affected leaves
- Flood the soil to kill pupae
- Spray with neem based products - Nimbecidine @50ml/20L Achook @ 20ml/20L, Neemrok @ 20-50ml/20L
- Cover with plastic mulch -use colored polythene
- Use yellow sticky traps to control of adults

- When using a pesticide always wear suitable protective equipment.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).

- Spray with Thiocyclam- (Evisect@ 80 g/Acre, Taurus @10g/20L). General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous) PHI 3 Days. Max 3 applications per season. Re entry interval-12hrs
- Spray with Abamectin- (Dynamec @ 10ml/20L, Abalone @10-20g/20L). General Restrictions: Abamectin is not classified by WHO. Dynamec Phi 3 days, Abalone Phi 7 days

Images.Caption: Leaf miner damage to cabbage (James Kimani)
Leaf miner larvae (3mm) before they begin to tunnel into the leaf (Andrei Sourakov)

Authors.Surname: Benson ngigi (MOALF), Phillip Kibet (K.U) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant border rows of coriander (Dhania) or African marigold to repel the whiteflies
- Intercrop with Capsicum/cucumber to attract whiteflies away from the kale
- Avoid application of excess N fertilizers which increase cases of whiteflies
- Rotate kales with onions, coriander or cereals
- Keep the field weed free to eliminate alternate hosts
- Select and transplant healthy vigorous seedlings
- Conserve natural enemies like parasitic wasps by avoiding non selective chemical sprays

- Additional relevant crops: cabbage, tomato, potato, watermelon, pawpaw, beans, cotton, cucumber, eggplant, peppers
- Look out for:
• Honeydew excreted by the whiteflies on upper leaf surface
• Sooty molds growing on the honeydew
• A cloud of whiteflies which appear when the plant is shaken. The insects quickly settle back on the plant
• Yellowing of the infested leaves
- Place 2 yellow sticky traps/acre to monitor pest population
- Take control measures when 3-5 adults are seen on 10 plants

- Spray with neem based pesticides (Achook @ 20ml/20L, Neemrok @ 20-50 ml/20L, Neemraj super @ 20ml/20L)
- Remove heavily infested leaves and destroy by burning or burying at a depth 50 cm.
- Encarsiaformosa from Dudutech (Encartech®), and Beauveria bassiana (Bb plus®) by Juanco SPS Ltdcan can be used against whiteflies
- Spray with water to dislodge adults from the leaves
- Cover the soil with reflective plastic silver mulch/aluminium foil to repel adult flies
- Spray with hot pepper at rate of 30 chopped peppers in 1 L warm water. Soak for 1 day, dilute in 10 L water

- Dispose of pesticide containers appropriately and safely away from water ways and animals
- Follow the instructions on the product label and ensure use of protective equipment during pesticide application
- Always consult the PCPB list of registered pest products
- Spraying of the pesticide should be done when the crop is young and maturing and not when harvesting

- Spray with Imidacloprid (Emerald @10-15ml/20L, Confidor 200SL, Imax 200SL,and Tata Mida 200SL @ 10mls in 20 L) . General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous) PHI 7 Days. Re-entry interval=12hrs
- Spray lambda-cyhalothrin (Karate 2.5WG @ 20gms/20L, Duduthrin 1.7EC @ 60ml/20L). General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous) PHI 3 Days
- Spray with Abamectin+acetamiprid (Amazing Top @ 4g/20L). General Restrictions: Abamectin and Acetamiprid are not classified by WHO
- Spray alpha-cypermethrin (Bastox 100EC @ 6ml/20L , Tata Alpha 10EC @ 6ml per 20L). General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous) PHI 3 Days

Images.Caption: Adult white fly on underside of leaf. (source: Amada44, CC-BY-SA)
Adult white fly on underside of leaf. (source: Rasbak at nl.wikipedia CC-BY-SA)

Authors.Surname: Benson Msinde (MOALF), Maurice Okeno (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Remove plant debris, burn or bury 2 feet deep to destroy the eggs before establishing new crop
- Keep the field free of weeds in the orchards as they act as alternate hosts
- Plant coriander and Mexican marigold around the edge of the field to repel whiteflies
- Conserve natural enemies by avoiding spraying during flowering

- Additional relevant crops: beans, brassicas, cassava, citrus, cotton, cucumber, eggplant, green gram, mango, okra, papaya, peppers, pigeon pea, pumpkin, sesame, sweet potato, tomato, watermelon
- Look out for whitish-brown eggs and/or whitish adults on the underside of young leaves
- Shake the young leaves to observe a cloud of 3-5 white insects
- Check for yellowing symptoms on lower leaves of the trees
- Check for sticky substance (honeydew) which makes leaves appear shiny and sooty (black) with mold
- The treatment threshold for mango whitefly is about 4 adults per leaf in a random 30-leaf sample of healthy leaves

- Prune heavily infested parts of the tree and burn the debris
- Use yellow traps to monitor the presence of whiteflies at a rate of 1-4 traps per 300m2
- Spray Azadirachtin 0.03% +Neem Oil based products (Neemroc EC) at a rate of 50ml in 20L of water

- Wear protective clothing when using a pesticide
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)
- Wash hands after handling pesticides

- Spray with Lambda-cyhalothrin Karate 2.5 WG at 20g in 20L of water or Dududthrin 1.7 EC at 60ml in 20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO class II, (Moderately hazardous) PHI 3 days. Toxic to fish and aquatic invertebrates
- Spray with Alpha-Cypermethrin (Bestox 100Ec at 6ml in 20L of water or Tata alpha 10EC at 6ml in 20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO class II, (Moderately hazardous) PHI 3 days

Images.Caption: Aduly whitefly (Source: NBAIR)
Masses of whiteflies on mango leaves (Source: NBAIR)
Whiteflies on mango leaf (Source: Lenis Marani, MOALF, Kenya)

Authors.Surname: Benson W. Masinde (MOALF), Maurice Okeno (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant French beans/snow peas away from cotton and maize crops
- Remove and destroy plant residues immediately after harvesting
- Plough the soil after harvesting to expose pupae so that may be killed by natural enemies or by desiccation of the sun
- Avoiding planting crops after each other that are susceptible to bollworm like cotton, maize, sorghum, tobacco, soybean, and tomato to reduce/prevent build up of bollworm populations
- Rotate French beans with cereals like rice and crops of onion family

-  Regularly look for eggs and young caterpillars (larvae) with short hairs along their backs to control the pest early
- Look for circular holes through fruits/pods usually bored by the caterpillars
- Look out for faeces/waste of the feeding caterpillars being evident on damaged plant parts
- Take action after observing over 3-5 larvae or carterpillers in a sample of 100 plants

- Handpick and destroy eggs and small caterpillars
- Sort out the harvested crop very thoroughly and remove the caterpillars manually
- Grow maize as a trap crop at 10 m interval to reduce pod damage in French beans.
- Cover the crop using agronets from KALRO to reduce pest infestation on the crop

- Wear protective clothing while applying extract or pesticides
-  Follow instructions on the product label
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)
- Wash hands after handling pesticide

- Spray Deltamethrin 5g/L e.g. Decis 0.5 ULV 10-15 ml in 20 liters of water OR Atom 2.5 EC at rate of 10-15 mls in 20 liters of water. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous) PHI: 1 day
- Spray Bifenthrin 25g/L e.g. Biferan 25EC OR Seizer 80 SC at a rate of 20ml in 20 liters of water. . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous, Yellow colour band) PHI: 3 days

Images.Caption: African boll worm in French beans, 3-4 cm in length (A.M. Valera, ICIPE).
African bollworm damage on Bean pods (A. M.Varela, ICIPE)

Factsheets.Title: African bollworm on French beans and snow peas

Authors.Surname: Esther macharia and Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Boniface N. Ndung’u (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Plant resitant varieties such as new Rose coco, Miezi mbili, Kenya Early and Kabete Super
- Use clean bean seeds originating from non-diseased plants or from certified seeds dealers
- Plough deep to about 45 cm to turn residues into the soil
- Practice 2-3 years crop rotation with non-leguminous plants such as tomatoes, cabbages and kale
- Avoid entering or cultivating bean field when it is wet

- Additional relevant crops: French beans, runner beans, climbing beans
- Look out for:
• Brick-red to-dark brown sunken elongate lesions on the stems, leaf petioles and veins on the undersurface of the leaves
• Brick-red to dark-brown sunken and circular lesions on the pods
• Discoloured seeds which may have lesions
• Gelatinous masses of pinkish spores developing from infected areas during the moist weather

- Work on the healthy part of the field first before the infected area
- Avoid unnecessary movement in the infected areas to minimise spread of the disease
- Disinfect farm implements after working from one field before proceeding to the other

- When using a pesticide always wear personal protective equipment
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)
- Alternate fungicide spray after 7 days

- Spray with Flutriafol 125/L based product such as Jupiter 125CS. General Restrictions: WHO class III - slightly hazardous, PHI - 7 days, MRL - 0.05mg/kg
- Spray with Tebuconazole based product such as Ducasse 250g/L EW. General Restrictions: WHO class III - slightly hazardous, PHI - 14 days, MRL - 0.014mg/kg
- Spray with Bifenoconazole based products such as Domain 25% at 250g/L. General Restrictions: WHO class U

Images.Caption: Brick red to brown, circular splotches on pods (David B. Langston, University of Georgia, Bugwood.org)
Brick red to brown, irregular elongate lesions leaf veins (David B. Langston, University of Georgia, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Jacob Ndungu (MOALF), Kenneth Kagai (MOALF), Samuel Mburu (MOALF), Peter Kodwaran (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Keep the field free of weeds and volunteer crops (pumpkin, tomato, cucumber, passion fruit, cowpeas) that may host insect vector
- Avoid over-crowding of plants and plant early to avoid exposure to main aphid flight period
- Use plastic reflective mulches to deflect insect vectors
- Practice crop rotation with maize, sorghum, sweet potatoes, coriander

- Additional relevant crops: pumpkin, cucumber, bananas, carrots, cowpeas, lupine, lilies, onions, passion fruit, potatoes and tomatoes
- Look out for:
• Prominent light and green mosaic patterns
• Mottling and leaf/fruit malformation
• Wrinkled or curled and stunted and dwarfed plants
• Presence of aphids and leaf miners that transmit the disease
• Leaf chlorosis (yellowing)
• Mottled green and yellow fruits that have dark green warts
- Take action when 1 plant in the field shows the sympoms

- Rogue and destroy by burning infected plants when symptoms first appear
- Disinfect farm implements before using in clean sections of the farm (use jik solution diluted at a ratio of 50 ml in 1L of water)
- Spray neem oil at 40ml/20L of water (Neemraj super and ozneem 1% EC)
- Use 1 to 4 yellow sticky cards per 300 m2 field area

- When using pesticides wear protective clothing, follow the instruction on the product label such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval maximum number of sprays restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)
- Insecticidal control of aphids vectors for this disease has a minimal effect on this disease spread in the crop as the virus is transmitted in a non-persistent manner

- Use imidacloprid (confidor 70 WG or EMERALD Gold at 5g/20L of water). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI 3 days
- Spray with Lambda-Cyhalothrin (Duduthrin Super at 15ml/20L Water or KARATE 2.5 WG at 25g/20L water). General Restrictions: WHO Class II, PHI-5 Days, MRLS-0.2mg/kg

Images.Caption: Leaf mosaic and distortion on WMV-2 infected watermelon (M.N. Pearson)
Fruit symptoms on WMV-2-infected rockmelon (HFRI of NZ)

Authors.Surname: Wilson Nabakwe (MOALF), Peninah Munyao (MOALF), Eston Njeru, Esther Macharia  and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant disease free seedlings from HCDA certified nurseries such as KALRO-Thika, JKUAT and Good neighbours (Bungoma)
- Keep the field weed free since weeds are alternate hosts for the vector
- Avoid planting cowpeas and cucurbits near a passionfruit orchard
- Control aphids at all growth stages (they transmit the causal virus)
- Prune starting from clean to infected plants

- Additional relevant crops: cucumber, pumpkin, cowpea, beans
- Look out for:
• Mosaic patterns, mottling, crinkling or distortion of leaves
• Plants with shortened internodes, bunching of foliage and stunted growth
• Small misshapen fruits with scabs, cracks, very hard rinds and small pulp cavity
- Initiate control measures on noting 1 colony aphids in 10 plants or 10% infected plants

- Uproot infected plants and burn or bury at least 2 feet deep
- Destroy infected prunings and fruits by burning
- Sterilize pruning tools with 10% jik solution (100 ml of jik in 1L of water)
- Spray aphids using a strong jet of water or insecticidal soap (1/4 bar of soap in 4L of water or 1 teaspoon of liquid soap in 4L of water)
- Spray aphids using azadirachtin (Neemark EC®, Neemraj Super® or Nimbecidine ®) at the rate of 50ml/20L of water) - PHI 1 day

- When using pesticides always wear protective clothing
- Always follow the instructions on the product label such as dosage, timing of application, PHI, maximum number of sprays, Re entry Interval e.t.c
- Always consult current list of registered pesticides

- Spray with Lambda-cyhalothrin based products (Karate 2.5% WG® at 20g per 20L of water or Tata Umeme 2.5 EC® at 15-20 ml/20L of water) . General Restrictions: WHO Toxicity class II; PHI 3 days
- Spray with Cypermethrin-based products such as Debush EC ® at the rate of 100ml per 20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO Toxicity class II; PHI 1 days

Images.Caption: Passionfruit woodiness potyvirus (Mary Mendi Kinuthia, Kenya)
Passionfruit woodiness potyvirus (PM Kodwaran, Kenya)
Passionfruit woodiness virus (Nicholas Kimeu)

Authors.Surname: Martha Wangari, Benson ngigi (MOALF), Philip Kibet (KU) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant varieties such as PAN 99, PAN5243, KSH 6214, WH 504, SC Duma 41, SC Simba 61 or Ua Kayongo 2
- Keep the field free from weeds
- Remove plant debris to reduce inoculum
- Rotate with Amaranthus, sunn hemp, beans and tomato
- Plough under infested plant debris to reduce level of inoculum
- Do not use infected maize stovers as mulching material

- Additional relevant crops: Amaranthus, sunn hemp, beans, tomato, vicia
- Look out for:
• Chlorotic spots on leaves
• Necrotic brown spots on younger leaves which are parallel to the leaf veins, which later merge and become ashy grey
• Spores of the fungus on the spots in older leaves and especially during prolonged wet and cloudy weather
- Monitor weekly for presence of gray leaf spot symptoms
- Take action where 5% of the leaf tissue is affected in 100 plants

- Rogue and destroy infected plants by burning or burying 2 feet deep
- Harvest severely damaged maize before it lodges and destroy by burning or burying 2 feet deep

- When using a pesticide always wear suitable protective equipment
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray with Azoxystrobin + Difenoconazol (Amistartop SC @ 200ml/acre and Ortiva @ 125g/20L/acre). It is a systemic and protectant fungicide. For dilution rate check product label. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class U: (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use); pre-harvest interval p.h.i: 28 days; restricted re-entry interval r.e.i. 1 day after spray; Maximum 2 sprays per season; Toxic to fish, predatory beneficial mites, and soil organisms such as earthworms. Do not pour chemical into river, dams or ponds
- Spray with Trifloxystrobin + Tebuconazol (Nativo SC @ 75ml/20 L). General Restrictions: WHO class III (slightly hazardous) Phi 35 days, Maximum 2 application. Blue colour band MRL 2.0mg/Kg trifloxystrobin 0.2mg/Kg, PHI = 40 days. Tebuconazole, 2.0 g/Kg. MRL = 2.0mg/Kg. PHI- 14 days

Images.Caption: Further lesion expansion results in coalescing of lesions and blighting of the entire leaf (Julian Ward/KwaZulu-Natal Dept of Agriculture, South Africa)
Moderately resistant hybrids display chlorotic lesions (Julian Ward/KwaZulu-Natal Dept of Agriculture, South Africa)
Grey leaf spot of maize (Gyanu Manandhar)

Authors.Surname: Eunice Ringera (KEPHIS), Lynnette Echessa (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant perennial pigeon pea hedges to encourage predatory mites.
- Keep the fields weedfree to remove alternate hosts.
- Maintain soil fertility to improve crop vigour and intercrop with sunflower or parsley to lure beneficial insects into the garden.
- Water plants during hot, dusty seasons to reduce water stress and remove dust on the plants (encourages mite outbreaks).

- Additional relevant crops: tomatoes, potatoes, courgettes, cucumber, cowpeas, beans, pigeon peas, dolichos lab lab, garden peas
- Monitor the crop regularly since mites population build up is very rapid.
- Randomly select 20 plants (3 leaflets/plant) and assess the level of damage. Look for:
• Stippled /yellowish/ bronze blotches on the upper part of the leaves.
• Tiny, reddish dot like soft bodied insects which moves fast once disturbed
• Adult mites, their eggs, and webbing on the underside of the leaves.
• Webbing on the leaf surface and/or on the whole plants in severe conditions
- Take action when 5% of the crop is affected.

- Remove all infested plants or plant parts and burn them.
- Spray with Real Metarhizium 78 at the rates of 1 litre per hectare,early in the morning.
- Release Phytoseiulus persimilis at the rate of 1-2 per infested leaf, 20-30 per medium sized plant, 2,000 per 700 square feet.
- Spray 70% neem oil (mix 2 tablespoons per 1 gallon of water), more emphasis on the leaf undersides, until the whole plant gets wet.
- Soap sprays can also be used. Test on one or two plants to be sure they don’t burn leaves before spraying whole field

- When using a pesticide always wear personal protective equipment.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).

- Spray with Abamectine 18g/l based products (Avirmec 1.8 EC, Romectin, Abalone 18EC, Acaramik 1.8EC at the rate of 10mls/20L (1L per Ha). General Restrictions: Abamectin is not classified by WHO (Rotate miticides to avoid pests developing chemical resistance)
- Spray with Diafenthiuron 500g/L based products (Mercur 500SC or Pegasus at the rate of 15 - 20mls/20L). General Restrictions: WHO class III (Moderately hazardous) and PHI 10 days (Rotate miticides to avoid pests developing chemical resistance)

Images.Caption: Red spider mite adult resting on the underside of a watermelon leaf (source Gilles San Martin, CC BY-SA)
Red spider mite symptoms on the upper side of the watermelon leaf (source: M. Otipa)

Authors.Surname: Peninah Munyao (MOALF), Wilson Nabakwe (MOALF), Jacon Ndungu (MOALF),Cyrus Njoroge(MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant disease free seedlings from certified nurseries such as KALRO-Thika, JKUAT, Good neighbours and other HCDA registered nurseries
- Plant seedlings grafted to brown spot tolerant yellow passion fruit rootstocks
- To improve aeration use recommended spacing of 3 metres between plants and 2 metres between rows

- Look out for:
• brown spots up to 10mm in diameter on the leaves extending along the veins and drying out in the centre
• brown lesions on the stem that cause dieback when they occur at the leaf axils
• spots that are light brown, round and sunken which often merge covering large areas and produce red brown spore masses
- Take immediate action once you see signs of the disease on one plant

- Remove and burn all infected plant parts
- Use drip irrigation and avoid overhead irrigation to reduce spread of pathogen
- Prune to promote proper orchard aeration and reduce disease build up
- Disinfect tools regulary e.g. by the use of jik solution 500ml in ten litres of water to prevent the spread of the fungus

- When using pesticides always wear protective clothing
- Always follow the instructions on the product label such as dosage, timing of application, PHI, maximum number of sprays, re-entry interval, etc.
- Always consult current list of registered pesticides

- Spray with Carbendazim + Mancozeb based products such as Saaf WP at the rate of 25g/ 20lts of water. General Restrictions: WHO Toxicity class IV; PHI 7 days
- Spray with copper based fungicides such as cupracaffaro at the rate of 50gm/20lts of water. General Restrictions: WHO Toxicity class IV; PHI 3 days;
- Spray with Propineb based products like Antracol WP 70 at the rate of 50ml/20lts of water. General Restrictions: WHO Toxicity class U; PHI 7 days
- Spray with saaf and alternate with Antracol after 7 days and repeat again untill the disease is controlled. General Restrictions: WHO Toxicity class III; PHI 7 days

Images.Caption: Passion fruit brown spot (Nicholas Kimeu)
Brown spot (Alternaria passiflorae) (Daniel Kamaru)

Authors.Surname: Eunice Ringera (KEPHIS), Lynnette Echessa (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Rotate melon with other non host crops such as maize, legumes, carrots and onions
- Mulch the plants to prevent larvae from getting to the soil to pupate
- Avoid planting new crop next to a previously affected crop
- Plough deep after harvesting crop
- Fertilise adequately to ensure plant health with both organic and inorganic fertilisers
- Remove weeds as they serve as a reservoir for leafminers

- Additional relevant crops: tomatoes, courgettes, bean, eggplant, pepper, potato, squash
- Look out for:
• Stippled appearance on foliage caused by egg laying female insects
• Slender white winding leaf mines (whitish blotches) on the surface of the leaves
• Colourless to yellowish green larvae with black mouth
- Trap adult flies by placing 3 x 5 inch yellow sticky farms in the farm.
- Take action when 5% crop is affected

- Placing of yellow stick traps in the farm to reduce population of adults
- Use of Natural enemies­parasitic wasps like Chrysocharis parksi and Diglyphus isaea
- Soil drenching with metarhizium 69 to kill pupae in the soil at the rate of 80mls per acre
- Physically crushing the larvae once first sign of tunneling is observed
- Spraying neem oil at rates of 40mls at 20l of water
- Destroy infested plants to ensure field hygiene by burning or burying

- When using a pesticide always wear protective gear.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).

- Use insecticides Abamectin (Dynamec, Abalone, Spidermec at 10mls per 20liters of water) at 2-4 weeks after planting. General Restrictions: Abamectin is not classified by WHO. PHI 3-7 days, MRL 2mg/kg,
- Spray bifenthrin e.g. Brigade EC at a rate of 20 ml in 20 litres of water. Non-systemic with contact stomach action. Pyrethroid; IRAC 3A. . General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous). PHI 3 days. MRL 1.0 mg/Kg
- Drench with imidacloprid e.g. Confidor 010 UL at a rate of 10ml in 20 litres of water. Neonicitinoid; IRAC 4A. Systemic insecticide with translaminar activity and with contact and stomach action. General Restrictions: WHO Class II. MRL 0.5 mg/Kg. Spray early morning or late evening to avoid harming bees.

Images.Caption: Adult leafminer (Source: Lyle J. Buss (UF/IFAS) from: Capinera JL, EENY-255, Dec 2001)
Mines on leaves cause by leaf miner ( Source Whitney Cranshaw, Colorado State University, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Carry out soil testing before fertilizer application
- Boost crop health by applying the recommnded fertilizers and manure
- Establish the ochard on an East-West orientation to receive maximum light to enhance quality of polllen quality
- Plant more flowering plants around the ochard to attract bees
- Keep the field weed free to ease nutrient competition
- Avoid water stress
- Avoid excess use of chemical sprays especially at flowering so as not to kill pollinators
- Intercrop with trap crops e.g. carrots, cucurbits, kales, spider plant

-  Look out for:
• Fallen, withered flowers (petals)
• Dry scars of floral stalk remains on the vine with no small fruits attached
• Presence of thrips (minute slender dark brown insects with fringed wings)
- Take action when 5% of the flowers are aborted in 100 plants

- Apply Yara Milla fertilizer at planting at the rate of 100g/tree in two splits (N,P,K,B:15,9,20,0.02)
- Spray foliar feed with boron nutrient e.g. Solubor at the rate 50-60g/20litres of water or Easygro-flowers-30-40g/20l before and during flowering and at fruiting stages at fortnight interval
- Put up at least one beehive near the ochard, bees are the best insect pollinators
- Carry out hand pollination using a paint brush
- Spray alpha naphthalene acetic acid before flowering e.g. Plantone at exactly 4mls/20 litres of water
- Spray 2 spoonfuls of mild detergent (tepeal) in 5 litres of water to control thrips

- When using a pesticide always wear protective equipment.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).

- In case of presence of thrips during flowering, spray alphacypermethrin (Albaz 10 EC, Alfatox 10% EC, Alphacymba 10% EC at 5ml/20litres of water). General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous) PHI 3 days
- Spray Deltamethrin (Atom 2 .5 EC at 10-15mls in 20 litres of water, Keshet 2.5 EC at 15mls in 20 litres of water). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) and PHI 1 day, MRL 0.3mg/kg. Spray during flowering at 2 weeks interval

Images.Caption: Thrips can cause flower abortion as well as damage to fruits (A. M. Varela, icipe)

Authors.Surname: Peninah Munyao (MOALF), Mary Mendi (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Solarise the soil by covering with a polythene sheet 8 weeks before planting
- Plough deep to kill pupae in the soil from previously infested crop
- Avoid excessive application of nitrogen since it promotes higher populations of thrips
- Remove weeds to eliminate alternate hosts
- Clean up crop debris after harvest
- Thrips thrive in dry/drought conditions therefore apply adequate irrigation to the crop
- In rain-fed areas, plant early so that crops are established and better able to tolerate an attack during dry conditions
- Practise crop rotation using cereals
- Preserve natural enemies such as lady bird beetles and spiders to help manage thrips by planting flowering strips or shrubs around edge of field, reducing use of broad spectrums or not spraying flowers

- Additional relevant crops: onions, Amaranth, black nightshade, beans
-  Look out for:
• Straw-coloured, slender insects with two pairs of feathery wings on the leaves and flowers by shaking them on a white piece of paper
• Silvery patches and small black spots of faecal material on the leaf
• Deformation, speckling or small necrotic patches on the surface of the attacked fruit
• Flowers and bud abortion in heavy infestation
- Take action when 4-6 adults are found per flower

- Discard any infested plants by securely bagging and putting in the trash
- Trap using blue sticky traps to kill or reduce their numbers
- Spray with Azadirachtin based products e.g. Achook EC@ 20ml/20L, Nimbecide @20-50 ml/20l, Neemroc@20-50ml/20L
- Spray using Beauveria bassiana and Metarhizium anisopliae biocontrol agents which are effective against thrips

- Good spray coverage is essential as thrips hide underneath the flowers of leaves
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

-  Spray with Spinosad based products e.g. Tracer@4mls/20L. General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Moderately hazardous), PHI 3 days
- Spray with Deltamethrin based products e.g. Atom 2.5EC, Decis 2.5 EC, Farm-X@10-15ml/20L. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) PHI 1 day
- Spray with Lambda Cyhalothrin e.g. Karate 2.5 % WG @ 20gms/20L, Tata Umeme 2.5 EC@ 15-20ml/20L. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) PHI 3 days

Images.Caption: Frankliniella schultzei (NBAIR)
Silvery patches and black spots (thrips excrements) indicating thrip damage on leaves (Photo: A.M.Varela, ICIPE)
Deformation, speckling and small necrotic patches on the surface of attacked fruit (Photo: AM Varela, ICIPE)

Authors.Surname: Gekone J.M. (MOALF)  Magoti R.N (KALRO), Cyrus N. Njoroge (MOALF), Esther Macharia, Eston Njeru and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid planting near crops infected with Tomato spotted wilt virus
- Plant resistant varieties such as Star 9008
- Control thrips at all growth stages (they transmit the causal virus)
- Control weeds and volunteer host plants
- Promptly remove and burn old tomato plants and other host crops after harvest
- Ensure that you transplant disease free seedlings and free of thrips
- Mulch with dry grass or polythene to prevent thrips pupation

- Additional relevant crops: eggplant, pepper, groundnut, tobacco
- Look out for :
• Bronzing and drooping of young leaves
• Numerous small, dark spots on leaves
• Thrips within the foliage and flowers
• Dark streaking of the terminal shoots
• Stunting of the plant and or one-sided growth
• Chlorotic rings, patches or lesions on fruits
- Initiate control measures on noting 5 thrips per plant or 10% infected plants

- Rogue all infected plants and destroy by burning
- Trap thrips using yellow sticky traps. Place 8 sticky traps per 0.5 acres of land.
- Spray Beauveria bassiana (Botanigard ES ® or Beauvitech WP ®) at the rate of 10ml per 20L of water

- Use protective clothing when handling insecticides
- Follow product label instructions
- Rotate insecticide classes to reduce resistance
- Ensure proper spray coverage of flowers and foliage

- Spray chlorpyriphos based insecticides (Bullet 48EC® at 40mls/20L of water) or (Bulldock Star 262.5EC® at 15mls/20L of water). General Restrictions: WHO class II, Moderately hazardous; PHI 14 days; MRLs 1.0mgs/kg;
- Spray imidachloprid based insecticides (Tata Mida 200SL® or Confidor 200SL ®) at the rate of 10ml per 20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO class III, Slightly hazardous; PHI 3 days; MRLs 2mg/kg

Images.Caption: Tomato plant exhibiting symptoms of TSWV infection (Gerald Holmes, California Polytechnic State University at San Luis Obispo, Bugwood.org)
Irregular chlorotic rings on infected tomato fruit (Source: William M. Brown Jr., Bugwood.org)
Western flower thrips -TSWV vectors  (Mohammad Mirnezhad, Leiden University, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Esther Macharia (KALRO), Boniface N Ndung'u (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO) , Philip Kibet (UoN) and Benson Ngigi (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Plant clean (insect free) vines that are deep rooted with long necks because adult weevils cannot burrow below 1cm
- Plant new fields away from infested crops a distance away from storage facilities
- Keep the fields weed-free
- Ridge, mulch and routinely irrigate to prevent soil cracking
- Rotate sweet potato with sorghum and other cereals every four years
- Harvest when mature and avoid piecemeal harvesting
- Plant early in the season or early-maturing varieties so that harvest can be completed before the dry season when the soil will dry and crack
- Dip planting material in a solution of Beauveria bassiana for 10 minutes to be effective
- Encourage generalist predators of the weevil like ants, spiders, carabids, and earwigs by planting hedgerows of target spp.

- Additional relevant crops: morning glory, wild spinach, wild Ipomoea
- Look out for:
• Sweet potato larvae in the tuber and basal 10cm of the vines
• Yellowing, cracking and wilting of vines
• Holes in the vines and tubers early in the season
• Storage roots that appear soft, smelling and have external scarring or small darkened holes
- Place pheromone traps in the field at a radius of 280m to catch the weevils

- Drench Nimbecidine at a rate of 5 ml/L
- Remove all infested sweet potato vines and storage roots and destroy by burning or burying 2 feet deep
- Flood infested fields for 24 hours after harvesting

- When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval, maximum number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)
- Do not empty containers into drains

- Dip planting material in a solution of Diazinon based products (Diazol 60EC at 40-50mls/20L for 10-15 minutes, Basudin at 15ml/20L). General Restrictions: WHO Class II Moderately hazardous REI 10-14 days
- Drench using Carbaryl based products (Sevin 80ml/20L) at planting of the crop. General Restrictions: PHI 7 days WHO Class II Moderately hazardous

Images.Caption: Damage caused by sweet potato weevil (Agnes Kariuki)
Adult Cylas formicarious (Georg Goergen/IITA Insect Museum, Cotonou, Benin)
Sweet potato weevil larva. The full-grown larva is 7.5-8.0 mm long (Peter A.C. Ooi/CABI BioScience)

Authors.Surname: Eunice Ringera (KEPHIS), Lynnette Echessa (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plough deep, plant early, use short early maturing varieties (KH500-53A, KH500-52A, PAN3M-01)
- Plant tolerant varieties like Ua kayongo, GAF4, WS303, KS 528, FRC 4251R or KSTP94
- Rotate (3-6 years) or intercrop with cotton, sunflower, legumes to reduce the striga seed bank in the soil
- Avoid dropping maize seed cob on the soil during harvesting to avoid dispersing the weed
- Take the soil to KALRO for nutrient analysis (N:P:K) as Nitrogen and phosphorous deficiencies can accentuate Striga damage and severity
- Uproot and burn crop stubble to prevent growth and seeding of Striga

- Additional relevant crops: sorghum, millet, upland rice
- Look out for:
• Long (1cm by 0.5cm) yellowish blotches on the foliage and on uprooting a hustoria and young parasite seedling
• Curled leaves and drought-stressed like appearance of the plants
• Stunting and wilting of plants
• Weeds with purple flowers at later stages
- Take action when 1% of the crop is affected

- Continously uproot and burn Striga weeds, 3 weeks at flowering and before seed setting to reduce dispersal
- Plant sorghum, millet or maize prior to the main season to stimulate germination of Striga, then destroy before the weed can mature and set seed
- Apply organic and inorganic fertilizers and irrigate during dry periods to improve crop stand
- Intercrop maize with desmodium, beans, cowpeas, groundnuts, greengrams to shade and supress the weed

- When planting herbicide treated maize always wear gloves and other personal protective equipment.
- Follow the instructions on the product label and always change gloves or properly wash hands to prevent contaminating other crops.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).

- Plant seeds dressed with imazapyr herbicide (registered as StrigAway). General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous) (Dressing restricted to seed companies only). REI 12 hrs. Burn seed packages to avoid contaminating food, water or feed

Images.Caption: Purple witchweed (Striga hermonthica) (USDA APHIS PPQ - Oxford, North Carolina, USDA APHIS PPQ, Bugwood.org)
Purple witchweed (Striga hermonthica) in corn (Zea mays) (USDA APHIS PPQ - Oxford, North Carolina, USDA APHIS PPQ, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Benson Masinde (MOALF), Martha Kariuki (MOALF), Hannah Oduor (MOALF), Miriam Otipa (KARLO)

Sections.Value:
- Improve soil drainage and fertility by adding organic matter to the soil such as farm yard manure and compost
- Rotate with kales, onions, maize, and beans
- Use correct spacing of 60cm x 60cm in the greenhouse or 90cm x 90cm in the field
- Avoid planting in previously infected fields for at least 3 years
- Avoid using a lot of nitrogen fertilizers
- Maintain field hygiene by removing and burning diseased residues

- Additional relevant crops: solanaceous plants such as tomato, Capsicum, pepper
- Look out for:
• Yellowing and wilting leaves starting from the lower upwards
• Brown hardened woody stem
• Plants with dried leaves still attached to the stem and later total collapse of the plant
- Uproot the diseased plant, cut the roots and check for discolouration in the vascular system
- Take action when one diseased plant is seen

- Remove and destroy infected plants from the field
- Mix a handful of wood ash with 1 lt of water and pour on to the basal part of the plants
- Drench with Trichoderma-based products (Trianum P and trichotech) at 1:5 (Trianum to water)
- Drench using rootguard 40gms in 20lts
- Practice soil solarisation in nurseries by covering soil in full sun with a polythene for 4 weeks to control nematodes

- When using a pesticide always wear protective equipment
-  Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)
- Soil fumigants should be applied by a trained technician

- Fumigate the soil with Metam Sodium at the rate of 1.1in 12lts of water and cover with 7-15 cm of moist soil. General Restrictions: WHO II, slightly hazadous, REI 14-21 DAYS. Fumigation MUST be carried out by trained personnel as the pesticides are very dangerous. Fumigation should take 3 weeks and uncover the soil for 2 weeks than plant aferwards.
- Drench Carbendazim based products (e.g. Rodazim @ 20ml/20l, SAAF @ 20g/20l). General Restrictions: WHO III, slightly hazadous PHI 7-14 DAYS
- Drench with propamocarb hydrochloride based products (Previcur @30-50mls/20lt), Propeller @60-120mls/20lts

Images.Caption: Fusrium wilt symptoms (Dr G M McPherson, Stockbridge Technology Centre)

Authors.Surname: Esther Macharia (KALRO), Boniface N Ndung'u (MOALF), Benson Masinde (MOALF), Maurice Okeno (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Deep plough the orchard in October-November to expose pupae and larvae to sun’s heat which kills them
- Source plant material only from clean, accredited suppliers such as KALRO Thika
- Check your orchard frequently for the presence of new pests and unusual symptom

- Additional relevant crops: banana, citrus, mulberry, fig tree, guava and jackfruit, etc.
- Check your orchard frequently for the presence of new pests and unusual symptoms
- Look for small raised red spots on leaves that become wart/pimple like galls that are 3-4 mm
- Check larval population by tapping on white paper in April/ May
- Notice curling up and premature drop off of heavily galled leaves and dieback of whole branches
- Take action when 10 galls are noticed on a leaf

- Remove fruits with dimples and oozing clear sap twice a week for whole season or as soon as noticed
- Collect and dispose of infested panicles, leaves and twigs by burning or burying at least 2 feet deep
- Prune affected plants to minimize the spread of the pests and diseases

-  When using a pesticide, always wear protective clothing. Do not empty into drains
-  Follow the instructions on the product label
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray with Lambda-cyhalothrin, e.g. Karate 2.5 WG at 20g in 20L of water or Dududthrin 1.7 EC at 60ml in 20 L of water. General Restrictions: WHO class II, (Moderately hazardous)PHI 3 days. Toxic to fish and aquatic invertebrate
- Spray with Alpha-Cypermethrin, e.g. Bestox 100 EC at 6 ml in 20 L of water or Tata alpha 10 EC at 6ml in 20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO class II, (Moderately hazardous) PHI 3 days. Toxic to fish and aquatic invertebrate

Images.Caption: Galls caused by mango leaf gall midge (A. M. Varela, icipe)

Authors.Surname: Jacob Ndungu (MOALF), Cyrus Njoroge (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Do a soil test to determine nitrogen deficiency in your soil before planting and implement recommendations accordingly (see Direct Control column)
- Boost crop health by applying recommended fertilizer and manure
- Keep the field weed free to reduce nutrient competion
- Avoid water stress to enhance nutrient uptake
- Rotate with crops like beans, garden peas and sweet potatoes
- Use mulch to preserve soil organisms that are useful in nitrogen cycling
- Plant nitrogen-fixing trees such as Leucaena, Calliandra, Sesbania spp.
- Use organic fertilizer e.g. compost FYM at the rate of 4 tons/acre.
- Leave the farm farrow for at least 1 season
- Incorporate Tithonia diversifolia in soil at a rate of 2 tons/acre before planting

- Look out for:
• Yellowing bolls
• Yellowing lower leaves starting from tips and margins and then entire plant
• Stunted crops showing chlorotic symptoms
- Take action as soon as nitrogen deficiency is confirmed in the laboratory test of your soil or crop samples in your crop
- Use bio-slurry from biogas digester and from animal sheds at a rate of 0.5l/1m2
- When using fertilizers always wear protective equipment

- Apply TSP/DAP at 10g/hole when planting. General Restrictions: Follow the label instructions, particularly for safety measures
- Topdress with CAN at 15g/plant after one month, NPK (17:17:17) at 10g/plant in 4 splits before flowering. General Restrictions: Do not apply more than 50 kg of nitrogen at once (apply split applications)
- Spray fast acting nitrogen foliar fertiliser: (Omex, 20mls in 20 litres of water, Murphy foliar at 100g/20 litres) after deficiency is observed
- Urea can be used as well when fast acting N-fertiliser such as Murphy foliar is not available

Images.Caption: Nitrogen deficiency causes leaves to turn yellow (Photo: Gillie Rhodes, CC BY-NC)

Authors.Surname: Judith Oyoo (KALRO), Paul Kiige (MOALF), Kibet (UoN) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Benson Masinde (MOALF) and Maurice Okeno (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Rotate with non solanaceae crops such as maize, sorghum, beans, etc.
- Plant certified potato seed from certified suppliers such as KALRO Tigoni and ADC Molo
- Plant potato varieties that have some tolerance such as Sherekea, Kenya Baraka, Dutch Robin and Annet
- Keep the field free of potential hosts of aphids like black nightshade, potato volunteers from previous seasons, and other weeds
- Plant at the onset of the rains to avoid aphid infestation

- Additional relevant crops: tobacco, potato, tomato, sodom apple, black nightshade
- Check for the upward and inward rolling of leaflet margin
- Check for dead spots on the leaves, branches and tubers. Check also for malformed tubers and dwarf plants
- Check if the lower leaves are turning brown
- High population of ants on or around the plants feeding on honey dew
- Start direct control when 5-winged aphids are caught on the traps or on the lower side of the leaf

- Uproot infected plants and burn or bury atleast two feet deep
- Place 4 yellow traps per acre to trap the adult aphid
- Protect and conserve natural enemies of aphids such as lace wing, lady birds or parasitic wasps/Amphitech (Aphidius transcaspinus) by using less strong synthetic pesticides
- Place honey traps under the plants to lure ants away from aphids to help control them
- Control aphids by spraying Azadirachtin (Neemroc EC and Nimbecidine EC: 20-50ml per 20L of water)

- Always wear protective equipment when spraying chemicals
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Control aphids by spraying Lambda-cyhalothrin, 17.5g/L e.g. DUDUTHRIN1.7 EC or KARATE 17.5 EC at a rate of 60ml in 20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) and PHI of 3-7 days
- Control aphids by spraying Bifenthrin (e.g. Defender 2.5% or Brigade at the rate of 20ml per 20L of water). General Restrictions: Defender: PHI: 7 days, WHO Class II, MRL -0.3mg/Kg Brigade PHI - 3 days

Images.Caption: Net necrosis due to PLRV in two hybrids of Solanum tuberosum subsp. tuberosum and Solanum tuberosum subsp. andigena (Luis Salazar)
Typical leafroll symptoms on potato foliage (Luis Salazar)

Authors.Surname: Martha Kariuki (MOALF), Philip Kibet (UoN), Benson Ngigi (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant certified disease free seeds
- Rotate with sorghum for three seasons
- Don’t plant in soils where there has been previous occurrence of the disease
- Plant on well drained soils
- Deep plough the previous year's residue
- Use proper spacing of 25cm x 15cm
- Do not use excessive nitrogen fertilizer use 80kg per acre
- Plant tolerant varieties e.g. KK 22 (RWR 719), KK 8 (SCAM 80/15), KK15 (MLB49/879)

- Additional relevant crops: French bean, snap bean, beets, cabbage, peas, melons, squash, cucumbers
- Look out for:
• Poor seed germination
• Death of seedlings shortly after germination
• Rotting of the taproots which turn brick red and become hollow and dry
• Elongated water soaked areas on the roots
• Stunting and eventually death of the plant
- Start direct control when 1% of the crop is affected
- Sunken dark lesions on seedling hypocotyls and the collar regions (soil levels) of the infected plants

- Drench with Trichoderma-based products e.g. Trianum P and trichotech at 1:5 (Trianum to water)
- Remove infected plants and destroy by burning or burying at a depth of 2 feet

- Make reference to the PCPB list of approved chemicals
- When using chemical wear protective clothing
- Read and follow the manufacturers instructions carefully

- Drench Carbendazim-based products (e.g. Rodazim @ 20ml/20l, SAAF @ 20g/20l, Chariot @ 20ml/20L). General Restrictions: WHO U, Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use, PHI 7-14 DAYS
- Dress seeds with Fludioxinil + Metalaxyl-M based products (e.g. Maxim XL @ 1ml/kg. General Restrictions: WHO III, slightly hazadous (seed dressing to be done by a trained expert)
- Dress seeds with Imidacloprid + Metalaxy + carbendazim-based products (Murtano super 10g/2kg seed, seed plus @10g/2kg seed). General Restrictions: WHO II, Moderately harzadous. (seed dressing to be done by a trained expert)

Images.Caption: Roots of drybeans showing advanced symptoms of Rhizoctonia root rot caused by Rhizoctonia solani (Howard F. Schwartz, Colorado State University, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Eunice Ringera (KEPHIS), Lynnette Echessa (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Use the correct seed rate of 50kg per acre to ensure good plant density
- Plant early before the onset of rains
- Fertilise the crop using adequate basal (planting) fertilisers such as DAP, NPK and foliar fertilisers
- Remove volunteer wheat and grasses because they act as the aphid's hosts
- Plant resistant varieties such as Kenya Fahari wheat variety
- Grow hedgerows, flowering strips to attract biological agents such as aphid predators-coccinellid beetles, hover flies, lacewings and spiders
- Avoid water stress/drought as aphids thrive in dry conditions or irrigate the fields regularly
- Apply DAP, NPK, Mavuno at planting at rates of 50kg per acre and foliar fertilisers (Omex, Booster grow, Bayfolan, Agroleaf) at least 3 times through the production period of crop

- Additional relevant crops: wheat, barley, oats
- From emergence of the crop look out for:
• Slight to moderate yellowing of small areas of crop within the field
• White, yellow, or purple longitudinal streaks on curled leaves due to the infestation
• Flattened plants with prostate young tillers
• Small green spindle shaped insects that may appear inside curled leaves
- Take action when 10% of crop is affected

- Use of contact biopesticides such as Real Metarhizium anisopliae 62 at a rate of 80ml per acre mixed with wetting agents like Aquawet
- Use of parasitoid such as Aphidius spp. at the manufacturer recommendation. This can be bought from dudutec company

- General Pesticide Restrictions
- When using a pesticide always wear protective equipment
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)
- For foliar sprays, complete coverage is needed to control aphids

- Dress seed using Thiamethoxam (Cruiser 350FS – 150 ml/100kg seed) . General Restrictions: WHO class III (moderately hazardous to humans), MRL 2mg/kg (dressing restricted to seed company)
- Seed dressing with Imidacloprid (Gaucho 350FS-200ml/100kg seed) . General Restrictions: WHO class II (moderately hazardous to humans) and PHI, MRL 2mg/kg
- Spray chlorpyrifos based insecticide eg Bullet 48%EC at rate of 40mls/20L of water. Sprays can be repeated fortnightly if necessary. General Restrictions: WHO class II, Moderately hazardous; PHI 14 days; MRLs 1.0mgs/kg. Farmers should be advised to alternate chemicals of different classes fortnightly
- Deltamethrin 25g/L (Decis forte EC, Keshet -10-15ml/L water). General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous) and PHI 14 days, MRL 2mg/kg

Images.Caption: Colony of Russian wheat aphids (Diuraphis noxia) in a wheat leaf (Frank Peairs, Colorado State University, Bugwood.org)
Russian wheat aphid (Diuraphis noxia) infestation (J.P. Michaud, Kansas State University, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Samuel Mburu (MOALF), Peter Kodwaran (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Remove or plough deep to incorporate previous crop residue in the soil to kill thrips
- Practice soil solarisation in areas with high temperatures for 8 weeks before planting to kill the pupa
- Preserve natural enemies like lady bird beetles, Orius and hover flies to help manage thrips. Plant barriers of Mexican marigold followed by sunflower (Mexican marigold attracts thrips from beans. Sunflower hosts Orius spp. which feeds on thrips)
- Keep the fields free of weeds and alternative hosts such as wild mustards
- Thrips thrive in dry/drought conditions apply adequate irrigation to the crop
- Practise crop rotation with non-host crops

- Additional relevant crops: bananas, coffee, papaya, passionfruit, potato, tea, watermelon, onions, kale, maize, tobacco
- Randomly check for thrip damage at the growing tips of the plants
- Look for thrips early in the morning (before 9.00am) as they tend to hide inside flowers or underneath leaves in high temperatures
- Regularly scout the morbydick crop
- Shake the flowers on a white piece of paper to check for presence of adult thrips
- Take action when you notice at least 3 thrips per plant

- Place blue sticky traps above the vegetative parts of the plants to capture, kill/reduce their numbers
- Spray with Azadirachtin-based products such as Achook EC, Nemros etc. at 20ml/20L
- Use Oriusjeanneli (Oritech®) which is available at Dudutech Kenya Ltd., email: dudtech@ kenyaweb.com

- When using a pesticide always wear personal protective equipment
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray with Imidacloprid-based products such as Confidor 200SL, Imaxi 200SC, TATA MIDA 200SL etc. at a rate of 10mls/20L of water . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI 3 days
- Spray with Deltamethrin based products such as Atom 2.5EC, Decis 2.5EC, Farm-X etc. at a rate 10ml-15ml/20L of water . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI 1 days
- Spray with Spinosad (tracer 480 SC) at the rate of 4ml per 20 litres of water. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (slightly hazardous). PHI 7 days
- Spray with Lambda Cyhalothrin, such as Karate2.5 % WG at 20gms/20L of water, Tata Umeme 2.5 EC at 15-20ml/20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI 3 days.

Images.Caption: Thrips (Alton N. Sparks, Jr., University of Georgia, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Judith Oyoo (KALRO), Paul Kiige (MOALF), Kibet (UoN) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Benson Masinde (MOALF) and Maurice Okeno (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Rotate with non-Solanaceae crops such as maize, dandelions, clover, mint, sorghum or beans
- Plant crop borders such as soybean, wheat, maize or potato to ‘trap’ the aphids
- Plant certified potato seed from reliable sources (KALRO Tigoni, Molo and ADC Molo)
- Plant potato varieties that show some resistance to PVY such as Kenya Baraka, Sherekea, Kenya Mpya, Roslin Eburu, Feldelslohn, Annet and Dutch Robjn
- Plant early at onset of rains to avoid aphid infestation
- Keep the field free of potential hosts of aphids like weeds, crop residues and potato volunteers from previous seasons

- Additional relevant crops: potato, tobacco, tomato, Physalis, okra and all crops in Solanaceae family
- Look for new growth that is undersized and distorted
- Check for adult aphids, eggs or pupae of aphids on the lower side of the leaves
- Look out for stunted plants with mosaic patterns and malformations on leaves
- Check for dead spots on the leaves, branches and tubers. Check also for malformed on the tubers
- Presence of high population of ants on or around the plants feeding on honeydew
- Start direct control when 5-winged aphids are caught on the traps or seen on the lower side of the leaf

- Uproot infected plants burn or bury 2 feet deep
- Place 1-4 yellow traps per 300m2 to attract and kill the adult aphid
- Disinfect all farm tools by dipping in 10% jik solution (3.85% sodium hypochlorite) at 50ml per litre of water for at least 5 minutes
- Place honey traps under the plants to lure ants away from aphids to help control them
- Keep natural enemies of aphids such as lace wing, lady birds or parasitic wasps/Amphitech (Aphidius transcaspinus)
- Spray Azadirachtin (Nimbecidine EC at rate of 20-50ml in 20L of water)

- Wear protective clothing when handling chemicals
- Follow instruction on the product label such as dosage, pre-harvest interval and appropriate time of application
- Spray only on the affected plants
- Properly dispose excess chemicals

- Spray Thiamethoxam 250g/Kg e.g. (Actara 25 WG 10g in 20L of water for foliar spray). General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous) and PHI of 3 days
- Spray Lambda-cyhalothrin 17.5g/L e.g. Duduthrin 1.7 EC or Karate 17.5 EC at a rate of 60ml in 20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) and PHI of 3-7 days

Images.Caption: Symptoms on PVY-infected potato leaves; note leaf deformation (Nicola Spence/Horticulture Research International)
Potato Virus Y (Potyvirus PVY) (Bruce Watt, University of Maine, Bugwood.org)

Factsheets.Title: Potato Virus Y and Potato Virus X

Authors.Surname: Eston Njeru, Esther Macharia and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Conduct soil testing to determine presence of nematodes before planting. If present solarise the soil by covering with a polythene paper for 4 weeks in hot sun
- Plant certified tubers from reliable sources like ADC and KALRO
- Rotate with non-host crops such as maize, barley, wheat, cabbage and napier grass
- Keep fields weed-free
- Avoid movement of workers and farm equipment from infested fields
- Maintain optimal soil fertility to increase crop vigour
- Observe spacing of 70cm x 30cm to optimize aeration
- Plant trap crops like marigold to minimize crop damage

- Additional relevant crops: tomato, pepper, eggplant, sweet potato and a wide range of other host plants
- Look out for:
• Stunting and yellowing of plants in patches of the field with a tendency to wilt under normal conditions
• Tubers with blisters or swellings, giving them a warty appearance
• Swellings (knots or galls) on roots of potato plants
- Take action when 5% of plants in 100 plants are affected

- Uproot and destroy by burning all affected plants
- Drench planting furrows with Purpureocillium lilacinus e.g. Bio-Nematon® at the rate of 100g/ml in 20L of water
- Drench plants using azadirachtin (Achook® or Nimbecidine ®) at the rate of 50 ml in 20 L of water
- Drenching the crop at seedling stage and repeat at knee high to control the nematodes

-  Wear protective clothing when handling pesticides
- Follow label instructions carefully
- Dispose pesticide containers responsibly

- Fumigate soil using Metam sodium at the rate of 1.1L per 12L water per 10m2 and cover with 7-15cm of moist soil. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (moderately harzardous): Applied by specialized persons such as Juanco Ltd.

Images.Caption: Bumpy tuber surface is an indication of infection by root-knot nematodes (Gerald Holmes, California Polytechnic State University at San Luis Obispo, Bugwood.org)
Dug up roots showing extensive galling of tomato roots (Gerald Holmes, California Polytechnic State University at San Luis Obispo, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Peninah Munyao (MOALF), Mary Mendi (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Do a soil test because the disease favours high nitrogen levels
- Rotate tomato with maize, carrots, cabbages
- Use correct spacing of 60x60cm in the greenhouse or 75x90cm outdoors
- Plant healthy seeds and seedlings
- Weed frequently to allow for aeration and to remove alternative disease host

- Do weekly scouting to monitor crop
-  Look out for:
• Yellow patches on the lower leaves where the disease starts
• White powdery growth either on the upper or lower surfaces of the leaves starting in patches
• Leaves wilting and falling off exposing fruits
• Excessive humidity in the greenhouse a condition that favors the establisment of the disease
- Take action as soon as the symptoms are seen on one plant

- Remove infected plant debris from the field after the season is over and burn.
- Prune the heavily infested leaves to minimize the innoculant and to allow for air circulation
- Sspray with baking soda sprays @ 1tbspoon of baking soda mixed with 21/2 tbspoon of vegetable oil and 1 tbspoon of liqiud soap in 5 litres of water.
- Spray with a solution of 325 mg of asprin tablets in one litre of water.
- Spray with 1-2 % neem oil, e.g. Neem Rose

-  When using a pesticide always wear protective equipment.
-  Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).

- Spray with azoxystrobin based chemicals e.g. Ortiva 250 SC 20mls/20lt. It is a systemic and protectant fungicide. For dilution rate check product label. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class U: (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use); PHI 28 days; restricted re-entry interval 1 day after spray; Maximum 2 sprays per season; Toxic to fish, predatory beneficial mites, and soil organisms such as earthworms. Do not pour chemical into river, dams or ponds.
- Spray with triadimefon based products e.g. Bayleton WP 40gm/20lts. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous) and PHI 14 days, MRL 2mg/kg. Spray twice in a growing season
- Spray with sulphur based products e.g. thiovit jet WP at 80gms/20lts Wetsulf WP 40 -80gm/20l,flosul plus 40-80 gms/20lts. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (slightly acute hazardous); pre-harvest interval PHI 10 days; restricted re-entry interval 1 day after spray. Max 3 sprays per season. Follow label instruction to avoid phytotoxic effects on crop. Keep livestock out of reach
- Spray with hexaconazole based products e.g. Cotaf 5% EC, 75-100ml/20lts . General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous) and PHI 1 day, REI 12hrs

Images.Caption: White powdery growth apear on the upper or lower surface of the leaves (Photo:Scot Nelson)

Authors.Surname: Jacob Ndungu (MOALF), Cyrus Njoroge (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Provide adequate air circulation by planting at the recommended spacing of 60x90cm.
- Avoid planting the crop under shade
- Do not exceed 200kg of CAN per hactare
- Selectively prune overcrowded plant material to help increase air circulation. This helps reduce relative humidity and infection
- Avoid overhead irrigation to minimise spread of the fungus

- Additional relevant crops: beans, carrots, eggplant, pumpkin, melons, tomatoes, snow peas, pepper
- Look out for:
• White powdery spots on both sides of the leaf, petiole and stems daily
• Heavily infested leaves which may turn yellow and gradually die
- Take action when one plant is affected

- Mix 1 tablespoon of baking soda with a teaspoon of dormant oil (vegetable or neem oil) and 1 teaspoon of liquid soap in 5 litres of water and spray weekly. Ensure the crop is completely covered
- Mix one part alcohol based mouthwash and three parts of water and spray the crop weekly
- Spray weekly with a mixture of one part milk to two parts water . Ensure all the plant is covered completely for proper control
- Remove and burn infected plant parts
- All the above biopesticides should be sprayed at the on-set of the disease

- When using a pesticide always wear protective equipment
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray Azoxystrobin (Ortiva 250SC at the rate of 20ml in 20L of water, or AMISTAR TOP 325 EC at the rate of 15 ml in 20L of water). General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class U: (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use); pre-harvest interval p.h.i: 28 days; restricted re-entry interval r.e.i. 1 day after spray; Maximum 2 sprays per season; Toxic to fish, predatory beneficial mites, and soil organisms such as earthworms. Do not pour chemical into river, dams or ponds
- Or spray Triadimefon e.g. Bayleton WP 25 at the rate of 10g in 20L of water, Ramsom 600WP at a rate of 12g/20L of water). General Restrictions: WHO Class U (unlikely to present acute hazards in normal use) and PHI 14 day, MRL 0.3mg/kg . Spray twice in a growing season

Images.Caption: Powdery mildew of cucumber (Scot Nelson, Flikr.com)

Authors.Surname: Philip Kibet (UoN), Martha Kariuki, Benson ngigi (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Do not apply Nitrogen fertilizer late in the growing season
- Avoid overhead irrigation to reduce splashing which spreads the disease
- Do not plant kales during wet seasons where possible
- Observe proper spacing of 60 x 60cm for proper aeration
- Ensure fields are clean by removing residues and destroy by burning or burying at a depth of 2 feet
- Apply mulch for moisture retention and to keep weeds out

- Additional relevant crops: beans, cabbage, carrot, cashew, cowpea, cucumber, eggplant, green gram, mango, okra, papaya, peas, peppers, pigeon pea, pumpkin, sesame, tomato, watermelon, wheat, zucchini/courgette
- Look out for:
• Whitish spots of fungal growth on the upper leaf surface which coalese and spread to the entire leaves and buds
- Look for the symptoms during wet weather seasons
- Take action when 5% of plants are infected

- Prune older leaves to reduce innoculum and increase air circulation
- Remove all infected plant parts. Dispose by burning
- Spray with baking soda sprays @ 1tablespoon of baking soda mixed with 21/2 tablespoon of vegetable oil and 1 tablespoon of liqiud soap in 5 litres of water
- Spray with a solution of 325 mg of Aspirin tablets in one litre of water
- Spray with 1-2% neem oil

- Always wear protective clothing when handling pesticides
- Read and carefully follow instructions on the pesticide label

- Spray with azoxystrobin based chemicals e.g. Ortiva 250 SC 20mls/20lt.It is a systemic and protectant fungicide. For dilution rate check product label. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class U: (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use); pre-harvest interval (p.h.i): 28 days; restricted re-entry interval (r.e.i.) 1 day after spray; Maximum 2 sprays per season. Toxic to fish, predatory beneficial mites, and soil organisms such as earthworms. Do not pour chemical into river, dams or ponds
- Spray with triadimefon based products e.g. Bayleton WP, 40gm/20lt, Edimefon 25WP. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous) and PHI 14 days, MRL 2mg/kg. Spray twice in a growing season
- Spray with sulphur based products e.g. Thiovit jet WP at80gms/20lt Wetsulf WP, 40-80gm/20lt, flosul plus 40-80 gms/20lt. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (slightly acute hazardous); pre-harvest interval p.h.i. 10 days; restricted re-entry interval r.e.i. 1 day after spray. Max 3 sprays per season. Follow label instruction to avoid phytotoxic effects on crop. Keep livestock out of reach

Images.Caption: Powdery mildew symptoms (Jeff Kubina, CC By-SA)

Authors.Surname: Benson Masinde (MOALF), Maurice Okeno (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean planting materials from certified suppliers e.g. KALRO Thika, Katumani etc.
- Plant at recommended spacing (8m x 8m) to avoid overcrowding
- Plant resistant varieties such as Tommy Atkins
- Prune frequently to enhance air circulation and light penetration
- Avoid late-season applications of nitrogen fertilizer to limit the production of succulent tissue, which is more susceptible to infection
- Avoid overhead watering to help reduce the relative humidity

- Additional relevant crops: eggplant, papaya, watermelon, tomato, green gram
-  Look out for:
• White powdery growth on the leaves, flowers and young fruit especially during dry weather when humidity is high and nights are cool
• Curling on infected leaves
• When flowers fail to open and drop from the tree without forming a fruit
- Take action when 5% of crop is affected

- Remove and destroy infected plant parts by burning
- Spray with a solution of 6 spoonfuls baking powder, 3 spoonfuls white oil and white barsoap foam in 15L of water
- Spray Ampelomyces quisqualis e.g. BioDewcon 2% Wp at 20L/20L water. Spary at the on set of infection
- Apply trichoderma harzianum e.g. Trichotech P WP 125g/HA

- Always wear personal protective equipment when spraying chemicals.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray with sulphur based products e.g. Thiovit jet WP at 80g/20L or Wetsulf WP 40-80g/20L or flosul plus 40-80g/20L. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class III (slightly acute hazardous); pre-harvest interval PHI 10 days; restricted re-entry interval r.e.i. 1 day after spray. Max 3 sprays per season. Follow label instruction to avoid phytotoxic effects on crop. Keep livestock out of reach
- Spray with triadimefon-based products e.g. Bayleton WP 40g/20L or Edimefon 25WP. General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous) and PHI 14 days, MRL 2mg/kg. Spray twice in a growing season
- Spray with azoxystrobin based chemicals e.g. Ortiva 250 SC 20ml/20L. It is a systemic and protectant fungicide. For dilution rate check product label. General Restrictions: WHO toxicity class U: (Unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use); PHI 28 days; restricted re-entry interval 1 day after spray; Max 2 sprays per season, toxic to fish, predatory beneficial mites, and soil organisms such as earthworms. Do not pour chemical into river, dams or ponds

Images.Caption: Powdery mildew on mango flower buds (Source: AA Seif, ICIPE)
Powdery mildew on mango florouresence (Source: Peter Kibinge, MOALF)

Authors.Surname: Thomas Kwambai and Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Pauline Murithi (MOALF), Eunice Ringera (KEPHIS), Lynnette Echessa (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Remove and destroy the old crop, infested residue and weeds by burning or burying after harvesting
- Plant new crops away from infested fields
- Avoid movement of tools and people from infested fields
- Plant perennial hedges such as pigeon peas that host predatory mites and other natural enemies

- Additional relevant crops: Amaranth, beans, cucumber, eggplant, okra, peas, peppers, pigeon pea, tomato, watermelon
-  Look out for:
• Clusters of yellow spots on the upper surface of leaves giving the leaf a speckled or mottled appearance
• Tiny red or yellow-greenish mites on the underside of leaves with whitish particles and webbings
• Mites seen on white paper when leaf is tapped on it
- Take action when 5-7 spider mites seen on three leaves per plant

- Use preditory mites e.g. Phytoseiulus persimilis and Amblyseius californicus from Dudutec in infested crop
- Intercrop with garlic or onion to repel the pest
- Spray a mixture of 1 teaspoon of liquid soap in 4L of water or quarter bar soap in 20L of water
