- Spray neem based insecticides- Azadirachtin e.g. Nimbecidine EC or Achook 0.15% at 20-50ml in 20L of water 3-4 times per season
- Use overhead irrigation

- When using a pesticide always wear protective equipment
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)
- None of the below pesticides have been registered in Kenya for use on the blacknight shade crop to control the target pest but they have been registered for use on the target pest on related crops in the same family as black nightshade crop. However, biocontrol agents usually, even when not registered, pose no danger to the crop and user and can be recommended with no cause of alarm

- Spray with Abamectin (Dynamec 1.8 EC, Abalone 18 EC, Romectin, Acaramik 1.8EC at rate of 10ml in 20L of water). General Restrictions: WHO class II (Moderately hazardous) PHI 3-7 days, MRLS 0.01mg/kg
- Fenpyroximate (Ortus 5 SC at the rate of 20ml/20L water). General Restrictions: WHO class II PHI - 1 day, MRL 0.2mg/kg
- Spray with Dictator plus 28.7% EC (Propargite 21.2% + Tetradifon 7.5% at rate of 16ml/20L water). General Restrictions: WHO class III PHI - 14 days, MRL 0.2mg/kg

Images.Caption: Red spiter mites on the lower side of leaf (Photo: Thomas Kwambai, KALRO, Kenya)
Yellowish white and mottled upper surface of the leaf (Photo: Thomas Kwambai, KALRO, Kenya)

Factsheets.Title: Red spider mites on black nightshade

Authors.Surname: Esther Macharia, Eston Njeru and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid dusty conditions around potato crop; they predispose crop to mite infestation
- Avoid planting on the windward side of infested field. Mites can be transmitted by wind
- Keep field free of weeds
- Perform farm operations starting from the non-infested areas to minimize spread
- Apply mulch and incorporate organic matter to increase soil moisture
- Uproot and burn infested plants soon after harvest
- Encourage natural enemies such as Phytoseiulus persimilis, predatory mites, ladybird beetles and lacewings by planting flowering strips or hedgerows

- Additional relevant crops: tomato, eggplant, pepper and many common weeds
- Look out for:
• Small red mites barely visible to the naked eye on the underside of leaves
• White to yellow speckling of leaves which later turn pale or bronze with increasing infestation
• Withering and browning of leaves leading to leaf fall
- Take action when 10 mites are seen on 1 plant

- Spray a strong jet of water to dislodge mites and destroy their webs
- Apply Azadirachtin (Achook® or Nimbecidine®) at the rate of 40ml in 20L of water) - PHI 1 day
- Soap sprays can also be used. Test on one or two plants to be sure they don’t burn leaves before spraying whole field

- Always wear personal protective equipment when handling pestides
-  Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB). Do not empty into drains and water sources

- Spray propagite e.g. Omite® at the rate of 50ml per 20L of water - PHI 7 days . General Restrictions: WHO Class III (moderately harzardous)
- Spray spiromesifen (Oberon® at the rate of 10ml per 20L of water) - PHI 7 days . General Restrictions: WHO Class III (slightly harzardous): Do spot spraying targeting the lower side of leaves
- Apply abamectin (Dynamec and Romectin at 10ml per 20L of water, PHI 3 days or bifenthrin e.g. Brigade at 24ml in 20L of water - PHI 3 days. General Restrictions: Abamectin is not classified by WHO
- Use garlic extract (GC Mite) or Pyrethrin + Garlic (Pyegar) at 60m in 20L of water or Petroleum oil (DC Tron plus at 50ml in 20L of water. PHI: 1 day. General Restrictions: WHO class II. (MRLs 0.05mg/kg) (Moderately hazardous), PHI 8 hours

Images.Caption: Red spider mite webbing (CABI)

Factsheets.Title: Red spider mites in Irish potato

Authors.Surname: Jacob Ndungu, Cyrus Njoroge (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Use disease free seedlings raised from a clean nursery
- Rotate with maize, sweet potatoes, sorghum for three seasons
- Avoid poorly drained fields
- Rogue volunteer onions
- Avoid using overhead irrigation.
- Remove and burn onion debris after harvest
- Use recommended spacing of 30 x 8 cm to allow free movement of air
- Keep the field free from weeds that may act as alternative host
- Avoid working on the field when leaves are wet
- Avoid excess nitrogen application

- Additional relevant crops: leek, garlic, shallot, chive, watermelon, pumpkins
- Look out for:
• Lesions formed near the tips of older leaves
• Yellowish patches covered in purplish-grey weft of fungus
• Shrunken leaf tips and death of leaves
- Take action when symptoms appear on one plant
- Remove and burn infected leaves

- When using a pesticide always wear protective equipment
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray matalaxyl based fungicide such as Redomil gold at a rate of 20gms I 20 litres of water, tata master at the rate of 50g in 20 litres of water. Start spraying shortly after transplanting when plants are about 15 cm high before symptoms appear. Spray every 7 to 10 days (more applications during dampy weather and less during dry weather). General Restrictions: WHO Class II (moderately harzardous) - Re-entry interval of 24 hours. PHI 1 day
- Spray using mancozeb, e.g. Farmcozeb at a rate of 50g in 20 litres of water, Melthane super at a rate of 50g in 20 litres of water. General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous) and PHI 3days, MRL 0.2mg/kg
- Spray chrolothionil e.g. Daconil, at the rate of 40gm in 20 litres of water, Katerina720 SC at the rate of 40mls in 20 litres of water 2 weeks before rainy season. Apply as soon as you see the disease at 7 to 14 day intervals. Apply as soon as conditions are favourable for disease outbreak . General Restrictions: WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous)

Images.Caption: Early leaf symptoms of downy mildew, Peronospora destructor on a field onion plant leaf (Howard F. Schwartz, Colorado State University, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Eston Njeru, Esther Macharia  and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Plant certified potato tubers from KALRO or ADC
- Rotate with non-solanaceous crops such as maize, beans and peas for at least two seasons
- Destroy infected crop debris after harvesting
- Keep field weed free to reduce inoculum pressure
- Maintain optimal soil fertility to increase crop vigour
- Observe spacing of 70cm x 30cm to optimize aeration

- Additional relevant crops: tomato, eggplant, pepper, black nightshade
- Look out for:
• Brown spots with concentric rings on leaves appearing first on older leaves and progressing upwards
• Slightly sunken, circular or irregular surface lesions on tubers that are darker than adjacent healthy tissue
• Tubers with internal brown to black corky rot
- Take action when 5% of plants are affected in 100 plants
- Uproot severely infected plants and burn

- Wear protective clothing when handling pesticides
- Follow label instructions carefully
- Dispose pesticide containers responsibly

- Spray a copper-based fungicide e.g. Sulcop 50 DF ® and Vitra 40 WG ® at the rate of 40g in 20L of water . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (moderately harzardous) - Re-entry interval of 24 hours. PHI 1 day. Start spraying shortly after transplanting when plants are about 15 cm high before symptoms appear Spray every 7 to 10 days (more applications during dampy weather and less during dry weather)
- Spray metalaxyl + mancozeb e.g. Ridomil Gold at the rate of 250 g per 20 L of water . General Restrictions: WHO Class II (moderately harzardous) - Re-entry interval of 24 hours. PHI 7 days. Spray as full spray. Apply as preventive early in the season when conditions are favorable for disease (before infection), and continue at 14-day intervals until the threat of disease is over. Apply 5 days before harvest

Images.Caption: Advanced symptoms on potato leaf (CSL/Crown Copyright)
External and internal view of Early Blight lesions; note symptoms within this tuber are shallow (Sandra Jensen, Cornell University, Bugwood.org)

Authors.Surname: Jacob ndungu (MOALF), Kagai Kenneth (MOALF), Stephen Koech (KALRO) Gekone J.M. (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Grow healthy crop that may tolerate or escape melon fly damage
- Avoid aternative host e.g. cucurbits, beans
- Harvest fruits on time avoid over rippening that attracts the pest
- Plant trap crops (castor and corn) along the borders at least 2-4 weeks before planting melon as adults prefer them to melon

- Additional relevant crops: beans, cucumbers, eggplant, peppers, pumpkins, squashes, tomatoes, etc.
- Look for reddish brown to dark brown fly with yellow marking on thorax and a black shaped marking on the abdomen with additional patches towards the outer egde of the wings
- Check for tunnels on the fruit with watery ooze as larva feeds. On cutting inside, larvae are observed at different stages of development
- Premature fruit fall and rotting
- Flower abortion due to larva attack

- Bury infested fruits and crop residues three feet under soil surface or feed livestock but do not leave leftovers around for over a day
- Bag the fruit to screen out melonfly
- Use 2-3 sticky traps/acre to lure and kill the flies
- Use a simple trap made of a mixture of 50ml vinegar, 4-6 drops of dishwashing soap and 75ml water in a 1/2L bottle (with 4-5) 7mm holes near the neck for entry of insects. Bottle should be suspended 1m from the ground
- Cover the crop using agronets from KALRO to control the melonfly

- When using pesticides wear protective clothing, follow the instruction on the product label such as dosage, timing of application, pre-harvest interval maximum number of sprays restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray using Imidacloprid based insecticides such as Imaxi 200SC or Confidor 200SL at a rate of 10ml/20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI-8days, MRL-2mg/kg, MRLS-0.2mg/kg
- Spay using Deltamethrin based insecticides e.g. Atom 2.5EC or Decis 2.5EC at a rate of 15ml/20L of water. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous) and PHI 1 day
- Spray Spinosad (a bacterial derivative) at a rate of 4ml in 20 litres of water to control thrips. General Restrictions: WHO class III (Slightly hazardous)

Images.Caption: Bactrocera cucurbitae (NBAIR)
Melon fly damage on pumpkin (Waitiki Kariuki)

Authors.Surname: Samuel Mburu (MOALF) , Peter Kodwaran (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Rotate with brassicas or cereals (kales, cabbages, sorghum, Napier grass)
- Do not locate seedbeds where susceptible crops have been previously grown
- Leave land fallow for 1-2 years to reduce inoculum
- Use only nematode-free planting material from reliable sources (KALRO-Tigoni)
- Always take the soil for testing for presence of nematodes in KALRO and solarise it using a polythene bag for 4 weeks in hot sun before transplanting the seedlings

- Additional relevant crops: bananas, beans, carrot, Citrus, coffee, papaya, passionfruit, potato, tea, tomato, watermelon
- Look out for:
• Slow/stunted growth, yellowing of the leaves, wilting of plant despite adequate soil water content
• Collapse of individual plants
• Swellings or galls that develop as a result of nematode induced expansion on roots when uprooted
- Take action when 5 root-knot nematodes are found in 200g of tested soil from the field

- Uproot and destroy by burning all infected plants as soon as they are detected
- Use Paecilomyces lilacinus 1.5%) = 1x108cfu/ml, e.g. Bionematon at 3.2L or 4 kg/acre
- Drench around the root zone at transplanting with Azadirachtin based products such as Neemraj (300PPM) at 40ml/20L of water or Nimbecidine EC at 50ml/20L. Repeat this after 2 weeks
- Disinfect farm implements before using in clean sections of the farm (use jik solution diluted at a ratio of 50ml in 1L of water)
- Drench using nematophagous fungi Pochonia chlamydosporia at 100g/20L at transplanting stage to control the nematodes. Repeat after one month

- When using a pesticide always wear personal protective equipment
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Spray around the root zone with Fosthiazate, e.g. farmchance 250 EC at 120ml/20L of water. Apply 3 times at planting, knee high and at flowering stage of the crop. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI 0, REI 12 hours

Images.Caption: A plant root heavily infected by root-knot nematodes (source: Miriam Otipa, KALRO)

Authors.Surname: Amata R.L. (KALRO),  Ringera E. (KEPHIS) and Otipa M. J. (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Collect soil, galled roots, water samples and send for analysis to KALRO-Kabete laboratory for presence of root knot nematode infestation
- Plant in nematode free fields and use clean irrigation water. Plant clean certified seeds or seedlings from reliable sources e.g. Amiran
- Plough infested fields deeply to expose soil to sunshine for a month during the hot seasons before planting
- Practice field sanitation by cleaning farm tools within and between fields
- Rotate with brassicas (kale, cabbage), cereals (maize, sorghum, millet) and nappier, onions or garlic

- Relevant additional crops: potato, carrots, spinach, capsicum, beans, peas, eggplant
- Look out for:
• Slow/stunted growth, yellowing of the leaves, wilting of plant despite adequate soil water content
• Fleshy galls on the roots that do not flick off easily on touching
• Numerous death of plants in the seed bed and seedlings do not survive transplanting
• Collapse of the individual infected plants
- Take action when 5 root knot nematodes are found in 200g of tested soil from the field

- Uproot all infected plants and destroy by burning
- Apply manure to boost crop vigor and release substances toxic to nematodes
- Solarize soil by ploughing fields and covering using a plastic sheet for a month before planting
- Drench the root zone at transplanting with Azadirachtin based products e.g. Neemraj (300PPM) at 40ml/20L of water or Nimbecidine EC at 50ml/20L. Repeat this after 2 weeks
- Use Purpureocillium lilacinum 1.5%) = 1x10 to power 10 cfu/ml, e.g. Bionematon at 3.2L or 4 kg/acre

- Use protective clothing when handling insecticides
- Follow product label instructions
- Rotate insecticide classes to reduce resistance
- Ensure proper spray coverage of flowers and foliage

- Spray around the root zone with Fosthiazate, e.g. farmchance 250 EC at 120ml/20L of water. Apply 3 times at planting, knee high and at flowering stage of the crop. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI 0, REI 12 hours
- For greenhouse production, fumigate 10% to 50% moist soil with metham sodium at 1.1L in 12L per 10m2 or at 60L to 90L in a quarter acre piece of land cover with a polythene imediately after fumigating. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI 0, REI 48 hours under field conditions and 7 days in the greenhouse. Fumigation should be done with caution or by a trained expert

Authors.Surname: Amata R.L. (KALRO),  Ringera E. (KEPHIS) and Otipa M. J. (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid overhead irrigation once onions start to bulb
- Allow tops to mature and dry fully before harvesting
- Provide for quick drying following topping, especially if temperatures are high
- Avoid wounding plants during cultivation and weeding as these serve as avenues for bacterial entry into the bulb
- Avoid surface run off from contaminated areas
- Rotate with maize or wheat
- Cure onions promptly and thoroughly before storage
- Plant using clean bulbs from clean plants
- Disinfect farm tools between plants and farms (Use 50ml JIK in 1L of water)

- Additional relevant crops: chives, leeks
- Look out for:
• Water-soaked and pale yellow to light brown lesions that appear on scales
• Soft and sticky scales with the interior of the bulb breaking-down
• A watery, foul-smelling thick liquid coming from the neck of diseased bulbs

- Uproot all infected plants and destroy by burning
- Store onions in well ventilated place to avoid accumulation of moisture on the surfaces of bulbs

- Use protective clothing when handling insecticides
- Follow product label instructions
- Rotate insecticide classes to reduce resistance
- Ensure proper spray coverage of flowers and foliage
- Disinfect farm tools between plants and farms (Use 50ml JIK in 1L of water)

- Drench the seedlings using copper based fungicides e.g. copper oxichloride (Amicop 50WP and Cobox 50WP at 60g/20L of water) and copper hydroxide (Cuprocaffaro Micro 37.5 WG and Kocide DF at 50g/20L of water) to minimize bacterial infection. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI 7 days
- Spray with Bronopol 27% W/W (Enrich BM) at 1.3kg/ha. General Restrictions: WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), PHI 7 days

Authors.Surname: Koech S., Mbevi B. and Otipa M. J. (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Flood the orchard to kill the eggs
- Band the tree trunks 20cm above ground with heavy gauge polythene sheet smeared with sticky gum
- Remove branches that touch the ground
- Work/rake the soil lightly to expose eggs and nymphs (crawlers) to predators or extreme temperatures

- Additional relevant crops: cacao, avocado, passion fruit, guava, papaya, tamarind, citrus, cotton
- Check leaves, stems and fruits for flat oval insects whose bodies are covered with white powder
- Look for sooty moulds on leaves, shoots and fruits
- Look for nymphs (crawlers) at the base of the tree trunk
- Initiate control as soon as you notice mealybugs as they will have already laid eggs in the soil

- Spray organic insecticidal soap which weakens the the insects protective waxy cover exposing them to adverse conditions
- Control ants by using gummed band to break the symbiotic relationships thus exposing mealybugs to predators
- Release parasitic wasps (Anagyrus pseudococci) and predatory beetles (Crytoloemus moulrouzlevi) to manage mealbgs from Koppert
- Spray dishwashing soap to suffocate the bugs/remove the waxy layer
- Spray neem based products e.g. Achook 1.5% at 20-50ml in 20L, 3-4 times/season or Nimbecidine at 50ml in 20L, repeated fortnightly

- Use protective clothing
- Follow label instructions on the product
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides
- Ensure safe disposal of empty containers

- Spray Thiamethoxam based product e.g. Actara 25WG at the rate of 8g/20L, repeated at fortnightly interval if pest re-occurs . General Restrictions: Thiamethoxam in WHO class III (Slightly hazardous) Neonicotinoid. For optimum control, apply when pest populations are first observed. Repeat at 7 days after monitoring when pest pesist
- Spray Imidachloprid based insecticides Confidor 200SL at the rate of 10ml/20L of water etc). Neonicitinoid; IRAC 4A. General Restrictions: Imidachloprid WHO class II (Slightly hazardous); PHI 7 days; MRLs 2mg/kg. Spray early morning or at late evening to avoid harming bees

Authors.Surname: Koech S., Mbevi B. and Otipa M. J. (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid planting courgettes on fields where onions, eggplant, capsicums, cucurbits were previously planted
- Test the soil to confirm nutritient requirements to ensure a healthy and vigorous crop
- Control weeds that are alternative hosts, use wind breaks and dry mulch
- Inspect seedling material imported into the field for signs of thrips/damage before planting

- Additional relevant crops: onion, garlic, cereals, cucumber, pumpkin, cucurbits, capsicums, eggplant, potato, watermelon
- Look out for silvering and flecking on seedling leaves. In severe infestation silvered leaves become bronzed, stunted, shoots and fruits become scarred and deformed
- Every week, shake foliage/flowers on to a white tray and look for the presence of mobile nymphs which are small pale in colour and wingless
- Use blue sticky traps to detect presence of thrips for appropriate action

- Introduce predatory mites e.g. Amblyseious or predatory bugs e.g. Orious spp.
- Spray neem based products e.g Achook 1.5% at 20-50mls in 20L, 3-4 times/season or Nimbecidine at 50ml in 20L, repeated fortnightly
- Spray biological pesticides e.g. Metarrhizium anisopliae 62 at a rate of 80ml per acre mixed with wetting agents like Aquawet or Bauveria bassiana (Botanigard ES® or Beauvitech WP®) at the rate of 10ml per 20L of water

- Use protective gear/equipment
- Follow label instructions on the product
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides
- Ensure safe disposal of empty containers
- Avoid contaminating waterways

- Spray chlorpyrifos based insecticide eg Bullet 48%EC at rate of 40ml/20L of water. Sprays can be repeated fortnightly if necessary. General Restrictions: Farmers should be advised to alternate chemicals of different classes fortnightly. Chlorpyriphos is WHO class II, Moderately hazardous; PHI 14 days; MRLs 1.0mg/kg
- Spray Imidachloprid based insecticides (Tata Mida 200SL at the rate of 10ml/20L of water, Confidor 200SL at the rate of 10ml/20L of water etc.). General Restrictions: Imidachloprid WHO class III Slightly hazardous; PHI 3 days; MRLs 2mg/kg
- Spray Lambda cyhalothrin based product e.g. Duduthrin super 65ml/20L. General Restrictions: WHO Class II, PHI = 3 days, MRL 0.02mg/kg
- Spray with Spinosad (tracer 480 SC) at the rate of 4ml per 20L of water

Authors.Surname: Stephen Koech, Mbevi Boniface and Otipa Miriam (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Maintain good cultural practices to increase plant vigour and enhance plant tolerance to thrip damage
- Keep the soil well irrigated and avoid excessive application of nitrogen fertilizers which may promote thrip populations
- Conserve natural enemies by avoiding use of persistent pesticides
- Avoid planting susceptible/alternative hosts of mango thrips
- Before planting, till the soil to bring the pupae to the surface
- Prune the trees to allow light to penetrate into the ochard
- Establish windbreaks before orchard plantation

- Additional relevant crops: cashew, grape, guava, avocado, ornamental shade trees
- Look for the silvery sheen on young leaves caused by thrips feeding
- Shake foliage/flowers on to white tray and look for the presence of nymphs with red bands on abdomen/black and elongate adults weekly
- Sticky blue traps can be used to monitor the presence of thrips
- Look for sooty mould symptoms
- When more leaves turn silvery, take action before they turn brown or appear burnt and take action when 4-6 adults are found per flower

- Spray biological pesticides e.g. Metarrhizium anisopliae 62 at a rate of 80ml per acre mixed with wetting agents like Aquawet or Bauveria bassiana (Botanigard ES® or Beauvitech WP®) at the rate of 10ml per 20L of water
- Use pheromone lures in mass trappings and/or add a contaminant to kill thrips
- Spray neem based products e.g. Achook 1.5% at 20-50ml in 20L, 3-4 times/season or Nimbecidine at 50ml in 20L, repeated fortnightly

- Use protective clothing
- Follow label instructions on the product
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides
- Ensure safe disposal of empty containers

- Use Chlorpyrifos based products e.g. Bullet 48%EC at rate of 40ml/ 20L of water. Repeat sprays fortnightly if necessary. General Restrictions: Chlorpyriphos is WHO class II, Moderately hazardous; PHI 14 days; MRLs 0.01mg/kg
- Spray Imidachloprid based insecticides e.g. (Tata Mida 200SL or Confidor 200SL at the rate of 10ml/20L of water). General Restrictions: Imidachloprid WHO class III Slightly hazardous; PHI 3 days; MRLs 2mg/kg
- Spray Lambda cyhalothrin based product e.g. Duduthrin 1.7EC @ 60ml/20L). General Restrictions: WHO Class II, PHI = 3 days, MRL 0.02mg/kg
- Spray with Spinosad (tracer 480 SC) at the rate of 4ml per 20L of water

Sections.Value:
- Test the soil to confirm nutritient requirements to ensure a healthy and vigorous crop
- Avoid excess nitrogen levels that will favour the pest
- Plant simple attractant flowers such as parsley to attract parasitic wasps

- Additional relevant crops: tobacco, cotton, other brassicas, beans, cucumbers, pepper, tomatoes
- Look out for:
• Small white winged insects that fly up in clouds from underside of leaves when plants are disturbed
• Sedentary, flat, oval, glassy and yellowish flattened scale-like nymphs under the leaves
• Sooty moulds on leaf surfaces due to excreted honey dew
- Use yellow sticky traps to indicate presence of whiteflies

- Use predators (e.g. swirski-mite by dusting 25-50/m2, Delphibug1-2/m2 for 20-40 w/flies/m2, 100/m2 in hotspots of 500w/flies/m2) and pathogens (e.g. Mycotal) when populations are low to medium
- Use soft insecticidal soaps + lecatech 1x1010 spores/g at intervals of 5-7 days for 2-4 applications, (250g/ha,1500-2000L) prophilactically before infestation
- Spray neem oil, botanicals e.g. Achook, Neemark early morning or late evening targetting underleaf

- Use protective gear
- Read label instructions on the product
- Avoid contaminating water ways
- Ensure safe disposal of empty containers
- Do not eat when handling pesticides

- Spray sythetic pyrethroid e.g. Deltamethrin (Bayer Provado Ultimate, Atom) Rate:15ml/20L. General Restrictions: Use insecticides only when infestations reach damaging levels but reduce the number of applications to 2 per season. PHI 14 days. WHO Class II. Highly hazardous to beneficial organisms
- Spray Lambda-cyhalothrin fortnightly at the rate of 20g/20L, e.g. Karate 2.5 WG, Duduthrin 50%EC. General Restrictions: PHI = 3 days, WHO Class II
- Pyrethrin based product e.g. Flower DS EC 4% pyrethrins. Rate 2-3l/ha, 40-60ml/20L water as foliage spray. General Restrictions: PHI = 0 (Zero days) Degradable by UV so spray early evening

Authors.Surname: Amata R.L. (KALRO)  Ringera E. (KEPHIS) and Otipa M. J. (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Use virus free planting material (sourced at KEPHIS PQBS or KALRO - visit the nearest KEPHIS or KALRO offices for assistance)
- Plant tolerant varieties such as Shibe, Tajirika, Nzalauka
- Uproot and destroy promptly by burning all infected plants to reduce inoculum in the field before planting
- Control the insect vector (whiteflies)
- Rotate with bananas, maize, coffee
- Practice mixed cropping with bananas, maize, coffee
- Disinfect farm tools between farms and plants (use 65ml JIK in 1 litre of water)

- Additonal relevant crops: soya bean, castor oil plant, Datura spp., Nicotiana spp., Leucaena leucocephala, Jatropha multifida
- Look out for:
• Chlorosis, mottling and mosaic pattern on leaves
• Stunted growth of plants
- Monitor during early morning hours, within 2 hours of sunrise for presence of whiteflies (before adults are active)
- Trap whiteflies using yellow sticky traps
- Apply an insecticide before whitefly numbers reach more than 2 adults per leaf in 50% of plants

- Uproot all infected plants and destroy by burning
- Mass trapping with yellow sticky polythene placed between plant rows (source; Koppert)
- Spray Beauveria bassiana (Botanigard ES ® or Beauvitech WP ®) fortnightly at the rate of 10ml per 20L of water

- Use protective clothing when handling insecticides
- Follow product label instructions
- Rotate insecticide classes to reduce resistance
- Ensure proper spray coverage of flowers and foliage
- Alternate pesticides from different classes to avoid pest resistance

- Spray thiamexotham based insecticides (Bullet 48EC® at 40ml/20L of water) or (Bulldock Star 262.5EC® at 15ml/20L of water) fortnightly. General Restrictions: WHO class II, Moderately hazardous; PHI 14 days; MRLs 1.0mgs/kg
- Spray imidachloprid based insecticides (Thunder OD 145 @ Confidor 200SL ®) at the rate of 10ml per 20L of water fortnightly. General Restrictions: WHO class III, Slightly hazardous; PHI 3 days; MRLs 2mg/kg

Authors.Surname: Samuel Mburu (MOALF), Peter Kodwaran (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean seed/certified from reliable sources
- Control run-off or splashing of water from infected areas to avoid bacteria spread to healthy plants
- Avoid injuring the plants while weeding
- Practise crop rotation with crops such as maize, beans and garden peas

- Additional relevant crops: carrots, potatoes, cucumbers, onions, tomatoes, lettuce and iris
- Look out for:
• Leaves that rot from the tip downwards, later turn brown black and die off
• Rotten bulbs that crumble when pressed
• Foul smell from the rotten bulbs
- Regularly scout the Arabicum crop and immediately remove diseased plants from the farm
- Take action when one plant is infected

- Uproot and destroy (bury below 2 feet) all severely diseased plants as soon as they are detected
- Soil solarization in hot weather for one month and two months in cold weather can give some control
- Disinfect farm implements before using in clean sections of the farm (use jik solution diluted at a ratio of 50ml in 1L of water)

- When using a pesticide always wear personal protective equipment
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB)

- Drench copper based fungicides e.g. isacop (70-140g/20L, cupracaffaro, Kocide 101 at the root zone of infected plant or those adjacent to infection sites. General Restrictions: WHO class III (Slightly hazardous) and PHI of 7 days

Images.Caption: Initial damage on Arabicum leaves (source: S. Kihara and M. Otipa KALRO)
Damage on Arabicum bulb by soft rot (source: S. Kihara and M. Otipa KALRO)
Yellowing of leaves and rotting of bulb in advanced soft rot infection (source: S. Kihara and M. Otipa KALRO)

Sections.Value:
- Use seed that is certified/free from bacterial infection
- Use tolerant or resistant varieties if available
- For smallholders who save their own seed:
• Select plants for seed without marks on the leaves or pods (disease symptoms)
• If most plants show symptoms, do not use them as a source of seed
• Sterilize the seed. Use heat treatment (20 minutes at 52°C) and a certified antibacterial agent (try this on just a few seeds first)
- Remove weeds, volunteer beans and other legume crops from the field before planting and as they appear. This eliminates sources of the bacterium and improves aeration
- Do not plant new crops next to infested crops
- Use maize as an intercrop; it reduces spread of the bacterium between bean plants by creating a physical barrier
- Allow plants to dry before allowing workers or machinery to enter the field to prevent the spread of the bacterium
- Avoid over-irrigation
- Rotate crops of beans every 2-3 years with non-susceptible crops, e.g. maize

- Relevant crops: common bean (snap or French bean), Phaseolus spp., including Phaseolus vulgaris,and Vigna beans
- Monitor for symptoms from seedlings to harvest, especially during favourable conditions (wet weather and temperatures between 28-32°C):
• Seedlings: spots which then produce spores to infect other leaves
• Leaves: small angular spots that look water-soaked, expanding as large brown dead areas. Spots may continue to expand and the leaves appear burnt and become torn
• Stems: dark streaks becoming lighter as they age
• Pods: spots are water-soaked at first, becoming red-brown and sunken, mostly circular. A yellow liquid containing bacteria seeps out of the spots when plants are wet and humidity is high. In severe cases, the pods shrivel and die
- After harvest, collect and burn or plough back the diseased crop. The bacterium probably survives only a few months in soil in the absent of a host

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Brown spots with wide yellow halos caused by bean blight (V.R. Wallen, Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada, www.bugwood.org)
Spots, some water-soaked, others brown, on the pods. Roughly circular and joining together (Howard F. Schwartz, Colorado State University, www.bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Use seed that is certified/free from virus infection
- Use resistant varieties if available
- Plant mixtures of bean varieties
- Establish fields in isolated areas i.e. not near established bean fields or in areas with extensive bean production
- The virus is transmitted through seed and by aphids; interplant bean with maize to reduce aphid infestation and virus infection
- Smallholders who save their own seed should:
• Carefully select plants for seed that do not show symptoms of disease
• Not use seed from plants if most of them show symptoms

- Affected crops: Phaseolus species, especially P. vulgaris (common, snap or French bean) but also Lablab purpurea (hyacinth bean) and Vigna unguiculata subsp. sesquidpedalis (yard long bean). Many pasture legumes are hosts, i.e. they are susceptible to infection
- Look out for:
• Stunted growth
• Distorted leaves with dark green areas along the main veins and light green-yellow between ('mosaic' pattern)
• Bubble-like (or blister-like) appearance of the green areas
• Leaves that curl downwards with rolling of the leaf blade
• Lack of pods
- Act as soon as the symptoms are detected in the fields

- Uproot crop plants with symptoms as soon as they are seen
- After harvest, collect and burn or plough back the diseased crop to destroy the aphids
- Do not plant new crops next to those that have the disease
- Do not use insecticides to control the aphids. The time is short between an aphid sucking up the virus when it feeds on a diseased plant and spreading the virus as it feeds again on a healthy one. By the time the insecticide has killed the aphid it has spread the virus

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Bubble-like appearance of leaf blades of a stunted Phaseolus plant (Howard F. Schwartz, Colorado State University, www.bugwood.org)
Mosaic patterns on the leaves of Vigna sp., yard long bean (Grahame Jackson, CABI)

Sections.Value: - Use mesh or net barriers to keep the pest out of the crop when possible

- Start monitoring when the chilli fruits start developing as the larvae only attack the fruits
- Insect:
• Eggs are less than 1 mm long, oval, flattened and difficult to see. They are laid singly or in group on the developing fruits
• Larvae are yellowish-white when young with dark spots. The full grown larva is about 15 mm long, bright red or pink, with a yellow-brown head. The young larvae mine fruit just beneath the surface, or bore into the skin causing premature ripening of the fruit
• The pupa (5-7 mm long) is contained within a tough silken cocoon and can be seen in the soil or amongst plant debris
• Adult moths are 15-16 mm (males) and 19-20 mm (female) in length. Forewings have grey, brown, black and orange-brown markings. False codling moth can look similar to other moths but can be distinguished by the triangular marking near the edges of the wings
- Open fallen fruits to detect the presence of the larvae. It is important to destroy the fruits after inspection by burning or burying to a depth of 60-90 cm
- Monitor adults with traps baited with a pheromone attractant and inspect the traps each week. If any moths are detected once the fruits are developing, take control measures immediately

- Control is difficult because the moth has many alternative hosts so reinfestation is likely to occur
- Hand pick the mature larvae from the crop
- If available, spray a mating disruption pheromone into the crop to stop the males and females from mating
- Destroy fruits that are infested and have fallen to the ground to reduce the build-up cycle and avoid carrying over the pest to the next season. Put the fruits in plastic bags and expose them to the sunlight, or burn and bury to a depth of 60-90 cm

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Pupa T. leucotreta (J.H. Hofmeyr, Citrus Research International, Bugwood.org)
Adult T. leucotreta (Todd M. Gilligan and Marc E. Epstein, TortAI: Tortricids of Agricultural Importance, USDA APHIS ITP, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant varieties if available
- Use certified/clean seed to reduce the risk of contamination
- Delay planting until seasonal rains have set in to reduce host plant water loss
- Intercropping can shade and surpress Striga e.g. use Desmodium, beans, cowpeas, groundnuts or green grams for maize
- Grow trap crops, such as cotton, cowpea, pearl millet and soyabean for S. asiatica. These stimulate Striga seed germination, but do not become infected, causing Striga to die
- Improve soil fertility and therefore crop stand using organic, inorganic, or green manure fertilizer for long-term control
- Irrigate crop during dry periods so plants do not get stressed, but prevent runoff water from infested land to avoid seed introduction as they are transported by water
- Keep farm tools, machinery and feet clean to prevent spread of seed
- Limit movement of livestock in infested areas as seed can spread via their hooves and gut

- Affected crops include: maize, sorghum, millets, upland rice, cowpea and sugarcane
- Most species of Striga have bright green leaves and stems 30-100 cm high, with bright (purple, pink, red, orange, yellow, white) flowers and poorly developed roots
• S. gesnerioides is totally parasitic, with small, unexpanded leaves and a cluster of fleshy, pale-green or yellow shoots, 10-20 cm high
- Symptoms appear before the appearance of Striga above the ground
- Look out for crop plants which are stunted, yellow, scorched and wilted even when the soil is moist. These symptoms are similar to nutritional deficiencies or drought
- Regularly (at least every two weeks) check for Striga flowers and seed development to prevent seed set, spread and build up of seed bank in the field. Take action as soon as one Striga plant is seen

- Continously uproot and burn crop stubble and Striga, before flowering and seed setting to reduce seed bank
- Hand pull the larger species, such as S. hermonthica, if populations are low, but not S. asiatica, which is much smaller and has seeds that mature and shed faster
-

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Striga gesnerioides parasitizing roots of cowpea (Rob Williams, CABI)
Flowers of Striga hermonthica (International Institute of Tropical Agriculture, Flickr)

Sections.Value:
- When transplanting in a new area, use only healthy seedlings and provide adequate plant spacing to reduce the density of the canopy, minimising humidity
- Good orchard hygiene:
• Prune trees to reduce humidity and increase transmission of sunlight
• Crop residues (fallen leaves and inflorescences) should be removed from the field and buried after harvest
- The fungi is transmitted by wind and rain; intercropping with other fruit trees or forestry species reduces the ease with which the disease can spread

- Starting before blooming, monitor visually every week (10 marked trees/ha). Especially in damp shaded areas (nurseries) with mild temperatures (< 24°C) and drier seasons:
• Young flushes are affected; terminal shoots may be killed
• Juvenile parts (inflorescence and leaves) covered by a white mycelium causing necrosis
• Leaf surface: dark, watery discoloration along the midribs. Leaves may be curled and distorted
• Underside of the leaves: white, powdery mycelium and spores. Eventually purplish net-like blotches appear
• Can weaken the tree and lead to defoliation
- Act as soon as any modification in the colour of the floral cluster is observed

- Prune infected shoots and inflorescences and burn or bury
- This disease is normally not serious enough to require control measures

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Oidium sp. on avocado leaves (EcoPort, www.ecoport.org: Kranz J.)

Sections.Value:
- Bacterial blight of coffee (BBC) can be a serious problem at high altitudes where heavy winds injure plants; plant shade trees and wind breaks on exposed sides of BBC areas to avoid the spreading of the disease
- Use clean disease-free planting material, avoid planting material from known BBC areas

- Carefully monitor symptoms, particularly during cool wet weather which favours the bacterium:
• Initial symptoms: necrosis of nodes, internodes and shoot tips, often accompanied by necrosis of the petiole and basal part of the leaf, spreading rapidly on primary branches
• Leaves: dark, water-soaked necrotic lesions. Leaves dry up and roll inwards turning brown, but remain attached
• Stems: canker on woody stems
• Whole plant: dieback
- Affected plantations have a fire-scorched appearance
- The symptoms of BBC differ from symptoms of typical halo blight of coffee which are more restricted to the leaves

- Cut off infected twigs, at least 5 cm from the point of infection, and collect them in buckets. Destroy by burning or burying away from the field
- Disinfect tools and implements with 70% alcohol after pruning infected trees or cutting twigs
- After heavy outbreaks, destroy infected trees

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Blackening of petioles and basal parts of leaves (James Minai, Coffee Research Foundation, Kenya)
Dieback of whole plant (James Minai, Coffee Research Foundation, Kenya)
Dieback of the growing point (James Minai, Coffee Research Foundation, Kenya)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant and tolerant varieties
- Avoid planting watermelons near perennial ornamentals
- The virus is transmitted over short distances by several species of aphids. Delay the entrance of the aphids into the field and reduce the incidence of the virus using the following cultural practices:
• Around the field, plant natural barriers that grow tall and are not hosts for the virus
• Adjust planting dates to prevent migration of winged aphids during the early stages of growth
• Protect seedlings from winged aphids using floating row covers, then remove for pollination
• Use plastic mulches (reflective, transparent and coloured) to repel aphids during the early stages of growth
• Control weeds

- Monitor plants for virus symptoms from seedling stage until the harvest, particularly during extended periods of high temperatures
- The most common symptom is mosaic patterns on leaves (which may be difficult to see under certain environmental conditions)
- Some plants may show reduced leaf size, shortened internal nodes and abnormal leaf shape
- Fruits: deformation, malformation and reduced size
- The growth and yield of plants can be reduced
- Due to frequent mixed infections with other viruses (cucumber mosaic virus and zucchini yellow mosaic virus) that can hide or modify the symptoms, a symptom-based diagnosis in the field is difficult and unreliable

- Remove infected plants as soon as symptoms are detected
- The use of insecticides to control aphids is not an efficient way of avoiding the spread of the virus in the field

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Symptoms on leaves (Gerald Holmes, California Polytechnic State University at San Luis Obispo, Bugwood.org)
Symptoms on leaves (Gerald Holmes, California Polytechnic State University at San Luis Obispo, Bugwood.org)
Symptoms on leaves (Gerald Holmes, California Polytechnic State University at San Luis Obispo, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Obtain healthy, disease-free seedlings from nurseries. If possible, use material produced in registered nurseries
- Avoid the establishment of nurseries in humid places with poor ventilation. The substratum should have been physically treated to eliminate soil-borne pathogens, for example through solarisation
- Maintain a thick layer of mulch (straw) at the base of the tree under the canopy to improve soil structure, plant nutrition, and reduce phytosanitary problems
- Keep trees healthy by avoiding stress such as high salt levels or a lack of water or nutrients
- Prune trees and remove dead leaves and wood in the canopy. Prune and harvest only during the dry season (avoid harvesting during the rainy season or shortly thereafter)
- Harvest the fruits to a level of optimum maturity as the unripe fruits develop rots easily
- Disinfection of cutting tools, knives and scissors during pruning (10% bleach)
- Control other diseases or insects that injure the trunk, leaves and fruits

- Monitor regularly during the development of fruits for symptoms
• Fruits: light decay begins as slight shrivelling around the stem button and spreads until everything inside the fruit rots
• Brown necrosis at grafting union, which advances downwards and results in dead tops to the trees

- Dispose of old wood and fruits away from trees
- Minimize the time between harvest and storage (less than 6 hours). To reduce the incidence of the disease, store rapidly at 5°C and control the temperature and postharvest conditions (hot and dry)

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Decayed fruit (David Rosen, UC Statewide IPM Program, University of California)

Sections.Value:
- Sow the new crops as far away as possible from, and upwind of, older ones, especially if they are infected by leaf spots, in order to avoid disease spread
- Use resistant, early yielding varieties which yield in the shortest time to avoid the disease
- Remove volunteer plants and weeds to reduce humidity and chances of infection
- Deeply bury or burn plant debris after harvest, or feed it to animals
- Leave at least one year between crops planted on the same land

- Early leaf spot is more common at first. This is gradually overtaken by late leaf spot, which produces more spots and more loss of leaves as the crop matures. (A hand lens or microscope is required to differentiate the diseases)
- Look out for:
• Oval spots on leaves, particularly the older leaves (this is the first symptom that appears, usually 45-60 days after sowing):
• Early leaf spots are reddish-brown on the upper surface surrounded by a yellow halo and brown on the lower leaf surface
• Late leaf spots are dark brown to black, usually with a smaller halo or without one. Dense spores form ring patterns on the undersurface
• Spots also appear on the stems and petioles
• Leaf and pod loss
- Temperatures of 25-30°C and 6-8 hours of high humidity are needed for infection and disease development
- If plants are infected, remove and bury or burn deep in the soil. Do not compost

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Early leaf spot, showing spots on the top surface of the leaf and clear yellow halos (Grahame Jackson, CABI)
Early leaf spot (left) and late leaf spot (right) on lower surfaces of leaves (Jill M. Lenné/ICRISAT)

Values.Value: Early and late leaf spot disease

Factsheets.Title: Early and late leaf spot of groundnut

Sections.Value:
- Use tolerant varieties if available
- Till the land to bury and kill the disease
- Plant crops away from, and upwind of, fields with the disease as it can travel by wind
- If direct seeding (no-tillage or zero tillage), grow legume cover crops before planting, e.g. lablab, velvet bean or sunhemp. Clear the legume just before planting the maize by making furrows without cultivating the land
- At first weeding, plant a short-term food legume cover crop such as beans, peas, mung bean or soybean as an intercrop to cover the soil
- Avoid overhead irrigation, if possible, as wet plants can encourage disease development
- Rotate crop at least every 1-2 years. The disease only infects maize, so other crops in the rotation will not become infected
- Use fertilizer moderately. High levels of nitrogen in the soil has been associated with increased disease severity

- Look out for:
• Pinpoint spots surrounded by yellow halos on lower leaves (best seen when held to the light)
• Expansion of the spots parallel to the leaf veins, sometimes light brown to grey, rectangular, up to 70 mm long and 4 mm wide
• Spots may join together to form a blight and may turn silvery-grey. The blight can cover the whole leaf
• Spots can also sometimes be found on stalks and leaf husks
• Rotting of the sheath and stalk causing the plant to fall over
- Regularly check crop, especially when full canopy has developed, as the resulting high relative humidity in the canopy encourages disease development
- Favourable conditions for disease development include high humidity and temperatures between 22 and 30°C
- After harvest, plough in or collect and burn crop debris. This is very important as the fungus can survive on the leaves and stalks from one season to another

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Maize growing in Zambia showing symptoms of grey leaf spot (Noah Phiri, CABI)
Spots join together resulting in long grey streaks and a blight of the leaf (Noah Phiri, CABI)

Sections.Value:
- The disease is spread by virus-infected budwood or plants; use only disease-free propagation material from certified nurseries. Use tolerant scions if available such as Mandarin and Valencia orange
- When using budwood, ensure that they are budded onto rootstocks that are resistant/tolerant to CTV such as sweet orange, Cleopatra mandarin, rough lemon, Rangpur lime and trifoliate orange
- It is also spread by several species of aphids, but the most efficient vector is Toxoptera citricidus, the brown citrus aphid:
• In nurseries, maintain good aphid control and keep trees under a screen to help keep the vector out of the planting material
• Control weeds under trees and in the field to eliminate host plants for the aphids

- The following three syndromes and the severity of their symptoms vary depending on the CTV isolate, environmental conditions and hosts:
• Stem pitting (mostly grapefruit): it does not kill trees, but causes a thin canopy, fewer fruits of reduced size and quality, deep pits in the trunk and stem and, in severely affected trees, dieback
• Seedling yellowing (inoculated grapefruit, lemon and sour orange seedlings): dwarfing and general chlorosis
• Decline (sour orange rootstock): in slow decline, wilting and chlorosis of the canopy, an abnormal crop of small fruits persisting after death of the tree and many small conical pits on the face of the bark surface (honeycombing). Trees affected by quick decline lack honeycombing, but frequently show a yellow-brown stain at the bud union
- Roots: necrotic streak or lesions, deterioration
- Remove a patch of bark across the bud union from declining trees to look for small pits (honeycombing)
- Inspect the orchards regularly for symptoms if the area is susceptible or at risk to the CTV, and more often during high aphid population periods
- CTV can be confused with diseases such as citrus blight (no bud union symptoms) and citrus greening (no stem pitting)

- Control strategies for CTV differ according to the incidence and severity of the isolates in a particular area and with the cultivars and rootstocks used. No single strategy is applicable to all situations
- Remove infected trees immediately to avoid spreading the disease and maintain surveillance
- Chemical control of aphids in the field is not recommended as it is an unproven strategy for CTV control and insecticides may not act quickly enough to prevent infection
- There are no treatments available to reverse the decline in affected trees on sour orange rootstocks

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Dieback of sweet orange grafted on sour orange (L. Navarro, Instituto Valenciano de Investigaciones Agrarias, Bugwood.org)
Stem pitting (Florida Division of Plant Industry Archive, Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, Bugwood.org)
Honeycombing on lemon rootstock (S.D. Sawant)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean certified seed
- Intercropping maize with beans
- Clean the storage facility prior to storage, using a disinfectant if necessary
- Harvest beans as soon as they are mature to reduce the risk of heavy infestation
- Air-dry the beans to a moisture level of 12% or lower before storage
- Do not store old beans with newly harvested beans
- Store beans in air-tight containers if possible, such as in plastic sealable bags, drums, or clay pots

- Relevant crops: pigeon pea, chickpea, soyabean, grasspea, tepary bean, runner bean, lima bean, common bean, pea, faba bean, cowpea, maize
- Known as a storage pest but starts attacking the pod while the crop is still in the field
- Look out for:
• Hollow bean, holes in the bean (about 2 mm wide) and adults on the stored crop
• Eggs: milky white, dome shaped and oval. Adults lay eggs on the outside of the ripening pods
• Larvae: white, found in tunnels in the bean where they feed
• Adults: 3-4.5 mm in length and grey and reddish-brown. The wings are short and have patches of yellowish and black hairs
- When threatened, adults will pretend to be dead and fall from the plant
- Remove and destroy all infested crop residues immediately after harvest

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult bean bruchid on bean with exit hole (Clemson University – USDA Cooperative Extension Slide Series)
Adult bean bruchid (Pest and Diseases Image Library, www.bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant/tolerant varieties if available
- When selecting planting material, avoid using any vine cuttings with symptoms on leaves, petioles and stems

- Look out for:
• Leaves: at first, small dark brown to black oval spots occur on the fully-grown leaves and show a pattern of rings
• Leaves: veins turn black on underside of leaves
• Leaves: spots grow up to 5 mm in diameter, frequently join together and are often surrounded by yellow halos
• Leaves: later, the infected leaves turn yellow and fall off. In severe cases they create a carpet of dead blackened leaves over the soil
• Petioles and stems: spots are grey at first, later becoming black and sunken. If they grow right around the petiole and stem they will kill them
- Destory vines after harvest to prevent disease spread

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Black sunken spots with grey centres on stems (Carlos Lopes, EMBRAPA)
Damage to leaves and stems causing a blight (Carlos Lopes, EMBRAPA)

Factsheets.Title: Leaf petiole and stem blight disease of sweet potato

Sections.Value:
- Use certified seed and varieties recommended by local extension services and national agricultural bodies. Do not recycle maize seeds from your field
- Eliminate host plants (weeds) of thrips, aphids and plant hoppers and clear/burn grasses around the field, both potential sources of the insect vectors
- Avoid planting maize if an infected field is less than 500m away
- Plant early with fertilizer and manure to enhance crop nutrition and vigour
- Synchronize planting date among farmers of the area to break continuous disease spread between fields
- Avoid moving plants from infected to non-infected regions to reduce the spread of the disease
- Avoid walking through established fields since the virus can be physically transmitted on clothes
- Practice strict crop rotation for at least 2 seasons with non-cereal crops like beans, garlic, onions and vegetables

- Inspect the field every 3-4 days for symptoms. Monitor as well vectors (thrips, aphids and plant hoppers) in the morning once per week under the leaves from crop emergence onwards
- All stages of plant growth are affected and the earlier the plant becomes infected, the greater the damage
• First symptoms are a scattering of small yellow areas (mottling) on leaves which eventually merge. The leaves become paler, and then the edges turn brown and dry inwards
• In some plants the young leaves die before they have expanded, producing a ‘dead heart’
• Distorted and shrivelled ears
• Little or no grain produced
• Dwarfing and premature aging of plants
• Death of the plants
- The disease can be confused with maize streak virus which has thinner yellow stripes that do not merge and there is no marginal browning and drying up
- Act immediately when symptoms are noticed on one plant

- Remove infected plants showing symptoms to reduce the local spread of MLND, burn or bury 1m deep
- Collecting and burning of plant remains to reduce the spread of the disease must be done on a large scale to be effective

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Chlorotic mottle on leaves and stunting  of the plant (Peter Kodwaran, Ministry of Agriculture Livestock and Fisheries (MoALF), Kenya)
Poor grain formation (Peter Kodwaran, Ministry of Agriculture Livestock and Fisheries (MoALF), Kenya)
Necrosis and drying up on a leaf (CABI/Rob Reeder)

Factsheets.Title: Maize Lethal Necrosis Disease
ScientificNames: Co-infection of Maize chlorotic mottle virus (MCMV) and sugarcane mosaic virus (SCMV)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant/tolerant varieties if available
- Use certified/disease-free seed
- Select a planting date which prevents flowering coinciding with periods of high humidity, which favours blast disease
- Plant at the same time as neighbouring farmers to avoid spread of blast from older infected crops to younger
- Do not plant crop downwind from an infected field. The disease can spread via wind
- Do not allow irrigation water from infected fields to run into uninfected/healthy fields since the disease can spread via water
- During crop growth, avoid any cultural practices that weaken the plants and make them more susceptible to disease:
• If applying nitrogen, divide the application into two or three splits, rather than applying it all at once
• Avoid water stress, or extended drain periods. Flood the field as often as possible

- Monitor regularly for symptoms when temperatures between day and night cause dew to form on the leaves and the overall temperatures are cooler
- Leaves: oval or diamond-shaped spots (5-15 mm long and 3-5 mm wide) with white centres and dark borders. Often the spots have yellow halos
• As they age, the spots become longer, the centres turn whitish-grey and the borders become wider and red-brown
• The spots join together and the leaves die
• Spots develop quickly under moist conditions
- Seeds: may not be produced or have brown spots/blotches and occasionally the diamond-shaped lesions as seen on leaves
- Sheath, stem and panicle: rots may appear. There are several different types of rot:
• Collar rot - appears at the junction of leaf base and leaf sheath; this can kill the leaf
• Neck rot (rotten neck) - appears on the stem below the panicles (flower heads) and can destroy the stem or result in pale-coloured grains that are partly filled, known as whiteheads
• Panicle rot - occurs on the branches of the panicle so that it appears brown or black
• Node rot - occurs on the stem below the panicles, the rots become black-brown and dry and, if the stem breaks, the plant dies
- Severely infected fields have a scorched appearance
- Eliminate crop residues as soon as possible after harvest, to reduce the possibility of the fungus surviving to infect crops of the next season’s plantings

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Diamond-shaped lesions on the leaves of rice (IRRI Photos, Flickr)
Rice blast may attack the stem at the nodes (IRRI Photos, Flickr)

Sections.Value:
- Plant mixtures of cultivars with different levels of resistence and similar stage of maturity to minimise losses
- Sow early (7-10 days before the onset of monsoon rains) so that crop growth does not coincide with high shoot fly populations
- Encourage high density growth to reduce shoot fly damage:
• Use a high seeding rate. Seedlings under high planting density have narrow leaves, which are less attractive for egg laying
• Delay thinning of crop
- Grow a healthy crop to reduce shoot fly damage:
• Grow seedlings in a nursery under high planting density before transplating
• Apply nitrogenous and phosphatic fertlizers. Do not use cattle manure as the resulting odour may attract shoot flies
• Maintain optimum irrigation
- Remove and burn weeds which act as hosts of shoot fly, such as grasses: Johnson grass, (Sorghum halepense), Brachiaria, Cynodon, Echinochloa, Eragrostis, Panicum, Pennisetum, Setaria
- Encourage natural enemies population (egg parasitoids and predators) by decreasing the amount of pesticides used in the fields
- Rotate or intercrop with cotton, groundnut, sunflower, sugarcane or legumes
- Collect and burn sorghum stubbles
- Let the land lie fallow for 2 months in the warmer part of the year. This reduces the carryover and build-up of pest populations from one season to the next
- Soil may contain pupae so should not be moved around

- Additional relevant crops: maize, finger millet, bullrush millet, rice, wheat
- Look out for symptoms:
• Young plants: Damage at 5-30 days after seedling emergence. The central leaf dries up forming a deadheart - it becomes thin and papery, and wraps around the other leaves. The damaged leaf can be pulled out easily and produces a rotting smell
• Older plants (>30 days after seedling emergence, >35 to 45 cm in height): Do not produce deadheart symptoms. They may have damaged leaf margins or partially damaged panicles with a portion which is rotting or dried up
• Plants: Produce axillary tillers due to stress
- Insect:
• Eggs: Laid on the underside of seedling leaves or on young tillers. 1-3 eggs are laid per leaf. They are white, elongated and measure 0.8 x 0.2 mm
• Larva: 8-10 mm long when full grown, whitish/yellowish in colour. They crawl down inside the sheath and bore into the base of the young shoot, killing the growing point and youngest leaf (causing deadheart)
• Pupa: Reddy-brown, 8-10 mm long. Found in the base of the dead shoot or in the soil
• Adults: rest on the underside of leaves. About 4 mm long and look like small house flies
- Assess infestation level using yellow sticky traps or a fishmeal baited square pan/plastic jar to catch adults. Alternatively, count the number of infested "hearts" in young sorghum plants
- Shoot flies are abundant during the rainy season under moderate temperatures and high humidity
- Check crop for shoot fly damage while thinning and destroy damaged plants

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Sorghum shoot fly egg on the undersurface of the leaf; the damaged plant showing typical deadheart symptoms (H.C. Sharma/ICRISAT)
Atherigona soccata adult (Georg Goergen/IITA Insect Museum, Cotonou)
Atherigona soccata larvae (H.C. Sharma/ICRISAT)

Sections.Value:
- Plant early-maturing varieties and time harvesting so that harvests occur before maximum rat populations
- Encourage owls to hunt in the field by placing owl nesting boxes nearby
• Before doing this, check with the local community
• Cats are not very effective (they do not necessarily kill rats, just frighten them away)
- Remove weeds within and around sweet potato fields so rats cannot hide from predators
- Place cow dung and pepper in rat burrows to smoke out the rodents
- Pour one-week old fermented cattle urine into burrows to chase away mole rats
- Dig deep ditches around sweet potato plantings to stop rodents from tunnelling straight into the field
- After harvest of sweet potato crops, collect the debris and bury or burn it; importantly, do not leave immature or broken storage roots in the field for rats to eat
- Protect the harvest in storage from rat infestations

- Additional relevant crops: rice, maize, squash e.g. pumpkin, various root vegetables, stored fruits e.g. apples
- Look out for bite marks in sweet potato and missing chunks. Rats dig through mounds or ridges to eat crops, or attack crop when exposed above ground
- Rat outbreaks tend to occur when there is:
• A long rainy season that provides more food and cover, allowing better survival
• A reduction in competition from other rat species, predators and disease, when there is a return to rains after consecutive dry years
• Early breeding, when unusually heavy rains occur during the rainy season and the offspring join the main breeding season population later in the year
- Rats live above ground and nest on or in the ground or in trees, depending on the species
- Mole rats burrow into the soil, eating storage roots from below. They live and breed in underground burrows
- Set traps (snap, snare or live), although care must be taken to protect livestock and children from being hurt by them

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Natal multimammate rat, Mastomys natalensis (William T. Stanley, Negaunee Collection Manager, Mammals, The Field Museum of Natural History)

Factsheets.Title: Rats and mole rats of sweet potato

Sections.Value:
- Plant early in the season, or use early-maturing varieties, so that harvest can be completed before the dry season when the soil dries and crack (weevils reside in cracks)
- Cuttings: vine-tips should be clean, especially the tender tips (the top 25-50 cm). Treat using a pre-plant dip to provide control for the first few months:
• Dip the cuttings into a solution of the fungus Beauveria bassiana for 10-15 minutes prior to planting
- Avoid using tubers for planting as they may contain weevil larvae
- Use deep rooting varieties with long necks - adult weevils cannot burrow below 1 cm
- Maintain deep root depth; use a hoe to create a small hill or mound of soil around the base of the plant and re-ridge about 30 days after planting. Or use a ground cover such as straw or plastic
- Irrigate regularly to prevent the soil from drying and cracking
- Encourage generalist predators of the weevil e.g. ants, spiders, carabids, and earwigs by planting hedgerows
- Remove alternative host plants (e.g. morning glory, wild spinach, wild Ipomoea) and volunteer plants from in and around the field
- Plant new sweet potato crop at least 1 km away from infested fields (weevils cannot easily fly from field to field)
- Harvest as soon as crop is mature and avoid piecemeal harvesting
- Rotate with a non-host crop, such as sorghum, rice or legumes, for 2 or 3 seasons

- Additional relevant crops: coffee, morning glory, sesame, cowpea, maize
- Monitor for weevils early in the crop season:
• Eggs: Yellowish-white, shiny and oval-shaped
• Pupae: 5-6 mm long and initially creamy white but become grey as they get older
• Larvae: chunky white legless grubs, about 5-10 mm long and slightly curved; the head is brown or light yellow
• Adults: black and shiny blue with long slender bodies (6-8 mm long), and a long snout with antennas on both sides. Adults are mostly active at night and hide under leaves or in soil cracks during the day
- Look out for signs of the weevil:
• Young plants (before storage roots form): small tunnels in lower base of stem where larvae feed. Also, adults can be found on the leaves and vines, leaving small round feeding holes
• Storage root: tunnels which become brown, soft and spongy. The damaged tissue has a bad smell
• Stems: turn yellow, crack, and wilt. This can cause seedlings to die. Look for feeding holes and larvae tunnels at the base (lower 10 cm) of the stems
• If damage to the stems is detected, dig up the roots of a few plants and inspect the surface of the roots for deep feeding punctures and cavities plugged with frass, and inspect the tunnels for larvae
- Place pheromone traps in the field at a radius of 280 m to catch the weevils
- Dry and hot temperatures between 27-30°C favour the development of weevils

- During crop growth, remove all infested sweet potato vines and storage roots and destroy by feeding to livestock or burning. Do not bury remains as weevils can still survive and do not store remains near fields
- After harvest, flood the field for 24 hours after harvest to drown and kill the weevils
- Destroy all remains of the old crop and volunteer plants, particularly infested vines and tubers
- Do not store roots that show symptoms with non-infested roots. Weevils can continue to cause damage during post-harvest storage

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult sweet potato weevil (Edwin M Escobar, Flickr)
A cut sweet potato showing larvae in tunnels (Scot Nelson, Flickr)
Sweet potato weevil larva (Peter A.C. Ooi/CABI BioScience)

Sections.Value:
- Select material for propagation from a reliable and disease-free source
- Use resistant cultivars if available:
• Note: many of the CMD-resistant cultivars are susceptible to CBSD
- Avoid planting alternative hosts of the virus, such as castor bean (Ricinus communis), adjacent to cassava
- Avoid planting cassava if your neighbours have virus-infected cassava as the virus will be carried by whiteflies to your field
- Avoid planting alternative hosts of the virus vector whitefly, Bemisia tabaci, such as tomato in or near a cassava field
- Weed regularly, especially during the early stage of the crop. Weeds such as Geratium spp. are alternative hosts of whitefly
- Intercrop with cereals and legumes, such as maize or cowpeas, to repel whiteflies

- Additonal relevant crops: soya bean, castor oil plant, Datura spp., Nicotiana spp., Leucaena leucocephala, Jatropha multifida
- Examine crop once a week for symptoms (note: infections can be symptomless). Consider taking action when 5-10 plants per acre are infested
- The disease is carried and spread by whiteflies, Bemisia species
- Scout fields for whiteflies early morning or evenings twice per week on 20 plants. If you shake plants, flying-off whiteflies can be seen
- Take measure controls before whitefly numbers reach more than 2 adults per leaf in 50% of plants
- Trap whiteflies using yellow sticky traps
- Symptoms:
• Leaves: patches of discolouration (chlorosis) which vary from light green to yellow and also vary in size. Distorted, often severely
• Leaf stalks: have a characteristic S-shape

- There are no treatments for virus-infected plants
- Uproot and bury or burn diseased plants as part of an integrated management strategy. This is only effective if done early, before many plants are affected
- Follow with crop rotation with non-host plants such as sorghum or cowpeas to reduce virus levels in your area
- Vector control offers few benefits - it is difficult, costly and time-consuming

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Advanced mosaic and distortion of leaves on an infected cutting (Photo: Eric Boa, CABI)
Although chlorotic (yellow) areas are well developed the limited leaf distortion suggests infection via whiteflies after planting (Photo: Eric Boa, CABI)

Factsheets.Title: Cassava mosaic disease
ScientificNames: Cassava mosaic geminiviruses (CMGs) such as African cassava mosaic virus, East African cassava mosaic virus

Sections.Value:
- Use varieties with known resistance to the main virus diseases, such as BlCMV and CABMV
- Only use seeds from healthy plants (those which lack obvious virus symptoms, particularly leaf mosaics and mottling). Both CABMV and BlCMV, and other viruses on cowpea are seedborne
- Thoroughly remove weeds which may harbour aphids or other insect vectors. Do this every season
- Avoid planting in the dry season when plants may be more stressed and aphid vectors, for example, are more likely to feed on plants

- Regularly visit the crop, taking action as soon as symptoms are detected
- Look out for:
• A patchwork of irregular light-coloured areas scattered across the surface of the leaf. Mosaic symptoms are easier to see with the leaf held against the light
• Leaves that are smaller than expected. They may have a wrinkled appearance and loss of colour
• Disease vectors in the field. CABMV and BlCMV are transmitted by aphids, as is cowpea mosaic virus (CPMV). Other viruses are transmitted by beetles or by whitefly
- It can be difficult to differentiate mosaics and mottling caused by different viruses (or combinations of them):
• The discoloured areas in a leaf mosaic disease have a clearly defined boundary corresponding to leaf veins and differ from mottling, caused by different viruses on cowpea, where similar areas are not defined by veins
- Laboratory testing is essential for precise identification. Good general advice on control can be given, however, based on a reliable field diagnosis of general virus attack

- Uproot and burn or bury (more than 50 cm deep) infected plants away from the crop field
- Collect and burn or deep plough crop residues after harvest to destroy insect vectors
- Do not plant new crops next to those that have the disease
- For aphid vectors:
• Early in the aphid infestation and during the early stages of the aphid life cycle, apply a mixture consisting of leaf extracts from papaya, teabush, Siam weed (C. odorata) and neem
• Do not use insecticides to control the aphids. The time is short between an aphid sucking up the virus when it feeds on a diseased plant and spreading the virus as it feeds again on a healthy one. By the time the insecticide has killed the aphid it has spread the virus

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Advanced, non-specific mosaic symptoms: this could be one of several different viruses (Eric Boa)
Mosaic viruses can also reduce and distort growth – note the rough surface of smaller infected leaves (Eric Boa)

Factsheets.Title: Mosaic diseases of cowpea
ScientificNames: Multiple viruses including blackeye cowpea mosaic virus (BlCMV), cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus (CABMV), cowpea mosaic virus (CPMV)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant varieties if available
- Use clean, healthy seed
- Plant crop early, when there is a lower prevelance of downy mildew
- Plant when soil temperature is below 20°C which is unfavorable for downy mildew development
- Alternate sorghum with crops other than maize, which may be infected by the same strains of downy mildew. Crop rotation will limit build-up of the disease in the soil
- Remove weeds, particularly related weed hosts such as Columbus grass (Sorghum almum) to reduce potential sources of the disease
- Seeds for sowing next season should be dried to less than 20% moisture to reduce the risk of disease transmission
- Keep crop density as low as possible to increase aeration
- If using non-resistant varieties, minimise application of high levels of nitrogen to make plants less susceptible to attack

- Additional relevant crops: maize, pearl millet
- Check crop at least every two weeks
- Leaves (not all symptoms may show):
• New leaves first show a loss of colour (chlorosis) before developing white stripes, widening with subsequent leaf production – this differs from much narrower streaks associated with maize dwarf mosaic virus
• Narrower and more erect, compared to leaves of healthy plants. The white areas eventually dry up, going reddish-brown. Leaves eventually shred
• Brown, rectangular lesions on leaves. Downy or woolly appearance on underside of leaves
- Plant:
• Stunted and usually does not produce any grain
- Monitor crop closely when humidity and temperature are high as downy mildew favours these conditions

- Remove infected crop debris if possible and burn or deep plough (at least to 20 cm depth)
- Minimise movement of people and livestock in affected areas so as not to spread the pathogen

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Symptoms on sorghum leaf (Rob Williams)
Symptoms on sorghum leaves (Rob Williams)
Symptoms on sorghum heads (Rob Williams)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean planting material only
- Remove alternative hosts, such as cocoyam, taro, ginger, cardamom, from the plantation and the surroundings
- Encourage the presence of natural enemies, such as coccinellids, hoverflies and lacewings in the plantation, by reducing the amount of chemicals used

- Monitor regularly during moderate humidity and temperature conditions (20-25°C) between leaves and pseudostem, and on the base of young leaves for small red-brown to almost black, oval aphids
- During rainy periods, dense colonies are found around the bases of pseudostems near ground level (down to 7-8 cm below soil surface)
- Aphids are sometimes found on fruits
- Look for signs of aphid presence:
• Feeding damage from large colonies causes stunting, honeydew build-up and growth of sooty moulds on the whole plant, and fruit blemishing
