• Leaves may be rolled or folded and show necrotic areas
• Colonies are often protected by ants, and may be hidden in earthen structures near ground level made by ants
- Banana aphid is a vector of the Banana bunchy top virus (BBTV). If aphids are found in the plantation, look carefully for BBTV symptoms for the next 25 days.

- If available, release parasitoids such as Lysiphlebus testaceipes, L. fabarum, Ephedrus cerasicola, Aphidius spp. or Aphelinus spp.
- Note that the release of natural enemies to lower aphid populations has not been fully successful in many countries due to ants protecting the colonies.

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Banana aphids hiding in between the leaves and pseudostem (Scot Nelson)
P. nigronervosa colony (Scot Nelson)
Ants protecting a banana aphids colony (Scot Nelson)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean planting material. Take one or two slices from the planting material and look for tunnels, larvae or pupae. If infested, destroy it
- If clean planting material is not available, then trim the material to remove the parts infested with eggs and larvae and use a hot water treatment:
• Remove the outer leaf sheath of suckers to get rid of weevil eggs
• Submerge the clean trimmed suckers in a hot water bath (52 to 55°C) for 15 to 27 minutes before planting
• Neem is also effective for cleaning infected planting material. Dip suckers in a 20% neem seed solution just before planting
- Practice good crop husbandary to produce healthy plants that are tolerant to weevil damage:
• Use mulch - leave a ring of about 60 cm from the base of the stool to keep roots from growing towards to surface and avoid moist conditions near the stool which attracts banana weevils
• Regularly desucker and remove water suckers. Clear mats of dead leaves/debris. Regularly remove weeds. Apply fertilizers e.g. manure, particularly in the early stages of plant development

- Additional relevant crops: all varieties of bananas and plantains (Musa spp.) as well as ensete (Ensete spp.)
- Look out for:
• Adults: 10-16 mm long, black or dark brown, in soil around plant base, between leaf sheaths and under plant debris/mats
• Larvae: creamy-white, reddish-brown head, legless, 12 mm long
• Tunnelling into the corm (up to 1.5 cm wide) causing fungal infection and reduced nutrient uptake, stem growth and stablility
• Weak or dying suckers, yellow floppy leaves and smaller bunches
• Plants that are heavily infested will show extensive damage to the pseudostem and may fall over
- Stunted plants and plants displaying early withering of leaves should be inspected for larvae and adult weevils:
• Cut corms with a knife at or just above ground level and search for larvae or larval tunnels
- Adults are attracted to freshly cut corms and pseudostems which can be used as traps for monitoring. To make a pseudostem trap:
• Cut small pieces of pseudostem in half lengthwise (about 25 cm long) and place the cut pieces on the ground near the base of the plant, with the cut surface facing down
• After 5 days, check the traps and count the weevils on each trap (and kill the weevils)
• If more than 2-5 weevils per trap are found, control is necessary
• Traps are best used when the weather is warm and wet. About 50 traps/hectare are needed to provide good coverage. Set traps once per month

- Destroy all infected materials and crop residues after harvest to reduce populations
- Do not replant previously infested areas while old corms remain in the ground:
• Remove all the corms after the final harvest, cut them into 4-8 pieces and allow them to dry to prevent larval development in harvested plants. Allow three months for the weevil population to die out, before replanting a field
- Apply 60-100 grams/mat of neem seed powder or neem cake around the base of the plant. Apply at planting and again every four months

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Damage caused by banana weevil (Scot Nelson, Flickr)
Adult banana weevil (Scot Nelson,Flickr)

Sections.Value:
- The bacterium can be spread by insects feeding on flowers of infected plants and then feeding on clean plants, and also via cutting tools contaminated with bacteria
- Use healthy planting material: Select planting material from areas where the disease is absent. Obtain suckers from trusted sources. Do not use suckers from banana plants affected by BXW, even if the suckers appear healthy
- Remove male buds by hand or with a forked stick. Male buds need to be cut off quickly after the fruit has been set. This is to reduce the risk of moving bacteria on cutting tools
- Clean cutting tools. Use household bleach (1 bleach : 4 water), solutions containing local plants with antibiotic activity, such as tobacco or chilli, or by passing through a flame. Bleach is the most effective method for killing bacteria
- Avoid the movement of animals in the banana plantation to prevent disease spread
- Follow national regulations (local quarantine and restrictions, e.g. do not sell banana bunches from infected areas in BXW free areas)
- If an area has been infected, crop rotation using any other crop besides banana for 5-10 years

- Regularly check crop at least 6 months after planting. Observe 2-3 times per week
- Thresholds: Remove infected plants as soon as they are noticed; When there is up to 70% of banana disease incidence, uproot the whole plantation and bury the plants
- Fruit: Individual bananas start to go yellow while others in the bunch remain green
- Fruit: When cut open, the bananas have dark stains, including those that are green. The bananas quickly blacken and eventually the whole bunch decays
- Bracts: Purple leaves of the male flower bud and shrivel, go black and die
- Young leaves: Leaves in the crown go yellow, fold in the centre and then collapse
- To detect the disease, cut the fruit stalk and, once the milky juices stop oozing, look for small yellow dots (which may be difficult to see). These indicate that the bacteria are blocking the flow of water and nutrients
- A fungus disease of banana, known as Fusarium wilt (Panama disease) also causes yellowing but on older leaves and fruits develop normally. The most distinctive symptom of Fusarium wilt is a dark staining inside the trunk, which is absent in bananas with bacterial wilt

- Remove trunks (pseudostems) showing symptoms of BXW and dispose of these carefully. Bury deeply or burn outside of the area of banana cultivation
• Single stem removal will reduce the amount of bacteria capable of infecting new plants, but this will not eliminate the disease
- Once the plant is infected there is no treatment to control the disease

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: BXW produces a distinctive premature ripening of fruit, which eventually rots (Eric Boa, CABI)
BXW affects younger leaves, though, and leaves collapse inwards (Eric Boa, CABI)
The rachis of an infected banana plant showing the yellow bacteria-laden ooze characteristic of Xanthomonas wilt (Pascale Lepoint, Bioversity International)

Sections.Value:
- Use tolerant/resistant varieties if available
- Reduce the length of time that the leaves are wet and can be infected by spores:
• For planting, choose areas that have good drainage, avoiding those with heavy clay soils where surface water remains for some time after rains
• Avoid areas where there is shade from trees
• If planting on hillsides, choose sites with morning sun to dry leaves rapidly and always plant so that the rows run in the direction of the prevailing wind, to allow air into the plantation to dry the leaf surface, to prevent infection
• Plant at wide spacing, about 2.5 m apart (1600 plants per hectare)
- Weed frequently
- Remove suckers to avoid clustering
- Avoid transporting infected plants into disease-free regions
- Disinfect farm equipment involved in plot management

- Additional relevant crops: plantain
- Take action as soon as symptoms are seen
- Symptoms:
• Leaves: Red-brown streaks, parallel to the veins, about 1-5 mm long by 0.25 mm wide. They are most noticeable on the underside of the third or fourth youngest leaf, especially along the edge of the leaf blade, which is first exposed as the leaf emerges
• Leaves: The streaks expand and become noticeable on the upper surface, darkening and later developing grey, slightly sunken centres with black margins and bright yellow halos
• Leaves: As the streaks join together they form bands of dead areas several centimetres wide, on either side of the midrib, and the leaves collapse and die
- Monitor crop closely when conditions are/have been wet or humid as these are optimal conditions for disease spread
- The symptoms of black Sigatoka are very similar to yellow Sigatoka but the disease management method is the same

- Rogue out young infected plants that have just shown symptoms and burn
- Collect infected leaves from the mother plant after harvest of the fruit and take them out of the plantation and burn them
• The fungus spreads on old planting material and on old banana leaves
- Remove older infected leaves regularly and burn or stack them in heaps, keeping the lower leaf surface facing the ground to help prevent disease spread

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Brown streaks with yellow areas between; the spots have joined together at the leaf margin causing a blight (Grahame Jackson, CABI)
Close-up of brown elongated spots, most with yellow margins, and some with grey centres (Grahame Jackson, CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Prior to planting, plough and harrow the field, and/or practice soil solarization, to destroy pupae
- Use resistant/tolerant varieties if available
- Plant early maturing varieties/plant early to ensure the crop is well established and better able to withstand an infestation
- Use correct planting density (wider spacing)
- Intercrop and rotate with non-leguminous crops such as maize or sorghum (crops which do not host the thrip)
- Remove host plants (weeds) at 3 and 6 weeks after planting e.g. wild mustards
- Provide adequate water to plants, as water-stressed plants are more susceptible to attacks
- Plant in a well prepared fertile seedbed to promote crop vigour
- Plant barriers of Mexican marigold followed by sunflower. (Mexican marigold attracts thrips from beans. Sunflower hosts the predator Orius spp. which feed on thrips)
- Preserve natural enemies such as ladybird beetles, Orius, hoverflies and Aphidius

- Additional relevant crops: cowpeas, French beans, groundnut, pigeon pea, lentil, winged bean
- Monitor for thrips about 30 days after planting - visit field twice a week
- Look for thrips early in the morning before sunrise since they tend to hide inside the flowers or underneath the leaves in high temperatures
- Shake the flowers onto a white piece of paper and count the thrips that fall out. Alternatively use blue or yellow sticky traps to capture adults
- Take action when you notice at least 3 thrips per plant
- Look out for:
• Adults: Tiny, slim, elongated, shiny, black. Distinguished from other species of thrips by pale bands across the top of the forewings
• Flowers: Become distorted, discoloured (brown) and dry
• Flowers: Severe infestations (20 or more thrips per flower) cause the flowers to fall from the plant, which prevents the pods from developing
• Leaves, fruits and pods: Silver streaks (created by the larvae feeding on leaves)

- Uproot and destroy crop residues after harvest by burning infested plants away from the crop field
- Place blue or yellow sticky traps above the vegetative parts of the plants to kill/ reduce their numbers
- Apply the fungi Beauveria bassiana and Metarhizium anisopliae if locally available and follow recommendations
- Apply neem-based products to reduce the number of eggs laid by adults
- Use pepper extracts to control and reduce the populations of the bean flower thrips:
• Dry the pods of West African black pepper (Piper guineense) and grind into a powder
• Mix 500-1000 grams with 3 litres of water and let it sit for 12 hours
• Filter the water to remove the solid parts and mix with an additional 1.5 litres tap water to make the concentrate
• Add some soap to make it stickier
• Spray 4-6 times a week

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult (Georg Goergen, IITA Insect Museum, Cotonou, Benin)
Larva (Georg Goergen, IITA Insect Museum, Cotonou, Benin)
The tiny adults on a bean flower (Ko Ko Maung, www.bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Use tolerant/resistant varieties if available
- Never use suckers for planting from plants that show symptoms of fusarium wilt, even though they may appear to be healthy, as the fungus may be in the roots
- Use clean planting material, preferably from disease-free certified plants. If these are not available, take suckers only from areas that have not shown symptoms of the disease
- Randomly check suckers to test for the presence of the fungus. Send to a lab
- Spores of the fungus can be transferred in soil, therefore:
• Avoid sharing farm machinery and equipment (e.g. shovels, knives and ladders) with other growers
• Remove debris and soil from machinery, equipment, vehicles and footwear before entry to any farm
• Fence infected areas so that people do not spread the disease in soil on footwear
- Dig drains to divert surface run-off (and irrigation) water if it flows through infested areas
- Use drip irrigation
- After removing an infested crop, do not replant with another fusarium wilt suscpetible variety
- Rotate crop with rice for at least three years

- Monitor crop at least every two weeks and take action as soon as an infected plant is detected
- Symptoms:
• Leaves: Yellowing at the margins, advancing towards the midrib
• Leaves: Turn brown, dry and eventually collapse
• Leaves: Symptoms move progressively from older to younger leaves until only a few of the youngest leaves remain green and erect, with the older ones forming a ‘skirt’ around the stem
• Stems: On some varieties the stems split. Internally, brown, red and yellow rings occur in the stem, at first at the centre and later, in cases of severe infection, spreading throughout
• Suckers: may also show symptoms
- Eventually, all parts above and below ground will die and rot

- If an infected plant is detected, disturb the soil as little as possible. Dig out the plant with its root mass and suckers, and burn everything on the spot. Do not chop the plant into pieces
• Clean the tools used to remove plants with sodium hypochlorite bleach
- Remove a ring of plants around the diseased one in case the disease has already spread to adjacent plants via root-to-root contact – even if plants look healthy they may develop the disease later
- Isolate the infected spots by constructing drains and bunds
- Apply neem cake at 250 kg/ha
- Apply bio-agents Trichoderma viride at 1 kg and Pseudomonas fluorescens along 1 kg with 100 kg farmyard manure per acre
- An oblique hole at 45° angle is made to a depth of 10 cm. Immediately apply a gelatine capsule containing 60 mg of Pseudomonas fluorescens. The capsule is injected into the hole with the help of a ‘corm injector’ on the 2nd, 4th and 6th month after planting
- Add lime or wood ash to the infected soil

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Leaves turn yellow, first at the margins and later hang down (Denis Persley, Department of Agriculture and Fisheries)
Water-conducting parts of the leaf turn red, brown or black (Denis Persley, Department of Agriculture and Fisheries)
Split base caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. cubense (CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Plant resistant cultivars if available
- Plant early to avoid periods of heavy infestation
- Intercrop with sorghum or green gram to reduce populations and the need for insecticides
• Do not intercrop with maize. Doing this can cause an increase in pod damage caused by pod-sucking bugs
- Clean up haulms to prevent the insects from over-seasoning in the crop residues

- Additional relevant crops: pigeon pea, chickpea, soyabean, hyacinth bean, common bean, hoary-pea
- Look for pod sucking bugs at 45 days after planting. Monitor crops regularly, particularly in the morning hours when bugs are active
- Pods shrivel and dry prematurely due to nymphs and adults feeding on the sap
- The shrivelling and drying symptoms can be confused with other stresses such as drought and disease, however, the feeding puncture wounds are a sign of pod-sucking bugs
- The insects can often be found on the pods or under the leaves of cowpeas and other host plants

- During flowering and pod formation, bugs can be collected and killed by hand in small plots
- Apply a mixture of black soap and kerosene:
• Dissolve 170 g of black soap in 150 ml of water
• Dissolve this in 1 L of kerosene to form a thick concentrate of soap/kerosene mixture
• Dissolve 400 ml of the mixture to 5 L of water
• Spray at weekly intervals after the cowpea has developed pods
- Apply plant based products, e.g. African hot peppers, cashew nut, garlic bulb, bitter leaf
- Pod-sucking bugs feed on a wide range of legumes and are very mobile, which makes them challenging to control

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Pod sucking bugs (IITA, Flickr)
Pod sucking bugs feeding on cowpea (IITA, Flickr)

Sections.Value:
- Plant early to avoid the period of heavy infestation
- Use resistant/tolerant varieties and/or early maturing varieties if they are available
- Deep plough and harrow to kill larvae/pupae or expose them to direct sunlight and predators
- Intercrop cowpeas with sorghum or maize to reduce the populations of the pod boring pests
- Remove weeds and alternate hosts, such as other leguminous plants, and destroy volunteer cowpea plants because they may harbor the borer
- Do not plant crop on the same piece of land for more than two seasons (rotate cowpea with maize or another non-host)

- Additional relevant crops: common beans, kudzu, lima beans, soybean, cowpeas, lablab, green gram and wild leguminous plants such as Mucuna
- Visit the field every day after flowering to look for signs of damage
- Check adult population using pheromone traps. Place about 4 weeks after sowing cowpea and check at least 3 times a week. When there is an average of two adults per trap take action
- Also, take action when 5 plants are damaged
- Cowpeas can be attacked by the legume pod borer from early budding through to harvest. Look out for:
• Flowers: presence of larvae (open the flowers to see them) and round holes
• Leaves: folded and stuck together
• Pods: A distinct hole where larva entered. Yellowish-brown balls on the outside (larvae faeces)
• Eggs: Single or in small groups. On the flowers or flower buds and on the terminal shoots of young plants. Oval, clear and light yellowish-white in colour; a single egg looks like a small drop of water
• Larvae/caterpillars: 17-20 mm long. Whitish/pale green in colour with irregular brown-black spots. Head is dark brown. Feed on flowers and foliage. Older larva feed on and bore into the pods. Pupates beneath plant litter
• Adult/moth: Wings are blackish-brown with white markings on the forewings and a wingspan of 20-25 mm. Active at night. During the day they rest on the undersides of leaves

- For small infestations, hand-pick eggs and larvae from the plants and crush them
- Prune leaves with white silk threads that stick together and also remove older leaves to allow more sunlight to reach the leaves and stems of the plants
- Neem products have proven to be effective against the larvae and are more cost-effective than synthetic insecticides
- Pod borers are difficult to control with insecticides because they remain hidden in the pod/bean

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: The adult moth has brown forewings with white markings (gailhampshire, Flickr)
Caterpillars are whitish to pale green in colour with irregular brown-black spots. The head is dark brown (Merle Shepard, Gerald R.Carner, and P.A.C Ooi)

Sections.Value:
- Plant as early as possible and use fast-maturing strains of crop so it can be harvested before quelea reaches an area
- As soon as quelea appears, protect small plots by banging and and making loud noises to scare them away. If they have newly built nests or unhatched eggs they may not return
- Place several scarecrows in the field
- Create physical barriers using materials such as string and streamers
- Minimize grain spillage
- Create an area where quelea can be trapped by planting purpose grown patches of grass which quelea eats, such as napier grass Pennisetum purpurum
- Harvest small colonies for food, either directly from nests or by catching flying adults

- Relevant crops: sorghum, millet, rice, teff, wheat and other small-sized cereals
- The birds look drab and have a distinctive red bill. They are small, between 11-13 cm long when adult, and weigh about 15-20 g
- It is sometimes possible to predict when quelea will appear. They migrate and breed when there is enough rain to stimulate the germination of grass seed - their food source

- Assess the risk from quelea attack before committing money and time to control programmes. Quelea are very difficult to control because of their large populations
- Trap birds if population is low. Use a traditional basket trap made of grass or wire mesh, a mist net, or a roost trap

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Juvenile, female and male red-billed quelea (Lip Kee Yap, Flickr)
Local measures taken by farmers to scare birds are useful but not enough to prevent losses caused by major irruptions (Eric Boa, CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Grow crop on land without previous history of the disease, if possible. The fungus survives a long time in soil
- Never plant groundnut straight after crops of tomato, Capsicum or beans, as the fungus commonly attacks those crops and it may be present in the soil
- Add mulch to the soil, such as corn or sorghum straw. This possibly increases certain organisms in the soil that compete with the stem and pod rot fungus
- Keep the soil well fertilized as nitrogen inhibits the fungus
- Remove weeds, but take care not to wound crop plant stems as it would allow entry of the fungus
- After harvest, collect and remove plant debris. Burn it, or bury it to at least 20-30cm deep to kill the fungus
- Use a 2-3-year rotation between crops of groundnut on the same land; e.g. rotate with maize, sorghum, cassava or yam

- Additional relevant crops: legumes, solanaceous crops (tomato, potato, capsicum), cucurbits (pumpkin, squash)
- Monitor for symptoms at least once a week
• Dark-brown spots on the stems just below soil level
• Yellowing and wilt of a single branch and, after a few days, the wilt of the entire plant
• Cottony growth of the fungus on the lower stem and, sometimes, over the soil surface (spreads from plant to plant in warm wet weather)
• Rotting pods
• Hardened round lumps of fungus, 0.5-2 mm diameter. White at first, becoming light brown

- If plants are beginning to wilt, remove the plants together with the soil around the roots. Burn them or bury to 20-30cm deep. Try not to drop soil or lumps of fungus on other crop plants to avoid spreading it
- Some biological agents could suppress the disease, e.g. Trichoderma harzianum, Gliocladium virens, Trichoderma viride, Bacillus subtilis, and Penicillium spp.
- After harvest, use soil solarization to kill the fungus. Cover moistened soil with a clear polyethylene sheet during hot weather. The fungus will be killed in 4-6 hours at 50°C and in 3 hours at 55°C

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Dense white mycelial growth and brown sclerotia of Sclerotium rolfsii, causing southern stem rot of peanut (North Carolina State University, Bugwood.org)
Sclerotia of the fungus Athelia rolfsii on groundnut stem – at first white, later light brown (Source: Grahame Jackson, CABI, CC BY 4.0)

Factsheets.Title: Stem and pod rot of groundnut

Authors.Surname: Samuel Mburu (MOALF), Eunice Sakong (MOALF) and Miriam Otipa (KALRO), Eunice Ringera (KEPHIS) and Lynnette Echessa (MOALF)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid planting mango trees near alternate hosts like guava, citrus, melons, pawpaw, coffee, avocados and wild fruits to reduce pest population
- Keep the orchard canopy open to improve aeration and spray penetration.
- Harvest early when crop is mature and green because over-ripe fruits attract fruit flies
- Plant Lantana camara hedge rows to attract and host natural enemies like ants, rove beetles, birds and parasitic wasps
- Release poultry in the orchard to feed on pupae at the base of plants.

- Regularly check fruit surfaces for small holes, punctured fruit, black lesions, soft spots, rotting, maggots, discolouration and oozing sap.
- Look for pupae 2-5 cm beneath the host plant.
- Use fruit fly pheromone traps 1 trap per 5 trees to monitor presence of fruit fly (males)
- Take action when 20 flies per trap are noticed.

- Use traps and baits. The traps should contain ½ cup (150 ml) of vinegar mixed with water.
- Trap fruit flies using pheromone traps - Methyl Euginol (Bactrolure liquid) at 1 trap per 5 trees.
- Till the orchard top soil (5 to 10cm deep) to expose pupae to the sun, birds, poultry and parasites.
- Infested fallen fruits should be collected daily in a tightly sealed polythene bag and exposed to the sun for two days before burying (60cm deep).
- Destroy fallen infested fruits to break the pest's lifecycle since pupation takes place in the soil.

- When using a pesticide always wear personal protective equipment.
- Follow the instructions on the product label, such as dosage, timing of application, max number of sprays, restricted re-entry interval. Do not empty into drains.
- Always consult recent list of registered pesticides (PCPB).

- Spot treat affected trees with poison baits of molasses with deltamethrin (Decis 2.5 EC) or bifenthrin (Brigade 25EC or defender 2.5% EC) or Buprofezin (Applaud 40% SC). . General Restrictions: Bifenthrin (MRLs 0.1mg/kg) and deltamethrin (0.2mg/kg): WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), Buprofezin( MRLs 0.1mg/kg): WHO Class III (Slightly hazardous) and PHI 3 days.
- Use pyrethrin extract (e.g. Flower DS) at a rate of 60ml per 20 litres of water every 5 days to two weeks depending on infestation severity. Start applications shortly after flowering. General Restrictions: Pyrethrin extract(MRLs 0.05mg/kg): WHO Class II (Moderately hazardous), Neem extract: WHO Class U (unlikely to present acute hazard in normal use), PHI 8 hours.

Images.Caption: Adult female fruit fly (reddish brown with yellow marks) ovipositing on a mango fruit (Photo: CIRAD, J.F. Vayssières)
Sliced mango fruit showing a whitish mango fruit fly larvae (Photo: U.S. Customs and Border Protection)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant varieties if available
- Use clean planting material
- Plant early, at the start of the rainy season, to encourage growth of healthy plants that are able to survive an attack. Cassava plants between 2 and 9 months old are the most vulnerable
- Do not plant downwind from an infested field as the mite can travel via wind
- Limit the movement of people within an infested field as this can spread the mite
- Intercrop with pigeon pea, in double or triple rows, to reduce the damage and also increase yields
- Encourage the presence of predators that feed on mites by reducing chemical use and keeping wild plants that attract the predators (e.g. Euphorbia heterophylla)
- Rotate crop with non-host plants

- Start monitoring regularly after 4-6 weeks after planting:
- Mites:
• Green to yellowish in colour and can barely be seen by the naked eye (they look like tiny greenish-yellowish spots)
• They feed on young leaves and may also be on fresh sprouts of stem cuttings
- Symptoms:
• Leaves: chlorotic spots (yellow spotting). Leaves become mottled and then die. Leaves may fall off leaving the shoot tip to look like a 'candle stick' if infestation is severe
• Roots: stunted bulking, lack of fresh root growth
- Use a hand lens to look for cassava green mites on the underside of leaves, along the veins and close to the base of the leaf. Mite populations increase on the young leaves in the early part of the dry season
- Symptoms can look similar to that of cassava mosaic virus (CMV), but CMV causes larger greenish-yellowish patches and leaf distortion

- During the growing period and after harvest, destroy the infested stems outside of the field (the mite can survive on cassava cuttings for up to 60 days)
- Release natural enemies available in your country such as predatory mites Typhlodromalus manihoti and T. aripo or predatory insects such as Stethorus and Holobus (=Oligota) spp.
- Remove infested tips with hand pruners and destroy outside of the field
- Control the mites by spraying a solution of:
• 3 garlic plants crushed in 10L of water, with 7gm of powder soap
• 500 g of onion crushed in 10L of water, with 2 teaspoons of vegetable oil and 7gm of soap powder

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Cassava green mite adult and egg (Eric Boa, CABI)
Symptoms on cassava leaves (CABI)
Cassava leaves with chlorotic (pale) spots caused by cassava mites (IITA)

Sections.Value:
- The coffee berry borer causes most damage in established and large scale coffee plantations where cultural practices are scarce or non-existent. The following cultural practices are important to reduce the damages:
- Use the same variety
- Highly shaded coffee plantations favour the proliferation of the borer. Prune and thin shading trees and coffee trees to avoid excessive shade conditions
- Avoid movement of infested fruits in areas free of the coffee berry borer
- Place mulch such as straw on the soil
- Balanced fertilization
- Control weeds
- Timely harvest (as soon as possible)
- After harvest, rigorously collect by hand all of the remaining fruits attached to the branches (especially the lower branches) or on the soil. Bury the fruits at 50 cm or boil if infestation level is high
- Elimination of decaying or abandoned coffee plantations

- Monitor developing fruits each week for infestation, from the eighth week after flowering. Divide the cropland into plots of 5 ha. From 20 plants/plot, collect 100 random fruits/plant. Cut the fruits in 2 parts and check for eggs, larvae, nymphs and adults. Sample and monitor the fallen fruits too
- To monitor adult population levels, set 20 baited traps/ha for 3 months at the onset of the rains. See the description of the technique in the direct control section
- Adults are black beetles. The female is 1.4-1.6 mm long X 1 mm wide, and the male is much smaller. Larvae are white, with a black head and legless
- The female perforates around the apex and the perforations deepen towards the centre of the seeds forming galleries. If the perforations are crusts, brown or rotten, it means that the larvae are inside the seeds and protected
- Take control measures when infestation level reaches 5 %

- Use baited traps (16/hectare) to catch adults flying after the first rains or in inter-harvest period (when the coffee berry borer is emerging and a few fruits are available). Fill in half the handmade traps (plastic bottles with two openings) with bait (1:1 ethanol: methanol) and place in the middle of the trees (1.5 m). Check every 5 days
- Fumigation in the morning with the fungus Beauveria bassiana 1 kg/ha when the coffee berry borer begins to attack the fruit (8 weeks after flowering)
- Collect ripe and dry fruits every two weeks to remove reproductive sites of the coffee berry borer
- Release of parasitoids if available in your country such as Cephalonomia stephanoderis or Prorops nasuta

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult coffee berry borer (Georg Goergen/IITA Insect Museum, Cotonou, Benin)
Perforations on fruits (CABI)
Damage to fruits (CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Maintaining balanced fertilization helps to minimize the impact of the pest
- Prune trees to avoid contact between trees and between branches and the ground, and to maintain good air circulation around the trees
- Avoid the presence of suckers or sprouts with excess vigour
- Mealybugs are often effectively controlled by a wide range of natural enemies (parasitoids, lacewings, ladybirds, hoverflies, etc.) and do not cause economic damage: avoid disturbing the natural balance by applying pesticides and control ants that protect the mealybugs against natural enemies
- Disinfect equipment and tools to prevent the propagation of mealybugs

- Once a week, monitor 1% of the orchard
- Check the protected areas of the trees where the mealybugs are grouped; fruits, cracks, shoots, under the sepals and at the base of the pedicel of the fruits, inside the dry rolled leaves and at the base of the trunks
• Cochinilla: The female has an oval body (3 mm long) covered with fine particles of white wax
• Leaves: the production of fumagina caused by the honeydew results in decreased rates of photosynthesis which can weaken young trees and cause defoliation
• Twigs: reduced tree vigor caused by mealybugs feeding on the sap
• Fruits: decrease in quality caused by spots and development of fumagina; discoloration caused by insects feeding; fruits dropping
- To monitor the presence and activity of the natural enemies, tie around the trunk an aggregation trap made of corrugated cardboard (10/2-4 ha orchard). In this artificial refuge, female mealybugs, parasitized mealybugs, parasitoids and predators are protected.
- Use pheromone traps for monitoring
- Monitor the presence and abundance of ants in the trees that protect the mealybugs

- Apply organic mineral oil or frequent washes with soaps at high pressure. This removes the honey and wax that prevents control by natural enemies
- Release parasitoids and predators that are commercially available in your country (e.g. Anagyrus pseudococci, Pauridia peregrina, Leptomastix dactylopii, and the predator Cryptolaemus montrouzieri)
- After harvesting, remove branches where a high number of ants are protecting the mealybugs. Otherwise these could serve as an inoculum for the next season

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Mealybugs P. citri (United States National Collection of Scale Insects Photographs Archive, USDA Agricultural Research Service, Bugwood.org)
Predator, C. montrouzieri(Sonya Broughton, Department of Agriculture & Food Western Australia, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Before building the stores, plan to build them well isolated, ventilated and with the least possible windows and cracks
- Early harvesting reduces the attack in the field
- Good store hygiene is essential for controlling this pest :
- Before storing new grain, remove infested residues from the previous harvest. Clean the store, bags and containers
- Dry grains until they are very dry (7-10%). Dry 2 times/week for 3 hours for at least 1-2 weeks
- Store grains in sealed plastic bags or metallic silos
- Make sure that the bags are stored on pallets at a sufficient distance from the ground, away from the walls and avoid touching the roof
- Separate new grains from the old grain store
- Maintain the store at a temperature below 10°C by ventilating and cooling
- Apply a thin layer of ash to cover the grain in store

- Every two weeks, inspect the store and sample 100 grains in bags to look for symptoms or insects
• Normally, no eggs, larvae or pupae developing inside the intact grains are observed
• Adults are dark brown in colour and 3-3.5 mm in length, with a head prolonged into a rostrum
- The females lay eggs on the stored grain and the larvae develop within these
- Grain infestation can start in the field: monitor random cobs in the field (look for adults and irregular perforations made when they feed or lay eggs)
- In the stores, use interception, pheromone, adhesive or light traps or bags with baits to monitor adults
- Take action when damage or insects are observed
- Sieve infested grains and dry again in the sun to kill the remaining eggs and adults

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult S. zeamais (USDA-ARS)
Damage to cobs (Frank Peairs, Colorado State University, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- This disease is transmitted by the psyllid vector Trioza erytreae or Diaphorina citri
- Avoid planting citrus in monoculture
- Remove any young citrus trees that become infected, as they will never produce fruits
- Use disease-free material for replanting
- Remove alternative hosts around the field such as Murraya spp.
- Encourage natural enemy populations in the orchard (e.g., spiders, lacewings, predatory mites, ladybird beetles, hover flies) by reducing pesticide use and maintaining flower strips
- HLB symptoms can be confused with those of zinc deficiency. Use appropriate fertilizers to avoid confusion
- L. africanus is heat-sensitive (no symptoms above 25-30°C); plant citrus at elevations under 600 m where temperatures are higher. L. asiaticus is heat tolerant and causes symptoms at all temperatures.

- Monitor regularly the whole year for both psyllid presence and disease symptoms to avoid it spreading, and act quickly as soon as the vector is present
- Psyllid monitoring:
• Adults feeding on leaves resemble winged aphids
• Orange/yellow eggs show on the edges of tender young leaves
• Raised bumps on the underside of leaves hide nymphs, which are small green/yellow scale-like insects
- Disease symptoms:
• Leaves: pale-yellow, yellow veins and blotchy mottling
• Whole tree: sparsely foliated, extensive branch dieback and reduced size
• Fruits: small, lopsided and poorly coloured with aborted seeds, severe fruit drop
• Compared to other diseases, citrus greening does not induce xylem dysfunction and wilting
- Can be confused with stubborn disease (Spiroplasma citri), Citrus tristeza virus, Phytophthora spp., citrus blight and zinc deficiency

- Control citrus psyllid vectors with parasitic wasps, e.g., Psyllaephagus pulvinatus, Tamarixia (Tetrastichus) dryi, T. radiata
- Destroy only very severely infected trees not producing economical yield
- If only a few branches are affected, prune them
- Disinfect tools between each tree with bleach

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult, nymphs and eggs of the African citrus psyllid Trioza erytreae (S.P van Vuuren, Citrus Research International, Bugwood.org)
Raised bumps from nymphs of the African citrus psyllid on a leaf (Peter Stephen, Citrus Research International, Bugwood.org)
Yellowing of leaves (Peter Stephen, Citrus Research International, Bugwood.org)

Factsheets.Title: Citrus greening (or Huanglongbing, HLB)
ScientificNames: Candidatus Liberibacter africanus, L. americanus and L. asiaticus

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant or tolerant varieties if available
- Use clean planting material
- Encourage neighbours to also scout their fields at the same time, particularly when CBSD has been recently reported
- All farm implements need to be sterilised over fire or with bleach, especially when cutting cassava stems into planting materials (cuttings)
- Intercrop cassava with maize, beans or sunflower as trap crops for the whiteflies, the main vector of the disease
- Uproot and bury all cassava volunteer plants
- Remove weeds to discourage habitats for the vectors
- Harvest early, don't leave tubers for more than 9 months in the soil as this increase the chances of getting the virus

- Sometimes symptoms only occur on tubers, not leaves, and sometimes they only occur on leaves, not tubers
- Symptoms may appear and disappear in young plants, but appear again in cassava plants at a later stage
• Leaves: patchy yellowing along the thin secondary veins which are more prominent on mature (bottom) leaves. This can spread and form bigger patches, with a ‘feathery’ or ‘blotchy’ appearance
• Stems: brown streaks and spots on upper green portions and necrotic lesion on the leaf scar. May show shoot top death which can progress into die-back
• Tubers: dry rot symptoms. Begin with localised dead areas that are yellow-brown, with a cork-like appearance, and characteristic white threads on the outside of the tuber. Some tubers have restricted growth, appearing like a series of rings stuck together
- Occurs alongside cassava mosaic disease (CMD) which is also spread by whiteflies and in infected planting material but the symptoms differ
- Daily monitor for the presence of whiteflies and take action when one whitefly is seen

- Remove diseased plants and dry all stems to use them as fire wood or stakes for climbing crops like beans. However symptomless plants may still contain the virus
- There are no chemicals against viruses

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Typical dry brown rot is only evident when tubers are cut open (Eric Boa, CABI,)
Leaf symptoms are seen clearly here against the light, but are easy to miss when walking through fields (Eric Boa, CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Use resistant or tolerant varieties if available
- Apply nitrogen, either as a mineral fertilizer, or as manure or compost, to enhance the crop's ability to sustain an attack
- A ‘push-pull’ system can be implemented in which Desmodium, a repellent plant, and Napier grass, a trap crop, are intercropped with maize to push and pull the insect away from the maize (see Plantwise Factsheet for Farmers):
• An additional benefit of this system is that Desmodium is a legume that fixes nitrogen into the soil; it also acts as a ground cover that supresses Striga, a parasitic weed
• Disadvantages of this system include the space taken up by the Napier grass; the cost and lack of availability of Desmodium seed; and the difficulty in establishing the Desmodium crop
- Intercrop with non-host plants, such as cowpeas or cassava. Adult moths will lay eggs on the non-host plants, but the larvae are unable to feed on them and will die
- Rotate maize with a non-host plant, such as a legume (e.g. groundnut), to increase the nitrogen in the soil. This will make the next maize crop hardier and less susceptible to an attack and break the cycle of the stalk borer

- Additional relevant crops: sorghum, bulrush millet, sugarcane and rice
- Immediately after emergence, start monitoring and continue at weekly intervals until maize reaches physiological maturity
- Consider control if you see one or two infested plants
• Stems: Feeding damage resulting in reduction of grain production. Stems are weakened and break
• Leaves: An early sign is small holes in straight lines or small dark larvae in the leaf funnel of young leaves
• Central leaves become dry and withered when larvae attacks growing points, forming 'dead heart' (drying of the central shoot). The top of the plant wilts, turns yellow, and eventually dries out and dies
• Larvae droppings (frass) are often visible on the leaves and in the stems
• Eggs: Round, flat on top, creamy-yellow in colour. May get darker as they develop. About 1 mm in diameter
• Larvae: Creamy-white. Might have a grey or sometimes pink colour and the head may be dark brown. Might have dark conspicuous spots and four purple stripes lengthwise across the back. Grow up to 40 mm long
• Pupae: up to 25 mm long and shiny yellow-brown to dark brown/red-brown in colour
• Adults/moths: Wing-span is about 20-33 mm. The forewings are light to dark brown or yellow-brown, possibly with dark patterns, and the hindwings are white to greyish-brown
- If plants show symptoms, cut open the stem and look for larvae, pupae and frass

- Dispose of crop residues after harvest to reduce stalk borer populations and limit the pest the following season:
• The crop residues can be burned, used as feed for livestock, or left on the ground exposed to the sun’s heat for one month to kill the larvae and pupae
- Apply ash or dry soil, by putting one teaspoon of ash or soil into the leaf funnel of young plants. Too much soil or ash can damage the leaf. Ash or soil should be used before the appearance of any symptoms. This means when stalk borers are known from the area or the last cropping season
- Apply 25-50 g of neem cake powder diluted per litre water every 10 days until maize flowers. The spray should be applied into the leaf funnel every 10-14 days until flowering
- Spray with neem seed liquid (2 handfulls of neem powder put in 10 litres of water left overnight and sieved before spraying)

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Maize stalk borer larvae and frass inside a young maize tassel (Photo: CIMMYT, Flickr)
Larva feeding on maize stem (Photo: International Institute of Tropical Agriculture, Flickr)
Busseola fusca (Francis Nduati, Kenya)

Sections.Value:
- Avoid the use of infested plant materials. Before planting, cuttings can be treated using a warm water treatment. See the 'Warm water treatment of cassava mealybug' factsheet.
- If available, plant varieties that are less susceptible to the pest
- Plant healthy cuttings
- Plant early in the rainy season to allow the cassava plant to grow well, before the dry season, as strong plants are more likely to withstand pest attack
- Use soil amendments and mulch to avoid moisture stress in sandy or poor soils. Mealybug numbers are higher on cassava grown on poor soil, and may cause damage in spite of the presence of natural enemies
- Restrict movement of infested planting materials across borders or mealybug-free areas
- Avoid planting cassava for more than 3 years on the same piece of land. Rotate with maize and legumes

- Check crop weekly for mealybugs on shoots, stems and leaves
- The adult females and larvae will be visible on the stem and leaves. They are oval in shape, pinkish in colour and covered in a white, powdery wax
- Symptoms on the plant include stunting, wilting, leaf distortion, leaf fall, rosetting of the stem, bunchy top and dieback
- Ants may also be present as they protect the mealybugs and feed on the honeydew they produce
- Black sooty mould may grow on the leaves and stem in the presence of honeydew
- Take action when you notice white waxy material on shoot tips, leaves and stems or any signs of mealybugs

- Remove and destroy infested plants or plant parts at early stages of infestation. Burn cuttings if this practice allowed in your area.
- Prune stems or leaves with high infestation and burn or bury more than 50 cm deep
- Mix 5 g of soap (alata samina) + 5 g of powdered pepper in 1 litre of water and leave it for about 30 minutes. Pour the mixture into knapsack and apply in 15 litres of water
- Apply neem oil e.g. Grow-safe. Add 10 ml soap to 1 litre of water and stir to mix. Add 50 ml neem oil to the 1 litre water-soap solution and mix thouroughly. Add the oil-water-soap solution to 14 litres water in the knapsack and apply within 8 hrs. Ensure thorough coverage
- If possible, use natural enemies such as the parasitic wasp Apoanagyrus lopezi and ladybirds
- Control ants as these will reduce the amount of natural predators

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Cassava mealybugs (Georg Goergen/International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA)/ Insect Museum, Cotonou, Benin)
Mealybug damage to leaves and stem (R Reeder, CABI)
Mealybug infestation on a cassava stem (R Reeder, CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Rotate cabbage, rape, broccoli or cauliflower with any of the following crops: tomato, onion, maize, or sweet potato
- Plant early in the season to avoid the period of diamond back moth build-up
- Remove and bury/burn crop debris including weeds at least 4 weeks prior to sowing to reduce DBM population
- Plant seedling beds away from production fields
- Transplant only healthy seedlings free of eggs, caterpillars and pupae of the DBM and other pests
- Intercrop with tomato, chilies, marigolds or mustard. Mustard acts as a trap crop for adult moths. Plant two rows of mustard for every 25 of cabbage
- Slash left-over cabbage stems after harvest to avoid regrowth which can act as a diamond back moth breeding area
- After harvest, plough the field to expose any pests harbouring in the soil

- Additional relevant crops: Crucifer family (rape, broccoli, cauliflower, chinese cabbage)
- Inspect crop weekly, especially the underside of leaves
- Look for small, grey moths, which have a diamond pattern on their wings when at rest
- Look for caterpillars which are yellowish green to green and around 1 cm long when fully grown. They hang from a web when disturbed and tend to appear at the four leaf stage of cabbage growth
- Look for damage on leaves: irregular holes, windowing and skeletonised underside
- Detect DBM adults using pheromone traps, placing 2-4 traps/Ha. Check traps twice a week early in the morning. Use control when 5 + adult moths are caught in a trap
- Alternatively, you may consider direct control when you notice 2 to 3 young larvae per plant

- Uproot and bury or burn cabbage debris, if burning is permitted in your country
- Crush larvae by hand if noticed when numbers are few
- Apply aqueous solution of botanical pesticide neem or tephrosia (40g/L soak over night and seive)
- Alternatively spray chilli mixed with water and few chopped pieces of bar soap or drops of liquid soap
- Plant trap crops such as mustard and rape at the edges of the the field to reduce DBM attack
- Parasitic wasps such as Diadegma and Cotesia vestalis spp. can reduce DBM populations. See if these biological controls are available in your country
- Use overhead irrigation which dislodges the pest from the plant surface

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adults diamondback moth (©David Cappaert, Bugwood.org)
Newly hatched larvae (CABI)
The pupa of a diamond back moth (David Cappaert, Michigan State University, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean pasture seed to reduce the chance of contamination
- Remove all existing hedges by cutting and digging out the roots (15cm depth)
- Move livestock out of previously infested fields. Sow land with pasture and/or native vegetation. Growth of new vegetation can outcompete the weed.

- Perennial woody shrub, 2-5m high, erect or scrambling.
- Branches with small thorns
- Leaves: yellow-green to green, rough, 2-12 cm in length
- Flowers: multicolored (yellow, orange, white, pale violet, pink or red), in dense clusters ca. 4 cm across.
- Fruits: round, fleshy, 2-seeded, each 5 mm wide, green turning purple then blue-black. Arranged in dense, round clusters
- Look out for this weed on disturbed land, plantations, forest edges/gaps, gassland, water courses, lowlands and gullies

- Do not control with grazing as the weed is poisonous to livestock
- Removal of small infestations may be possible by cutting and digging out the roots (15 cm depth)
- Remove flower heads prior to seed set to prevent further spread
- Slashing and burning can stimulate regrowth of the weed. Combine with other control methods
- Control will need to be repeated, potentially over many years as the weed is difficult to get rid of

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Largeleaf lantana (Lantana camara) (Forest and Kim Starr, Starr Environmental, Bugwood.org)
Largeleaf lantana (Lantana camara) (Forest and Kim Starr, Starr Environmental, Bugwood.org)
Largeleaf lantana (Lantana camara) (Rebekah D. Wallace, University of Georgia, Bugwood.org)

Sections.Value:
- Use tolerant crop varieties if available
- Where possible, cover small plants with transparent plastic (such as polytunnels) to prevent insects from laying eggs
- Weed out leguminous plants which can be alternative hosts such as sweet clover, Lathyrus, and many others
- Destory and bury the remains of broadleaf weeds as they can harbour leaf miners
- Deep plough crop residues

- Monitor weekly at all growth stages of crop
- Look for tiny thread-like tunnels (mines) on the upper leaf sides
- Look for larvae inside tunnels or on the upper side of leaves (tiny legless maggots with no separate head, whitish transparent and later yellow-orange)
- Threshold: At 8 to 12 infected plants per 100 plants, consider green direct control action
- Use glue traps or yellow sticky traps to see whether leafminers are present

- Hand pick heavily infested leaves with many leaf miner tunnels, and destroy them by crushing or burying them, or feeding them to cattle if palatable
- Spray neem extract against larvae onto leaves in the early morning or late evening. Add a sticker such as liquid soap to the neem water mix. Reach good leaf coverage. Neem slightly enters the leaves and reaches some of the larvae inside the tunnel
- If possible cover soil under infested plants with plastic sheets to prevent larvae from reaching the ground and pupating
- Use glue traps or yellow sticky traps to trap leafminers
- Biological controls of leafminers include parasitoids (e.g.Chrysonotomyia punctiventris and Ganaspidium hunteri), nematodes (e.g. Steinernema carpocapsae, bacteria and fungi

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Adult leaf miner fly 1-2 mm  (Source: Ian Marsman, CC By-NC-ND)
Leaf miner larvae (3mm) before they begin to tunnel into the leaf (Source: Andrei Sourakov)
Leafmines created by L. trifolii (NBAIR)

Sections.Value:
- Use clean pasture seed to reduce the chance of contamination
- Avoid movement of livestock though infested areas to prevent spread of seed
- Prevent water runoff from infested land to non-infested land
- Maintain a regular weeding regime before the plants grow big in order to facilitate uprooting
- Remove Prosopis from roadsides, wastelands, field boundaries and other areas that serve as source of infestation

- Perennial, woody shrub 3-5m or tree growing up to 15 m height
- Bark: ough grey-green, becomes scaly with age
- Branches: often multi-stemmed, especially following cutbacks, with abundant large and very sharp thorns (up to 5 cm)
- Leaves: doubly-divided composed (6-8cm long), 12-25 pairs of oblong leaflets per leaf
- Flowers: fragrant golden-yellow, dense spikes about 5-10 cm long
- Fruit: cylindrical or slightly irregularly curved green pods which turns yellow upon ripening (10-20 cm long) containing 10-20 hard oval or elliptic, brown seeds
- Regularly check edges of waterbodies, grazing areas and animal gathering areas and consider direct control if present
- Check for growth of trees where there are animal dropping/dungs since seed passes through animal dungs and germinate
- Consider direct control as soon as the weed observed in the field

- Seedlings up to 20 cm in height can be hand pulled
- Cut the weed before seed production to prevent spread
- Uproot trees or cut below ground to remove crown in order to prevent coppices
- Follow up weeding consistently to achieve longer term control

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Images.Caption: Coppicing Prosopis (Eschen/CABI)
Dense infestation of Prosopis (Eschen/CABI)

Sections.Value:
- Minimise the level of nutrients in water by limiting fertilizer use
- Use of containment fences across the waterways to prevent introduction of weeds to paddy fields
- Use water from tanks free form Salvinia

- Evergreen, mat-forming, free-floating fern, branching horizontal stems (up to 6–25 cm long and 1.2 cm thick), submerged feathery roots
- Leaves: Green or yellowish-green fronds, in pairs, oval (2–6 cm long and 10–15 mm wide); almost impossible to wet due to a covering of fine egg-beater-shaped hairs (1–3 mm long) on upper surface; undersides covered in matted brown hairs.
- Flowers: none
- Fruits: None, reproduces from detached fragments
- Look out for weed in drainage ditches, irrigation channels, dams, ponds, swamps, wetlands, lakes and slow-moving rivers

- Manually remove weed if infestation is small
- Biological control options include the salvina weevil, Cyrtobagus salviniae. See if they are available in your country

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Salvinia molesta (kariba weed) plant with roots (Colin Wilson)

Sections.Value:
- Use tolerant crop varieties if available
- Where possible, cover small plants with transparent plastic (such as polytunnels) to prevent insects from laying eggs
- Weed out leguminous plants which can be alternative hosts such as sweet clover, Lathyrus, and many others.
- Plant maize around beans because maize acts as a barrier against the leaf miners
- Rotate beans with cereals, and not with legumes, tomatoes, garlic, onions, groundnut, rape, melon or cucumber.
- Tomato is a host plant for L. trifolii

- Monitor weekly at all growth stages of crop
- Look for tiny thread-like tunnels (mines) on the upper leaf sides
- Look for larvae inside tunnels or on the upper side of leaves (tiny legless maggots with no separate head, whitish, transparent and later yellow-orange)
- Threshold: At 8 to 12 infected plants (with 5-6 infected leaves) per 100 plants, consider green direct control action
- If, after green direct control, leaf miner damage still increases up to 20 to 30 infected plants per 100 plants, then consider chemical action
- Use yellow sticky traps to assess the presence of L. trifolii

- Hand pick heavily infested leaves with many leaf miner tunnels, and destroy them by crushing or burying them, or feeding them to cattle
- Spray neem extract against larvae onto leaves in the early morning or late evening. Add a sticker such as liquid soap to the neem water mix. Reach good leaf coverage. Neem slightly enters the leaves and reaches some of the larvae inside the tunnel
- If possible, cover soil under infested plants with plastic sheets to prevent larvae from reaching the ground and pupating
- Use yellow sticky traps to reduce numbers of L. trifolii
- Parasitoids, and to a lesser extent to nematodes, bacteria and fungi, are used for biological control of leafminers

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Keep density of crop high in order to shade out the weed (it grows poorly in low light):
• Plant crop before weed germinates in late summer
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread

- Annual or perennial creeping herb; produces seed above and below ground.
- Leaves: oval to lanceolate; short hairs when young; 3-7 cm long, 1-2.5 cm wide (length up to twice width only)
- Flowers: three lilac blue petals; 3-4 mm long - lower is smaller than other two and sometimes white
- Fruit: pear-shaped capsule; five seeds (sometimes appear sugar-coated; grey-brown)
- Stems: short hairs when young
- Distinguished from other species in its genus by: all three petals blue; leaves broadly elliptical (length up to twice width only); rough, ribbed seeds; presence of stolons; leaf sheaths with reddish-brown tipped hairs
- Keep a close eye on row cropping systems such as peanuts, soybeans and corn - these types of crops are favoured by the weed
- Prefers wet soils but can survive for long periods without moisture. Particularly likes disturbed land.
- Take action as soon as weed is seen

- Uproot by hoeing or hand-pulling. When removed, shake off soil, spread out and dry for more than a week
• Cut stems can resprout. Stem fragements must dessicate to a moisture content of 50% for a period of 30 days to prevent resprouting
- Moldboard plough more than 1 inch below surface
- Use conventional tillage as supposed to strip tillage (do not use minimum tillage systems)
- Note: emphasis should be given on preventive and mechanical measures as extreme tolerance to glyphosate has been documented.

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Prevention measures are particularly important as this weed is difficult to control. Tubers are the main means of spread;
• Clean tools and farm machinery to prevent introduction to new fields
• Do not accept potentially contaminated materials, e.g. soil on planting stock
- Plant highly competitive cover or cash crops such as jack bean, velvet bean, bush bean, soybean, cotton, chayote and cucumber.
- Narrow crop row spacing can help prevent the establishment of the weed by shading it
- Control established populations near waterways to prevent spread during flooding and storm events

- Erect, perennial sedge (30-60 cm high), with extensive underground network composed of tubers
- Tubers dark brown/black, irregular shaped, 1-2 cm long at maturity, with several buds
- Leaves linear with distinct midrib, 7 mm wide
- Flowering stems 3-sided, erect. Inflorescence with several unequal 'branches', each 2-6 cm long, emerging from the tip of the stem; each with 3-8 purplish-brown flowerheads

- Destroy tubers and rhizomes in the soil via dessication (most effective in dry soil) or exhausting food reserves
- Cultivate every 2-3 weeks until crop canopy forms: the weed is shade intolerant
- Plough and cover an infested area with a polyethylene sheet to destroy tubers and rhizomes in the dry season (soil solarization). This can be very effective but not always 100%.
- Place organic mulch over areas where weed is expect to grow to provide temporary weed suppression
- Tillage must be deep (> 12cm) in order to disturb as many of the rhizomes as possible. Do this every three weeks and under dry conditions so the exposed rhizomes dessicate.

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Whole plants (S.D. Sawant)

Sections.Value:
- Purchase certified crop seed and animal feed to reduce the chance of contamination
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread
- Keep crop healthy to maximize competitiveness - use optimal water and fertilizer levels
- Limit the amount the tillage where D. stramonium is present. Post-harvest tillage may promote survival since seeds become buried
- Do not allow livestock to graze on sparse pasture where weed is present. Livestock otherwise may eat the poisonous weed

- Bushy annual herb; 0.5-2 m tall
- Seedling leaves: oval-shaped, pointed tips, few or no lobes
- Mature leaves: oval to broadly triangular-shaped, unevenly toothed
- Stems: green to purplish, stout
- Flowers: trumpet-shaped, white to creamy or violet, rarely completely open
- Seed capsules/cases: egg-shaped, walnut-sized, spiny or bald
- May be confused with other species within the Datura genus:
• D. stramonium: 100 or more capsule spines; long flower (up to 10 cm) D. ferox: up to 60 capsule spines; shorter flower (4-6 cm)
• D. stramonium (and D. ferox): straight capsule stalks; black or grey seeds. D. leichhardtii, D. metel, D. inoxia and D. wrightii: curved capsule stalks; brown or yellow seeds
- Monitor open and disturbed areas particularly closely. D. stramonium can be found on roadsides, agricultural land and riverbanks.
- Take action as soon as weed is seen

- Dig, pull or hoe out before seed sets in order to prevent it spreading. Wear gloves when handling it since it is poisonous, particularly its leaves and seeds. Be thorough since it can regenerate from root fragments if not removed effectively
- To dispose of pulled weed, if seed has not set, add to a compost heap. If seed has set, ensure pulled weed is buried to least 60 cm/2 ft, or burn it to prevent spread (if permitted in your country)
- Till the soil when weeds are seedlings. When mature, stems become woody and difficult to remove
- Grow winter annual crops and forage crops and cut them several times during the year to control the weed
- Remove weed before making hay, silage, grain or other animal feed to prevent spread
- Seedlings emerge over a long period of time so repeated removal may be necessary

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Purchase certified crop seed and animal feed to reduce the chance of contamination
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread
- Keep crop healthy to maximize competitiveness - use optimal water and fertilizer levels

- Creeping, perennial grass, rhizomatous; 50-100 cm high
- Leaves: flat; bluish-green 15 cm long, 2-8 mm wide
- Inflorescence: 2-25 racemes. Spikelets in pairs
- Rhizomes: can be over 1 m deep in soil forming dense mats
- Fruits: elliptical in various shades of light brown, grey and purple
- Looks similar to Cynodon dactylon, but C. dactylon has a membraneous ligule where the leaf blade joins the sheath

- Use a forked hoe to remove rhizomes. Ensure removal is thorough to prevent resprouting
- Till land to expose and dessicate rhizomes, but be aware that this action may also spread fragments which can grow new plants
- For coffee, plant Guizotia abyssinica and Linum usitatissimum as cover crops to suppress weed

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Purchase certified crop seed and animal feed to reduce the chance of contamination
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread
- Keep crop healthy to maximize competitiveness - use optimal water and fertilizer levels
- For pasture, encourage good grass coverage since grass can outcompete the weed. Limit the amount of grazing in a particular area:
• Supply multiple watering points to prevent livestock congregating
• Rotate livestock between paddocks

- Tufted annual grass, spreading or stands straight, up to 60 cm tall
- Seedlings: first leaf is about 1 cm long, pointed, may lie flat on soil
- Leaves: bright green; smooth; flat to V-shaped; up to 8 mm wide, 15 cm long. Tends to form a long-growing rosette with white-coloured leaf sheath at the base
- Flowers: arranged in clusters of 3-5
- Does not root at nodes of growing stems.
- Seeds: reddish-brown to black; oblong; ridged; about 1 mm long
- Roots: centralized system; very strong when mature
- Spreads along disturbed habitats such as roads and powerline corridors. Look for it along marshes, stream banks and coasts
- Can be confused with weeds such as Digitaria, Dactyloctenium, Cynodon, Chloris or Paspalum spp. E. indica is distinguished by the combination of its flattened stem, bright green leaves, size and many-flowered character of spikelets, lack of awns.

- Remove by hand if the weed is smaller than 5-8 cm in diameter. Use a hoe if removal is difficult. Removal gets harder as weed grows (root system is stronger)
- Till the land. The weed grows best in compact, poorly drained soils so make sure it is aerated and drained
- Use solarization to kill weed seeds down to 5 cm. This requires watering (light irrigation) of the soil area after mulching and before covering the area with the transparent polyethylene sheet
- Use shredded newspaper as a mulch on tomato fields
- Use a rye cover crop – its residues should supress the weed

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Clean tillage equipment and other farm machinery to prevent rhizomes being spread
- For maize: weed infested fields at least five times to minimise yield reduction
- After eradication of I. cylindrica, it is necessary to establish useful species which suppress regrowth of weeds and conserve soil fertility
• Use legume cover crops to smother the weeds, stabilize the soil and fix nitrogen. Calopogonium caeruleum, C. mucunoides, Desmodium intortum, Centrosema pubescens, Mucuna spp., Pueraria phaseoloides, P. triloba and Stylosanthes guianensis are examples of legumes that are used to rehabilitate grassland or provide ground cover in plantation crops.
• Or gradually change your cropping system to include agroforestry by planting trees in the field to increase shade e.g. plant mahogany (Swietenia mahogani), sungkai (Peronema canescens) or candle nut (Aleurites moluccanus.
• Use alley cropping to shade and surpress weeds e.g. plant Gliricidia sepium and Leucaena leucocephala

- Perennial grass; can be up to 3 m tall
- Rhizomes (underground stems): tough; white; around 1 m deep; concentrated in upper 15-20 cm of soil; produced from seedlings after 4 weeks:
• Remain dormant but viable for a long time. Can reshoot from fragments – shorter fragments are less likely to survive
- Leaves: can be green or red; stiff; finely toothed edges; hairy upper surface near plant base; 120 cm long, 4-18 mm wide
- Flowers: white; two stamens; fluffy; 5-20 cm long, 2.5 cm wide
• Flowers after exposure to stress such as burning, overgrazing and repeated slashing
- Seeds: dispersed by wind; one plant can produce 3000; have little or no dormancy period; remain viable for over a year
- Check for presence of weed every 2 months in cassava fields, and every 2 weeks in other crops
- Take control measures if present

- Any management strategy should aim to destroy the grass rhizomes. Control strategies should be based on an integrated approach
- Extract using a hoe or hand-pull weed
- Dispose of fragments by burial or burning. Do not only burn as this enhances seed production
- Cultivate soil during the dry season when most of the weed's biomass is in the rhizomes and when dessication is most effective. If done in the wet season there is not enough sun to kill the exposed rhizomes
- To expose the rhizomes, execute deep mechanical tillage (30-40 cm) with tractor during field preparation. Leave for at least 2 weeks to desiccate rhizomes in the sun and plough again at right angles to the previous direction to expose fragmented rhizomes. After, harrow field twice at an interval of about 2 weeks
- Execute grass pressing to decomposes and dry up weeds within 1 month and to enable the establishment of legume ground covers:
• Ensure grass shoots are only bent, not broken, otherwise it will send up new shoots
• Do this when weed is about 1 m high to ensure stems remain bent
• Roll logs or stand on planks

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- As seeds can travel on animals and machinery, do not allow animals into an affected area, limit machinery use in the area and keep machinery clean to prevent spread
- Do not allow livestock to graze in infested pasture – seeds can pass through digestive tract unharmed
- Clean shoes, clothing and hair after being in a potentially infested area. The bristly one-seeded pod segments are sticky
- Ensure uncontaminated water is used when flooding rice paddys as pod segments float and can be transported by water

- Regularly check sites such as machinery tracks, grazing places, previously flooded areas fallen dry for seeds and any seedling establishment
- Check for any seed germination at the start and end of the wet season
- Spreading, multi-stemmed, thorny shrub usually up to 2 m tall,
- The inflorescences, containing up to 100 flowers, flowers are pale pink and arranged in fluffy, globular clusters (10-20 mm across)
- The fruit is an elongated and flattened pod covered in bristly hairs and up to 15 cm long and clustered at the stem tips
- The plant is evergreen and bears bipinnate (twice-compound), sensitive leaves, up to 18 cm in length. When touched they fold together and also during the night
- Recurved spines (to 7 mm long) are located on the undersides of the petioles, petioules and stems

- Uproot plants by hand-pulling or using machinery, and destroy roots
- Collect seeds and burn before weeding
- Cut plants off at 10 cm below ground level to kill the weed. Use long handled cutters, axe or machete:
• Blade ploughing is effective since it cuts below ground level. Slashing and chaining alone is not (requires herbicide application afterwards)
- Burning is not recommended – does not prevent resprouting and kills only surface seeds. It may stimulate germination. Also reduces the numbers of the stem-mining moth Carmenta mimosa
- Check which biocontrols are available in your country. Examples of biological controls include:
• Beetle species such as Acanthoscelides puniceus or A. quadridentatus
• The green twig-mining moth Neurostrota gunniella attacks mature plants and seedlings greater than 15 cm (should not be used in Thailand or Vietnam). You can use this after weed removal to reduce herbicide use
- Fragment infestations to increase numbers of control agents such as N. gunniella since it increases weed stand edges

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.

Sections.Value:
- Clean tillage equipment and other farm machinery to prevent weed rhizomes being spread
- Do not accept potentially contaminated materials, e.g. fill dirt, hay, and clean vegetation off boat trailers and machinery
- Limit the presence of open and disturbed areas by preventing overgrazing
- Use legumes as cover crops to smother weed in plantation crops in sufficiently humid climatic conditions
- Control established populations near waterways to prevent weed spreading to fields
- For pasture, encourage a healthy and diverse ecosystem to deter infestation

- Perennial grass, clusters of flowers up to 50-100 cm high
- Look out for it in wetlands and along waterways. Water and storm events can spread it
- Leaves: bright green; stiff; sparsely hairy on upper surface; edges of leaf coverings have long white hairs; 15-20 cm long, 1 cm wide
- Rhizomes: grow horizontally; up to 20 cm deep; several metres long
- Flowers: spikelets (flower clusters) 2-flowered; pale green, sometimes tinged with purple; 2.5-3 mm long
- Similar to Panicum repentellum, distinguished by its nerveless lower glume (a small modified leaf surrounding the spikelet)
- Rhizomes can be spread via soil transport

- Use a combination of continuous tillage, hand weeding, cutting and burning. Using only one of these methods can result in rapid regrowth from rhizomes.
- Tillage must be deep in order to disturb as many of the rhizomes as possible. Do this under dry conditions so the exposed rhizomes dessicate
- Use legumes as cover crops to smother weed in plantation crops in sufficiently humid climatic conditions

Pesticides may be available to control this pest. Please check with the Ministry of Agriculture in your country to find out which pesticides are registered in your country and the local restrictions for their use.
